title: China, Africa stengthen ties --- Package of 14 deals valued at $1.9 billion competes with West
description: China, Africa strengthen ties --- Package of 14 deals valued at $1.9 billion competes with West By Andrew Batson 705 words 6 November 2006 The Wall Street Journal Europe WSJE 9 English (Copyright (c) 2006, Dow Jones   Company, Inc.) BEIJING -- Leaders from China and 48 African nations, wrapping up a summit unprecedented for its size, announced a new type of partnership intended to strengthen links between the developing world's biggest economic-success story and some of its poorest nations. This weekend's gathering in Beijing has drawn global attention to an increasingly significant trade-and-political relationship that has the potential to eclipse Africa's historical reliance on Western-led development institutions and former colonial powers. China is unapologetic about its need for African resources to supply its booming economy, but its leaders also point to the construction projects, technical training and low-price goods it is bringing to Africa. 'In this new era, China and Africa share increasing common interests and have a growing mutual need,' Chinese President Hu Jintao said in a speech. At a business forum yesterday, Chinese and African enterprises signed 14 business deals valued at a total of $1.9 billion, including contracts to build a rural telephone system in Ghana, construct an aluminum factory in Egypt and build a highway in Nigeria, the official Xinhua news agency reported. Mr. Hu, signaling that China isn't acting purely out of self interest, promised to provide Africa with $5 billion in preferential funding in the next three years. China also will double its aid to Africa and cancel some debt owed to China by the poorest African nations, he said, though Mr. Hu didn't put a value on either commitment. United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan and World Bank President Paul Wolfowitz have both publicly welcomed the summit meeting, saying there is much Africa can learn from the economic overhauls in China that have lifted hundreds of millions of its people out of poverty. 'Economic cooperation should be at the core of the renewed Sino-Africa strategic partnership,' said Ethiopian Prime Minister Meles Zenawi. Messrs. Hu and Meles, with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, read a declaration calling for strengthening China-Africa ties on a basis of 'political equality and mutual trust.' Total trade between China and Africa has been increasing at 30% a year and is expected to top $50 billion this year, up from $39.7 billion in 2005. Resources and raw materials dominate the relationship: Angola this year surpassed Saudi Arabia as China's largest supplier of crude oil, and the scale of China's purchases means the country runs a trade deficit with Africa. The economic links are even broader than those figures suggest. Chinese engineering companies have built thousands of miles of railways and highways across Africa, and are expanding. China Civil Engineering Construction Corp., a state-owned company, said last week it signed a $8.3 billion deal to build a 1,315-kilometer railway between the Nigerian cities of Lagos and Kano. It said the project is the largest international construction project by value ever undertaken by a Chinese business. For African countries, whose chronic lack of infrastructure has stunted their economic expansion, such deals are attractive -- especially when China's government-backed banks also can offer inexpensive financing. And China gets credit for being willing to work in war-torn countries where others fear to tread. 'Chinese investment is crucial to us because we have destroyed everything' in the civil war, said George Wallace, the foreign minister of Liberia. Critics say such munificence is just a way for Chinese firms to get a leg up over competitors in the scramble to lock up Africa's resources. China has also been willing to trade with regimes, like those of Sudan and Zimbabwe, that have been criticized in the West as repressive. The rapid expansion of economic ties has sparked tension. China became an issue in September's elections in Zambian elections after workers at a Chinese-owned copper mine rioted over low wages and poor working conditions. South Africa's textile industry has asked for restraints on Chinese imports, saying local producers are being driven out of business by the flood of inexpensive China-made goods.

title: Sign joint economic and trade commission (duplicate)
description: >Text of report in English by official Chinese news agency Xinhua (New China News Agency)>> >>Beijing, 20 July: Chinese President Hu Jintao met isiting Namibian President Sam Nujoma here Tuesday [20 July]. Both leaders owed to strengthen cooperation in arious fields between the two countries.>> >>Hu said China is willing to expand bilateral economic cooperation and the Chinese government encourages Chinese businesses to invest in Namibia.>> >>China and Namibia established diplomatic relations in 1990. The trade olume between the two countries reached 74.57m US dollars last year, up 52 per cent compared with 2002.>> >>Nujoma said Namibia will improve the domestic investment environment to attract more Chinese investment, especially in high value-added industries and tourism.>> >>Hu said China, with a deep tradition of friendship with Namibia, supported the country's struggle for national independence before its independence.>> >>Since the establishment of diplomatic ties 14 years ago, leaders of both countries have kept close contact and bilateral cooperation in economic, cultural and educational fields have been fruitful, Hu said.>> >>China expects to further increase exchanges between leaders, governments, parliaments and political parties of the two countries, and expand bilateral cooperation in trade, investment, culture and education and other fields, Hu said.>> >>Expressing appreciation for China's assistance to Namibia in its fight for independence and reconstruction, Nujoma said he hopes the two countries will take advantage of the sound bilateral political ties to develop reciprocal cooperation in arious fields.>> >>Nujoma reiterated that Namibia sticks to the one-China policy, and expressed appreciation of China's positive and constructive role in addressing major international and regional issues, including the Korean Peninsula nuclear issue.>> >>Hu said the two countries understand and support each other on international issues and China appreciates Namibia's firm stance on supporting China on the Taiwan issue and the issue of human rights.>> >>Nujoma said Namibia will strengthen cooperation with China in international organizations including the United Nations and the World Trade Organization, and jointly enhance South-South, South-North cooperation and promote world peace and development.>> >>After the meeting, the two sides signed two agreements, one on establishment of a joint economic and trade commission and one on economic and technical cooperation, and an implementation programme (2005-2008) under the cultural agreement.>> >>Nujoma arrived here Monday on a ten-day working isit to China. It is his twelfth China isit. He and his entourage, including the foreign minister and defence minister, will also isit the Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region in northwest China and Shanghai Municipality in east China. >> >
sector: Trade, Tourism, Banking and Financial Services

title: US$100 million credit line (duplicate)
description: Feb 10, 2009 (The Namibian/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- THE Peoples' Republic of China signed another grant agreement with the Namibian Government yesterday, this time for 50 million Yuan (N$65 million). It brings the total funding from China since Independence in 1990 past the one billion Namibia dollar mark. More aid is in the pipeline, such as the upgrading and expansion of the Namibia Defence Force (NDF) military school to a full-fledged Defence Academy for around N$65 million and the construction of a youth training centre for about N$130 million. According to Chinese Ambassador Ren Xiaoping, the use of the new grant will still be decided on. 'The projects to be funded by this new grant will be negotiated between our two countries,' Xiaoping said. She added that China was fully paying for the construction of the presidential residence at the new State House. 'This is a pure grant and construction will be completed by September this year.' China is about to build a school at Omuthiya and a hospital for the Namibian Government. Two more schools will be built at Tsumkwe, while an aquaculture research centre was recently completed near Divundu close to the Okavango River. Since Independence China has given Namibia two grants of 30 and 50 million Yuan, an interest-free loan of 30 million Yuan and one billion Yuan as a concessional loan. The Director General of the National Planning Commission, Dr Peter Katjavii, yesterday said that Government launched its third five-year national development plan (NDP3) last November which required some N$76 billion. 'While a large part could be secured, it still leaves a gap of N$11 billion in potential resources that need to be mobilised.' Asked what happened to the US$100 million (N$1 billion) credit line offered by Chinese premier Hu Jintao during his state visit to Namibia in February 2007, Katjavii replied that this had not yet been utilised. Ambassador Xiaoping said the credit line might possibly be used to upgrade and expand the port of Walvis Bay, which will cost approximately N$1,3 billion. In response to a question about complaints of low wages by Namibian workers employed by Chinese construction companies, and northern businesses worried about being pushed out of business by Chinese retailers, Katjavii said this 'issue is being shared with our Chinese friends and addressed by our line ministries'. 'I am aware of a recent report on a survey about this issue but I am not in the full picture,' he said. Last week, Works and Transport Minister Helmut Angula told a meeting at Keetmanshoop that the Chinese government was pushing for Chinese workers to do construction work in Namibia. 'They cannot work with African workers since they have a different culture,' Angula said. According to him, the Chinese government believes that Namibian construction companies do not have the capacity to take on large projects like the rehabilitation of the final 47 kilometres of the Aus-Luderitz railway line. Namibia has no money left for that project, which will cost N$70 million, and is negotiating another soft loan to complete the rail link upgrade. 'The bone of contention is whether to allocate the tender to a Chinese or Namibian company,' Minister Angula said.

title: Conakry, Labe, Faranah and N'Zerekore medical missions and health worker training- may include 15705 and 13066
description: Guinean website assesses ties with China ahead of bilateral commission talks613 words13 April 201111:10 AMBBC Monitoring AfricaBBCAPEnglish(c) 2011 The British Broadcasting Corporation. All Rights Reserved. No material may be reproduced except with the express permission of The British Broadcasting Corporation.Excerpt from report by Cisse Aboubacar entitled 'The world-Diplomacy: The state of Chinese-Guinean cooperation' published on Guineenews website based in Canada but with editorial team in Guinea on 12 AprilDiplomacy: the state of the Chinese-Guinean cooperation on the eve of the opening of the fifth joint bilateral commission of cooperation of the countries in Conakry.The fifth session of the joint grand commission of bilateral cooperation between China and Guinea will take place in Conakry on 13 and 14 April 2011. The high powered delegation led by the Chinese deputy minister of trade, Fu Ziyinc, which will take part in the discussions, is arriving by a special flight from Peking on this 13 April for a session which is beginning with the visit to the construction site of the 50,000 seating capacity stadium at Nongo and the commissioning of the Kipe International Hospital which are both donations from China.According to the technicians at the Ministry of International Cooperation of our country, 'the Chinese-Guinean diplomatic ties which date back to October 1956 and the dominant characteristics of which are discreet, are achieved mainly through interest free loans, completed by financial grants, donations of food and pharmaceutical product, budgetary aids and military assistance'. Several accomplishments are also among this cooperation on the level of agriculture, industry, handicraft, infrastructure, trade, energy, health, education, training and telecommunications among others. They are achievements that contributed greatly to the socio-economic development of Guinea.On the education level, for instance, China gave Guinea 300 scholarships in the areas higher and post-university education and in the fields of architecture, mathematics, food technology, biochemistry, agriculture and health in the last 13 years. However, in the case of health, 22 Chinese medical missions have been circulating between Conakry, Labe, Faranah and N'Zerekore on the basis of a biannual renewable contract from 1968. The training of over 140 health workers of all categories is also in this programme.On the trade level, statistics show that commercial exchange between our two countries which were up to the tune of 43m dollars in 2002 rise to about 200m dollars currently. With the admission of Peking in 2004 into the World Trade Organization (WTO), the Chinese authorities gave a quota of 87 products to Guinea from the following year under special customs preferential tariff treatment.It should be noted that Guinea received from China in cash and kind a total sum of nearly 7m dollars from 1984, under the terms of this donation, for the purchase of rice seeds, tractors, learning materials for the deaf and dumb, building and telecommunications materials and fertilizers etc.Under infrastructures, the Sekhoutoureya Presidential Palace, the Kinkon and Tinkisso hydroelectric plants, the Kipe International Hospital, the People's Palace, the RTG [state-owned Guinean Radio-Television] Broadcasting House at Koloma, the Chinese-Guinean Friendship Schools at Coyah, the 50,000 sitting capacity stadium at Nongo which is being built are among the showpieces of this cooperation.We should note finally that about 40 Chinese technical assistants are currently working on various Chinese-Guinean cooperation projects, without speaking of the multitude of Chinese private companies which give birth to a massive presence of Chinese nationals in our country.It is therefore in this favourable atmosphere that the discussions on the fifth session of the Chinese-Guinean joint grand commission of bilateral cooperation is opening on Wednesday [13 April], which is the harbinger of bright prospects for the deepening and diversification of this over five decade old cooperation based on a win-win policy.Source: Guineenews website in French 12 Apr 11adaa7181Document BBCAP00020110413e74d002e5

title: Phase Two Education
description: (PPIAF) Previous description: Oil-backed loan to repair damaged infrastructure, mainly railway tracks bombed in the country's civil war. The money will also lay roads and electrify slum areas of the capital, Luanda, and also fund rehabilitation of the water supply systems Updated description: On March 2, 2004 the first Credit Accord with the Eximbank of China was signed for a financial package of two billion US Dollars and meant for the financing of projects of Angola's public investment. The first package was implemented in two different phases, with each taking one billion US Dollars. The first phase involved 27 contracts, corresponding to 50 projects, of which 21 have been completed. These projects focused on areas of electricity, water, health, education, public works, each of which taking about 20 percent of the total amount released.The second phase included 13 contracts and 52 projects that are underway. These contracts are in the areas of telecommunications, fisheries, health, education and public works.A contract is near approval to complete the second phase. The contract is called EDEL III, plus another two in final stage of negotiation, also in the sector of electricity and waters.The balance at the end of September 2007, according to the Finance Ministry, is of Usd 7.1 million, of which Usd 1.6 million are for the first phase of the financing and Usd 5.4 million for the second phase.The total amount disbursed until the end of September is Usd 932.9 million, being 733.1 million for the first phase and 199.8 for the second phase.As a result of the positive evaluation made by the two parties concerning the first package of two billion US Dollars, a memorandum of understanding was signed on June 20, 2006, between the Angolan Finance Ministry and China's Eximbank, for the granting of a new financing of the same amount.; Contractor Comment: Tied to the loan, is the agreement that the public tenders for the construction and civil engineering contracts will be awarded primarily to Chinese state-owned enterprises approved by the Chinese government. Exim Bank has compiled a list of 3; Political/Resource Considerations: Oil (China was to receive 10,000 barrels of oil per day. Sinopec wins a license for a large oil-production block previously held by Total of France. Sinopec then formed a joint venture to bid on other oilfields in Angola.); Chinese Commitment: USD 30 Million; PPIAF-ID:15
donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency

title: Scholarships to study in China- duplicate with 1225
description: Nairobi, Jan 29, 2004 (The East African Standard/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) --A Chinese language teaching centre is to be set up at the University of Nairobi.The project, expected to cost Sh30 million, will be funded by the Chinese Government.Ambassador Guo Chongli said his government would cater for teaching equipment and provide professors to teach the language.'The money will cater for the first phase and more might be required as the project continues,' he said. Chongli said the university planned to promote the programme from a certificate to diploma course.He was speaking when handing over Chinese language books donated by his government to the Education Assistant minister Kilemi Mwiria.The books are to be taken to Egerton University's Chinese Teaching Centre. Since 1998, more than 100 Kenyans have benefited from the programme.'We are working hard to promote Chinese teaching and learning in Kenya,' the envoy said. China gives 10 scholarships to Kenyan students every year and currently, more than 30 Kenyans are studying in that country.Document AFNWS00020040129e01t0013l
verified: Egerton University, Academic, Training and Research

description: 4月28日，由广州军区武汉总医院医护人员组成的中国援助加蓬军医组一行9人，完成为期一年的医疗援助任务返回武汉。援非期间，他们先后救治病患6000多人，为加蓬三军总医院培训医护人员300多人次，指导开展新技术新业务10余项，加蓬总统和国防部长曾分别为军医组成员授勋。图为加蓬国防部秘书总长为军医组成员佩戴勋章的情景。 李玉宝、余 敏摄影报道

title: construction of a National Sports School
description: Dec 03, 2007 (The Post/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- The Chinese Government has pledged to construct five sports stadiums of international standards in the country.The governments of Cameroon and China signed a partnership accord on Friday, November 30, at the conference hall of the Ministry of Finance in Yaounde.According to the agreement, an ultra-modern sports complex would be erected at Olembe in Yaounde to be baptised Paul Biya Stadium and a stadium each in Douala, Garoua, Ebolowa and Bafoussam.Meanwhile, rehabilitation of the existing stadiums in each of the provincial headquarters would be carried out within the agreement. Both construction and renovation projects have been estimated to cost FCFA 272 billion, and would span for eight years during which the government of Cameroon is expected to refund the money to her Chinese counterpart.It was disclosed that each of the stadiums would be constructed to contain 60,000 spectators. Speaking shortly after the signing ceremony, the Director of China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export Corporation, Li Huaijun Chanxin, revealed that the construction of the Paul Biya sports complex would take three phases.The first phase would be to construct a 60.000 seats capacity stadium to be accompanied by an aquatic centre built to provide a chemical system comprising air conditioning among others. Still, this phase would also witness the building of a modern associated facility such as a hotel.The last but one phase of the work takes into account the construction of a 35,000 seats capacity of a National Sports School to cover some 10 thousand square metres of land with a medical rehabilitation centre for students to recover from physical activities.The sports school would incorporate an indoor gymnasium and an aquatic centre. Meanwhile, the renovation of provincial stadiums would constitute the last phase. It is estimated that phase one would consume EU 144,000 million; phase two would take EU 60 million while phase three is EU 209 million project.The Chinese construction company would provide only the expertise. Meanwhile, Cameroon labour began preliminary work at the site at Olembe since January this year.In a chat with The Post, Li Huaijun said his company would effect a modern lighting system that gives our national colours as it automatically changes from green to red to yellow in the night.He said both the energy and water supply in the complex would be the business of his company.It was also stated that the ability to carry out the work according to time is based on bi-lateral efforts of both Cameroon and China.Sports and Physical Education Minister, Augustin Edjoa, said Li's company was chosen based on its experience and know-how. He also made known that his team had spent nine days in the country during which they visited the construction sites and carried out budgetary estimation with finance experts from the Ministry of Sports and Physical Education and from their experts.Minister Edjoa disclosed that his Ministry has drawn up an elaborate plan to provide sports infrastructure in all the provincial headquarters. According to the plan, he went on, proximity sports edifices would be erected in all Divisional headquarters in the country. He said this development is in line with government's determination to see the country host the 2016 African Cup of Nations as well as other international sports jamboree.All Africa Global MediaDocument AFNWS00020071203e3c3001y0

title: Drought relief assistance
description: Chinese vice-foreign minister, Jang Wenchang, said that his country would donate 5,000 metric tonnes of emergency relief assistance to the drought-induced food shortage in Ethiopia.The status of this project is uncertain.
sector: Humanitarian and Disaster Relief and Preparation

title: Construction of agricultural technology demonstration centre (Duplicate)
description: Kampala, Oct 03, 2008 (New Vision/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- China will continue supporting Uganda's economic and social development, the Chinese ambassador, Sun Heping, has said.'Since the forum on China-Africa cooperation in November 2006, eight policies announced by president Hu Jintao to support Africa's development have been implemented in Uganda,' Heping said at a reception held at the Sheraton Kampala Hotel to mark the 59th anniversary of the Peoples Republic of China.'Those that have been implemented include expansion of aid, debt relief, tariff exemption and increase ofassistance and input to Uganda's social development,' he said.'The government of China is to build two schools, a hospital, a centre for malaria treatment and prevention, an agricultural technology demonstration centre and a government office block in the near future.'Heping said China's gross domestic product (GDP) share of the world economy and global trade rose to 5% and 8% respectively from 1% in 1978.'China's development has opened a huge market for international capital, attracting over $780b of net foreign investment, while direct overseas investments by the Chinese are also growing.'According to the Uganda Investment Authority, over $35m has been invested in Uganda by theChinese from June 30, 2007 to June 30, 2008. Also, the Chinese government has given over $85m inaid over the last four years.Heping said China has become the world's third largest import market and the largest import market in Asia.It contributes over 10% to global economic growth and over 12% to expansion of global trade.'China's average annual import volume has reached close to $560b since 2001, generating 10 million jobs for the trade partners.'Document AFNWS00020081003e4a30006jUGANDA - The Uganda and Chinese government have joined forces to build an agricultural technology demonstration centre at Kajjansi Aquaculture Research and Development Centre.The centre will continue research on new fish species, offer technical training and technical demonstration of highly effective freshwater aquaculture techniques.The centre is also designed to foster freshwater fry breeding techniques and demonstrate better fish feed processing and application, according to a report in the Ugandan Daily Monitor. New fish species such as grasscarp, silvercarp, and bighead carp are to be introduced from China.And the project General Manager Yi Ronggan told trhe Monitor that they also want to introduce blue tilapia for breeding, spawning and later all the species will be distributed to farmers across Uganda.The project, being built by Sichuan Huaqiao Fenghuang group and funded by the Chinese government, will also develop and promote large-scale breeding of the Nile perch, the main species in Uganda’s waters.The project is one of the outcomes of the Sino Africa Summit that marked 50 years of collaboration and cooperation of Africa with China.
recipient_agencies: Sichuan Huaqiao Fenghuang Group Co., Ltd.

title: Loan for construction of hospital/government office (Duplicate)
description: Possibly part of 23467---------China gives Uganda 77 mln dollars aid to boost development248 words13 January 2009Trend News Agency (Azerbaijan)TRENDEEnglish(c) 2009 Trend News Agency. Copyright for the present information is reserved, in case of reprint of any part of it reference should be done to the Agency.The Chinese government has offered 77 million U.S. dollars to Uganda in a renewed bid to boost the East African country's development, the visiting Chinese Foreign Minister Yang Jiechi revealed after signingaid agreements here on Tuesday, reported Xinhua.The low interest aid package signed between the two governments included a framework agreement on provision of a concessional loan for the construction of e-governance project worth 60 million dollars and procurement of engineering equipment for Kampala City Council worth ten million dollars.The other package is a seven million dollar economic and technical cooperation agreement on the construction of a hospital and government offices.Yang, who is currently on a two day official visit to Uganda, the first leg of his seven nation tour to the continent and Brazil, said China will not cut its aid pledges to Africa despite the global economic downturn and appealed to the developed countries to do the same.' China as a firm friend of Uganda and Africa will by no means cut our aid to Uganda and Africa, on the contrary we will exert even greater effort to help our African and Ugandan brothers and sisters,' he said.Sam Kutesa, Uganda's minister of foreign affairs hailed China's support and pledged that Uganda will closely work with the Asian country both at the UN Security Council and other international fora to deal with both regional and international issues.Document TRENDE0020090113e51d006k5

title: Army Fatigues
description: 'BANGUI, Dec 7 (AFP) - Chinese-made tractors and army fatigues will be heading to the Central African Republic under a bilateral agreement signed with Beijing, national radio reported Wednesday. The deal was signed late Tuesday by President Francois Bozize, who is also defence minister, and He Siji, China's ambassador to Bangui. 'The Chinese army will supply the Central African army with logistical resources, military uniforms, communications equipment and other items,' He told the radio station. 'This is important because the country needs a strong army, and a strong army needs to be equipped,' he said. Tractors will be provided under the agricultural component of the accord, whose value was not revealed. Diplomatic relations between the landlocked republic, a major diamond producer, and China broke down when former president Andre Kolingba's regime established relations with Taiwan in 1992. They resumed three years later when then president Ange-Felix Patasse broke off with Taipei. Since then China has supplied technical assistance to the aid-dependent African country, building public infrastructure and public housing, and providing cash loans. acp/jac/gd '

title: New Radio Equipment (duplicate #478)
description: In 2005, the Chinese construction company Gwang Ding was building a two-story building fitted with audiovisual equipment. A group of Chinese engineers are responsible for maintaining the infrastructure of Radio Bata. Within the building, two 50-kW shortwave transmitters were being installed at the radio station, along with two antennas, one domestic and the other external. Based on the Chinese source, it is unclear if the project was completed.

title: Mining Projects (Duplicate of 450)
description: 'More information has emerged about the conditions obtained by China in return for Beijing’s recent accord to grant USD 8.5 billion in financial aid to the Kinshasa government. The preliminary agreement, signed on 17 September 2007 by the Congolese minister Pierre Lumbi Okongo and the group ChinaEximbank/ China Railway Engineering Corporation/Sinohydro, represented by Li Changjin, CREC,’s chairman, a copy of which was obtained by AMI, covers the granting of mining concessions totalling 8.05 million tonnes of copper ores, 202,000 tonnes of cobalt and 372 tonnes of gold «to be identified» (sic). The document specifies the following concessions: the Mashamba basin (1 million tonnes of copper and 151,000 t of cobalt), the Dima basin (3.93 m t of copper and 49,000 t of cobalt), the Dik Colline D syncline (2 m t of copper) and Kolwezi (1.11 m t of copper and 1,076 t of cobalt). The agreement calls for the formation of a joint venture between the Chinese group and Congolese companies designated by Kinshasa which are not identified in the document. These companies would only own 32% of the joint venture. Financial costs of the deal will be covered in several stages: priority will first be given to the amortisation of the USD 3 billion mining investment, which is to be financed by the joint venture’s revenues; then infrastructure construction work will be financed to the tune of 66% by the joint venture’s net profits (the rest will be distributed proportionally between the parties); finally, with commercial production, all remaining investments will be amortised. The joint venture will be granted special conditions for supplies and public works contracts for a period of 30 years. The list includes cost exemptions for transactions such as demand for or award of mining rights, transfer or sale of mining participations or exploration and production permits, for example.'   '【星岛网讯】中国签署了一份协议草案，同意向刚果民主共和国[刚果（金）]提供50亿美元贷款，发展交通设施和采矿业。这项协议还将部分资金用于建设新的学校、医院和政府提供的住房建设。这将是中国在非洲最大的投资之一。 　　美国之音报道，在中国提供的贷款中，约有三十亿美元被规定用于交通建设，包括一条主要高速公路以及一条连接刚果南部的矿区中心和西部马塔迪港口的铁路。这笔贷款也将用来建设新的学校、医院和两所规模很大的大学。刚果基础设施部部长说，剩下的二十亿美元将用来发展刚果的采矿业，并启动中国和刚果的合资项目。 　　国际危机组织高级分析员贾森·斯特恩斯说，中国的贷款对去年底赢得里程碑式大选的刚果总统约瑟夫·卡比拉来说十分关键。他说：“卡比拉急迫地想以和平回报支持他的选民，但是他们今年困难重重，难以对当地老百姓的社会服务项目做出改变。” 　　斯特恩斯说，刚果的基础设施在过去三十年遭到破坏，简直是一片废墟，那里只有几条铺过的道路和一条破旧的铁路。他说，因为政府的财政状况缺乏透明度，许多国际投资者去年起减少了在刚果的投资。 　　此外，中国政府没有对贷款附加任何条件。刚果自然资源极为丰富，有钴、铜、锡、黄金、钻石和木材丰富的森林。这些资源的开采由于连年战乱而减缓。'

title: Military hospital- not sure this is aid
description: BUSINESS CIRCLESA wave of Sino-Guineans arrive368 words22 January 2011The Indian Ocean NewsletterIOLET1301EnglishCopyrights 2011 Indigo Publications All Rights ReservedSeveral Guinean dignitaries, who have already worked with Chinese companies in their country, are aiding China Sonangol and its subsidiaries to set up in Antananarivo.Chinese companies have gone on the offensive in Madagascar, where the Minister for Finance, Hery Rajaonarimampianina, has just informed the President for Transition, Andry Rajoelina known as TGV, about the project to create the Madagascar Development Corporation (MDC), a joint venture between the Malagasy State (15%) and the China International Fund Ltd (CIF). A company based in Hong Kong and related to China Sonangol (an alliance between Chinese capital and the Angolan State), CIF is particularly planning to revive the tram project in Antananarivo (ION 1297). The financial configuration of this future MDC is similar to that of the Société Sino-Guinéennede Développement which the CIF tried to found in Conakry (Guinea) at the end of 2009 when the country was under the thumb of President Moussa Dadis Camara. The sponsors of this Guinean company are the very same that are now trying to promote Sino-Angolan interests to TGV: the former Guinean Minister for Mines, Mahmoud Thiam, a close friend of his Malagasy opposite number, Mamy Ratovomalala, and the International Football Federation (FIFA) player agent Amadou Diaby. These two men went to Antananarivo several times, where they were received by TGV and his advisors. According to Africa Energy Intelligence (sister publication to The Indian Ocean Newsletter), China-Sonangol is planning, via their intermediary, to recover the oil search permits that the Malagasy State is trying to revoke from Madagascar Oil.Thiam and Diaby also took a Frenchman along with them: Gilles Wertheimer, a businessman who may already have participated in building a military hospital in Guinea with Chinese funding. Via his company Alliance International Partners, whose Africa representative is Diaby, Wertheimer offered TGV to build several pre-fabricated hospitals, thereby enabling him to keep promises he had made during the campaign for the constitutional referendum last year. Wertheimer estimates that this construction work could be financed by levying $10 million on the amount paid by the Chinese company Wisco to obtain its contract to work iron ore at Soalala.87610343|XMLExtract_ION_1301.xmlDocument IOLET00020110204e71m0000s

title: Military barrack financing
description: China agreed to grant the Ghana Armed Forces and Police Service a $4.5 million USD interest-free loan In January of 2003, Ghanaian Minister of Defense and Acting Interior Minister Dr. Kwame Addo-Kufuor initiated the construction of the barracks. The barracks comprising three blocks of twenty-eight units and two blocks of twelve units will accommodate 105 families. It is unclear when the commitment year was, and the project was abandoned for some period of time, but in 2010, Poly Technologies Inc. agreed to complete the project. The project does not yet appear to have been completed.

title: Friendship hospital construction
description: Programme summary of Guinea-Conakry RTG television 2030 gmt 13 Apr 11368 words15 April 201102:41 AMBBC Monitoring AfricaBBCAPEnglish(c) 2011 The British Broadcasting Corporation. All Rights Reserved. No material may be reproduced except with the express permission of The British Broadcasting Corporation.1. Headlines2. Presidential decree on the appointment of two managers at the Conakry Airport Management Company.3. The prime minister yesterday held a meeting with the union of Lebanese businessmen in the country. They discussed the illegal operations of some industrial units in the country. Also, safety measures are not in place in some of these companies.4. Report about the inauguration of Chinese-Guinean Friendship Hospital today in Conakry. It was declared opened by President Alpha Conde. Construction works started in 2009.5. The prime minister today received the general manager of a Tatarstan aluminium mining company. He has come to explore investment avenues in our country in the mining sector.6. The minister of territorial administration today held a working meeting with leaders of some 103 political parties to discuss the preparations for the legislative elections. The minister outlined the preparations, namely, the need to carry out another registration of voters, the restructuring of the Independent National Election Commission, CENI. He said the voters register cannot be accessed at this point. It is only the Sagem that has access to it and this company says it cannot release the key, saying that its contract is only with the UN and not with the government. Some party leaders said the composition of the CENI is unacceptable. [processing]7. A Chinese delegation led by that country's deputy trade minister arrived today in Conakry. He has come to hold talks on promoting cooperation.8. The minister of mines and geology is on a working visit to Dinguiraye.9. The minister of social affairs today received a visiting delegation of the UN Commission for the Consolidation of Peace.10. A communiquéssued by the National Communication Council says after a quarter of operations, it has noted the increase in private media houses. It regrets the lack of professionalism on the part of some journalists.11. The CNC has earned the Soleil FM radio station for repeated violation of the ethics of the profession.12. Cultural news: Arrival of Miss Black-Soul from France.Source: Radiodiffusion Television Guineenne Television, Conakry, in French 2030 gmt 13 Apr 11adac9cc7Document BBCAP00020110415e74f00105

title: Technical and economic co-operation agreement (Duplicate of 13464)
description: Tunisia, China sign technical and economic co-operation agreement380 words21 April 2011Agency Tunis Afrique PressAGETAPEnglish© 2011 TAP. All Rights Reserved. Provided by Syndigate.info, an Albawaba.com companyTUNIS, April 21, 2011 (TAP) - Tunisia and China signed, on Thursday, a technical and economic co-operation agreement.Under this agreement, China will grant Tunisia 40 million Yuans (8 million, 370 thousand dinars), under the form of investments in development projects to be identified later by both sides.The agreement was signed at the end of a working session held, on Thursday morning in Tunis, between Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs Radhouane Nouicer and Chinese Deputy-Trade Minister Fu Ziying, who is on a working visit to Tunisia on April 20-23, heading an important delegation including government officials, economic operators and bankers.The working session provided the opportunity to review ways to develop the relations of friendship between Tunisia and China and further boost bilateral co-operation in various fields.At the end of the working session, Mr. Fu Ziying emphasised the Chinese Government's respect for the Tunisian people's will and reiterated its support to the process of transition triggered in Tunisia.'The Chinese Government has always stood with Tunisia which is a partner of major importance to China,' he pointed out, saying that he was 'confident in Tunisia's future and deeply convinced that the Chinese-Tunisian relations will be further strengthened, particularly in the economic and commercial fields.'He also voiced satisfaction at the close and long-standing relations binding China and Tunisia which', thanks to its strategic geographic position, will be a preferred destination for Chinese investors.'Mr. Fu Ziying's visit, which follows that of the Deputy-Foreign Minister last month, will certainly open new prospects for bilateral co-operation, particularly in the fields of investment, financing and scientific and technological research.It will also help establish a profitable partnership for both countries likely to generate joint investments in promising sectors.It should be noted that China had already granted a donation of 2 million dollars (2.7 million dinars) to the National Defence Ministry.At the beginning of the month, China had sent a humanitarian assistance worth 30 million Yuans (6.2 million dinars) to the Tunisian-Libyan border to help cope with the flow of refugees.China is Tunisia's first commercial partner in Asia, its 4th supplier and 18th customer.

title: University Hospital Center (Too late to be a project)
description: Tunisia: China to build $ 30 million UHC in Sfax110 words29 May 2012African ManagerAFMAENEnglish© 2012 African Manager. All Rights Reserved. Provided by Syndigate.info, an Albawaba.com companyChina will build a new University Hospital Center (UHC) in Sfax, with a capacity of 300 beds through a donation of $ 30 million (45 million dinars).A delegation of Chinese experts is expected in Tunisia later this week to discuss the development plans of the hospital with the Tunisian side.The announcement was made by Huo Zhengde, Ambassador of the People's Republic of China in Tunis during an interview with TAP news agency.He said the hospital is one of the largest development projects achieved by China in Tunisia, reaffirming his country's support to Tunisia during the transition period.African ManagerDocument AFMAEN0020120530e85t00002

title: Coal power plant
description: In 2011, Guinea sked China Power Investment to build a 340 mW coal-fired power plant in the African state. CONAKRY, Sept 18 (Reuters) - Guinea has asked state-owned China Power Investment (CPI) to build a 340 MW coal-fired power plant in the electricity-starved west African state, its mines minister said.The project is part of ongoing negotiations between Guinea and CPI over the potential development of a bauxite mine in Boffa and construction of an alumina refinery and deepwater port, source have said.'We have asked China Power Investment to build a 240 MW thermal power plant powered by coal to which they will join up another 100 MW plant,' Mines Minister Mohamed Lamine Fofana said on state television.Fofana, one of the Guinean officials who is with President Alpha Conde on a trip to China, gave no details on the financing or timing of the project.'We have visited a 2,000 MW power plant (in China) that doesn't even emit dust. It is only water vapour that we see. We've asked them to do the same thing in Guinea, only in miniature,' he said.CPI has three bauxite exploration permits in Guinea and has said it has found 900 million tonnes of reserves.Guinea is the world's largest exporter of the aluminium ore, and has vast deposits of iron ore that have drawn billions of dollars in planned investments by companies such as Rio Tintoand Vale .CPI is negotiating with the Guinean government to open a bauxite mine to develop the Boffa reserves, build an alumina refinery to process it and a deepwater port for exports for a total $5.8 billion.Despite its vast mineral wealth, Guinea's 10 million people face routine blackouts and a power generation capacity shortage is seen slowing mining investment.(Writing by Richard Valdmanis)GUINEA-CHINA/POWERReuters LimitedDocument LBA0000020110918e79i000dj几内亚要求中电投建340兆瓦发电厂中铝网综合外电9月19日讯  几内亚已要求国有公司中国电力投资公司（CPI）在电力匮乏的西非国家建立一个340兆瓦的燃煤发电厂，其矿业部长表示。　　该项目是几内亚与中电投之间正在进行的关于博法铝土矿潜在发展以及氧化铝精炼厂和深水港口建设谈判的一部分，内部人士透露。　　“我们已经要求中国电力投资（公司）建立一个240兆瓦以煤为动力的火力发电厂，他们将加入另外100兆瓦的装置供电”，矿业部长穆罕默德拉福法纳在国家电视台上说。

title: China gives grant to Liberia Inactive
description: China lends Mozambique another R418.6-m103 words4 March 2009FT NowFTNOWEnglish(c) 2009 Now Media (Pty) Ltd. All Rights Reserved.   The Mozambiquan and Chinese governments signed three agreements in Maputo, under which China is to provide a total of R418.6-million in loan and grant finance. News agency AIM reports that the largest sum is a loan of R224.2-m for the fourth funding phase in the construction of Mozambique's new national sports stadium. A second loan, for R183.6-m, is to support agricultural projects in the Zambezi Valley, while the third agreement is for a grant of R30.6-m to be used in basic development sectors yet to be identified.

title: Chinese company interested in Ugandan refinery (Not a project)
description: Uganda to woo China money for energy, infrastructure533 words4 November 200908:19 AMReuters NewsLBAEnglish(c) 2009 Reuters Limited* Wants investment in nuclear energy, high-speed rail* Chinese investors already interested in refineryBy Elias BiryabaremaKAMPALA, Nov 4 (Reuters) - Uganda intends to woo Chinese investment to boost the country's efforts in adding value to exports and to tackle energy and infrastructure handicaps, government officials said.China's commercial footprint has been expanding in Uganda over the last five years. It was the third biggest FDI source in the third quarter of 2009 after India and Britain, according to the Uganda Investment Authority (UIA).'Our prime economic interest in China is if they can invest in our processing industry, infrastructure and energy, including nuclear energy, as the president has emphasized in the past. That would be a good partnership,' President Yoweri Museveni's spokesperson, Tamale Mirundi, told Reuters.He said Museveni plans to attend a China-Africa Summit in Egypt later this month. Trade between the continent and China has grown at 30 percent a year, climbing to $107 billion in 2008 to eclipse the United States for the first time.Museveni has previously named modern, high-speed railways and a refinery for Uganda's newly-found petroleum deposits as some of the immediate projects the Chinese can invest in.Landlocked Uganda still depends for a great deal of its external trade on the derelict and inefficient Uganda-Kenya rail line to get its exports to sea, blunting the goods' competitiveness and stifling economic growth.The volume of trade between Uganda and China remains relatively small and heavily imbalanced in favour of China.Uganda imported goods worth $274.2 million from China in 2007 compared with 138.2 million in 2006, according to a Uganda Bureau of Statistics report that did not give export figures.REFINERY FOR UGANDAN OILA delegation from the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China -- which holds a 20 percent stake in Standard Bank, Africa's biggest bank by assets, -- met Museveni in June and said it was interested in a partnership for the refinery.Uganda is locked in a dispute with the exploration companies Tullow Oil, Heritage Oil and Gas of Canada over whether the country should refine its petroleum, an option the government prefers, or export crude.The east African country has estimated reserves of 2 billion barrels and levels are forecast to grow substantially over the next few years.'The exploration companies don't want us to refine our oil but we're saying no. The president thinks the Chinese can come in with their vast expertise to help us acquire refining capacity,' Tamale said.Uganda mainly exports cotton, leather, coffee, fish, and minerals to China and buys textiles and garments, footwear, porcelain, enamel, mechanical and electrical goods.Keith Muhakanizi, a top Treasury official, told Reuters that Uganda was targeting China's huge investment funds.China has 'enormous investment funds capable of undertaking huge infrastructure projects in energy and infrastructure and these are the areas where we're focusing our efforts,' he said. (Editing by Helen Nyambura-Mwaura; Editing by Ron Askew)UGANDA-CHINA/|LANGEN|ABN|M|D|Z|O|OIL|ELE|AFA|CSA|LBY|RWSA|RWS|REULB|GNS|ABX|DNP|PEN|SXNADocument LBA0000020091104e5b40017q
donor_agency_count: Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC), State-Owned Company
recipient_agencies: Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC), State-Owned Company

title: Chinese-constructed hospital and malaria centre (Duplicate)
description: China Donates Sh1 Billion Malaria Drugsby Josephine Maseruka295 words10 October 201009:38 PMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2010 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedKampala, Oct 10, 2010 (New Vision/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- The Chinese government has donated anti-malaria drugs worth sh1.25b to Uganda. The drugs were officially handed over to health state minister Dr. Richard Nduhura on Friday.This is the fourth donation of anti-malarial drugs from the Chinese government at the request of Uganda in an attempt to cut down on the estimated 320 daily deaths caused by malaria.According to the Uganda Bureau of Statistics, between 70,000 and 110,000 annual child deaths are due to malaria.Handing over the consignment, the Chinese ambassador to Uganda, Sun Heping, said medical care and health were a priority in the China-Africa cooperation.'African people have long been plagued by malaria. To help them improve health care and enhance the capacity to prevent malaria, treat it and deliver better health services to the people, China has intensified its efforts to cooperate with African countries in the field of health over the past three years,' Heping said.He also commended the good relations between Uganda and China. China is constructing a hospital and malaria research centre in Naguru, a Kampala suburb.'We will also continue to provide Uganda with medical equipment and anti-malarial resources to improve the capacity for diagnosis and treatment, and to ensure that China aid projects are sustained to better serve Ugandans.'Nduhura thanked the Chinese government for continued support to Uganda in many fields, including the construction of the Naguru hospital.Malaria accounts for 40% of Uganda's public health expenditure.The Government is distributing free treated mosquito nets to households and introduced free anti-malarial drugs to its health centres across the country to contain the disease.Document AFNWS00020101011e6ab0007n

title: US$4m grant to Zambia (duplicate)
description: Chinese Firms Keen to Invest in Zambia589 words13 November 200303:03 PMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2003 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedNo13, 2003 (The Times of Zambia/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) --MORE than 70 Chinese companies in textile manufacturing, construction, telecommunications and agricultural businesses are interested in exploring investment opportunities in Zambia.President Mwanawasa disclosed this yesterday at the Lusaka International Airport on arrival from a six-day State visit to that country.He said he was pleased that next month Zambia would be accorded the status of 'final destination' for Chinese tourists in order to boost the tourism industry.He described his visit to China as fruitful and a further demonstration of good and strong bilateral relations that existed between the two countries.President Mwanawasa, who was accompanied by First Lady Maureen, was welcomed on arrival by Vice-President Nevers Mumba, several Cabinet ministers, their deputies, defence chiefs and several party members.He said his visit to China coincided with an investment promotion mission from Zambia, and he was also privileged to officiate at the first Zambia-China investment seminar which was attended by more than 70 Chinese companies.'All these are keen to establish themselves in Zambia through direct investment or through joint ventures with Zambian companies,' the President said.The two governments have also signed a US$ 6 million grant, some of it in cash form, and the rest to be used for projects mutually agreed upon.Giving a breakdown of the grant, Mr Mwanawasa said US$ 2 million would be in cash form and US$ 4 million would go towards various projects to be initiated in the country.President Mwanawasa said the assistance had come at an opportune time and the money would be utilised effectively and efficiently as Government was in need of resources to implement the Poverty Reduction Strategic Paper (PRSP).On debt relief, the two countries had agreed on possibilities of discussing a further debt relief to Zambia.China last year cancelled a US$ 10 million debt to Zambia.'Given the huge burden the country continues to face and the difficulties we have in servicing these loans due to financial constraints, I requested my counterpart for further debt relief. Technical experts from our two countries will consult on this,' he said.President Mwanawasa said the Zambian Government had signed a letter of intent with Sinohydro Corporation, among other companies who are interested in investing in the energy sector, especially in the hydro power plant projects in Kafue Gorge Lower for 600 megawatts and in the Itezhi Tezhi for 180 megawatts.Another agreement was signed with the municipal people's government of Quindao on the establishment of the Mulungushi industrial park as a joint venture project.Quimdao Kailan group of companies also signed an agreement for the establishment of a chemical fertiliser and pesticides project at a cost of US$ 10 million with an expected production of 200,000 tonnes and 10,000 tonnes, respectively.Meanwhile, President Mwanawasa says he has not yet received a report on the revocation of title deeds from Minister of Lands Judith Kapijimpanga and Copperbelt Minister Webby Chipili by the lands tribunal.Responding to a query, Mr Mwanawasa said he was yet to be briefed on the matter before he could make a decision.The lands tribunal in its ruling on Monday revoked titles for a commercial plot jointly owned by the duo through their companies Pineland Investment and WC Engineering.The two ministers have since indicated that they would be appealing to the Supreme Court against the decision of the tribunal, which was chaired by Mr Sebastian Zulu.

title: Oil Plant contruction (Duplicate of 1996)
description: 'BEIJING, June 05, SinoCast -- Chinese oil titan China National Petroleum Corporation (PetroChina Group) plans to invest USD 5 billion in the following three years to develop Niger's Agadem oil block jointly with the Nigerian government, in line with an agreement signed on June 2, 2008, said China's Ministry of Commerce yesterday.The Agadem oil block is the largest one in the African country and is proven to have considerable oil reserve, according to the Chinese ministry. PetroChina Group will also build a plant capable of refining 1 million tons of crude oil every year and also a 2,000-kilometer pipeline in the country.Zhang Shengli, an official from the Chinese ministry, said there was not any third party in the project.PetroChina Group is expected be benefited in terms of profitability by forming a complete industry chain from exploitation to oil transportation in the project, said Guotai Junan Securities analyst Yang Wei.The Chinese oil titan has been prospecting the Blima block and the Tenere block in Niger. '

title: Dabola Groundnut Oil Factory [commitment year before 2000]
description: The ambassador of China to Guinea announced to the deputies at the end of last week that his government promised to Guinea 50 luxury cars for the 50th anniversary of independence, observed Guineenews at the National Assembly.In addition to the cars, China promised to build a 150-bed modern hospital in Conakry, specifically at Kipe. According to the ambassador, the construction works will begin this year and will be put to use in 2009. 2009.'The hospital will relieve to some extent the physical sufferings and charges of Guineans. China will construct soon three rural schools in the Conakry suburb', he added.We can cite, among the investment of China in Guinea, ENTAG [cigarette manufacturing firm], the Macenta Tea Factory [in southeastern Guinea], the Dabola Groundnut Oil Factory [in south central Guinea], Boffa Sugar and Sugar Cane Factory [in southwestern Guinea], the Kankan Brickyard [in northeastern Guinea], the Bordo (Kankan) Agriculture School, Mamou Agricultural Tool Factory [in southwestern Guinea], the Kaback Water Development Works [in southwestern Nigeria], the Boffa Water Cooperation Project [in southwestern Guinea], the Kindia Agriculture Extension Works [in southwestern Guinea], the People's Palace [in capital], the Sekhoutereya Palace [in capital] and the new RTG House [Guinean Radio-Television], which became today the symbols of Chinese-Guinean friendship.In line with the strengthening of their cooperation, China launched the construction of a 50,000-capacity stadium costing 50m dollars on 18 September 2007. According to the ambassador, the stadium will be the biggest project ever to be built by China in Guinea as a development aid since the beginning of the Chinese-Guinean relations. [Passage omitted].Source: Guineenews website in French 15 May 08a8325366The British Broadcasting CorporationDocument BBCAP00020080516e45g001gt

title: Oil Pipeline and Refinery (Duplicate of 1998)
description: 203 words3 June 200801:10 PMAgence France PresseAFPREnglishCopyright Agence France-Presse, 2008 All reproduction and presentation rights reserved.Niger has granted China's national oil company rights to prospect, explore and produce petroleum in the northern Agadez region, state radio reported Tuesday.The pact, signed Monday between the Niger government and the China National Oil and Gas Development and Exploration Corporation (CNODC), will see the company invest about 300 million dollars (194 million euros) to explore and drill 18 new wells in the coming eight years.Western companies have been prospecting for oil in Niger's Agadem region in the northern area of Agadez since 1985.They have concluded that the estimated 324 million barrels there were not lucrative enough to prospect and drill.The Chinese firm has also pledged to invest 1.2 billion dollars in Niger's petroleum sector to build a pipeline and a refinery near the second city of Zinder with a daily capacity of 20,000 barrels.It will sell a part of its production locally at 'affordable' prices, according to the contract.Since 2006, China has reinforced its economic ties with Niger helping the former French colony to tap its vast uranium wealth, one of the largest in the world.bh/jlh/ach/rtNiger-China-oilDocument AFPR000020080603e46300aj7

title: Chinese-funded hospital in Lugogo, Uganda (Duplicate)
description: China Tightening Grip On Trade With Countryby Charles Mwanguhya1235 words18 October 201105:05 AMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2011 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedOct 18, 2011 (The Monitor/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- At a street corner in the small town of Fort Portal, 300 kilometers west of Kampala, the old illuminated sign has been removed and a new one in English, complete with its Chinese translation, beckons brilliant against sun.Inside the Supermarket, the managers and workers do not understand each-others' language. The local workers as well as most customers neither speak English nor Chinese or Mandarin. Equally the supermarket managers hardly speak any English and know nothing of the local language, yet this store opens every morning and is apparently doing brisk business.The Mukwano Shopping Arcade, a large circular two-storey arcade opposite the main taxi park in downtown Kampala, is a beehive of activity with people of all walks of life squeezing for space. The shops here teem onto the verandas and the vendors, who started on the verandas, are pushing more into the road already crammed by the 14-seater minibus taxis that is the common transport in Kampala.The traders that mix here are a medley of all nationalities from Congolese traders to South Sudanese and Kenyans. But recently traders say they have noticed a new competition, not just increasing volumes of cheap Chinese-made products but of Chinese traders dealing exclusively in 'Made in China' products. At night when the crowds reduce, Chinese families that have set camp on the two top floors are a common site, staring down at the large open yard that turns into bars.This same situation can be said of many towns in Uganda as is the case of Fort Portal - the penetration of China seeking new markets and opportunities for its billion plus population has spread wide and deep across the African continent.At this year's Uganda Manufacturers Association (UMA) Trade Fair at the Lugogo Show Grounds, some 70 odd Chinese companies exhibited. Industrial players said these largely constituted 'new opportunity' seekers and less of already established businesses.'Chinese are investing both downtown and uptown; they are everywhere,' says Mr Awel Uwihanganye, the chief executive officer of the Uganda National Chamber of Commerce and Industry.Mr Uwihanganye says he is amazed that in the few months he has been at the chamber, he has experienced a sheer volume of Chinese delegations, traders, and officials seeking opportunities in the country.'It is true China is engaging with Africa heavily,' he says.Mr Dennis Kawuma, the Business Editor at the Independent newspaper, the Daily Monitor, which is part of the Nation Media Group says; ' if you were to use South Africa-the biggest economy in Africa- as a bellwether, it is obvious that Chinese influence is growing on the continent. Today, China is South Africa's largest trading partner.'In Kampala, Fang Fang Restaurant was the flagship enterprise opened in the upscale Nakasero suburb by an enterprising woman, Fang Min, more than 15 years ago for Kampala's choosy A' Class clientele.Today another branch has opened but more importantly is 'Chinese Restaurants' are becoming a common site with new ones of various grades to cater for various clienteles are opening almost all over town.Just like the open market where China is chasing customers like any other trader to efforts to woe government monies, China's aggressiveness is the same. Large Chinese construction companies are in the countryside opening new highways at multi-billion dollar contracts. The Chinese construction firm, SBI rebuilt a 75-kilometer stretch of tarmac road from Fort Portal to Kasese Town just after they had completed a longer, over 100 kilometer Mbarara--Kasese Road through Bushenyi District.The construction firm is now working bitumen on a $152 million Kabale--Kisoro road project near the Rwandan and Congolese borders.Mr Kevin Chen, the CEO of a $15m digital TV investment project, Star Times, says China's aggressive drive into Africa is driven by largely two factors; the money for capital investment and the technological knowhow.'The driving force now is capital; we have the money, enough capital and because of this we have to look for investment opportunities to make more money,' says Mr Chen, adding rather brusquely; 'China is opening up and expanding. When you open up you have advantages, for a long time we were closed but now we are opening.'Because of the sudden turn-around, Chinese investors are not blind to the challenges of infrastructural inadequacies in Africa, as Mr Chen says the potholes might be a menace but not as bad and, therefore, tolerable. He, however, notes that intermittent power supplies and a high cost of fuel to run diesel engines coupled with erratic mobile telephone networks still present major obstacles.Does China care about political stability? Mr Chen says it does, especially for its investment projects.'(Political) stability is important, now it is difficult for Chinese investors to go into a country such as Libya. Uganda is much more stable.'Investment is not like trading, Chen says, but the Chinese are doing both here and elsewhere. The numbers have grown so big in a very short period of time that recently, a Chinese event was held at the five-star Kampala Serena Hotel.Pioneer Chinese investor Fang Min, who arguably opened the door for Chinese investment and trade in Uganda, is seen here as an iconic figure. Her country even honoured her on its postage stamps.When Chen begins to reel off Chinese businesses in Uganda at the snap off the finger--his countrymen are into steel rolling and are exploring investing in mineral exploration and expanding into the hospitality industry more aggressively than the cautious Fang Min.Mr Uwihanganye says China is pushing in all directions and, in his view, appeasing African governments with not only cheap credit but large construction projects.Evidence abounds to vindicate this view. The Ugandan Ministry of Foreign Affairs is housed in a gleaming six-storey block donated and constructed by China.Two new towers that will house the President's Office are nearing completion on a plot between the Kampala Capital City Authority (KCCA) and Parliament and overlook the ministries of finance and foreign affairs. The two towers dwarf all the other buildings.In nearby Lugogo, a new hospital is nearing completion to ease the pressure on the country's only national referral hospital, Mulago.Mr Uwihanganye says government seems to have been blinded by apparent extreme Chinese generosity to put any checks. There are hardly any local partnerships between the Chinese investors and local people; they are taking all.'They are finding a culture which is too liberal, which does not require them to partner,' he says, noting that Africa has not learnt from the experiences of exploitation first by colonial invaders and later by Indian and Asian business people who invest and repatriate all their profit while keeping closed communities of their kith and kin without integrating into the local communities.But China has been willing to engage, to negotiate without putting conditions like their western rivals who put human rights and governance as key to their aid or pre-conditions they wave at their companies seeking opportunities in Africa. China is also not know for issuing sometimes distabilising advisories to its citizens venturing into Africa, a position many African leaders fancy as they battle to re-assert their authority in the post-independence era.All Africa Global MediaDocument AFNWS00020111018e7ai000g3

title: Investec Group wins Chinese Contract
description: 171 words26 June 2000African Mining MonitorAFMMEnglishCopyright 2000 M2 Communications, Ltd. All Rights Reserved.Investec Group, a South African bank, has won a contract to supply the Peoples Bank of China - China's central bank - with about a ton of gold from the Rand Refinery every three weeks.Under the agreement Investec will airfreight the gold from South Africa to Shenzen, China from where the Peoples Bank, which controls all gold buying and allocation in China, will supply the gold to customers such as jewellery manufacturers. Investec will not be paid until the manufacturer has sold his products.The agreement is for an unlimited period of time. The amount of gold shipped can be negotiated upwards.(Business Day, 16 Jun 2000; Platt`s Commodity News, 15 Jun 2000). African Mining Monitor includes paraphrased and abstracted material with the source, which is deemed to be reliable and duly identified. AMM is unable to provide full-text copies of these original documents.((Comments on this story may be sent to info@m2.com))Document afmm000020010802dw6q0008q
donor_agency_count: People, State-Owned Company; Investec Group

title: Semi-Arid Maize Cultivation Training, Pilot Project
description: In Lanzhou, Xinhua, May 28 (Reporter Zhang Wenjing) an exploration and practice pioneered by Gansu, dry farming techniques can increase grain output is currently Kenya trials, demonstration, and will gradually be extended.    Local reporters learned from Lanzhou University of Arid and Grassland Ecology, Ministry of Education Key Laboratory, the laboratory has repeatedly led his team, Professor Fengmin Bear Youcai to fieldwork in Kenya, and Kenya, University of Nairobi, Kenya National Agricultural Research Institute research institutes, academic exchanges and communication with local agricultural officers and farmers, promotion of the Gansu dry farming techniques to Kenya.    Kenya and other African countries, food production is less able to cope with drought. In 2011, Kenya suffered a severe drought in 60 years, farming and animal husbandry has suffered a huge loss. Gansu for the actual situation of the drought and water shortage in recent years, and vigorously promote corn whole film double furrow sowing dry farming techniques, development of rainfed agriculture, its grain production increased from 161.6 billion kilograms in 2006 to 202 in 2011. 9 billion pounds.    The Bear Youcai, Gansu and Kenya there are some similarities, belonging to the arid climate of the semi-arid climate resource conditions, natural and geographical conditions, but the drought situation is slightly different, with four distinct seasons, Gansu Kenya Four Seasons Fuzzifying the. In addition, the different nature of the two soil Gansu belongs to the alkaline soil, Kenya, compared with acidic soil. 'To this end, we have carried out the localization of improvement and innovation to make it adapt to the natural and geographical conditions of the African native.'    According to reports, Lanzhou University researchers in Kenya to establish a test base of over 4000 square meters, more than 100 ha Experiment Station, the use of the whole film double furrow sowing technology and Straw covering technology dryland corn and wheat, to carry out rainwater harvesting technology development and demonstration, and actively training local agricultural officers and farmers to encourage them to conduct technical trials in their own farmland.    Bear Friends said before, the two sides will also to yield key technology promotion and demonstration, as well as the training of local technicians cooperation in the efficient low dryland agriculture water-saving technology research and development, promotion and demonstration, high yield and drought-resistant corn, wheat. The project after the implementation of the promotion in Kenya, Ethiopia, Zambia and other African countries will also step-by-step promotion.

title: Two Trade and Investment Projects

title: Apple and pear sanitation agreement
description: In 2007, China and South Africa signed an agreement to set sanitation guidelines for the export of apples and pears to China. The agreement was meant to facilitate trade.

title: China, SA to boost economic/trade cooperation
description: 647 words7 February 2007Xinhua News AgencyXNEWSEnglish(c) Copyright 2007 Xinhua News AgencyPRETORIA, Feb. 6 (Xinhua) -- China and South African agreed on Tuesday to view and develop bilateral ties from a strategic perspective and push forward their strategic partnership based on equality, mutual benefit and common development.Visiting Chinese President Hu Jintao and his South African counterpart Thabo Mbeki held talks here on Tuesday afternoon, at which they reached broad consensus on future development of bilateral relations.Hu said China firmly stood alongside the South African people during their struggle against apartheid and that the Chinese-South African ties have enjoyed fast, multi-facet and all-round growth since the two countries established diplomatic ties 10 years ago.The two countries have had fruitful bilateral cooperation in economy and trade, science and technology, education, culture, tourism and justice, he noted.Hu expressed China's appreciation for South Africa's adherence to the one China policy and its support for China's reunification cause.During the talks, Hu put forward a five-point proposal for further promoting China-South Africa ties, including ways of boosting political mutual trust, deepening economic and trade cooperation, expanding the scope of bilateral cooperation, increasing people-to-people contacts and intensifying multilateral cooperation.To build up political mutual trust, Hu suggested that the leaders of the two countries keep frequent contacts and have in-depth exchanges of views on major bilateral and global issues through both bilateral and multilateral channels.On economic and trade cooperation, Hu suggested that both sides optimize trade structures and create an environment conducive to the healthy growth in bilateral trade.He also proposed to explore ways to expand cooperation in vocational training, Chinese language teaching, infrastructure, mining, energy, information technology and crackdown on crimes.To boost people-to-people contacts, Hu announced that the Chinese government will invite 500 young people from South Africa and other African nations to visit China in the next three years.On international issues, Hu proposed that both countries enhance multilateral cooperation and safeguard common interests and said bilateral cooperation should also be enhanced within the framework of the United Nations and other multilateral organizations.Expressing his appreciation for the endeavors made by South Africa to resolve internal conflicts in Africa, Hu said China will continue to support and participate in peacekeeping operations in the region.For his part, Mbeki said South Africa and China have established a solid friendly and cooperative relationship and both countries share the resolve to enhance their bilateral strategic partnership.Through concerted efforts of both sides, the South African-Chinese relationship will be further consolidated and developed, Mbeki noted, adding that he fully agreed with Hu's proposals to advance the strategic partnership between the two countries.Economically, China is one of South Africa's most important partners; politically, the consultation and cooperation with China is an asset to South Africa in meeting various challenges, he stressed.China's attention to and cooperation with Africa is of great significance for the rejuvenation of the African continent, he said.Mbeki hoped that both sides will deepen cooperation in the areas of trade, investment, technology, agriculture and natural resources, and increase people-to-people contacts.He applauded China's determination and actions to implement measures adopted at the Beijing Summit of the Forum of China-Africa Cooperation last November, saying the African people have been encouraged by China's follow-up moves.After the talks, Hu and Mbeki witnessed the signing of five documents on bilateral cooperation in economy and technology, plant quarantine and other fields.Hu arrived in Pretoria earlier Tuesday from the Namibian capital of Windhoek for a three-day state visit to South Africa.South Africa is the sixth leg of Hu's current eight-nation African tour that has already taken him to Cameroon, Liberia, Sudan, Zambia and Namibia. Hu will also travel to Mozambique and Seychelles.

title: Morocco and China Trade
description: 1997 Mount provides some educational equipment, and sent experts to Morocco training fishing vessel salvage and technical personnel; thus more than twenty companies jointly engaged in fishing, they have a more than 80Only fleet of fishing boats, marine products sold in the markets of Europe and Japan;In agriculture, China provides technical assistance projects in silkworm breeding and mulberry; addition, China has also built a multi-purpose sports center in Rabat, including a 8,000-seat stadiumAnd a 60,000-seat stadium; public health aspects of cooperation can be traced back to 20 years ago, the first Chinese medical team arrived in Moldova in 1975, Since then, there have been about 100 Chinese medical team(The experts 120) settled in many cities of Mount.Mount also enjoy some of China's donation, worth a total of several million dirhams, mainly used for the development of the field of agriculture, marine fisheries, energy, equipment, health and sericulture industry items donated to Morocco:- 1995, provides a value of 3 million dirhams of sericulture and water supply center equipment as well as the value of 500 million dirhams pumps; -1996, health equipment worth 300 million dirhams, andWorth 320 million dirhams the fisheries training equipment; - 1997, rural road construction equipment worth 15 million dirhams; - 1998, worth 5 million dirhams potable water for rural waterPumps and medical equipment; - 1999, presented to the Information Center of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation of 10 computers and provide equipment for village access roads open up public works equipment and cooperation; - 2000, funds to VProvide a grant of 60 million dirhams He Saima provide 6.5 million worth of supplies for the construction of the road leading to this remote city construction; - China provided free of charge the necessary construction of two micro-hydropower center -2,000 Million U.S. dollars of preferential loans funded more than 100 manufacturing plan, especially the export of phosphate fertilizer production; -7,050 million U.S. dollars in China's Export-Import Bank and the Moroccan Foreign Trade Bank signed earmarked gifts CMSAAgreement, of which 5,000 million for the opening of credit lines, to provide a margin for the Chinese imported goods; -1,800 ten thousand U.S. dollars earmarked to help the development of small and medium-sized enterprises; - a sea on the use of nuclear energy in the southern provinceWater desalination protocol. This technology can start to produce 8000 cubic meters per day of potable water, approximately for 70,000 residents to drink.In July 1999, signed an agreement on cooperation in the field of maritime transport; October of the same year, signed an agreement on economic and technical cooperation;The three agreements were signed in August 2002. title: Stake in Lender (duplicate of 16439)
description: 329 words7 January 200801:37 PMAssociated Press NewswiresAPRSEnglish(c) 2008. The Associated Press. All Rights Reserved.JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (AP) - Chinese foreign minister Yang Jiechi began a two-day visit to South Africa Monday, marking 10 years of diplomatic relations between the two countries.Yang paid a brief courtesy visit to President Thabo Mbeki before meeting with foreign affairs minister Nkosazana Dlamini Zuma in Pretoria. It was the start of a tour of Africa, where China foreign ministry officials have traditionally started the year in a sign of the importance they place on the resource-rich continent.Yang was also to visit Congo, Burundi and Ethiopia.Yang said the China-South Africa relationship is 'of great importance,' the South African Press Association reported.Since South Africa, the continent's economic powerhouse, dropped Taipei for Beijing 10 years ago, China has become the country's largest trading partner.Trade between South Africa, the continent's economic powerhouse and a major gold-producing country, and China reached US$240 million in the first 11 months of 2006, an increase of 34.5 percent from the previous year.Last year China's biggest bank, the state-owned Industrial   Commercial Bank of China Ltd. bought a 20 percent stake in South Africa's biggest lender, Standard Bank Group Ltd. in one of China's biggest foreign corporate acquisitions to date.Chinese investments into South Africa amount to US$130 million, mostly in a chromium mine while South African investments in China stand at about US$400 million including investments by Anglo American, SAB Miller and a US$120 million investment by a property group.Yang's visit comes a year after Chinese President Hu Jintao visited South Africa in early 2007.South Africa and China on Monday established a diplomatic mechanism to enhance political, economic and trade relations.Yang and Dlamini Zuma were also expected to discuss co-operation between the two countries in international affairs as well as Chinese support for peacekeeping operations in Africa.7Document APRS000020080107e41700378
