title: Pledge to strengthen military ties
description: China, South Africa pledge to strengthen military ties208 words29 August 2006Hindustan TimesHNTMEnglish(c) 2006 The Hindustan Times LtdIndo-Asian News Service Beijing, Aug 29 -- The Chinese armed forces will make joint efforts with the South African military to push forward bilateral friendly cooperation, said a senior Chinese officer Tuesday.Liang Guanglie, chief of the general staff of the Chinese People's Liberation Army, made the remarks after meeting with visiting Chief of the New South African National Defence Force G.N. Ngwenya.Ngwenya is on a six-day official goodwill visit to China from Aug 27.The two armed forces have kept high-level exchanges of visits and friendly cooperation in recent years, he said.Liang said the two countries have shared a deepening political trust since the establishment of diplomatic ties eight years back. The two sides have also made substantial progress in the fields of trade, technology, education and culture.Ngwenya said the South African armed forces are willing to continue to enhance cooperation with the Chinese side in various fields including personnel exchanges.'Strengthening the bilateral friendly and cooperative relations between the two countries and the two armed forces is in the interest of the two countries,' he said.Published by HT Syndication with permission from Indo-Asian News Service.HTS ir 060829-319033Document HNTM000020060829e28t000uo© 2012 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.

The facility was arranged by Standard Bank and coordinated by ICBC through their Macau subsidiary, and was repayable in a bullet capital single tranche at maturity. The deal was signed in Macau. According to Standard Bank, the money would be used for general corporate purposes.

title: (Pre-2000) President Mugabe Inaugurates Sino-Zimbabwe Cement Plant
description: HARARE, October 26 (Xinhua) - Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe on Friday officially inaugurated the Sino-Zimbabwe Cement plant in Gweru, about 300 kilometers south of Harare.Speaking at the opening ceremony, Mugabe disclosed that at present, the plant has a production capacity of 700 tons of cement per day and it is expected to achieve full capacity by January 2002 when it will produce 900 tons per day.He also said that the project has created employment for 215 permanent and 109 contract workers.Under a joint venture agreement between Zimbabwe's Industrial Development Corporation (IDC) and the China Building Material Industrial Corporation for Foreign Economic-Technical Corporation (CBMIC) in June 1994, the cement plant was completed in September 2000 with a total cost of 51 million U.S. dollars.Among those present at the opening ceremony were Zimbabwean Minister of Industry and International Trade Herbert Murerwa, Minister of Finance and Economic Development Simba Makoni and ChineseAmbassador to Zimbabwe Hou Quingru.Document xnews00020011026dxaq004u2---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Construction - Zimbabwean cement industry in crisis533 words16 February 2003Economist Intelligence Unit - Business AfricaEIUBFBusiness AfricaNumber: 304English(C) 2003 The Economist Intelligence Unit Ltd.Zimbabwe's cement industry is on the verge of closure because of inadequate coal supplies. United Portland Cement (Unicem) stopped production at its Colleen Bawn plant in mid-February while Circle Cement, a subsidiary of France's Lafarge group, suspended sales and deliveries early in the month because it had no stocks. The firm comments that rail- delivered coal supplies have been 'erratic and inadequate' since mid-2001. While a number of alternatives have been investigated, including the use of road transport, the cost is 'totally prohibitive,' especially when the government has imposed controls on the sale price of cement.Unicem, a subsidiary of South Africa-based Pretoria Portland Cement, says Wankie Colliery has been unable to supply coal because of production and loading problems at the colliery as well as an inadequate supply of rail wagons. Unicem adds that the supply of fuel from local sources has 'virtually stopped,' forcing the firm to import its own diesel fuel.It adds that since price controls were imposed on cement in August 2001 it has been allowed only one price increase -- of 50% -- while input costs have escalated by 500%. 'At current controlled prices the industry is no longer viable,' it says.Between them Circle and Unicem account for some 90% Zimbabwe's cement production, some of which is exported, mostly to neighbouring Zambia. Such sales have proved controversial, since the state media claims that Circle Cement continues to export to Malawi, and that domestic cement deliveries have been suspended because of price controls rather than the coal shortage. Circle denies this, however, and points out that the country's newest and smallest supplier, Sino-Zimbabwe Cement -- a joint venture between a Chinese group and Zimbabwe's state-owned Industrial Development Corporation -- has also suspended production.No funds for maintenanceLast month the country's sole coal producer, Wankie Colliery, said it was operating at 50% of capacity. It has not been able to source adequate foreign currency to repair and maintain the dragline at its open-cast mine, which produces 85-90% of its coal. 'More than half of major mining equipment is on breakdown' according to Wankie. As a result, the firm's ability to supply coal to the country's Hwange Thermal Power Station has been 'severely compromised'. Coal deliveries are also constrained by the inadequate supply of railway wagons from the state-owned National Railways of Zimbabwe, which is providing only 55% the agreed 150 wagons per day. Wankie is using road transport to send out some 45% of its deliveries, but this is very costly and suitable only for smaller products.The cement shutdown is likely to hit the construction sector, while it is only a matter of time before the coal shortage gives rise to load-shedding by the Zimbabwe Electricity Supply Authority (ZESA); this will have knock- on effects across industry and mining. ZESA has warned industry that power shedding will become necessary from April onwards. Other construction- related businesses are being affected. Turnall Fibre Cement, which makes asbestos sheeting, says it is now sourcing some of its products from South Africa.

Powerstar has sold 1500 units to South African operators. The deal involves China North Vehicle Corporation, known also as Norinco Motors, which has a 78.3% equity in the new company.

title: Duplicate: Energy and Minerals Deal
description: CAPE TOWN, Nov 17 (Reuters) - Chinese Vice President Xi Jinping signed an energy deal with resource-rich South Africa on Wednesday in a visit aimed at obtaining minerals the Asian giant needs to fuel its blistering growth.China is South Africa's biggest bilateral trading partner and the focal point of its plan to divert more trade and investment from traditional markets in Europe and North America to the world's fastest growing economies.Xi, touted as China's next president, on Tuesday began a three-day visit to Africa's largest economy, which is seeking to reduce a deficit in trade with China that hit $2.7 billion last year, skewed in Beijing's favour.South African Deputy President Kgalema Motlanthe and Xi co-chaired the 4th China-South Africa bilateral commission and signed a number of agreements, including an energy deal.No monetary details were released.'The Chinese government undertook to encourage more imports from South Africa, especially value added products and will urge Chinese companies to invest in infrastructure development, automotive manufacturing, energy and information and communication technology,' Motlanthe said in a statement.South Africa has also signed a deal with China's Yingli Solar to build a $435 million manufacturing plant with a local partner, a senior government official said.Yingli will partner with a local company and aimed to start building the plant within 12 months.South African exports about $5.5 billion a year in minerals to the state and has been increasingly a destination of Chinese foreign direct investment.BRICSA?Beijing sees South Africa, a global mining power and regional financial services leader, as a vital source of commodities and a stepping stone to access other African states.Motlanthe said the help of countries including China is vital for South Africa's new economic growth path, which aims to create millions of jobs, mainly in the private sector.For South Africa, China also serves as a model of state action in the economy, with Pretoria hoping to join it in the BRIC -- Brazil, Russia, India and China -- group of fast emerging economies.But a 'BRICSA' grouping seems unlikely for now with South African growth projected at 3 percent this year, hardly the blistering pace of the other members. Its economy is also less than a quarter of the size of the smallest BRIC economy.South Africa's ruling African National Congress has rolled out plans to tackle a massive unemployment problem, with many ANC officials seeing the success of the BRICs as evidence that the state should intervene more.But experts said the ANC, in a governing alliance with organised labour, is loath to loosen a rigid labour market to make it easier for its companies to hire and fire staff with the ease of Chinese firms.'There are things to be learned but that can only come if one is willing to listen. Around labour policy, there is no translatability of a China or U.S. approach to labour and labour flexibility,' said Martyn Davies, CEO of Frontier Advisory and an expert on Africa-China relations. (Additional reporting by Jon Herskovitz; Editing by Mark Heinrich) (For a graphic on South Africa-China trade, see http://r.reuters.com/qew65q [http://r.reuters.com/qew65q])SAFRICA-CHINA/ (UPDATE 2, PIX, TV, GRAPHICS)|LANGEN|AFA|CSA|LBY|RWSA|RWS|REULB|GNS|RNA|ABX|BNX|FUN|SXNADocument LBA0000020101117e6bh000nt

title: Nuclear Cooperation
description: **On April 27, 2012, China Daily ran an article stating that South Africa was inviting tenders to build six nuclear plants for which the total cost would equal roughly $38 billion U.S. dollars. We have not yet found evidence that China's has been awarded a contract or has committed financial resources to this.**On August 24, 2010, Standard Bank Group signed an memorandum of understanding with Industrial   Commercial Bank of China Ltd. to promote nuclear cooperation. The two banks have led engagements by China Guangdong Nuclear Power Co. with the Chinese and South African governments. A R1 trillion contract to build six new nuclear reactors by 2030 is up for bid among five companies, from France, China, South Korea, Russia, and a joint US-Japanese consortium. The French and the Chinese had also considered a joint-bid based on South African encouragement. The contract was finalized in 2011, and bidding for it was planned to begin in 2012. The status of the project is uncertain.

title: Chongqing Chang'an Automobile Co., Ltd. (duplicate of 16820)
description: Automobiles; Automobile DealingChery, JAC, Chang'an Auto Eye on Overseas Marketswww.163.com447 words23 July 2009SinoCast Transportation BeatSTRANB1EnglishCopyright 2009 SinoCast LLC. All Rights Reserved.SHANGHAI, July 23, SinoCast -- Chinese automakers like Chery Automobile Co., Ltd. and Great Wall Motor Co., Ltd. (SEHK: 2333) are strengthening their presence in the global markets.Chery Automobile will put Tiggo into the Brazilian market and the SUV model will start marketing in stores of 27 dealers in 25 Brazilian cities at the end of July 2009, according to its sales subsidiary.Equipped with 2.0-liter engine and priced at about USD 25,000, the model will be the first Chery-branded product that enters Brazil. The Chinese automaker will bring more products to the country in the years ahead.Chery Automobile will drive China-made QQ and A3, and Uruguay-built A1 into the Brazilian market at the end of this year, disclosed one of its deputy general managers. By 2010, the four models will have a total sales volume of 10,000 there.Last week, Great Wall Motor just brought its three products to Australia, and their sales volume is expected to hit 300 a month and top 1,000 at the end of this year.The automaker has just gained an order for 3,300 pickup trucks from Libya. The order is of great importance when China exported only 61,000 vehicles in the first quarter of 2009, slumping 62.06 percent year on year, according to the Chinese Association of Automobile Manufacturers (CAAM).As the biggest pickup truck producer in China, Great Wall Motor has ranked first by sales and export for 11 years. It exported 4,500 pickups to Cuba last year.Now, more than 160,000 pickups of the Chinese automaker have been sold in the global markets. These products have become available in 128 countries and regions.Anhui Jianghuai Automobile Co., Ltd. (JAC, SHSE: 600418) plans to set up a joint venture in Vietnam, an effort to sharpen its competitive edge in the global markets. Moreover, the Chinese automaker will likely build plants in its major overseas markets, Middle East and South Africa.The Vietnam-based venture will be responsible for the manufacturing, marketing, service of JAC's light trucks and some light engineering products and parts. It will possibly expand its business to more JAC products, which depends.Chongqing Chang'an Automobile Co., Ltd. (SZSE: 000625) plans to invest more than USD 80 million in South Africa within the following five years.The Chinese automaker will set up a sales firm in the country, form an auto financing company with its partner, and create an auto subsidiary with a yearly production capacity of over 50,000 vehicles.(USD 1 = CNY 6.83)Document STRANB0020090723e57n00007

title: Zimbabwe granted Approved Tourism Destination status for Chinese
description: In December 2003, the government of China granted the 'Approved Tourism Destination' status onto the country of Zimbabwe. This status indicates that the Chinese government will compel its citizens to visit the country in question while the Zimbabwean government and companies, such as airlines, hotels, tour operators, are permitted to market itself to tourists inside of China. This status is also recognized by the World Tourism Organization and the World Travel and Tourism Council. The Zimbabwean government was represented at the agreement ceremony at the China-Africa Summit in Addis Ababa by President Robert Mugabe while the Chinese government was represented by Premier Wen Jiabao.

title: Nairobi-Thika Road Project - please check Chinese
description: A project to upgrade works of the Nairobi-Thika highway involves expansion of the highway to eight lanes as well as construction of interchanges at six locations to replace roundabouts. The project  also involved improvement of major arteries — Outering, Ngara, Murang’a and Forest roads linking Pangani to Uhuru Highway as well as rehabilitation of drainage and bridge Construction.A blog written about the road's construction reveals that the project's implementation is approaching completion, currently scheduled for July 20, 2012. This road project forms part of a massive infrastructure/road project currently being undertaken in Kenya and financed with Chinese assistance. Connected projects include #1027 and #1112.目前，胜利油田在肯尼亚共有三个项目，分别是内罗毕—西卡道路升级改造项目、援肯尼亚莫伊体育中心维修项目和肯尼亚西部成品油管道扩建工程项目。    内罗毕—西卡道路升级改造项目。该项目位于距肯尼亚首都内罗毕约20公里处，全长23.88公里，是肯尼亚国道主干线A2道路的一部分。该项目业主为肯尼亚政府，中标价约10.7亿元人民币。2008年9月19日，胜利油田胜建集团正式收到肯尼亚道路公共事业部发出的中标通知书，工期30个月，从2009年1月26日到2011年6月25日。目前项目正按计划正常运行，已完成项目部驻地建设、拌合站场地建设。施工内容全合同段路基清表工作，填筑路基土方20万立方米，完成道路设计15公里。    肯尼亚莫伊体育中心维修项目。该工程主要包括体育场、体育馆、游泳馆和运动员宿舍四部分的维修、加固、破损更换及重新装修。该项目中标价约1220万美元，由我国商务部无偿援助。2009年11月14日，胜利油田胜建集团正式收到商务部发出的中标通知书，约定工期12个月，从2009年12月24日至2010年12月23日。目前办公设施及施工用水、用电已经完成，正在做材料和设备物资的准备工作。    肯尼亚西部成品油管道扩建工程项目。2007年7月11日，胜利油田勘察设计院与肯尼亚管道公司签订401万美元的管道扩建工程。根据合同，胜利勘察设计院将承担管道增容的设计咨询、施工招标和施工监理工作，合同工期18个月。监理工作已于2009年11月16日开始，目前正处于监理准备阶段。

title: Zimbabwe Army receives vehicles from China (Duplicate of 17628)
description: ZNA Receives 22 Vehicles From China365 words13 January 200503:05 PMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2005 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedHarare, Jan 13, 2005 (The Herald/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) --THE Zimbabwe National Army (ZNA) yesterday received a total of 22 Troop Carrying Vehicles (TCV) from the Chinese government as a gesture of fostering the cordial relations between China and Zimbabwe.The vehicles are set to transform the ZNA into a well-equipped, highly-mobile and hard-hitting force.Speaking at a ceremony to handover the vehicles at KGV1 Barracks in Harare, the Chinese Embassys charge daffaires Mrs Ma Deyun said the vehicles were procured after the two countries signed an agreement for co-operation in different areas of interest.She said China and Zimbabwe have enjoyed good relations since the days of the liberation struggle and they have always supported each other in times of need.'We are proud of the achievements we have made in various areas of co-operation,' said Mrs Deyun.ZNA Commander Lieutenant General Philip Valerio Sibanda, who received the vehicles on behalf of the army, thanked the Chinese for the donation.He said the vehicles would go a long way in alleviating transport problems that the army has experienced of late.Lt General Sibanda said most vehicles the ZNA had been using were obtained from Western countries but they were now grounded because spare parts could not be acquired owing to sanctions imposed against the country.Sanctions have been imposed on Zimbabwe by Western powers, particularly Britain and the United States after Zimbabwe embarked on the Land Reform Programme which saw thousands of blacks being allocated land acquired from white former commercial farmers.'We will be holding elections in March so the army vehicles are coming at an appropriate time. This is testimony to our increasing co-operation with China,' said Lt. Gen. Sibanda.He urged the ZNA personnel to look after the vehicles properly.Trade and economic co-operation between Zimbabwe and China has grown tremendously.Under the partnership with China, several joint venture companies have been established in the country.China also remains the biggest buyer of Zimbabwes tobacco.Under the Zimbabwe-China Joint Commission, Zimbabwe has benefited through the Chinese Governments concessionary and interest free loans and grants.Document AFNWS00020050113e11d0018m

title: Zimbabwe Purchases Chinese Fighters and Missiles
Zimbabwean entrepreneurs fact-finding trip to China
description: Marketing Agency Organises Business Trip to China369 words27 June 200504:05 PMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2005 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedHarare, Jun 27, 2005 (The Herald/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) --A LEADING local marketing agency, African Business Communications (ABC), is organising a seven-day business trip to China that is set to benefit young Zimbabweans seeking to start their own businesses.The business trip, scheduled for the last week of July, would be open to about 100 young entrepreneurs drawn from various sectors of the Zimbabwean economy.China has traditionally offered immense opportunities to Zimbabweans from all walks of life to learn from its political, military, cultural and economic experiences. According to ABC the visit by the delegation would act as a catalyst in facilitating trade links between local businesses headed by young entrepreneurs and the Chinese business community.'The delegation will tour major industrial centres of China where they will visit companies with potential for trade. A number of events outside of the company tours will be organised to allow the local business people to network and interface with their Chinese counterparts,' said an ABC spokesman at the weekend.'Participants will have an opportunity to establish partnerships and linkages with Chinese business, access new markets and expand client base for export-oriented business and networking with Chinese companies wishing to invest in Zimbabwe.'At national level, the visit will cement the relations between Zimbabwe and China, and consolidate the 'Look East' policy that has been articulated by the Government in the face of Western-inspired economic sanctions.Since independence in 1980, Zimbabwe has signed numerous agreements covering economic and technical co-operation, trade, investment protection with China, currently the world's fastest growing economy.A joint economic and trade commission between the two nations has since been set up.'In preparation for the tour, an interactive breakfast meeting has been organised on June 27 (today) at a local hotel where all interested young business people will have a chance to get more information and apply to participate in the tour.'Present at the meeting will be the Deputy Minister of Youth Development, Gender and Employment Creation, Mr Saviour Kasukuwere, and executives from various banks who have committed to financeany business deals that result from the tour,' ABC said.Document AFNWS00020050627e16r002px
sector: Trade, Tourism, Banking and Financial Services
donor_agency_count: Africa Business Communications Inc., Private Sector
verified: Africa Business Communications Inc., Private Sector

title: Telkom Kenya Facilities and Equipment Installation, ZTE (Commitment too early)
description: In 2002, ZTE was awarded a contract to install some telecommunications equipment in Thika, Gatundu and Ruiru. In February 2004, it donated transmission equipment to Telkom Kenya which was installed and commissioned at GPO, Embakasi, Kabete, Uthiru and Jamhuri in Nairobi. It has also donated some equipment, to be installed at Ngong, Karen and Langata.''Now that we have been listed in two stock markets, we have more capital for investment,' ZTE general manager for East Africa, Mr Hesse Dong, told BusinessWeek. The expansion plans have also come after an eight-year engagement with Telkom Kenya. where ZTE has installed facilities and equipment worth Sh400 million.

title: CICO wins bid for road project in Liberia
description: Chongqing Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation Group Co., Ltd. announced on February 5, 2012 that its subsidiary, China Chongqing International Construction Corporation (CICO) won the bid for the No. 15 Gate of Public Engineering Department-Pa'anga Road Rehabilitation Project in Liberia. The project is for a 180.36 kilometer road. The cost of the project is US$166 million. This does not appear to be an 'aid' project, but a Chinese state-owned enterprise is implementing the project。

title: Chinese delegation in Zimbabwe to offer health and medicine assistance
description: China, Zimbabwe to boost cooperation on traditional medicine248 words5 April 2007Industry UpdatesBDUEnglishCopyright 2007 China Daily Information Company. All Rights Reserved.China and Zimbabwe should redouble the efforts to boost cooperation on projects of the two countries' traditional medicine, a visiting Chinese traditional medicine scholar said on Wednesday.Xiao Caisong, head of a Chinese delegation and executive officer of Changsha Taibao Pharmaceutical Group, said they were in Zimbabwe to inspect the industry and seek out investment opportunities.'We are happy to know some Chinese doctors specializing in acupuncture in the Chgituingwiza hospital when we toured the hospital,' he said.Xiao told Xinhua that they planned to introduce 25 Chinese medicines on the market, seven of them traditional.'We are engaged in talks with the Ministry of Health and Child Welfare that we hope will give us a better insight into Zimbabwe's common problem diseases. From our initial research we understand some of them are HIV/AIDS, malaria, tuberculosis and skin diseases,' Xiao said.The delegation is on a two-week tour of Zimbabwe's pharmaceutical industry to scout for investmentopportunities.On Wednesday, they met Zimbabwe's Health and Child Welfare Minister David Parirenyatwa and they will visit some Zimbabwean pharmaceutical companies, including CAPS and Varichem medicine processing plants.The visiting delegation is also expected to tour the National Pharmaceutical Company (NATPHARM) and several pharmacies in Harare.The Zimbabwean government has also urged the local health sector to make joint efforts with their Chinese counterparts to develop traditional Chinese medicine and local traditional medicine to meet the country's demands.Document BDU0000020070405e34500015
donor_agency_count: Changsha Taibao Pharmaceutical Group Co., Ltd., Private Sector
recipient_agencies: Changsha Taibao Pharmaceutical Group Co., Ltd., Private Sector
verified: Ministry of Health and Child Welfare, Government Agency

title: Kavumu Airport Road
description: The commitment for this project was made as a part of FOCAC 2006. The China Communications Construction Company (CCCC) is the contractor on the Kavumu Airport Road, which is financed by a donation from the Chinese government. The project, when finished, will connect Bukavu to the Kavumu airport, and will stretch 35 km long. The work was launched in Bukavu on May 26, 2008, and the most recently found status is implementation as of January 2010. The financial amount and current status are yet unknown.

title: Zimbabwe gets Chinese farm machinery
description: In 2007, China donated farm machinery worth $25 million USD to replace equipment damaged when President Robert Mugabe's government seized white-owned farms to resettle landless blacks. The total loan facility granted by China was $58 million USD (Project ID#19193), and these items comprise the first phase of this total loan. For the first phase of the project, comprising US$25 million of the grand total, the Chinese company CAMC Engineering will supply the agricultural equipment to Zimbabwe including 424 tractors, 65 dump trucks, 40 heavy duty harrows, and 8 bulldozers. Farmers' World, a Zimbabwean agricultural equipment dealer, was responsible for importing the equipment and was also responsible for loaning out the equipment to needy farmers on a five-year basis would service their loaned equipment with payments of harvested tobacco. Farmers' World operates this program in conjunction with the State Department of Agricultural Research and Extension Services, the Zimbabwe Farmers' Development Trust, and the Agricultural Development Bank of Zimbabwe. On April 12, 2007, a Chinese media report indicated that President Robert Mugabe oversaw a ceremony commissioning the 424 tractors, disc harrows, and planters imported from China from the first phase of the project. A Zimbabwe Reserve Bank report from January 2007 indicated that an additional 357 tractors, 65 dumper trucks, 50 thirty-tonne truck horses, 50 twenty tonne trailers, 8 bulldozers, and 86 water pumps were also purchased and imported under this loan facility. The Zimbabwean government, through the Zimbabwe Farmers' Development Trust, intends to repay the loan from the Chinese company through the delivery of 30,000,000 kilograms of tobacco for four straight years to China followed by an increase to 80,000,000 kilograms in the fifth year. The government of Zimbabwe was represented by Minister for Agricultural Engineering Joseph Made and the Vice President Joice Mujuru, CAMC Engineering was represented by Jia Qinglin, the chairman of the National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, and Luo Yan, the company president, and Farmers' World was represented by company managing director Edward Raradza and company vice president Joseph Msika.The second phase of this project is outlined in ID#27714.

title: China provides loan for offices, research center
description: In 2008, the Chinese Vice-Minister of Commerce and the Ivorian Minister of Foreign Affairs signed an agreement worth 26 billion CFA provided by China to help rehabilitate ministerial offices and to build a Research Center to fight against malaria. Anti-malaria medicines were also provided by the Chinese government. Reporting on the same subject, Le Jour Plus (a daily close to the opposition) said that China donated 27.3 billion CFA to help with post-crisis reconstruction.

title: Zimbabwe signs US$5 billion platinum deal with China
description: On July 6, 2009, the Export-Import bank of China and the Reserve Bank of Zimbabwe signed a memorandum of understanding for a US$5 billion loan to Zimbabwe that would be used to improve infrastructure and restore economic well-being in the country while China, on the other end, will receive 50 percent equity in the mining of platinum in Zimbabwe. Estimates suggest that China will collect up to US$20 billion, or 50%, of the estimated US$40 billion-worth platinum supplies in Zimbabwe. The government of Zimbabwe was represented by the Minister of Finance, Tendai Biti; the governor of the Reserve Bank of Zimbabwe, Gideon Gono; Minister Tendai's chief adviser, Conrad Nyamoruva; Ministry of Finance official Mary Takavarasha; the deputy governor of the Reserve Bank of Zimbabwe, Edward Mashiringwani, and Governor Gono's chief adviser Munyaradzi Kereke. A singular July 4, 2009 report from Zimbabwean media outlet ZimEye suggests, contrarily, that no such agreement occurred in the first place. A 2011 report stated that Eximbank's offer was for $3 billion rather than $5 billion. It also suggested that the deal was still being discussed, and no formal agreements had been made.

title: China offers loan to Zimbabwe mobile phone service provider (duplicate #976)
description: On January 21, 2010, the government of China signed an agreement with the government of Zimbabwe for the provision of a US$46 million concessional loan towards the Zimbabwean mobile phone service provider, NetOne. The loan money is to be used towards expanding network coverage and a series of implementation projects that are to be decided upon in the future. The government of China was represented by its Ambassador to Zimbabwe, Xin Shunkang. Additional research into updates on the implementation of the loan was unsuccessful. The terms of the loan are unclear and thus it cannot appropriately be designated either ODA or OOF-like.

Niger's Minister expressed gratitude for the two-year long work of the 8th team of experts and enthusiastically awaits for the arrival of the 9th team.

title: Sinopec Acquisition of Offshore Oil Block 18
description: In March 2010, Chinese company Sinopec signed a deal to acquire a stake in Oil Block 18 in Angola, from its parachute company, China Petrochemical Corporation. Under the terms of the agreement, Sinopec is to take a 55% controlling stake in Sonangol Sinopec International (SSI) from Sinopec Group subsidiary Sinopec Overseas Oil   Gas (SOOG). The firm is set to pay $1.68 billion USD and take on $0.78 billion of debt and interest payments owed by SSI to SOOG. This brings the sum total paid for SSI to $2.46 billion. As a result, Sinopec's oil reserves will have grown by 102 million barrels. Furthermore its production levels will increase by 72,520 barrels per day.

title: Duplicate: Chinese charity donates sweaters to African countries
description: Chinese charity to donate sweaters to abandoned, disabled African childrenrongyan241 words22 November 201006:45 AMXinhua News AgencyXNEWSEnglish(c) 2010 Xinhua News AgencyBEIJING, Nov. 22 (Xinhua) -- A Chinese charity will this year give sweaters to abandoned and disabled children in six African nations - South Africa, Kenya, Nigeria, Sudan, Zambia and Zimbabwe.A spokesperson for the China Children and Teenagers' Fund (CCTF) said Monday 2,010 sweaters weaved by Chinese moms will be donated.'For the different climates on the African continent, sweaters are necessary to keep out the cold,' CCTF spokesperson Hu Wenxin said.The sweaters will be specially weaved by the volunteers with thin wool, since most of the children do not need thick sweaters.Over the past five years, more than 550,000 sweaters have been given to abandoned and disabled Chinese children under the charity program.'Everybody that can weave and that has spare time can show their love by knitting the sweaters,' said He Junyi, an official in charge of the charity program.He said he hopes the orphans and disabled children in Africa will feel the love of Chinese moms.Peter Oloishura Nkuraiyia, executive director of the NGO Coordination Board of Kenya, told He during a visit to Shanghai in July the generosity of the Chinese mom volunteers shows the love that exists between the Chinese and African peoples.Nkuraiyia's Shanghai trip unveiled the charity program's first donation to the six African nation's children - 2,010 Shanghai World Expo commemorative T-shirts.Enditem01Xinhua News AgencyDocument XNEWS00020101122e6bm0066j

title: Airport improvements
description: In November 2003, the government announced an ambitious ten-project program to upgrade the country's road network and improve the airport facilities at Bata, the country's second city (on the mainland). A new road links Malabo with the airport and there have been improvements in the city.

title: Construction of KRC Friendship School (Duplicate)
description: In 2000, the newly-built Khartoum Refinery donated USD 700,000 to establish the KRC Friendship School. Located in the residential area for Sudanese employees around the refinery, the school occupies an area of 1,824 square meters, and consists of Pre-School, Primary and Secondary education divisions. At present, the school has 31 staff and faculty members and 687 students. Since the school began operating, the refinery donates about USD 10,000 in stationary supplies to the school each year. Over the ten years of the school’s operation, over 3,000 students have graduated, with a 100% graduation rate, and 104 graduates have been recruited into universities and colleges in Sudan. With such excellent results, the school is now well known far and widePossibly a duplicate of Project ID#20758

description: >'A total of 18 trainees from 10 countries, including Angola, Ghana and Mongolia, received diplomas from Chinese experts on Tuesday, ending their two-month training session on solar energy technologies in Gansu Province, northwest China.>> >>'Although two months is not a long period of time, we learned a lot of practical information about solar energy,' said Ali Abdelrahman from Sudan.>> >>Gansu is China's cradle of solar energy development where the country's first solar energy research institute and first international solar energy training center are located.>> >>The 2004 International Solar Energy Training Workshop was co- sponsored by the Gansu Natural Energy Research Institute and the Asia-Pacific Research and Training Center for Solar Energy.>> >>The 18 trainees were from Angola, Ghana, Kenya, Lesotho, Mongolia, Nigeria, Romania, Rwanda, Sudan and Thailand. They systematically studied solar energy technology through class teaching, field visits and hands-on operations, said Xi Wenhua, director of the institute and the center. '>

title: Highway Project (Inactive See Project 54)
description: >'Copyright 2005, Global Insight Limited. All Rights Reserved.>> >>A Chinese company, the China Roads and Bridge Corporation, has been awarded the contract to build or rehabilitate the 371 km highway between Kifangondo in the metropolitan region of Luanda and the town of Negage in the northern province of Uíge, via the the city of Caxito (Bengo Province). The announcement of the award was made by the Angolan National Roads Institute (INEA), which is overseeing the US$211 million project. According to O Apostolado, the first phase is focusing on the 58 km stretch between Kifangondo and Catete. Work on this stretch is reported to have begun last week. The entire project should be concluded within 27 months.>> >>Significance: The Luanda-Uíge road rehabilitation will be crucial to the revial of coffee production and copper mining in the northern provinces, which has been largely moribund since the outbreak of the civil war in 1975 and has shown few signs of recovery since the end of the conflict in 2002. The project also highlights the growing role of Chinese investment in Angola. The road rehabilitation programme is financed by the US$2 billion credit line provided by the Chinese Eximbank on extremely cheap terms. Under the agreement, Chinese companies must be awarded 70% of the resultant construction work, a small price for the Angolan authorities to pay for a loan so unburdened by conditions. The Chinese loan facility will be the main source of income for the Angolan government's public investment programme in coming years. Although the facility will hopefully improve the overall infrastructure and growth performance in the economy, it also has been the catalyst in the Angolan government's recent spat with the International Monetary Fund (IMF; see Angola: 16 February 2005: Angolan Government Unable to Comply with IMF Criteria). The substantial loan facility from China has opened up the opportunity for the Angolan government to ignore the IMF's loan conditions, so it remains to be seen if issues between the two parties can be resolved in the coming months (see Angola: 20 April 2005: Angolan Finance Minister Downplays IMF Disagreement). '>> >>'Luanda, Angola, 27 June – Chinese state company China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC), which is rebuilding 371 kilometers of the national road linking Kifangondo (Luanda), Caxito (Bengo), Uíge and Negage (Uíge) in Angola, is due to finish work in June 2008, officials told Angolan news agency Angpop.>> >>The project, work on which began in December 2005, is estimated to cost US$211 million.>> >>So far 140 kilometers of the road have been de-mined, which is the first stage of work required for rebuilding to go ahead.>> >>The rebuilding project, which involves over 3,000 Angolan and Chinese workers, includes 12 bridges, 10 of which will be new, and also requires over 200 aqueducts to be built.>> >>One of the main aims of the reconstruction of this road is to re-launch agricultural activities in the region. (macauhub)'>

title: Duplicate: Malarial Research centre in Abidjan
description: See ID# 716Text of report in English by official Chinese news agency Xinhua (New China News Agency)Abidjan, 16 August: The problem of poverty is a big challenge for Africa and the fight against this scourge has been the main preoccupation of most governments on the continent.Most analysts have observed that China has been deeply involved in the fight against poverty on the continent besides African governments. China has also remained faithful on the side of the continent as witnessed in a number of initiatives that have been launched in various sectors.Among African countries, Cote d'Ioire is one of those which have benefited a lot from China's support and help.In the health sector, taking the case of malaria as an example, the means to fight against the disease have been reinforced in Cote d'Ioire thanks to Sino-Cote d'Ioire cooperation.Through collaboration with Cote d'Ioire's health ministry, the Chinese government has put up a research centre in Abidjan which will help in the fight against malaria. The Cote d'Ioire authorities have said that this malaria research centre came at the right time and it will help to improve the health status of the population.'Malaria is a real health problem in the country and it represents the first reason for medical consultations in our hospitals. A centre offered by a friendly nation (China) will help to relieve the pain of most of our people,' Patrice Konan, a doctor at a hospital in Abidjan, said in a recent interview with Xinhua.The impoverization of the people comes not only through the deterioration of health conditions, but also through food deficiency.Cote d'Ioire has also received support from China in her efforts to achieve food sufficiency through production of foodstuffs like rice.In March this year, China which is the biggest rice producer in the world gave Cote d'Ioire authorities over 200 tons of fertilizers and hundreds of agricultural machines whose cost was evaluated at 2 million euros.Still, following the appeal from Cote d'Ioire for the Chinese support on the strategies for reviing rice farming, a Chinese delegation of experts visited several Cote d'Ioire localities in 2010 to train rice farmers.The Chinese delegation in Cote d'Ioire was led by Director of the International Center for the Fight Against Poverty (LPRCC) Wu Zhing.'There's need to take advantage of the Chinese experience in order to increase food production,' a Cote d'Ioire investment expert Raymond Sibailly said recently.'The IPRCC is one of the biggest global institutions involved in the fight against poverty. This center also works with the universities of China and through its actions, this country has achieved miracles in the fight against poverty,' Sibailly said.The problem of housing is another big challenge for Cote d'Ioire. In the country, most of the people do not have decent houses to live. In most towns, there's a problem of slums which house the jobless people or those who earn little wages. Most families live in makeshift houses because of poverty.In order to help resolve the housing problem, China has partnered with the Cote d'Ioire government in the construction sector to try and reduce the housing shortage.During a recent meeting with a Chinese construction company, Cote d'Ioire Prime Minister Guillume Soro called for concerted efforts with Cote d'Ioire's Construction and Housing Company (SICOGI) to ensure that majority of the people live in decent houses.Recently Cote d'Ioire experienced a post-election crisis which resulted in the loss of lives and destruction of property. Soon after the crisis was over, the country's President Alassane Ouattara announced that reconstruction of the country would be one of his main priorities.China has expressed its willingness to help Cote d'Ioire in the reconstruction process.After several preliminary meetings with Cote d'Ioire's authorities during which the Chinese emissaries promised support from their country, Sino-Cote d'Ioire agreements regarding Chinese aid for Cote d'Ioire's post-crisis reconstruction were signed in June this year.Chinese Vice Foreign Minister Zhai Jun and Cote d'Ioire's Foreign Minister Daniel Kablan Duncan signed the documents which granted Cote d'Ioire loans and cancellation of Cote d'Ioire's debt.In addition, China has also given Cote d'Ioire 'urgent materials' worth 1.09 billion Fcfa.China has honoured the commitments she made to Cote d'Ioire.'The crisis increased poverty in Cote d'Ioire. The Chinese contribution is expected to help in the revial of activities in some of the country's sectors,' said Emmanuel Lohoues, an official at Cote d'Ioire's finance ministry.'On the path of development, Cote d'Ioire will always have China on her side,' Zhai promised.Chinese Ambassador to Cote d'Ioire Wei Wenhua has on several occasions reiterated his country's willingness to help Cote d'Ioire on her development path.Source: Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in English 0644gmt 16 Aug 11

title: PPIAF - Wind Power projects in Adama and Mesobo Harena- duplicate with 1380
description: (PPIAF) The Adama and Messobo Harrena projects will cost about 123 million and 127 million dollars, respectively. They will be financed by the Chinese Government through the Export-Import Bank of China. The contracts were signed between EEPCo and HydroChina. The signing oft he contracts was attended by Girma Biru, minister of Trade and Industry, Alemayehu Tegenu, minister of Mines and Energy, and Sinkinesh Ejigu, state minister of Mines and Energy. The two projects will generate 51 MW wind power each. The Adama wind farm is located 95 km east of Addis Ababa, near Adama in Oromia, while the Messabo Harrena project lies 763 km o the north near Mekelle. EEPCo plans to get 30 MW wind power within six months from the date of the contract.

title: Zhu signs five documents on cooperation
China seeks timber from Gabon (needs confirmation)
description: The new entrant to the scramble is China. Despite its large land area, it is a resource-poor country and Africa offers the natural resources vital to fuel its rapidly growing economy. China looks to the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) and Zambia for copper and cobalt, to South Africa for iron ore and platinum, and to Gabon, Cameroon and the Republic of the Congo (Congo-Brazzaville) for timber.//加蓬和中国林业国际合作公司建立了加蓬华嘉木业股份公司，这是一个合资的木材加工企，项目总投资为2 673.9万美元，建设规模为年产12万m3旋切单板和5万m3的制材厂。//自2004年以来，在两国元首互访的带动下，中加两国经贸合作的步伐越走越快，合作领域越扩越宽，特别是2006年中非合作论坛北京峰会之后，我与加在木材开发领域的互利合作更是跃上了一个新台阶。 　　中方投资企业由过去的两三家发展到现在的十来家，尤其是最近两年，中国木材加工出口企业响应加蓬政府关于林地整治规划、保证可持续开采、减少原木出口、增加就地加工、提高出口木材附加值、解决当地就业的号召，正在进入到大规模投资创业阶段。 　　据初步统计，中国企业在加蓬森林行业的投资额已超过1亿美元，拥有林地200多万公顷，已建成和在建木材加工厂10家，雇佣加蓬员工1500多人。　 　　大部分中国企业都与水森部签署了林地规划临时协议，开始进行林地规划和工厂建设。　 　　当前，中国木材企业遇到的最大问题是原木出口配额问题的困扰，去年开始，中国企业所得配额大量减少，主要是按加蓬新政策，出口配额和规划进展程度挂钩，而中国企业来加蓬落户较晚，大部分处在投资创业阶段，还没有来得及做规划，而做规划的投资相当昂贵

title: New Mosaics Unit in Guelma (duplicate of #22429)
description: On August 17, 2002 a Chinese delegation led by Prime Minister Zhu Rongjil, Algeria and China signed several agreements. One agreement provide for the construction of a new mosaics unit in Guelma and for the dispatch of a Chinese medical team to Algeria. Searching for this project did not reveal any new information.Other agreements signed at the same time include an economic and technical agreement with Algeria that regulates a USD 6mn (although some sources say 7mn) loan with 25 years maturity from China #272, an agreement for a medical dispatch team # 21879, an agreement to rehabilitate and modernize a Chinese-built factory started over in 1999 #22429, and an agreement to enhance the existing cultural cooperation, which covers the 2002-2004 period #22436.

title: Dam construction Burundi (Duplicate)
description: 'Text of report by Burundi news agency ABPBujumbura, 9 October: The economic context of Sino-Burundian cooperation is marked by six priority projects in various sectors, ABP has learnt from the department in charge of Asia at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.These projects include the construction of the presidential palace, the rehabilitation of the Mugere Hydroelectric Station, the construction of three rural elementary schools, including two in Karusi Province (eastern central Burundi) and another at the Bujumbura Town Hall, the construction of a general hospital, the installation of a malaria prevention and treatment centre and the supply of anti-malarial drugs.At the conclusion of the 10th session of the Joint Sino-Burundian Commission held from 11 to 13 September 2007, when both parties went through cooperation in the financial, technical and commercial plans with a fine tooth comb, it emerged that an agreement for a donation of 30m yuan, or 4,414,050 US dollars, was signed for the rehabilitation of Mugere Hydroelectric Station.In addition, the session ended with a draft agreement relating to the cancellation of Burundi's debts to China of 137,470,000 yuan, equivalent to [approximately] 15,210,455 US dollars.The two governments are currently in negotiation over the Mpanda power generation hydroelectric and irrigation project which is being built by the Chinese company Gezhouba Water and Power (Group) Company Limited (CGGC). This project was to be financed through a preferential loan, will be carried out at a cost of 40,920,157 US dollars. The Burundian Foreign Ministry department in charge of Asia stresses that Sino-Burundian cooperation is very diversified and also touches the education and health sectorsIn 2008 China offered to 10 scholarships to Burundi for post-graduate studies.In the medical field, China sends medical teams every two years to assist the Burundian people.Source: ABP news agency, Bujumbura, in French 1027 gmt 9 Oct 08a8f2d59fDocument BBCAP00020081009e4a9001xj'

title: Bus factory and bus provision (duplicate #328)
description: In March 2010 chairman of China's National Committee of the People's Political Consultative Conference Jia Qinglin and Cameroonian President Paul Biya signed a deal to provide for the construction of a car factory that produces buses in Cameroon. The operation will join private investors from China and Cameroon, and was expected to start producing buses by the end of 2010. The same agreement also calls for the delivery of 500 Chinese buses in July for use between and within Cameroonian cities. Wu Yue, vice president of China's National Machinery Import and Export Corporation and Zacharia Awanga, the deputy chief of International Development in Cameroon's Ministry of Economy and Planning both publicly commented on the deal.
donor_agency_count: National Machinery Import and Export Corporation, State-Owned Company
recipient_agencies: National Machinery Import and Export Corporation, State-Owned Company

title: Souapiti hydroelectric dam- duplicate with 187
description: Energy   electricity: Guinea246 words16 January 2007Economist Intelligence Unit - Business AfricaEIUBFBusiness Africa15Number xxxEnglish(C) 2007 The Economist Intelligence Unit Ltd.The Chinese government is reported to have pledged funding of US$850m towards the building of the Souapiti hydroelectric dam on the Konkouré River in the north of the country. Lack of funding has stalled the project—whose total cost is put at US$1bn—for many years. Attempts were initially made to link the project to various proposals for building alumina refineries, but the relevant investors could not be persuaded to help finance the construction of the dam. There are chronic electricity shortages in Guinea—the capital experiences frequent power cuts and most businesses that can afford it rely on a diesel generator to supplement their power supply. Outside Conakry electricity supply is minimal and mainly restricted to large towns. style='BACKGROUND-COLOR:#FFFF00'>The proposed Souapiti station would generate 750 mw of electricity and would have the potential to supply not only the capital but also many industrial projects, such as the alumina refineries, as well as areas outside Conakry.However, the distribution of electricity will also require significant investment, especially if the area of distribution is expanded to include some rural areas. The Chinese interest in the project comes at a time when many bauxite-prospecting licences have been awarded to Chinese companies. style='BACKGROUND-COLOR:#FFFF00'>The US$850m financing is being organised through a Chinese commercial bank, Exim Bank of China, and a Chinese construction company, Sinohydro, is to build the dam.SOURCE: Business Africabfbfmain20070116t0000000015; Business Africa 16 Jan 2007, Part 15 of 36Document EIUBF00020070127e31g0000f--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------China to fund $1 bln hydro dam in Guinea -sourceBy Saliou Samb348 words7 July 200702:02 PMReuters NewsLBAEnglish(c) 2007 Reuters LimitedCONAKRY, July 7 (Reuters) - China has agreed to fund the construction of a $1 billion hydroelectric dam in mineral-rich Guinea and renovate a series of state buildings, government officials in the West African country said on Saturday. The Souapiti dam should allow the former French colony to generate some 750 MW of electricity, officials said. Guinea is one of the world's least developed countries and even parts of the capital city have only sporadic mains power.A senior Chinese government delegation visiting Guinea had confirmed that China's government-owned Export-Import Bank (Eximbank), which has invested in projects across the world's poorest continent, would fund the dam.Local media reported that in return, Guinean authorities would guarantee China access to mineral reserves equivalent to some 2 billion tonnes of bauxite, the raw material used in the production of aluminium.'To guarantee Chinese investment, you have to give them guarantees but nothing has yet been formally decided,' said Cece Noramou, a senior official in Guinea's mines ministry.'They are interested in bauxite but we haven't finished determining the tonnage and so on,' he added.China has been offering low interest loans, debt relief and other incentives to countries around Africa as it seeks to increase its influence on the continent and gain access to natural resources to feed its fast developing economy.Guinea is the world's top bauxite exporter but most of the population survie on less than $1 a day.The Chinese delegation also promised debt relief worth around $4 million and an aid package of $5.2 million, according to Aboubacar Cisse, a spokesman for Guinea's foreign ministry.He said China had pledged to renovate the People's Palace cultural centre in Conakry and the state radio and television centre, partially destroyed when a Guinean air force jet crash-landed on it in April.GUINEA-HYDROPOWER/CHINA|LANGEN|G|RBN|Z|AFN|AFA|CSA|LBY|RWSA|RWS|REULB|GNS|RNP|DNP|PGE|SXNADocument LBA0000020070707e377000dj----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Souapiti Dam: Beijing Gets Way With Package273 words18 July 2007Africa Mining IntelligenceAMIN160EnglishCopyright 2007 Indigo Publications All Rights ReservedAs they did with the Belinga iron mine in Gabon the Chinese got their way in Guinea’s bauxite sector after several years of lobbying: tstyle='BACKGROUND-COLOR:#FFFF00'>hey are to undertake an integrated program worth over USD 1 billion that includes construction of a dam, bauxite mine and an aluminium smelter. On July 2, a delegation from China’s Export Import Bank turned up to present the package to the minister for economic and financial controls, Saidou Diallo. The Chinese are to be awarded deposits containing over two billion tons of bauxite ore in return for financing construction of the Souapiti hydro power dam and building an aluminium facility. style='BACKGROUND-COLOR:#FFFF00'>The Souapiti dam is to generate 94 MW and be linked to the Kaleta and Amaria mines (an application for the hook-up is being examined by Conakry). Some of the 2 billion tons of ore covered by the agreement will come from concessions already awarded to the Chinese in the Fria and Telemele regions.But other licenses of better quality, located at Boke, will also be turned over to the Chinese next year after properties are relinquished in the region by BHP Billiton, RusAl, CGB and IMIDRO. Management of the bauxite resources will be seen to by Chalco while Sino Hydro is to build the hydro dam by 2012. China’s deputy foreign minister, Zhai Jin, was still in Conakry on July 7 to negotiate the bonus for the package: the write-off of USD 45 million in debt, renovation of the Palais du People and the Radio Television Guineenne between now and October.31129145Document AMIN000020070824e37i00002----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Eximbank Floored by Competition ! Bauxite274 words14 November 2007Africa Mining IntelligenceAMIN167EnglishCopyright 2007 Indigo Publications All Rights ReservedThe vast Cogon project to build an aluminium smelter linked to the planned Souapiti dam could slip through the fingers of China Eximbank and its partners Chalco and Sino-Hydro (see AMI N°160). According to our information, Eximbank sought to impose too many conditions as guarantees of its investment. Among other things, style='BACKGROUND-COLOR:#FFFF00'>it demanded some of the revenue that Conakry gets from the Compagnie des Bauxites de Guinée (CBG) as well as 2 billion tonnes of superior quality bauxite (with alumina content of 60% or more) ! These conditions were judged unacceptable by the Prime Minister, Lansana Kouyaté, and the Minister for Mines, Ahmed Kanté, particularly as CBG’s revenues have been used to buy heating oil, rice and sugar for the country via an account with BNP Paribas since Kouyaté became head of the government. The Prime Minister therefore favoured encouraging another company to become involved in the project.The managing director of Cogon, Ahmed Tidjane Diallo, brought a group run by Sinozonto Mining Investment Co. Ltd backed by China Development Bank to Guinea to take the reins of the project. The grouping, run by Sun Jimming, is negotiating, among other things, taking on the bauxite bloc that had been allocated to China Eximbank at Fria. Sinozonto proposes building all the hydroelectric dams on the Konkouré, not only Souapiti, but also Kaléta and Amaria. It expects to commence bauxite production in 2010 and electricity production in 2012. Feasibility studies will begin between 2011 and 2012 for building an alumina refinery and then, depending on the availability of reserves, for construction of an aluminium smelter.34927882Document AMIN000020071130e3be0000k------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------New Chinese Group Formed for Souapiti - Conakry118 words28 November 2007Africa Mining IntelligenceAMIN168EnglishCopyright 2007 Indigo Publications All Rights ReservedIt seems that the removal of China Eximbank and its partners Chalco and Sino-Hydro from the integrated bauxite-alumina-aluminium development project linked with the Souapiti dam (AMI N°167) is confirmed. style='BACKGROUND-COLOR:#FFFF00'>On November 16, the government’s “new” Chinese partners, Hongpeng Sinozonto Mining Investment Co Ltd and Shanxi Luneng Jinbei Aluminum Corporation, formed Luneng Sinozonto Aluminium Guinea, a locally registered subsidiary. The same day, both signed a preliminary agreement covering development of the bauxite-alumina-aluminium branch and the integration of that activity with hydro-electric, rail and port infrastructure. Besides the Souapiti dam, the development programme now includes a plan to build a dam at Kaléta.35274948Document AMIN000020071214e3bs00004Energy   electricity: Guinea246 words16 January 2007Economist Intelligence Unit - Business AfricaEIUBFBusiness Africa15Number xxxEnglish(C) 2007 The Economist Intelligence Unit Ltd.The Chinese government is reported to have pledged funding of US$850m towards the building of the Souapiti hydroelectric dam on the Konkouré River in the north of the country. Lack of funding has stalled the project—whose total cost is put at US$1bn—for many years. Attempts were initially made to link the project to various proposals for building alumina refineries, but the relevant investors could not be persuaded to help finance the construction of the dam. There are chronic electricity shortages in Guinea—the capital experiences frequent power cuts and most businesses that can afford it rely on a diesel generator to supplement their power supply. Outside Conakry electricity supply is minimal and mainly restricted to large towns. The proposed Souapiti station would generate 750 mw of electricity and would have the potential to supply not only the capital but also many industrial projects, such as the alumina refineries, as well as areas outside Conakry.However, the distribution of electricity will also require significant investment, especially if the area of distribution is expanded to include some rural areas. The Chinese interest in the project comes at a time when many bauxite-prospecting licences have been awarded to Chinese companies. The US$850m financing is being organised through a Chinese commercial bank, Exim Bank of China, and a Chinese construction company, Sinohydro, is to build the dam.SOURCE: Business Africabfbfmain20070116t0000000015; Business Africa 16 Jan 2007, Part 15 of 36Document EIUBF00020070127e31g0000f

title: Memve'ele hydropower station- duplicate with 289
description: 'SHANGHAI, April 26, SinoCast -- The Cameroonian government is to sign a contract to borrow about EUR 500 million from the Export-Import Bank of China at the end of April so as to fund the construction of Memve'ele hydropower station in the south of Cameroon, according to the country's finance minister ESSIMI MENYE Lazare.An executive with the Export-Import Bank of China confirms that the lender is indeed in talks with the Cameroonian government on the lending but he declines to comment on disclosure by the finance minister, airing that it is not convenient to unveil details before inking the contract.SINOHYDRO undertakes construction of the Memve'ele hydropower station. The Chinese company clinched a EUR 556 million construction contract with the Cameroonian government as early as 2009, and the government files with the Export-Import Bank of China for preferential loans to fund the project.The Memve'ele hydropower station, with an installed capacity of 200 megawatts, was previously predicted to come under construction in March 2010 and to come into official operation prior to December 2014. However, the financing has not been implemented to date.'

title: Energy package to Comorian islands (Not a project...yet...)
description: 'Copyrights 2007 Indigo Publications All Rights ReservedThe aid proposal formulated by the Chinese energy mission during its visit to Moroni in mid-August turned out to be controversial. The mission had come at the request of President Ahmed Abdallah Sambi and had been guided by the Union of the Comoros Minister for Energy Houmadi Abdallah, a native of the island of Anjouan. It had offered to supply four 1.6 MW electricity generators and 40 km of cable to the island of Ngazidja, two 1.6 MW generators and 40 km of cable to Anjouan and two 800 KW generators plus 30 km of cable to Mohéli. After the delegation left a dispute broke out between the government of Ngazidja and the island legislative assembly on one hand and the Minister Houmadi Abdallah on the other hand. The former accused the latter of having sidelined them from the meetings with the Chinese experts.According to the Ngazidja MPs, the original Chinese idea was to install an electricity power station on Grande Comore, but the office of President Sambi and Houmadi Abdallah had “denatured” this project “to the benefit of Anjouan and Mohéli” where the energy situation is nevertheless less alarming than on Ngazidja”. Hoping to calm down the debate, Houmadi Abdallah stated that “the Chinese proposal can only be put into effect after approval by the government of the Union”. The MPs were furious and insisted that the government of the Union ask the Ngazidja authorities for their opinion on this matter.33143440Document IOLET00020070921e39800006'

Information on completion and organizations involved with the aid package are yet to be determined.

title: Copper for Infrastructure Deal
description: In September 2007, China and DRCongo signed a loan agreement for $5 billion for infrastructural and mining projects. The Congolese Infrastructure Minister Pierre Lumbi reported that $3 billion will be spent on infrastructure, including 2,000 miles of railway between Sakania and Matadi, a 2,000-mile road linking Kisanganiand and Kasumbalesa, a motorway between Lubumbashi and Kasumbalesa, 31 hospitals, 145 health centers, two international-standard universities, and 5,000 government housing units. The motorway between Lubumbashi and Kasumbalesa was completed by the CREC from March-November 2008, totaling 72 km of road. The transportation projects were planned to be completed within 36 months. The remaining $2 billion will be used for mining projects. An unnamed four Chinese SOEs will own a 68% stake in the joint venture with the DRC-owned Gecamines.THIS IS NOT A DUPLICATE WITH PROJECT ID#450, please consult http://www.sarwatch.org/component/content/article/126-headline-news-for-the-drc/258-china-eyes-congos-treasures-.html and http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFPR000020071206e3c6004nh

title: Egyptian-Chinese joint industrial venture (Duplicate)
description: 'ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, April 17 (AFP) - Chinese President Jiang Zemin held talks here Monday with his Egyptian counterpart Hosni Mubarak about the Middle East peace process and bilateral trade, Egyptian officials said.Before entering talks at a seafront palace in the Mediterranean city of Alexandria, Jiang issued a statement calling for 'more cooperation in politics, economics, culture and international relations' between Egypt and China.He recalled that when Mubarak visited China last year, the two leaders signed an agreement to start a 'strategic cooperation' paving the way for future relations.'Egypt is a very important state in the Arab and African area and it has special influence in regional and international relations,' Jiang said.'The international situation and the Middle East (have) become more complex and more volatile at a time when there is economic globalization, which creates more challenges for developing countries,' he added.The Chinese leader arrived from Israel in the morning on his second visit to Egypt.Beijing has been encouraging Chinese firms to invest in Egypt as they would get or will get tariff exemptions enjoyed in African and Arab regional economic groupings as well as the European Union.An Egyptian-Chinese joint venture has bought parcels in an industrial zone in the northwestern Gulf of Suez in order to build a petrochemical plant, oil refinery, fertilizer plant, automobile parts factory and a steel mill.The venture is made up of the Tingjin Economic Development Area Corporation and the Egyptian partners of Osman Ahmed Osman Arab Contractors, the Suez Canal Authority, the National Investment Bank and Misr Bank.Chinese embassy officials said last year that Chinese textile firms have been limited by export quotas to EU countries and the United States.Tingjin was to design and plan the zone, carry out construction and infrastructure development and then sell to investors.Chinese investment in Egypt amounts to only 17 million dollars, according to the General Authority for Investment.In 1956, Cairo became the first Arab capital to have diplomatic relations with China. '

title: Mubarak-1 Oil Rig/Drill Manufacturing (Duplicate)
description: 'BDUEnglishCopyright 2007 China Daily Information Company. All Rights Reserved.Chinese and Egyptian officials on Wednesday laid a foundation stone for a joint venture project to make oil drills, which is the first land oil rig plant in the Middle East region.Jointly laying the foundation stone with Chinese Ambassador to Egypt Wu Sike, Egyptian Minister of Petroleum Amin Sameh Samir Fahmi told Xinhua that the project in the Suez northwestern industrial zone, about 120 kilometers east of Cairo, is a successful story, expecting more Chinese investments in the oil sectors of Egypt as the bilateral cooperation is practical and mutually beneficial.Fahmi also expressed Egypt's keenness to learn China's technology and development experience to promote Egypt's social and economic progress.For his part, Wu praised the progress the joint venture has made, reviewing that the memorandum of understanding was signed last October, the contract signed last December and the venture could start to produce drills only half a year later.The Chinese party to the joint venture is Sichuan Honghua Petroleum Equipment Co Ltd while the Egyptian side comprises three parties, which included an oil and oil processing firm, an oil consultation company and a petroleum company.Earlier statistics from China's customs showed that the trade volume between the two countries reached US$3.19 billion in 2006, up 48.8 percent year on year.Document BDU0000020070601e36100003'

title: Suez Free Trade Zone (Duplicate)
description: Cairo, 18 April: Egyptian Prime Minister Ubayd said emphatically here recently that Egypt and China share a long-standing history of friendly exchange; and the two countries have achieved notable results in cooperation in various fields in recent years. He expressed the belief that through the joint efforts by the two governments and the two peoples, the two countries will have a still brighter future in the development of their relations. Chinese State Council Premier Zhu Rongji will begin an official visit to Egypt from 19 April at the invitation of Egyptian President Mubarak. In an exclusive interview with the Xinhua News Agency on the eve of Premier Zhu Rongji's visit, Prime Minister Ubayd said that both Egyptian and Chinese Governments have always attached great importance to developing bilateral relations; and that the top leaders of the two countries have exchanged visits frequently. President Mubarak has visited China eight times thus far, while the Chinese leaders have visited Egypt on many occasions. During President Mubarak's visit to China in January this year, the two countries signed a total of five documents, including an agreement on economic and technical cooperation, an agreement on cooperation in peaceful use of atomic energy, a framework agreement on cooperation in the field of petroleum, and a memorandum of understanding on implementing the proposal on Chinese citizens' group tours in Egypt. Thanks to the joint efforts by both sides, bilateral friendly and cooperative relations have become stronger and stronger; and the two countries have achieved fruitful results in economic, trade, military, agricultural, and tourism cooperation. Ubayd said: Remarkable progress has been made in bilateral trade and economic relations in recent years. The volume of two-way trade has increased by a big margin year after year, while Chinese investments in Egypt have also increased considerably. He said: Located in an important geographical position, Egypt enjoys domestic political stability and has a vast market. The Egyptian government has adopted a series of measures designed to improve the investment environment, to build up confidence in the Egyptian market among foreign entrepreneurs, and to attract more foreign capital. Ubayd believed that there exist vast vistas for increasing bilateral trade and improving the structure of trade and economic exchange between the two countries. In addition, the two countries also have great potentials for cooperation in the fields of petroleum, agriculture, banking, insurance, tourism, and ocean shipping. Progress has been made in China's participation in the construction of Egypt's Suez Canal Free Trade Zone. He added that there are broad prospects for cooperation in science and technology; and the two countries can work together in organizing technical seminars, and strengthen contacts and exchanges of scientific research personnel. Source: Xinhua news agency domestic service, Beijing, in Chinese 0731 gmt 18 Apr 02.

title: CMEC iron infrastructure in Belinga- duplicate with 630
description: China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export Corp. (CMEC) recently inked an agreement in the Republic of Gabon to develop the country's Belinga iron ore deposit, according to a CMEC announcement released on July 7.Under the agreement, a Chinese consortium lead by CMEC, with financial support from the Export-Import Bank of China, will establish a joint venture with Gabonese partners to construct and operate a 30 million-ton per annum iron ore mining facility, as well related infrastructure.Infrastructure will consist of two railway lines stretching approximately 500 kilometers in total, a deep-water port and a hydropower dam, which along with the mining facility, will require total investment of approximately EUR 450 million ($706.63 million).The mining facility is expected to commence production by 2010, and CMEC has pledged to offtake the entire iron ore output from the joint venture, state-run Shanghai Securities News reported July 8.CMEC defeated competitor Vale, the Brazilian iron ore miner, in a June 2006 auction for the mining rights to the Belinga iron ore deposit, which boasts an estimated 1 billion tons of iron ore reserves at a grade of 64 percent.CMEC, a subsidiary of the state-owned China National Machinery Industry Corporation (Sinomach), specializes in overseas engineering contracting as well as in the import and export of machinery. //State-owned China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export Corporation (CMEC) has signed an agreement with the government of Gabon to develop a iron ore mine in the African country, the official Shanghai Securities News reported. The parties will set up a joint venture to run the Belinga mine, which is expected to produce 30 mln tons of iron ore annually, the paper said. Total investment on for the development and exploration of the mine is expected to reach more than 790 mln usd. The company will also build a 500 kilometer railway, a water power station and a deepwater port, it added. The Export-Import Bank of China will finance the project, according to the paper. kelly.zang@xfn.com//Ask the Chinese to finance and expand even further the Sishen-Saldanha rail link? In Gabon, the Chinese are building the link between the Belinga iron-ore deposit and the port of Santa Clara, plus the associated power station and port facilities as well.//The government and the Chinese consortium led by the China National Machinery and Equipment Corporation (CMEC) have signed a convention specifying new regulations for the exploitation of the giant Bélinga iron ore deposit in the northeast of the country. Bélinga holds an estimated 1bn tonnes of iron ore with 64% purity. The project has progressed more slowly than was originally expected after the signing of the first memorandum of understanding (MoU) in 2006, in part because of disagreements over shareholdings in the project. After several months of intense discussions, a convention signed in December 2007 granted the Gabonese state a 25% stake in the company responsible for exploiting the deposit, Compagnie Minière de Bélinga (Comibel). Technical specifications have been another apparent source of tension: following the signing of the first MoU, the government believed that the works could be completed by 2012 (that is, before the scheduled presidential election).

title: China supports African countries seeking development aid
description: 'LIBREVILLE, Feb. 3 (Xinhua) - Visiting Chinese President Hu Jintao and his Gabonese counterpart El Hadj Omar Bongo Ondimba have pledged to push the China-Gabon cooperation to a new high. In a communique signed here on Tuesday, the two leaders expressed satisfaction over the healthy and steady development of China-Gabon ties since the two countries forged diplomatic relations three decades ago. They vowed to maintain the exchange of high-level visits between China and Gabon, step up cooperation in various fields and increase consultations on African and international affairs. Gabon voiced support for China's reunification. It reiterated that there is only one China in the world, with the government of the People's Republic of China being the sole legal government representing China as a whole and Taiwan being an inalienable part of China. Both sides said that they will boost trade and investment, continue to support cooperation between enterprises and make sure the implementation of the signed cooperation agreements. They said cooperation will be focused on agriculture, infrastructure construction, resources exploitation and personnel training. China reaffirmed its willingness to render support within its ability for Gabon's economic and social development. The two countries agreed that in a world undergoing complicated and profound changes, peace and development remain to be the two major themes of the present times and the common aspiration of the peoples of all countries. They called for more international consultations to maintain diversity of the world and promote exchanges among countries of different civilizations and development modes. In regard to the economic globalization, both sides called on the international community to adopt measures to help developing countries overcome difficulties and enhance their ability to achieve an independent, sustainable development and protect the environment. They also urged developed countries to shoulder due responsibilities, expand access to their markets, remove trade barriers, and honor their commitments on financial and technological support and debt reduction and cancellation.     They said maintaining stability and alleviating poverty are twopressing tasks faced by African countries.   China supports the Africa Union and sub-regional organizations  in Africa in playing a greater role in achieving peace and stability in the continent and promoting regional integration process. China also supports African countries in seeking development and prosperity through the implementation of the 'New Partnership Program for African Development.' The two sides stressed the importance of solving conflicts in Africa through dialogue, and called on the international community to care more about the continent's situation. China will continue to participate in the United Nations peace-keeping missions in Africa and provide support to peace-keeping activities of Africa's regional and sub-regional organizations. The two countries highly value the China-Africa friendship and cooperation and regard the 'China-Africa Cooperation Forum' as an important platform for China-Africa consultations and cooperation.     China and Gabon will strengthen cooperation within theframework of this forum and promote the China-Africa partnershipdesigned for full cooperation and common development.'

title: Possible railway construction in Gabon
description: 'China's role in the operation is decisive,' Onouviet said, but he added that a role for the French group Eramet, which mines manganese in Gabon and runs the Transgabonese Railway via a subsidiary, has been provided for in the framework accord signed in China. Apart from the infrastructure and future possibilities opened by the rail link, 'this work is going to create thousands of jobs,' the minister said, but while he was full of enthusiasm, he said 'the labour will only begin once the Chinese side is convinced of the worth of the site'. The full Chinese answer should be known at the end of October, once a team of geologists and logistics experts, due to arrive in Gabon in the next few days, has done its work.

title: Manganese mining in Mbigou, Gabon
description: The government of Gabon signed a contract in 2005 with China’s Sinosteel to prospect for manganese ore in the southern region of Mbigou. However, the mine in Mbigou was situated in a rugged area making exploitation very difficult. In 2011 Sinosteel declared the mine no longer economically viable, and returned its mining license to the Gabonese State.STAFF_NOTES:The included Local Language Source may not reference this project, and may only be related to project #633.
