title: Ghana to get $167 million more from China for Bui Project （Duplicate）
description: GHANA : Ghana to get $167 million more from China for Bui Project183 words19 February 2011Mena ReportMENREPEnglish© 2011 Provided by Syndigate.info, an Albawaba.com CompanyFinance Minister of Ghana, Dr Kwabena Duffour declared that the country will receive an additional $167 million from the Chinese government to support the Bui Hydro Electric Project, in addition to the initial $562 million received for the project.The country has signed two trade agreements with China, under which Ghana would access $6 billion to support its infrastructure development.He said President Mills better Ghana agenda was on course, stressing that the President would like the services sector to be driven by infrastructure development in terms of roads, hospitals and schools.The strong bond between the two countries had put Ghana on a sound footing to tackle its development agenda but underscored the need to reduce trade imbalances between the two countries, said Ms Hannah Tetteh, Minister of Trade and Industry.Ghana had witnessed significant foreign investment of more than $100 million from China over the last 10 years. We look forward to more, not only in the extractive industry or oil but also in agriculture and manufacturing, she said.Document MENREP0020110219e72j00039

title: China Donates Office Equipment for OAU Summit (duplicate)
description: China Donates Office Equipment for OAU Summit.193 words29 June 2001Xinhua News AgencyXNEWSEnglish(c) Copyright 2001 Xinhua News AgencyLUSAKA, June 29 (Xinhua) - The Chinese government Friday donated office equipment and a cheque of 500,000 U. S. dollars to Zambia in a bid to help the cash-strapped country host the upcoming Organization of African Unity (OAU) summit, which will kick off here early next month.At the hand-over ceremony, Chinese Ambassador to Zambia Peng Keyu said China's assistance to Zambia and the OAU summit is very limited.However, the ambassador said China is a developing country in the world with 1.3 billion people and is still not strong enough.'The Chinese government has been trying her best to render her assistance to Zambia and other African countries,' Peng said.The donation of office equipment has been provided under a 5 million yuan (620,000 dollars) grant from the Chinese government for the provision of computers, printers, copy machines, fax machines and other equipment, he said. For his part, Zambian Vice President Enoch Kavindele commended the Chinese government for the generous assistance to Zambia, saying that Zambia is confident to hold the summit with the help of China and other countries.

title: Sao Tome & Principe and Nigeria Sign Deal with Sinopec (Duplicate with 107)
description: 23 March 2006Global Insight Daily Analysis WDAN English Copyright 2006, Global Insight Limited. All Rights Reserved. Sao Tome   Principe and Nigeria have signed a deal with China's Sinopec for Block 2 in the Gulf of Guinea Joint Development Zone (JDZ). The signing follows a number of disputes over the awards process for the country's second tender, which has seen some investors pull out, including Pioneer, which was originally awarded the rights to Block 2 (see Sao Tome   Principe: 9 February 2006: Pioneer Withdraws from Two JDZ Exploration Blocks). Under the conditions of the Joint Development Treaty signed in 2002, Sao Tome   Principe will receive only 40% of monies from the oil and gas exploration, while Nigeria, already Africa's largest oil-exporting country, will receive 60% (see Africa Regional: Sinopec Set to Pick Up Pioneer's Block 2 Stake in the JDZ). In December 2005, the Sao Tome judiciary said that there were serious flaws in the allocation of offshore blocks 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6 of the JDZ, but the country has still gone ahead with awards (see Africa Regional: 15 March 2006:Sao Tome Gives In; Signs JDZ Deals for Blocks 3 and 4). Significance: Despite its reservations about the actual awards process, Sao Tome   Principe will hope this deal and the signature bonus of US$71 million is the first of many to bring huge revenues to the tiny islands. With Chevron due to disclose results of its exploration in Block 1 shortly, there is keen anticipation about prospects in the deepwater Gulf of Guinea areas surrounding the islands. For Sinopec, the JDZ awards have offered an easy way into prospective Gulf of Guinea acreage, with more risk-averse investors, like Pioneer and Noble Energy, pulling out because of problems with the awards process, terms and partners.  12 March 2007 08:15 AMReuters News LBA English (c) 2007 Reuters Limited SAO TOME, March 12 (Reuters) - China's Sinopec Corp and Canada's Addax Petroleum Corp will spend $73.8 million on prospecting in two blocks of a Joint Development Zone of Sao Tome and Nigeria, a spokesman said. Jeff Schrull, a spokesman for the exploration venture, was speaking in Sao Tome at the weekend at a ceremony to sign a contract with with Indian deepwater specialist services group Aban Offshore Limited . Addax said last week it had agreed with Aban to start drilling operations as early as the second quarter of 2008. Aban said separately the contract was worth $123 million. Sinopec heads a consortium that paid a $71 million signature bonus last March for a production sharing agreement for block 2 in the Joint Development Zone. Addax holds a stake in block 4. The Joint Development Zone was created under a deal to end a long-running dispute between Nigeria, Africa's most populous country and top oil producer, and the tiny Atlantic archipelago of Sao Tome and Principe, which currently produces no oil. Nigeria owns a 60 percent stake in the zone with 40 percent belonging to Sao Tome, most of whose 170,000 people live on less than $1 a day and hope crude oil could drag them out poverty. U.S. major Chevron Corp. raised hopes last May when it announced it had found oil and gas in block of the Joint Development Zone, but it is still too early to say whether the reserves are commercially viable. Under the treaty governing the zone, even if viable reserves are found, Nigeria and Sao Tome only start to benefit after the firms involved have recouped their research costs, which could run into billions of dollars.

title: Riad Motors Plant
description: On May 19, 2008, Riad Motors Holding announced that it would open their biggest Chinese constructed vehicle assembly plant in North Africa by June 2008. Riad invested 275 million dirhams in the plant. The plant aimed to produce 5,000 vehicles, mainly small trucks, per year to supply the Moroccan market before expanding output later to export to West Africa, Middle East and Asia. Riad signed deals with Chinese vehicle-maker Sinotruk , Mudan and Baw, to supply the assembly plant to be located in Settat region, near Casablanca -- Morocco's commercial capital. The three firms are linked to the Chinese army and produce vehicles for the Chinese armed forces.  摩洛哥境内首家中国卡车组装厂将於今年6月进入量产，年产量预计会超过1,000辆，投入资金约合3,800万美元。经营实用车辆的MECOMAR股份有限公司和中国重汽、牡丹汽车以及北汽集团最近达成协议，将从中国进口汽车零部件至摩洛哥进行组装，这些在摩洛哥境内组装的中国品牌汽车将在当地和西非国家销售。据悉，此举主要是考虑到摩洛哥整车进口关税税率为40％，而全散件组装仅为2.5%，通过降低中国汽车在当地销售的关税成本，有利於开拓北非和西非市场。中国卡车开始在摩洛哥组装 性价比优势突出时间:08-06-14来源:第一商用车网作者:第一商用车网责编:本站编辑我要评论(0)      据摩洛哥媒体日前报道，摩洛哥首家中国卡车组装厂近日将投入生产。该厂占地面积10万平方米，预计投资3900万美元 　　据悉，摩洛哥Mecomar公司与中国重汽、牡丹汽车以及北汽集团签订了独家代理协议。Mecomar公司不仅负责三家中国品牌汽车的销售，同时从中国进口汽车散件至摩洛哥组装。　　目前，摩洛哥整车进口关税税率为40%，而汽车散件进口税率为2.5%。化整为零的模式将大幅降低中国品牌汽车在摩的销售成本。上述三家中国品牌汽车在摩洛哥的销售价格比当地同类产品价格低20%～30%。　　摩洛哥中国卡车组装厂年产量的60%将满足摩当地市场需求，其余40%计划销往塞内加尔、毛里塔尼亚、喀麦隆及科特迪瓦等西非国家。摩洛哥境内的销售及售后服务网点将覆盖10个大中城市。　　2006年，中国汽车通过法国销售商正式进入摩洛哥。仅仅两年，中国汽车就获得摩洛哥消费者的青睐，一些品牌的车型供不应求。与当地同类车型相比，中国车具有较大性价比优势。

title: Tanzania-Zambia Railway Authority to get four locomotives from China. TAZARA (Duplicate of  1366)
description: Tanzania-Zambia Railway Authority to get four locomotives from China.119 words22 March 200112:12 AMBBC Monitoring Africa - PoliticalBBCAPEnglish(c) 2001 The British Broadcasting Corporation [date of publication]. All Rights Reserved. No material may be reproduced except with the express permission of The British Broadcasting Corporation.Excerpt from report by Tanzanian newspaper The Guardian web site on 22 MarchThe Tanzania-Zambia Railway Authority [TAZARA] will get four shunting locomotives from China after the China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation (CCECC) and TAZARA yesterday signed a contract to effect the supply of the locomotives.The contract, worth 16.5m Chinese yuan (about 16m shillings), was signed by the permanent secretary to the Ministry of Works, Salim Msoma, on behalf of the government, and vice-director of the foreign aid department of CCECC, Huang Chuanzhi [name as published], on behalf of the Chinese government...Source: The Guardian web site, Dar es Salaam, in English 22 Mar 01.

title: Office Equipment and Machinery (duplicate of 14529)
description: Government to Build Sophisticated Hospital.434 words3 July 200112:23 PMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) Distributed via COMTEX News.Lusaka, Jul 03, 2001 (The Post/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX)-Government will this year build a highly sophisticated hospital to deal with some of the cases currently referred to other countries, Vice-President Enoch Kavindele has disclosed.Speaking when he received equipment from the Egyptian government on Friday for the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) summit, Vice-President Kavindele said the multi-billion hospital would be built in conjunction with the Egyptian and Japanese governments.'As you are aware in the past three years the government of Zambia has sent to hospitals outside Zambia a total number of 332 patients for treatment,' he said. Vice-President Kavindele said the cost of sending patients outside Zambia was too high.Egyptian Ambassador to Zambia Abadelgghaffar Eldib said the inspection of the site would be done by experts on July 7, this year before the construction could be commenced. Vice-President Kavindele said the Zambian government was indebted to the Egyptian government for many things it had done which include the sending of doctors to lecture at the University of Zambia School of Medicine.He also disclosed that four of the doctors had already arrived while the rest were expected soon after the OAU summit. 'Not only that, but when I was in Egypt I had a discussion with President Mubarak who generously offered to send more highly trained doctors to beef up our medical facilities and work in what is to be one of the most highly sophisticated hospitals,' he said. Ambassador Eldib said his government had also invested in a rice growing project in Chanyanya area which he said would be very sustainable. Earlier Chinese Ambassador to Zambia Peng Keyu also donated equipment worth US$600,000 which included computer software, printers, uniform for the brass band and other operational machinery and US$500,000 cash. Ambassador Keyu said China was committed to bringing investment in Zambia.He said there was already more than US$200million investment in the country through various Chinese companies. Vice-President Kavindele said the relations between China and Zambia would continue to grow because of the growing unconditional co-operation. He said the Chinese government had also offered road construction equipment.'The equipment is here so that most of our feeder roads are graded so that our farmers can have access to the markets,' said Vice-President Kavindele. China has also sent in their experts to assemble the equipment for use during the OAU summit.by Sheikh ChifuweCopyright The Post. Distributed by All Africa Global Media(AllAfrica.com)

title: Construction of Qarre 1 power plant
description: 5 January 2004Visiting Chinese Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing joined Sudanese officials north of here Monday in inaugurating two electric power stations, including one built and financed by China. The Qarre I and Qarre II stations, which are about 50 kilometers (30 miles) north of Khartoum, will together produce 330 megawatts, Sudanese Electricity Minister Ali Temim Fertak said at the ceremony. Qarre I station was built by China's Harbin power company with the Chinese central bank providing 149 million dollars in financing. The Qarre II station was built by the international Star company, with Arab investors providing 39 million dollars in funding. The investors are the Jeddah-based Islamic Development Bank, Abu Dhabi Development Fund and the Arab Investment company. Fertak said contracts will be signed with international companies for building power stations that are expected to produce up to 700 megawatts before the completion in 2008 of the Merowe dam which would produce 1,250 megawatts. Li, who is on an official visit to Sudan, was reported by state radio and television as signing with his Sudanese counterpart Mustafa Osman Ismail a number of agreements for bilateral cooperation. According to SUNA news agency, Li said in a meeting with Sudanese Energy and Mining Minister Awad Ahmed al-Jaz that his ministry would offer 'more facilities' to major Chinese companies to participate in Sudan's development in order to economic and other ties.
donor_agency: China Central Bank, State-Owned Company

title: Establishment of oil pipelines (Duplicate)
description: Sudan and China have signed a number of agreements in the area of oil manufacturing and explorations, including establishing oil pipelines from Fula town in Western Kordofan State [central Sudan] to Khartoum Oil Refinery.This was announced by the minister of energy and mining, Dr Awad al-Jaz, in a statement issued soon on his return from China yesterday evening. The minister of energy further said the Khartoum Oil Refinery administration discussed in its meeting in Peking ways promoting and manufacturing oil-related products especially petro-chemical goods, in partnership with China. He also said that he held a meeting with German businessmen on his way from China and discussed ways of promoting German investments in Sudan. Dr Al-Jaz pointed out that high quality of Sudanese oil and its international demand and competition were behind oil investment in Sudan. Source: Republic of Sudan Radio, Omdurman, in Arabic 0400 gmt 4 No 02.

title: Capacity expansion of Al Khurtum Refinery (Duplicate)
description: 16 September 2003China Chemical Reporter CHCR English (c) 2003 China Chemical Reporter. All rights reserved  The Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources of Sudan and China National Petroleum Corporation recently signed 3 agreements on joint oil development in Al Khurtum. President of Sudan, attended the signing ceremony.     The first agreement is concerned on the capacity expansion of Al Khurtum Refinery. The project has an investment of US$340 million. After the completion of the project, the oil refining capacity in the plant can increase from 56 000 barrels to 100 000 barrels per day. The second agreement isabout the construction of a 720km-long oil transmission pipeline from oil producing areas to Al Khurtum. The transmitting capacity of the pipeline will reach 200 000 barrels per day. The third agreement is about the joint establishment of an oil geophysical company. Not long ago CNPC Explorationand Development Co. discovered a large oilfield with oil reserves amounting to 2.0 billion barrels in a Basin of Sudan.        Sudan can already produce various oil products including jet fuel oil. Besides meeting the domestic demand, some export can also be made each year.(c)2003. China Chemical Reporter. All rights reserved. title: China provides 2m dollars aid to Zambia (duplicate)
description: China provides 2m dollars aid to Zambia251 words4 December 200309:11 AMBBC Monitoring Asia PacificBBCAPPEnglish(c) 2003 The British Broadcasting Corporation [date of publication]. All Rights Reserved. No material may be reproduced except with the express permission of The British Broadcasting Corporation.Text of report in English by official Chinese news agency Xinhua (New China News Agency)Lusaka, 4 December: The Chinese government officially released 2m US dollars in cash here Thursday [4 December] to the Zambian government.This amount of money is part of 6m dollars' grant that the Chinese government promised to give to Zambia during Zambian President Levy Patrick Mwanawasa's recent visit to China.The other 4m dollars will be utilized for projects that will be agreed upon by the two governments.Zambian Finance and National Planning Ministry Permanent Secretary Richard Chizyuka said at the signing ceremony this gesture signifies the importance that the Chinese government attaches to the efforts being made by the Zambian government to improve the economy and to reduce poverty.Chizyuka thanked the Chinese government and its people for this assistance and also the assistance China has continued to render to Zambia since its independence.'The two countries have been all weather friends since independence,' he said.He assured that the Zambian government will utilize the money to the benefit of the people.Chinese Ambassador to Zambia Peng Keyu mentioned at the same function that Mwanawasa's recent visit to China was very successful.Peng said the high level exchanges between the two countries have been increased a lot this year. He hoped the relationship between the two countries can be further improved in the future.Source: Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in English 1044 gmt 4 Dec 03

title: TAZARA Loan to Zambia and Tanzania (Duplicate of 14393)
description: China has Given a Loan to Zambia and Tanzania264 words16 November 200403:04 PMLiquidAfrica Holding LimitedLQAFEnglish(c) 2004 Liquid Africa, All Rights Reserved.No 16, 2004 (LiquidAfrica via COMTEX) --China has given a loan of $10.87 million (90 million Yuan) to Zambia and Tanzania to be used in part to rehabilitate the jointly-owned Tanzania-Zambia Railway (TAZARA), media reports said here Monday.Each of the two countries will receive $5.4 million (45 million Yuan), out of which one million dollars would to go towards the rehabilitation of TAZARA.The loan agreement was signed here Friday night by ministers from the three countries at a State House ceremony witnessed by Zambian President Levy Mwanawasa and Wu Banggou, chair for the National People`s Congress (NPC) of China, who is heading a visiting delegation of 200 persons, including 40 journalists.Zambia`s finance minister Ng`andu Magande and Tanzania`s trade and industry minister Mark Mwendoshya signed for their countries, while Wei Jianguo signed for China.Tanzania and Zambia will draw down on the loan starting 2005 to 2009, while repayments start 2015 and end in 2019. The three countries also signed a protocol on technical cooperation that will include the management and maintenance of the infrastructure of TAZARA.In addition, Zambia has received from China a general grant of $2.4 million (20 million Yuan) to finance programs centered on poverty alleviation and general development of the country.The Chinese also signed the third agreement involving digital equipment worth $500,000 dollars to upgrade the mobile phone equipment at the Zambia Telecommunication Company Limited. The equipment will be supplied by ZTE, a telecommunication company in China.

title: Chinese surveillance boat (duplicate)
description: 'Text of report by Sierra Leone's Radio Democracy on 17 JanuaryChinese Ambassador to Sierra Leone Chen Wenju and Deputy Minister of Defence Joe Blell have signed a memorandum of understanding on behalf of the peoples of China and Sierra Leone. Under the memorandum, the two sides will work out a protocol agreement on assistance from the Chinese Ministry of Defence to its Sierra Leone counterpart. A Chinese team will be in Sierra Leone for six months to provide adequate training to the Republic of Sierra Leone Armed Forces [RSLAF] maritime wing on the operations and maintenance of a Chinese surveillance boat due in Sierra Leone before the end of January 2006.Source: Radio Democracy, Freetown, in Krio 1900 gmt 17 Jan 06a3d59f26Document BBCAPP0020060120e21k002pa'

title: inter-governmental agreement with Sierratel (duplicate of ID# 53)
description: In July of 2008, China signed an agreement to provide a concessional loan to Sierra Leonean telecommunication company Sierratel for $16.6 million USD in order to support a CDMA project. According to the Economic and Commercial Counselor at Freetown's Chinese Embassy, the project will provide Sierra Leone with an improved and efficient telecommunication system. The loan for this project, known as the Sierra Leone Rural and Sub-urban Telecommunication CDMA Network Project, will be financed by China's Ex-Im Bank and subsequently carried out by Chinese company Huawei Technologies. It is expected to be completed at the end of 2008, after which Huawei will provide technical support for one year. In April of 2009, Sierra Leonean President Ernest Bai Koroma launched the new telecom company.

title: China gives Zambia 1m dollars to purchase relief aid
description: China gives Zambia 1m dollars to purchase relief aid270 words9 February 200610:16 AMBBC Monitoring Asia PacificBBCAPPEnglish(c) 2006 The British Broadcasting Corporation. All Rights Reserved. No material may be reproduced except with the express permission of The British Broadcasting Corporation.Text of report in English by official Chinese news agency Xinhua (New China News Agency)Lusaka, 9 February: China has given drought-hit Zambia 1m US dollars for it to purchase relief food. At the signing ceremony held here Thursday [9 February] of the notes to acknowledge receipt of the fund, Chinese Ambassador to Zambia Li Baodong said that this donation is in the conditions that Zambia is suffering the food shortage because of drought.The ambassador said that the Chinese government is doing the job to help the Zambian government to implement the project of maintenance of water supply in Lusaka, Ndola and Kitwe with about 80m RMB [renminbi] yuan (about 10m dollars).The Chinese government has also agreed to provide the government with a batch of goods worth 10m RMB yuan (about 1.2m dollars) to be used in the elections later this year.On occasion Zambian Finance Minister Ng'andu Magande thanked the Chinese government for the assistance. The minister assured the Chinese ambassador the grant will be utilized to purchase relief food to benefit the hunger stricken people and accountability and transparency in the utilization of grant is strictly observed.It is estimated that 1.7 million Zambians are facing food shortage due to the drought that hit most part of the southern African country in the 2004/05 farming season. In November, 2005, Zambian President Levy Mwanawasa declared the hunger situation in the country as a 'national disaster', calling for international food aid.Source: Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in English 1154 gmt 9 Feb 06
sector: Humanitarian and Disaster Relief and Preparation

title: China's Jinchuan invests in Zambian nickel project (duplicate #111)
description: In 2006, Chinese state-owned Jinchuan Group Ltd. signed an investment deal for the Munali project in Zambia. The company has agreed to buy all the nickel concentrates produced at Albidon's Munalie mine and provide $20 million in debt financing to develop the project. The Chinese firm also will make an equity investment of $5 million in Albidon. Munali is located around 60 km south of the capital Lusaka and is expected to produce 8,500 tonnes per year of nickel in concentrate after a ramp-up period in 2008. The project has commenced, but it is unclear if it has been completed. The project is tied.As part of the agreement, Albidon Ltd. will also invest $100 million USD in the establishment of the mine.

title: China boosts Zambia mining investments to $900 mln
description: LUSAKA, May 23 (Reuters) - China has boosted its planned investment to $900 million in Zambia's mineral-rich Copper Belt over the next four years, the government said on Wednesday.The Ministry of Commerce and Trade said China Nonferrous Metals Corporation (CNMC) president Luo Tao told Zambian authorities that Chinese firms would now add an extra $100 million to the initial $800 million investments planned for the new Chambishi economic zone.The zone, pioneered by CNMC, is designed to draw investment from scores of Chinese companies in copper and cobalt mining, agriculture and manufacturing to create 60,000 jobs.Deputy Commerce and Trade Minister Dora Siliya was in China to finalise investment arrangements with firms planning to set up in Zambia starting from this year, the statement said.A senior Treasury official told Reuters that Chinese firms had shown interest in setting up manufacturing plants, including processing copper into finished products such as cables.President Levy Mwanawasa said in February after talks with Chinese leader Hu Jintao that his government would create the economic zone in the Copper Belt town of Chambishi, 420 km north of the capital Lusaka, and exempt Chinese firms from import and value added taxes.Analysts say the move fitted in China's strategy to tap raw materials from African nations in exchange for grants and unconditional loans to the world's poorest continent.ZAMBIA-MINING/CHINA|LANGEN|ABN|C|MTL|SF|AFN|Z

title: 800 million dollars in investment to Zambia (duplicate)
description: China's Hu announces giant investments in ZambiaDJ681 words4 February 200704:38 AMAgence France PresseAFPREnglishCopyright Agence France-Presse, 2007 All reproduction and presentation rights reserved.LUSAKA, Feb 4, 2007 (AFP) -Chinese President Hu Jintao unveiled more than 800 million dollars in investment and debt waivers as he toured Zambia, where escalating anti-Sino feelings have forced Lusaka to tone down his programme.Hu's flagship announcement was a fresh injection of 800 million dollars to develop copper mines in Zambia, one of the world's top producers of the ore, in the northern region of Chambeshi.The visiting leader, who arrived in Lusaka on Saturday on the latest leg of his eight-nation swing through Africa, also said Beijing was writing off Zambia's bilateral debt due last year totalling nearly eight million dollars.He said China, the third largest foreign investor in Zambia, would extend 150,000 dollars in cash to help with damage caused by recent floods.Other measures include building schools, hospitals and an agriculture technology centre.The president's itinerary for Sunday was severely curtailed by Lusaka in the wake of planned protests against the alleged exploitation of local workers by Chinese firms and the supposed plunder of the country's mineral resources.A trip to a Chinese-run copper mine in the north, where a blast in 2005 killed 50 Zambians, was cancelled after reports of planned demonstrations.Hu had also been due to commission a 200-million-dollar copper smelter in Chambeshi and lay the foundation stone of a giant Chinese-funded stadium at Ndola in the country's Copperbelt province.Zambia has enforced tight security during the trip, confined Hu to Lusaka and not invited main opposition leader Michael Sata, a vitriolic critic of Beijing, to any public function with the visiting leader.Hu on Sunday met with Zambia's founding president Kenneth Kaunda after holding talks with parliament speaker Amussa Mwanamwambwa.He was later scheduled to launch a Sino-Zambian economic trade cooperation zone with his Zambian counterpart Levy Mwanawasa.Mwanawasa, in a banquet speech late Saturday, tried to play down the controversy over the Chinese juggernaut in his country.'The decision by your government to establish a special economic zone here in Zambia is the most welcome development,' he told Hu.'Apart from creating the much-needed employment opportunities, it will produce a culture of adding value to our own materials,' he said, underlining that 'the transfer of technology will be considered as a deliberate policy.'Hu meanwhile stressed that ties between Zambia, the first southern African nation to establish diplomatic links with China 42 years ago, and Beijing had 'endured the test of changes in the international arena and both countries' domestic situation.'He also thanked Zambia for its unswerving commitment to the one-China policy.Chinese investment in Zambia -- mainly in mining, textile and construction -- has soared in recent years but the litany of complaints is growing.Many Zambians accuse Chinese companies of paying low wages, ignoring basic safety standards and bringing scores of Chinese workers in to do jobs meant to be reserved for locals.Last week, workers of the recently closed Zambia-China Mulungushi Textiles, the country's largest textile mill, protested outside the Chinese embassy to complain about poor wages, mistreatment and the temporary closure of the plant because of massive losses.Despite the protests, Hu was quoted by China's Xinhua news agency as saying that economic cooperation between China and Africa was mutually beneficial and carried out on a level playing field.Zambia is Hu's fourth stop in Africa after Cameroon, Liberia and Sudan. He travels on Monday to Namibia followed by South Africa, Mozambique and the Seychelles.China, which is avidly courting Africa for its oil and energy resources, recently said it would write off debts owed by 33 countries on the world's poorest continent as part of a multi-billion-dollar pledge made last year.Sino-African trade reached 55.5 billion dollars last year, a more than five-fold increase from 10.79 billion dollars in 2001, according to official Chinese figures. Beijing hopes to attain a 100-billion-dollar target by 2010.dj-ach/ssDocument AFPR000020070204e324004xu

title: Zambia and China to spend $28 mln in power project (duplicate of 985)
description: Zambia and China to spend $28 mln in power projectBy Shapi Shacinda403 words31 August 200709:04 AMReuters NewsLBAEnglish(c) 2007 Reuters LimitedLUSAKA, Aug 31 (Reuters) - Zambia and China will invest $28 million to supply power to Chinese firms which set up operations in the African country's mineral-rich Copper Belt region, a senior industry official said on Friday.Rhodnie Sisala, managing director of state power utility Zesco, said it would provide electricity to a new copper smelter the Chinese are building in the Chambishi multi-facility economic zone (MFEZ), 420 km north of the capital Lusaka.'The total cost of providing power supply is about $27.8 million. It is expected that the project will be completed by August 2008 to enable the smelter to commence copper processing,' Sisala said in a statement.Investors from China will build leach and brick-making plants, and others to treat slag from the mines into finished copper. Expansion of the Chambishi copper mine, owned by China's NFC Africa, was also in the pipeline.The government said earlier this year that Chinese companies would also set up manufacturing plants and agricultural processing factories in the Chambishi MFEZ.Officials say China has pledged to invest $1.2 billion in two economic zones, including one for high-technology manufacturing firms in Lusaka. Of that investment, $900 million is earmarked for Chambishi.In July, Zambian President Levy Mwanawasa said he would fight political opponents trying to limit or frustrate Chinese investments in the mineral-rich southern African nation.The main opposition Patriotic Front (PF) party won parliamentary polls in the mineral-rich Copper Belt province, after its leader campaigned on an anti-China platform in 2006 presidential and parliamentary elections.Zambia became the first African country to experience riots over charges against Chinese firms of poor labour relations, poor safety standards and low wages paid to local miners.In 2005, 50 workers died at BIGRMM Zambia Ltd, a Chinese-run firm after an explosion which experts said was caused by poor safety standards.The state Environmental Council of Zambia (ECZ) granted BIGRMM a new licence in June to set up another plant despite resistance from families of the dead workers.Chambishi is one of five economic zones China plans to set up across Africa as Beijing strengthens its economic partnership with the continent, which has abundant natural resources and cheap labour.ZAMBIA-CHINA/ELECTRICITY|LANGEN|ABN|E|RBN|AFN|Z|RNP|DNP|PCO

title: Banda Launches $400 Million Kariba Power Project (duplicate of 2316)
description: Banda Launches $400 Million Kariba Power Project539 words9 March 200910:54 AMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2009 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedMar 09, 2009 (The Times of Zambia/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- PRESIDENT Rupiah Banda yesterday launched the US$400 million Kariba North Bank extension project and said the Government had placed emphasis on building new power stations as well as expanding the existing ones.Mr Banda said to facilitate this development in the electricity sub-sector, the Government was in the process of concluding the legislation to make the sector one of the priority sectors in the provision of incentives under the Zambia Development Act.Mr Banda, who was speaking at the launch of the project in Siavonga yesterday, said the Government had special focus on the development of the energy sector which was a vehicle towards the attainment of economic prosperity.'It is my Government's resolve to create a conducive environment for the development of power projects in the country. Government shall prioritise its resource allocation to the electricity sub-sector,' he said.He said the energy sector, specifically electricity, played a critical role in facilitating growth of the economy.The Kariba North Bank extension project would involve the installation of two additional generators with a total capacity of 360 mega watts. This will bring the total installed capacity at the Kariba North Bank to 1,080 mega watts.Mr Banda said in cognisance of the role that electricity played in the sustainable growth of the country, the Government, in addition to the project which was launched yesterday, would work on the Kafue Gorge Lower hydropower project at a cost of about $1.5 billion.Mr Banda said the Itezhi-Tezhi hydropower project of 120 mega watts would cost Government $200million.He said the 210-mega watts Kalungushi hydropower project would cost about $400 million.And Mr Banda thanked the Chinese government for facilitating the provision of 85 per cent of the cost of the project through the China Export and Import Bank and the Development Bank of Southern Africa for providing the balance of the project funds.Energy and Water Development Minister, Kenneth Konga said the expansion project at Kariba North Bank was a milestone in Zambia's energy sector and that the Government had realised the need for new power stations.Mr Konga said electricity was one of the key drivers for development, saying there had been little development in the sector for a long time.Chinese ambassador to Zambia, Li Qiangmin said the project demonstrated the cordial bilateral relations by the Zambian and Chinese governments.Mr Li said Zambia was one of the preferred investors' destinations by the Chinese because of its good policies which they had taken advantage of.He said the company contracted to do the works, Sino Hydro, was the biggest power company in China and one of the largest in the world.Southern Province Minister, Daniel Munkombwe urged Zesco to consider giving priority to the local people when they start employing general workers.Southern Africa head international finance, William Lugemwa, said his bank was keen to support infrastructure projects with a clear focus on development and the communities.Zesco managing director, Rodney Sisala said the project would not only be beneficial to Zambia but the entire Southern African Development Community region.Document AFNWS00020090309e539000wd

title: Chinese to Pump U.S. $150 Million Into LCM Rehab (duplicate)
description: Chinese to Pump U.S. $150 Million Into LCM Rehab648 words10 December 200908:47 AMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2009 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedDec 10, 2009 (The Times of Zambia/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- THE China Non-Ferrous Metal Company/Luanshya Copper Mine (CLM) is set to inject an additional fresh investment of more than US$150 million in the rehabilitation of Luanshya Mine, which commences production on December 14.And Mines and Minerals Development Minister Maxwell Mwale said the Government was impressed with the manner in which CLM had introduced the new mining technology replacing the 1930's technology.Mr Mwale said replacing the 1930 technology would lead to a situation where the mine would now start rocovering 93 per cent of copper which was being lost under the old copper ore processing method.Meanwhile, Labour and Social Security Minister, Austin Liato said he was impressed that the CLM management and the unions had signed the recognition agreement and were now chatting the way forward in signing the collective agreement.CLM chief executive officer, Luo Xingeng said in Luanshya yesterday that so far, his company had spent over $30 million in the rehabilitation of the mine and replacement of equipment and by the end of the year, $42 million would have been used on the development of the mine prior to the commencement of production.Mr Luo said although the mine had not started actual production of copper, it had recruited over 2,250 employees despite the company having earlier projected that it would recruit 1,700 employees. The lowest paid worker at CLM gets a monthly salary of K1, 224,000.Speaking when Mr Mwale, Mr Liato and Copperbelt Minister Mwansa Mbulakulima toured the mine's concentrator and the Muliashi Mine project sites yesterday, Mr Luo said the CLM management and Mineworkers Union of Zambia (MUZ) and National Union for Miners and Allied Workers (NUMAW) were coordinating well.Mr Luo said although the mine had engaged more than 37 local and foreign contractors, most of the qualified personnel working for most of the former contractors had been re-engaged by the mine.He said the CLM had over the past six months been undertaking the rebuilding and rehabilitation works of Baluba Mine.'Already we have done the necessary preparations of viability of the conditions needed for production. We are scheduled to do the first blasting of the copper pre-underground on December 14,' he said.Mr Luo said the mine's concentrator was undergoing a complete overhaul with all the five crushers being replaced by modern ones and so far, three out of five had been replaced while two new crushers were still in transit.He said the hard work being exhibited by the Zambian workers was helping in enhancing production at CLM.CLM deputy chief executive officer in charge of technical services, Robert Kamanga said all was set to ensure that the Muliashi Open Pit Mine project and seven oxide camps were made operational next year.Mr Mwale said the Government was impressed with the manner in which a lot of work had been done at the mine within a short period of time.He said the rate at which the mine was being developed had left those doubting about the viability of Chinese investment with no option but to join those who wanted to allow the Chinese to work with the Zambian people as partners in development.The minister said there was need for all those working on the mines to ensure that the Zambian and Chinese cultures converged to all the people from the two countries.Mr Mbulakulima said construction of a 7.6-kilometre-long tarred road from the mine's offices to the Muliashi mining site at a cost of K8.2 billion, which was being incurred by the mine even before the commencement of production, was a clear testimony of how serious CLM was as an investor in the mining sector.Document AFNWS00020091210e5ca000yb

title: interest-free loan agreement of K32 billion (duplicate)
description: ZAMBIA : Zambia and China Sign two big deals459 words15 December 2011Mena ReportMENREPEnglish© 2011 Provided by Syndigate.info, an Albawaba.com CompanyZAMBIA and China have inked an economic and technical cooperation grant agreement amounting to K43.3 billion and also an interest-free loan agreement of K32 billion. The grant funds will be used in the fight against poverty and projects to be agreed upon by the two governments.The projects is of a priority nature due to context of the Sixth National Development Plan (SNDP) in which poverty reduction was the Government s core programme.On behalf of the Government, Finance and National Planning Minister Alexander Chikwanda signed the economic and technical cooperation grant and interest-free loan facilities while visiting Vice-Foreign Minister of China Zhai Jun signed for his country in Lusaka.Mr Chikwanda stated that the signing of two monetary facilities was in the spirit of further strengthening the warm and friendly bilateral relations and cooperation that existed between Zambia and China.Government was committed to uplifting the standards of living of the people and the funds acquired would be put to good use to ensure maximum benefits were derived in the fight against poverty said Chikwanda.He Further stated 'Zambia greatly admires the strides made by China in uplifting the standard of living of its people as well as the spectacular advancement in the areas of manufacturing, commerce and trade, infrastructure, information and communication technologies and culture.Mr Chikwanda said the assistance Zambia received from China was a great milestone in helping the Government s industrious quest to fight poverty within the context of the SNDP.He said Zambians were grateful to China for rendering assistance in many other areas of development endeavours. The minister said the construction of the Tanzania Zambia Railway Authority (TAZARA) had stood in as a monumental testimony of generous support from the people of China to Zambians.He said Zambia had also positioned itself to ensure it maximised benefits arising from the 2009 Africa-China summit declaration, where the Chinese government made available US$10 billion to finance a series of projects for Africa within the period 2010 to 2012.We are equally gratified by the decision by the China-Africa Development Fund (CADFUND) to establish a regional office in Zambia with an investment outlay of $1 billion, Mr Chikwanda said.He said Zambians remained appreciative of the enormous assistance from China and the Government was committed to continue strengthening a strong bond of bilateral cooperation between the two countries.Mr Zhai speaking on behalf of the Chinese government, who spoke through an interpreter, said China was impressed with positive strides the Zambian Government was making to eradicate poverty. Although China signed a number of grants, his government would continue to give monetary and various forms of aid to help the Zambia.Al Bawaba.com, Inc.

title: China grants US$40m loan to Tazara [conflict with 2318]
description: Chinese Envoy Commissions 90 Tazara WagonsDistributed by Contify.com361 words15 June 2011China Business NewsATCHBNEnglishCopyright © 2011. Contify.comBeijing, June 15 -- Ministry of Commerce of the People's Republic of China issued the following news release:CHINESE Ambassador to Zambia Zhou Yuxiao has commissioned the newly-acquired 90 wagons by Tanzania Zambia Railway Authority (TAZARA) from China at a cost of US$5 million as part of implementation of a bilateral protocol the Asian country signed two years ago.Speaking in Kapiri Mposhi on Saturday during the flagging off of the wagons that were laden with 1,143 tonnes of copper cathodes destined to the port of Dar-es-Salaam in Tanzania, Mr Zhou said it was his government's hope that the new wagons would help TAZARA expand operations.He said TAZARA was a symbol of the bilateral relations that existed between China and Zambia and pledged his government's support to various sectors of Zambia's economy such as education, construction and health.He said China accepted to construct the railway line because it long valued the friendship between the two countries.Mr Zhou paid tribute to former president Kenneth Kaunda and his counterpart from Tanzania, Julius Nyerere for their efforts in contributing to the construction of TAZARA, whose results had so far been remarkable.Speaking at the same function, TAZARA managing director Akashambatwa Mbikusita-Lewanika said he was confident that the new wagons would impact positively on the operations of the railway firm.Mr Mbikusita-Lewanika said in a speech read for him by TAZARA regional manager for Zambia, Sinonge Masiliso that the wagons, with a capacity of 50 tonnes, were being used to transport copper cathodes and fertiliser.He said the wagons were bought using a $40 million loan from China by the two sharing governments, and reaffirmed TAZARA's commitment to taking good care of them.Meanwhile, Mr Zhou said he was confident that Zambia would hold peaceful elections this year.He said peace was cardinal for any meaningful development and urged Zambians to uphold unity for the country to continue attracting more investments.Source: Ministry of Commerce of the People's Republic of ChinaImages, graphs or charts, if any, have been removedContify.comDocument ATCHBN0020110616e76f00001
donor_agency_count: Tanzania-Zambia Railway Authority (TAZARA), State-Owned Company

title: TAZARA - Boosting TAZARA Operations (Too Late to be a Project)
description: China Boosts Tazara Operations459 words16 March 201201:06 AMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2012 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedMar 16, 2012 (The Times of Zambia/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- CHINA has injected US$66.2 million (K344 billion) in Tanzania-Zambia Railway Authority (TAZARA) to rehabilitate infrastructure and revamp operations.The money would be given in form of a grant amounting to $23.5 million (K123 billion) for the rehabilitation of the railway line and related infrastructure while $42.6 million (K223 billion) would be an interest-free loan to revie the operations.The Chinese-constructed firm jointly owned by Zambia and Tanzania has recently been faced with operational problems between Kapiri Mposhi in Zambia and Dar-es-Salaam in the neighbouring Tanzania.Transport, Works, Supply and Communications Minister Yamfwa Mukanga confirmed to the Times yesterday that the Chinese government had offered to fund the railway firm.The offer would be concluded at a tripartite meeting to be held on March 26, this year.The minister said the tripartite meeting involving Zambia, Tanzania and China would discuss, among other issues, TAZARA's financial problems and the revial of its operations.Mr Mukanga said the special grant and loan agreement were expected to be sealed during the tripartite meeting under the 15th protocol of the TAZARA Financial and Technical cooperation.Last week, more than 1, 600 Tazara workers in Tanzania downed tools to press management and Government to find a permanent solution to financial problems.Management was prompted to suspend the passenger train service and directed that the passenger train from Zambia on Tuesday to Dar-es-Salaam be stopped at Nakonde until the situation in Tanzania normalisedGeneral secretary for TAZARA Workers Union in Tanzania, Erasto Kihwele and General Secretary for the Workers Union of TAZARA in Zambia, Africa M'kandawire had insisted that the firm should suspend passenger train services and concentrate on cargo transportation.Mr Mukanga appealed to TAZARA workers to remain patient while the two holding governments were looking at ways of addressing the problems.'We know that the employees have suffered for a long time and that a lot of things have not been going well at the company but they should be patient,' he said.He said that the two governments were interested in seeing TAZARA become self-sustaining and not always depending on 'handouts' from donors to finance its operations.The minister said the K45 billion which the Zambian Government had recently given the firm would not be the last allocation.He said the Tanzanian government had also committed itself to liquidating the debt owed to retirees.The railway company which had for a long time been faced with a number of challenges is in need of more than $700 million.Challenges include unpaid statutory contributions to National Pensions Scheme Authority and unpaid retirement benefits.All Africa Global MediaDocument AFNWS00020120317e83g0000z
donor_agency_count: Tanzania-Zambia Railway Authority (TAZARA), State-Owned Company

title: 50 luxury cars for independence anniversary (duplicate of 2369)
description: In 2008, China promised 50 luxury cars to Guinea for the 50th anniversary of independence.  The ambassador of China to Guinea announced to the deputies at the end of last week that his government promised to Guinea 50 luxury cars for the 50th anniversary of independence, observed Guineenews at the National Assembly.In addition to the cars, China promised to build a 150-bed modern hospital in Conakry, specifically at Kipe. According to the ambassador, the construction works will begin this year and will be put to use in 2009. 2009.'The hospital will relieve to some extent the physical sufferings and charges of Guineans. China will construct soon three rural schools in the Conakry suburb', he added.We can cite, among the investment of China in Guinea, ENTAG [cigarette manufacturing firm], the Macenta Tea Factory [in southeastern Guinea], the Dabola Groundnut Oil Factory [in south central Guinea], Boffa Sugar and Sugar Cane Factory [in southwestern Guinea], the Kankan Brickyard [in northeastern Guinea], the Bordo (Kankan) Agriculture School, Mamou Agricultural Tool Factory [in southwestern Guinea], the Kaback Water Development Works [in southwestern Nigeria], the Boffa Water Cooperation Project [in southwestern Guinea], the Kindia Agriculture Extension Works [in southwestern Guinea], the People's Palace [in capital], the Sekhoutereya Palace [in capital] and the new RTG House [Guinean Radio-Television], which became today the symbols of Chinese-Guinean friendship.In line with the strengthening of their cooperation, China launched the construction of a 50,000-capacity stadium costing 50m dollars on 18 September 2007. According to the ambassador, the stadium will be the biggest project ever to be built by China in Guinea as a development aid since the beginning of the Chinese-Guinean relations. [Passage omitted].Source: Guineenews website in French 15 May 08a8325366Document BBCAP00020080516e45g001gt

title: Rural school construction- duplicate with 2363
description: China said to build 150-bed hospital, three schools in Guinean capital329 words16 May 200810:48 AMBBC Monitoring AfricaBBCAPEnglish(c) 2008 The British Broadcasting Corporation. All Rights Reserved. No material may be reproduced except with the express permission of The British Broadcasting Corporation.Excerpt from report by Boua Kouyate entitled 'International: China promises 50 luxury cars for the fiftieth independence anniversary of Guinea' published by Guinean newspaper Guineenews website, based in Canada but with editorial team in Guinea, on 15 MayThe ambassador of China to Guinea announced to the deputies at the end of last week that his government promised to Guinea 50 luxury cars for the 50th anniversary of independence, observed Guineenews at the National Assembly.In addition to the cars, China promised to build a 150-bed modern hospital in Conakry, specifically at Kipe. According to the ambassador, the construction works will begin this year and will be put to use in 2009. 2009.'The hospital will relieve to some extent the physical sufferings and charges of Guineans. style='BACKGROUND-COLOR:#FFFF00'>China will construct soon three rural schools in the Conakry suburb', he added.We can cite, among the investment of China in Guinea, ENTAG [cigarette manufacturing firm], the Macenta Tea Factory [in southeastern Guinea], the Dabola Groundnut Oil Factory [in south central Guinea], Boffa Sugar and Sugar Cane Factory [in southwestern Guinea], the Kankan Brickyard [in northeastern Guinea], the Bordo (Kankan) Agriculture School, Mamou Agricultural Tool Factory [in southwestern Guinea], the Kaback Water Development Works [in southwestern Nigeria], the Boffa Water Cooperation Project [in southwestern Guinea], the Kindia Agriculture Extension Works [in southwestern Guinea], the People's Palace [in capital], the Sekhoutereya Palace [in capital] and the new RTG House [Guinean Radio-Television], which became today the symbols of Chinese-Guinean friendship.In line with the strengthening of their cooperation, China launched the construction of a 50,000-capacity stadium costing 50m dollars on 18 September 2007. According to the ambassador, the stadium will be the biggest project ever to be built by China in Guinea as a development aid since the beginning of the Chinese-Guinean relations. [Passage omitted].Source: Guineenews website in French 15 May 08a8325366Document BBCAP00020080516e45g001gt

title: China to fund second bridge over Niger river into Niamey (Duplicate of 135)
description: 'China will fund the construction of a second bridge into Niamey over the Niger, Africa's third longest river, a Niger diplomatic source said Tuesday.China has granted 20 million yuans (two million euros, 2,5 million dollars) and an interest-free loan of 30 million yuans to finance the project.It will send experts to Niger to conduct feasibility studies on the building of another bridge to ease congestion on JF Kennedy memorial bridge, built more than 30 years ago.Kennedy Bridge, built by the United States in the 1970s, is the only route to the capital Niamey across the river.The often congested 710-metre (775 yards) long bridge provides landlocked Niger's only access from Niamey to the sea via Ghana and Benin.Niger established diplomatic ties with Beijing in 1960, but broke them in 1994 for three years when it recognised the Taiwan.The bridge financing deal was concluded on July 18 during a visit to Beijing by Niger Foreign Minister Aichatou Mindaoudou.The Niger river is the continent's third longest after the Nile and the Congo and runs through five west African countries, Guinea, Mali, Niger, Benin and Nigeria. '218 words7 November 200703:22 PMBBC Monitoring Asia PacificBBCAPPEnglish(c) 2007 The British Broadcasting Corporation. All Rights Reserved. No material may be reproduced except with the express permission of The British Broadcasting Corporation.Text of report in English by official Chinese news agency Xinhua (New China News Agency)Niamey, 7 Nov. (Xinhua) - Niger and Chinese governments have signed an economic and technical cooperation agreement worth 40 million yuan (around 5.3 million US dollars).The agreement was signed Tuesday by the Niger Foreign Affairs and Cooperation Minister Aichatou Mindaoudou and Chinese Assistant Foreign Minister Zhai Jun, who is currently visiting Niger.The financial assistance will be used for the construction of two rural schools and the rehabilitation of General Seyni Kountche Stadium, constructed by China in the 1980s.During the signing ceremony, Mindaoudou said 'as in the past, the Chinese government has once again decided to implement part of the measures announced by President Hu Jintao during the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation held in Beijing last year, by undertaking three important projects for the benefits of our country and people.'The Chinese assistant foreign minister said his visit to Niger falls within the framework of strengthening cooperation ties between China and Niger.On Monday, he took part in a foundation laying ceremony for the construction of a second bridge over River Niger in Niamey financed by China.Source: Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in English 1744 gmt 7 Nov 07a736d30cDocument BBCAPP0020071107e3b70048t213 words9 November 2007Global Insight Daily AnalysisWDANEnglishCopyright 2007, Global Insight Limited. All Rights Reserved.Niger is to receive a 27.3 million euro (US$ 34.8 million) loan from China for the construction of a second bridge over the River Niger, according to Agence France-Presse (AFP). Additionally, in fulfilment of pledges made at last year's Forum on China-Africa Co-operation, Niger and China have signed a US$5.3-million economic and technical co-operation agreement, according to an African Press Agency (APA) report. The money will be used for the construction of two rural schools and rehabilitation of the General Seyni Kountouch stadium. The first, and at present only, Nigerien bridge across the River Niger was built in 1972 with U.S. assistance.Significance: Construction of the new bridge is expected to be completed by mid-2011 and it is hoped that congestion on Niger's first and only bridge across the river will be reduced as a result. The investment is one of China's largest in the sub-region, according to Nigerien Minister for Equipment Lamido Harouna.ChineseNigerien relations have been complicated of late by violence in the north of the country. One Chinese expatriate uranium mining worker was briefly kidnapped by the Tuareg insurgent movement earlier this year.Document WDAN000020071109e3b90002o

title: Wildcat Oil Wells (Duplicate of 137)
description: 'China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) will drill two wildcats this year on its Tenere block in landlocked Niger using a Great Wall Drilling rig to be sent from Tanjin via Cotonou before the end of January, writes Barry Morgan.Great Wall is a subsidiary of operator CNPC, which partners TG World Energy on Tenere.Subsurface target depths for the respective probes range from 3671 to 4035 metres in the T-1 and T-10 prospects in the West Fachi Graben.The drilling phase will start after May and last through the end of 2006. About $44 million is budgeted for the two wells along with 1000 kilometres of extra 2D seismic and 150 square kilometres of 3D in the event of a find.This is additional to the $26 million spent for acquiring 2569 kilometres of 2D seismic and efforts to reprocess older Tenere seismic started in 2005. About 500 kilometres remains to be shot in the southern portion of the block from last year's seismic programme.The West Fachi wells will test deeper, secondary and tertiary targets as well as primary targets at shallower depths such as the zone that yielded discoveries for ExxonMobil and Petronas of more than 350 million barrels of oil equivalent. A third well is planned for early 2007CNPC holds an 80% interest in Tenere leaving TG World with a 20% carried interest. '

title: Humanitarian aid for Darfur
description: On 8 December, 2007, Sudan's commissioner for humanitarian aid, Hasabu Muhammad Abd-al-Rahman, and the Chinese ambassador to Sudan, Li Chengwen, signed an agreement for China to offer Sudan humanitarian aid worth 600 million CNY for Darfur. The aid includes tents, mobile schools and equipment for water and health projects. The current status and start and end dates of the project are unknown.STAFF_NOTES: This project is marked as suspicious primarily because of the only source is a Sudanese radio station.
sector: Humanitarian and Disaster Relief and Preparation

title: Palace of Congress (Built 3 decades ago; Not a Project)
description: 7 November 200303:22 AMAssociated Press NewswiresAPRSEnglish(c) 2003. The Associated Press. All Rights Reserved.LOME, Togo (AP) - As followers drummed and danced, Togo President Gnassingbe Eyadema laid the corner stone for a new multimillion-dollar presidential palace being built by the Chinese for the poor west African nation.Telecommunications Minister Faure Gnassingbe -- the president's son -- called the project 'a priority for Togo,' saying it would give the nation a palace 'befitting the dignity and status of a modern presidency.'Chinese diplomats and Togo leaders at Thursday's ceremony declined to give an exact price.The palace is the latest high-profile gift from the Chinese as they vie across Africa and much of the developing world for diplomatic recognition, in competition with Taiwan.Chinese also are competing with the West for oil, minerals and other resources in many West African nations.Other Chinese-built landmarks for Togo include a recently constructed US$36 million sports stadium, a hospital, and the Palace of Congress.Laying the cornerstone, Eyadema declared, 'The people of Togo are happy to celebrate with you the glory of Sino-Togolese friendship.'Eyadema took power in 1967 after Africa's first post-colonial coup, and stands today as Africa's longest-ruling leader.International rights organizations accuse his regime of suppressing the opposition and charge him with widespread rights abuses, and most aid to the tiny country remains frozen.A nation dependent mostly on commercial and subsistence agriculture, Togo has more than one-third of its 5.4 million people living in poverty. With development and economic reform stalled, roads and other infrastructure are crumbling.Opposition leaders condemned the mansion project.'What Togo needs is a solid foundation for the country's move toward multiparty democracy,' said Cornelius Aidam, vice president of the Convergence Pan African Patriotic Party. 'Not a new presidential palace.'eg-ek

title: Interest-free loan- duplicate with 13260
description: In 2010, China agreed to support the Guinean government by providing an interest-free loan worth more than 21 billion Guinean francs to support development efforts. It is unclear how the funds will be used.

title: Establishment of an agricultural center (Duplicate)
description: Sudan and China today signed eight agreements covering such fields as economic and technological cooperation, finance, agriculture and public health; in presence of Ali Osman Mohamed Taha, Vice-President and Xi Jinping Chinese Vice-President.Taha arrived in Beijing on Monday to start his third China trip. He visited China in March 1996 and March 2001.According to the signed agreements China will extend two grants of financial assistance to the Sudanese Government in addition to a interest-free loan, the establishment of an agricultural centre in state of Gedaref, eastern Sudan and to send Chinese agricultural experts to Sudan.The parties agreed to establish a hospital in Al-Damazin, Blue Nile state funded by the Chinese side, besides the signing of the memorandum of understanding on the migrations procedures of Chinese workers in Sudan.The agreements were signed by Awad Ahmed al-Jaz the Sudanese minister of finance and national economy and Chinese Minister of Trade Shi Quangsheng.While the protocol of agricultural cooperation between Sudan and China was signed by al-Zubayr Bashir Taha, Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Chinese Minister of Agriculture Sun Zhengcai.The vice-president Taha invited Chinese businessmen to invest in his country saying that Sudan enjoys broad possibilities for investment and agriculture besides the oil projects and infrastructure like dams, roads, bridges, electricity, industrial and various commercial activities especially in Communications and engineering sectors.Source: Sudan Tribune website, Paris in English 10 Jun 08

title: Joint-Business Council (Not a project)
description: The Tripoli Post155 words10 August 2010The Tripoli PostTRIPOSEnglish© 2010 - The Tripoli Post. Provided by Syndigate.info, an Albawaba.com Company All Rights Reserved.Libyan and Chinese business people signed on Wednesday an agreement to establish a joint Libyan-Chinese Business Council.The agreement is between the China Council for the Promotion of International Trade and the Libyan Businessmen Council.Mr. Mohamed Hassan Beck, a member of the Libyan Businessmen Council, signed on behalf of the Libyan side, and Mr. and Mr. Jan Lee, the chairman of the Chinese Business council, signed on behalf of the Chinese side.The Chinese businessmen underlined their desire to deal with the Libyan Council and to exchange commercial and economic information, organizing trade missions and the participation on investment and trade between both countries.Dr. Abdulhafez Zlitni , Secretary of GPC for planning and finance, and Mr. Mohamed siyala, undersecretary of GPC for foreign affairs attended the signing of the agreement as they were present at the seventh session of the Libyan- Chinese Joint Commission.Document TRIPOS0020100815e68a00005

title: N$720 million is a concessional credit line (duplicate of 18237)
description: China offered Namibia a NAD 720 million line of credit in February 2007 to be used for investments to be determined by the Namibian government, though it was reported later that year that only NAD 60 million had actually been tapped into in the form of either grants or interest-free loans.China Offers Country N$1.7 Billion by Brigitte Weidlich 500 words 7 February 2007 02:16 PMAll Africa AFNWS English (c) 2007 AllAfrica, All Rights Reserved Feb 07, 2007 (The Namibian/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- CHINA has offered Government one billion Namibian dollars as a concessional loan over a three-year period until 2010, plus another N$720 million as a credit line, The Namibian established yesterday. The offer was made on Monday during bilateral talks shortly before Chinese President Hu Jintao wrapped up his brief visit of barely 23 hours to Namibia yesterday morning. After talks with Namibian President Hifikepunye Pohamba on Monday, a new grant and an interest-free loan agreement worth N$60 million were signed at a brief public signing ceremony. The state visit culminated with a banquet held in honour of Hu and his 130-member delegation. The Permanent Secretary in the Finance Ministry confirmed the huge amount yesterday afternoon. 'The N$1 billion is in the form of a concessional loan, which means that Namibia can use those funds on projects it will decide on,' Calle Schlettwein told The Namibian. 'The second offer of US$ 00 million (about N$720 million) is a concessional credit line. This will enable our Government to acquire goods, services and equipment from China,' Schlettwein added. He said Government still had to decide whether it would accept the offer. 'We will then have to decide on which projects we will use those funds and then negotiate the loan terms,' he explained. After Hu's departure, the two countries issued a joint communique, but the loan offer was not mentioned. Namibia and China expressed their satisfaction with the strong ties that exist between them as well as political trust and good co-operation. 'Both heads of state recognised the achievements made in trade and agreed to work together to strengthen co-operation in mining, agriculture, tourism, manufacturing and human resources development,' the communique stated. Both countries now have four agreements in place: trade and economic co-operation, establishing a joint commission on trade and economic co-operation, a reciprocal treaty for the protection of trade and investments for both Chinese and Namibian businesspeople in China and Namibia. The fourth agreement was signed in Beijing last November during the Forum for China-Africa Co-operation (Focac). The Namibia Investment Centre and a similar institution in China, the China investment Promotion Agency (CIPA), agreed to promote and facilitate investment between the two countries. After Hu left, some 35 Chinese businesspeople who are part of his official delegation remained behind in Windhoek for a business presentation on Namibia as an investment destination. It was organised by the Namibia Investment Centre and the Ministry of Trade and Industry and some 50 Namibian captains of industry attended the session. Minister Immanuel Ngatjizeko called on the Chinese executives to form joint ventures with their Namibian counterparts and to invest in local value addition of the country's raw materials. 'It is imperative that during all your deliberations and interactions, value addition should become your central strategy of engagement,' Ngatjizeko urged. Document AFNWS00020070207e327000kb

title: Chinese Company to Build Airport in Sudan (Not a project)
description: 29 April 2011Sourcing Hardware HTSOHW English Copyright 2011. Bracecorp Publications Pt. Ltd. India, April 29 -- A $1.2 billion construction contract for a new airport in the Sudanese capital Khartoum has been signed by a stateowned Chinese company. The new airport will have a runway long enough for the giant Airbus A380, says China Communications Construction Company, and added that the new airport will strengthen Sudan's international ties, which have suffered due to sanctions and a poor aviation safety record.China is Sudan' biggest investor, with most of its investment in the oil sector. Sudan, being listed as a state sponsor of terrorism by the US, is banned from using the US currency for trade, thus making it diffi cult for international companies such as airlines to conduct business there.However, the US has hinted that it may lift sanctions if the Sudanese government lets the oil-rich south Sudan live peacefully. On the other hand, Sudan's President Omar al-Bashir has accepted the result of last month's referendum on independence for the south, in which some 99% of voters chose to secede.Published by HT Syndication with permission from Sourcing Hardware.
donor_agency_count: China Communications Construction Company (CCCC), State-Owned Company
recipient_agencies: China Communications Construction Company (CCCC), State-Owned Company

title: China gives loan to Support Agricultural Projects Inactive
description: China lends Mozambique another R418.6-m103 words4 March 2009FT NowFTNOWEnglish(c) 2009 Now Media (Pty) Ltd. All Rights Reserved.The Mozambiquan and Chinese governments signed three agreements in Maputo, under which China is to provide a total of R418.6-million in loan and grant finance. News agency AIM reports that the largest sum is a loan of R224.2-m for the fourth funding phase in the construction of Mozambique's new national sports stadium. A second loan, for R183.6-m, is to support agricultural projects in the Zambezi Valley, while the third agreement is for a grant of R30.6-m to be used in basic development sectors yet to be identified.

title: Grant for development projects (Duplicate)
description: 25 October 2011 05:05 AMAll Africa AFNWS English (c) 2011 AllAfrica, All Rights Reserved Juba, Oct 25, 2011 (Government of South Sudan/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- The government of the Peoples' Republic of China today donated 200 million Renminbi (the official Chinese currency abbreviated as RMB) to support agriculture, education, health and water supply projects in the Republic of South Sudan.The donation was announced this morning by the Chinese ambassador in Juba Hon Li Zhiguo during a meeting he held with the minister for Information and Broadcasting Hon Dr Barnaba Marial Benjamin. The ambassador said that China will continue to support development in the new country now and into the future.The ambassador also announced that the Chinese government will soon send Chinese international radio stations to South Sudan to help develop the sector and share experiences and skills with the South Sudanese media fraternity. He also announced that the Chinese peacekeepers in South Sudan will remain in the country until the nascent peace is stabilized.He expressed hope that the bilateral relations between the two countries will be strengthened for the mutual benefit of their peoples. He explained that his government is in constant touch with their South Sudanese counterparts so as to identify the areas and frameworks of partnership. He said Chinese companies will come to South Sudan as soon as these modalities are worked out.On his part, Dr Marial expressed South Sudan's gratitude for the support of China and explained that the government is keen to strengthen its bilateral links with the Asian country. 'We want you to look comprehensively in the areas of investment as well as education, especially university education, which is constantly facing infrastructural and personnel challenges', he said.Meanwhile in another event Dr Marial also hosted the former Prime Minister of Angola Mr. Lopo do Nascimento. Mr Nascimento announced that SONANGO, the Angolan national oil company will soon invest in South Sudan.Dr Marial welcomed the announcement and said that South Sudan stands to benefit greatly from the experience of such renowned companies.

title: Chinese firm wins contract for Uganda drainage system (Not a project)
description: Chinese firm wins contract for Uganda drainage system 157 words 25 July 2000 07:11 AM Japan Economic Newswire KYODO English Copyright Kyodo News International Inc. 2000 KAMPALA, July 25 -- China Civil Engineering Corp. has signed a $24 million deal with the Kampala City Council to construct an 11.5-kilometer drainage channel in Uganda's capital city, officials said Tuesday. The Chinese engineering firm scooped the contract after it bid $11.5 million among 24 international companies that bid for the contract. The two-year project will begin in September and will cover rehabilitation and expansion of the channel. The project is aimed at preventing the frequent flooding that occurs in the city. It constitutes the main water drainage system for the city, while 95% of the central urban area drains into the channel. The existing channel will be widened from an average maximum width of 4 meters to about 18 meters. The World Bank gave Uganda a loan of $22.38 million for the city project, while the Uganda government contributed $2.5 million.
recipient_agencies: China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation (CCECC), State-Owned Company

title: Study of proposed coal-to-liquids plants
description: CHINA: Joint venture project feasibility study regarding construction of proposed $6,000,000,000 coal-to-liquids (CTL) plants, SASOL LTD. [South Africa], SHENHUA COAL LIQUEFACTION CORP.   NINGXIA COAL [China] - Order #: 114504. 2273 words 1 November 2004 WWP-Report on Oil, Gas   Petrochemicals in the Developing World ESOG 0 Volume 13; Issue 11 English Copyright 2004 Gale Group Inc. All rights reserved. Project Oerview: China, that is rich in coal resources, is presently keen on using coal-to-liquid (CTL) plants as a way of controlling its rising import costs of crude oil. As a result, a Sino/South African joint venture was recently established in view of looking into the feasibility of building 2 CTL plants in China. The partners in the planned undertaking include SASOL LTD. of South Africa in addition to the local SHENHUA COAL LIQUEFACTION CORP. and NINGXIA COAL. Construction plans under consideration call for building units based on the CTL technology used at SASOL's 155 000 barrel per day (b/d) plant at Secunda, South Africa. These are expected to cost $3,000,000,000 each to build. In so doing, production output is expected to amount to around 80 000 b/d of petroleum fuels and chemicals. SASOL employs a total workforce of approximately 31,000 and operates as a holding company. The group is engaged in the mining and distribution of coal as well as being acknowledged to be a world leader in the conversion of coal to oil and gas. In addition, it is involved in the production of petrochemicals, plastics, fertilizers and mining explosives.
