title: China writes off &17m debt (Duplicate)
description: China Writes Off $17m Debt by Sylvia Juuko 231 words 21 September 2007 04:06 AM All Africa AFNWS English (c) 2007 AllAfrica, All Rights Reserved Kampala, Sep 21, 2007 (New Vision/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- CHINA has waived Uganda's $17m (sh30b) debt and promised to do more to boost economic ties with Uganda. China's assistant minister for commerce, Fu Ziying, made the announcement during the signing of five protocols on economic and technical cooperation with finance minister, Dr. Ezra Suruma. The agreements signed included; the protocol on cancellation of the $17m debt, an agreement to provide a grant of $6.8m (sh12b) and a letter of exchange for the construction of a government office block. Other protocols signed were for the construction of two rural schools and a hospital. He said China had granted tariff-free and quota-free treatment to more than 400 commodities from Uganda, while coffee was granted preferential treatment. Ziying said China would intensify efforts to convince more Chinese companies to invest in Uganda. 'About 20 years ago, Chinese enterprises were like the Ugandan small and medium enterprises, lacking knowledge on expanding to the international market. We have experience on trade promotion. In future under a training programme, we can provide specific training on exploring international markets for SMEs,' Ziying said. Chinese president Hu Jintao hosted Africans leaders at an unprecedented summit in Beijing in November last year and offered billions of dollars in loans, aid and debt write-offs.

title: Concessional loan to rehabilitate railway lines (likely a duplicate of 1226)
description: In November of 2005, China signed an agreement to provide a 206 million Namibian dollar loan for the rehabilitation of railway lines across Namibia.

title: Chinese youth volunteers to be sent to Tunisia (Duplicate of 11112)
description: Chinese advisory body chief meets Tunisian prime minister   741 words18 April 200706:54 AMBBC Monitoring Asia PacificBBCAPPEnglish(c) 2007 The British Broadcasting Corporation. All Rights Reserved. No material may be reproduced except with the express permission of The British Broadcasting Corporation.   Text of report by official Chinese news agency Xinhua (New China News Agency)   [By reporter Luo Hui: 'Jia Qinglin Meets Tunisian Prime Minister Ghannouchi']   Tunis, 17 Apr (Xinhua) - Jia Qinglin, chairman of the National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, met Tunisian Prime Minister Mohamed Ghannouchi in Tunis on 17 April. Jia Qinglin conveyed Premier Wen Jiabao's sincere regards and good wishes to Mohamed Ghannouchi. Mohamed Ghannouchi expressed his thanks and asked Jia Qinglin to convey his warm regards and sincere wishes to Wen Jiabao.   Jia Qinglin said: China-Tunisia relations have achieved significant progress in recent years. Their economic and trade cooperation has increased for several consecutive years. Bilateral trade volume topped 400m dollars last year, an increase of 20 per cent over the same period of the previous year. Energy cooperation has made new headway. Cooperation in the fields of telecommunications, household appliances, high technology, and tourism has maintained a development momentum. The Chinese side is willing to make efforts with the Tunisian side to further widen mutually beneficial cooperation and constantly enhance the development level of the two countries' relations.   Jia Qinglin said: The economies of China and Tunisia are strongly complementary to each other, have great cooperation potential, and enjoy a broad prospect. To deepen mutually beneficial cooperation, achieve common development, and actively implement the results of the Beijing Summit of the China-Africa Cooperation Forum, we hope that both sides will make efforts in the following aspects: First, expanding bilateral trade and jointly promoting a balanced trade development. Second, increasing mutual investment, supporting each own country's competitive and reputable enterprises in making investing in the opposite country to build businesses. There are nine Chinese entrepreneurs accompanying my current visit. Hopefully, both sides will seize this opportunity to establish direct links and cooperation channels so as to add vitality to the two countries' economic and trade cooperation. Third, actively exploring cooperation in tourism, drawing from each other's strong points, and turning cooperation potentials into real productive forces that promote both sides' economic development.   Mohamed Ghannouchi said: Both Tunisia and China cherish a good political intention of developing friendly relations. The two countries' cooperation in various fields has achieved positive progress. The Tunisian side agrees with the Chinese side's proposal on deepening the two countries' economic and trade cooperation and is willing to strengthen cooperation with the Chinese side in the economic, trade, investment, and tourism fields and promote the two countries' economic and trade relations towards sustained and stable development. The Tunisian side welcomes more Chinese enterprises to open up markets in Tunisia and invest in new fields, so as to promote the two countries' common development. The positive results of the Beijing Summit of the China-Africa Cooperation Forum demonstrate the intention and determination of China and African countries in achieving common development. The Tunisian side is willing to work with the Chinese side to implement the results of the Beijing summit.   After the meeting, Jia Qinglin and Mohamed Ghannouchi jointly attended the signing ceremony of five bilateral cooperation documents, including a China-Tunisia economic and technological cooperation agreement and an exchange document on China sending young volunteers to Tunisia.   On the same day, Jia Qinglin went to Sousse Province for a tour of the social and economic development situation there, during which he also met Sousse Governor Raghubi [name as transliterated].   Also on the same day, Jia Qinglin met in his hotel some members of the Chinese medical team in Tunisia and listened to a report on their work by the team. He praised all the team members for their superb medical skills and lofty spirit of healing the wounded and rescuing the dying, making contributions to the development of China-Africa and China-Tunisia relations through hard work, building a bridge for China-Tunisia and China-Africa friendship, and winning glory for the country. On behalf of the CCP Central Committee, the State Council, and the people of the entire country, Jia Qinglin expressed sincere regards, heartfelt thanks, and highest respect to them; encouraged them to explore new perspectives for foreign-oriented medical work; and make greater contributions to enhancing China-Tunisia and China-Africa friendship. Jia Qinglin also met representatives of Chinese Embassy personnel, Chinese institutions, overseas Chinese, and Chinese nationals in Tunisia.   Source: Xinhua news agency domestic service, Beijing, in Chinese 1830 gmt 17 Apr 07   a62aad7eDocument BBCAPP0020070418e34i001ur

title: Assistance for power line construction
description: In 2006, the state-owned Chinese National Corporation for the Construction and Import and Export of Agricultural Machinery (CAMC) met with the State House of Namibia and NamPower regarding assistance with construction of a power line from Zambia. The 400 mW of electricity will be imported via the Caprivi line from Zambia by 2009. The chief technical adviser of NamPower, Rainer Jagau, confirmed this. However, he stressed that, as was the case with other offers from various places, NamPower would carefully compare the proposals with conditions elsewhere on the open market. According to Mr Jagau it is however not a settled thing that CAMC would be a partner in the Caprivi project. The link of northern Namibia over Sesheke and Livingstone to the power network of the Zambia Electricity Supply Corporation [Zesco] will according to reports cost about 3 billion Namibian dollars. The ability to supplement Namibia's power demands on a large scale from this quarter depends amongst others on upgrading in Zambia, which has been topping the agenda of Zesco for the past years.According to Mr Jagau the infrastructure for the Caprivi line should be completed by 2009. He therefore stressed that NamPower's strategy for the next years, like in South Africa and Zambia, would be to economize.
donor_agency: China National Construction & Agricultural Machinery Import & Export Corporation (CAMC), State-Owned Company
donor_agency_count: NamPower, State-Owned Company
recipient_agencies: China National Construction & Agricultural Machinery Import & Export Corporation (CAMC), State-Owned Company
verified: NamPower, State-Owned Company

title: Interest free loan of RMB 30 million (duplicate)
description: What new projects are envisaged under this programme?In February this year, President Hu Jintao announced that China would provide Namibia with a grant of Yuan RMB30 million (US$1 = 7.75 Yuan RMB), an interest-free loan of RMB30 million, a preferential loan of RMB1 billion, and US$100 million as Preferential Buyer's Credit. He also announced that by utilising the surplus of grant, China would aid Namibia to build two rural primary schools - one with 100 to 150 hospital beds.Currently, the two governments are negotiating how and on what to utilize the grants and loans provided. The projects prioritised by the Namibian side are power transmission and transformation, railway and road construction, the Walvis Bay port terminal expansion, the Green Scheme and aquaculture development.//Windhoek, Jan 28, 2008 (The Namibian/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- Namibia and China signed a grant agreement in Windhoek on Friday detailing the N$1 billion grant promised by that country a year ago during a visit of the Chinese head of state to Namibia.'The N$1 billion will be used for social projects like the agricultural Green Scheme and to complete the remaining section of the northern railway,' said Helmut Angula, Director General of the National Planning Commission.'The sum of N$700 million also granted will be used as concessional loans for State-owned agencies.' Another N$20 million will go to two rural schools at Tsumkwe and Omuthiya, where combined secondary schools exist.They will be upgraded to full secondary schools until Grade 12 and equipped accordingly. The Tsumkwe school is in a pitifully dilapidated state due to neglect. 'Part of the funds will also be used to support State hospitals,' said Ren Xiaoping, the new Chinese Ambassador to Namibia.'We also signed for the dispatch of a Chinese expert team to Namibia to conduct a feasibility study on the agricultural project of Ndonga Linea in the Kavango Region,' Angula said.//Windhoek, Jan 28, 2008 (New Era/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- The Chinese Government gave the Namibian Government a grant of RMB Yuan 20 million to build two rural schools in the Omuthiya and Tsumkwe areas.The Namibian Government has chosen the localities for the schools, with the Chinese completing the design of the two schools. The new Chinese Ambassador to Namibia, Ren Xiaoping, said her government would also give a RMB Yuan 30 million interest-free loan to its Namibian counterpart to go towards specific projects still to be discussed.The Chinese will similarly give the Namibian Government a N$1 billion preferential loan, and extend a US$100 million credit line to the Government's commercial agencies. Signing the agreement on behalf of the Namibian Government on Friday, National Planning Commission Director Helmuth Angula said some of the money would go towards the building of a rural hospital with a capacity of 60 beds. Other projects likely to benefit from the cooperation are the irrigation project at the National Youth Development Centre of the National Youth Council and the completion of the northern railway line.The two governments also signed exchange letters that deal with the dispatch of a Chinese expert team to Namibia to conduct a feasibility study on the Agricultural Project of Ndonga Linena in the Kavango Region.

title: Scholarships to Namibian students
description: Chinese benefaction to Namibia in particular held steadfast on Monday when President Hu Jintao announced a N$1-billion soft loan and also offered N$60 million in the form of an interest-free loan, a grant and dozens of scholarships.Hu made the announcement in Windhoek during the fifth leg of his marathon tour of eight African countries some of which have received substantial sums of money in aid while in the same vein benefiting from debt-cancellation from the Asian giant.Hu said during talks with President Hifikepunye Pohamba that China would further avail US$100 million in buyers' credit and build youth-training centres in Namibia.Because Namibia is among the few African countries officially designated a tourism destination by the Chinese government, some of the money would go towards boosting its market share of the rapidly expanding Chinese tourism industry, particularly group tours.During the official talks on Monday that preceded the signing ceremony for the soft loans and other bilateral aid, Pohamba told his counterpart that Namibia has numerous opportunities for investment in the fields of agriculture, tourism, aquaculture, mining, energy, technology and infrastructure and human development.'In this regard, we are inviting Chinese entrepreneurs to come and form joint ventures and other business partnerships with their Namibian counterparts for the mutual benefit of both countries,' Pohamba said at the meeting held with Hu at a local hotel.He assured Chinese investors that they have nothing to fear because Namibia offers a conducive business environment in line with the Reciprocal Treaty on the Promotion and Protection of Investment signed by the two nations.China's tremendous economic and social growth, elevating it to a global economic powerhouse, was also commended by President Pohamba who said Namibia 'would like to emulate' the Asian nation's successes and learn from 'your tremendous experience'.'Namibia needs partners in the promotion and realization of industrial development, investment and local value addition which are all critical for the achievement of our national development goals as set out in our National Development Plans and Vision 2030,' the Head of State said at a meeting that included several cabinet ministers.He said the recent Beijing Summit of the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation reached common ground on major international political and economic issues, especially on the reform of the United Nations and the maintenance of international peace and security.'Namibia supports the China-Africa policy, which is based on peaceful co-existence and anchored on the values of sincerity, equality and mutual common development,' he said.And Namibia being a member of the Troika of the SADC Organ on Politics, Defence and Security, shall continue to support regional efforts aimed at conflict prevention.And equally important Pohamba reaffirmed his government's full support 'for the one-China policy and to reiterate our position that Taiwan is an integral part of China.'Hu said the cooperation between Namibia and China has been growing steadfastly in the fields of politics, economics, education, public health and culture.Since taking office in March 2005, Pohamba has actively promoted bilateral ties with China, and according to the news agency AP, trade between the two nations in the first 11 months of 2006 amounted to US$240 million, an increase of 103 percent from 2005.Hu, whose 130-strong delegation included his wife Liu Yongqing and several senior ministers and high-ranking officials, left yesterday morning for South Africa.//CHINA has offered Government one billion Namibian dollars as a concessional loan over a three-year period until 2010, plus another N$720 million as a credit line, The Namibian established yesterday.The offer was made on Monday during bilateral talks shortly before Chinese President Hu Jintao wrapped up his brief visit of barely 23 hours to Namibia yesterday morning.After talks with Namibian President Hifikepunye Pohamba on Monday, a new grant and an interest-free loan agreement worth N$60 million were signed at a brief public signing ceremony.The state visit culminated with a banquet held in honour of Hu and his 130-member delegation.The Permanent Secretary in the Finance Ministry confirmed the huge amount yesterday afternoon.'The N$1 billion is in the form of a concessional loan, which means that Namibia can use those funds on projects it will decide on,' Calle Schlettwein told The Namibian.'The second offer of US$ 00 million (about N$720 million) is a concessional credit line.This will enable our Government to acquire goods, services and equipment from China,' Schlettwein added.He said Government still had to decide whether it would accept the offer.'We will then have to decide on which projects we will use those funds and then negotiate the loan terms,' he explained.After Hu's departure, the two countries issued a joint communique, but the loan offer was not mentioned.Namibia and China expressed their satisfaction with the strong ties that exist between them as well as political trust and good co-operation.'Both heads of state recognised the achievements made in trade and agreed to work together to strengthen co-operation in mining, agriculture, tourism, manufacturing and human resources development,' the communique stated.Both countries now have four agreements in place: trade and economic co-operation, establishing a joint commission on trade and economic co-operation, a reciprocal treaty for the protection of trade and investments for both Chinese and Namibian businesspeople in China and Namibia.The fourth agreement was signed in Beijing last November during the Forum for China-Africa Co-operation (Focac).The Namibia Investment Centre and a similar institution in China, the China investment Promotion Agency (CIPA), agreed to promote and facilitate investment between the two countries.After Hu left, some 35 Chinese businesspeople who are part of his official delegation remained behind in Windhoek for a business presentation on Namibia as an investment destination.It was organised by the Namibia Investment Centre and the Ministry of Trade and Industry and some 50 Namibian captains of industry attended the session.Minister Immanuel Ngatjizeko called on the Chinese executives to form joint ventures with their Namibian counterparts and to invest in local value addition of the country's raw materials.'It is imperative that during all your deliberations and interactions, value addition should become your central strategy of engagement,' Ngatjizeko urged.//Mar 27, 2007 (The Namibian/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) --GOVERNMENT will engage a Chinese software company to install an electronic management system for the public service.Cabinet approved that the Office of the Prime Minister could secure funding under a concessional loan agreement signed last month between China and Namibia during the state visit of Chinese president Hu Jintao for the implementation of an Electronic Documentation and Records Management System (EDRMS) across the public service.This is viewed as a critical project in terms of existing e-governance policy directives.China offered over N$1 billion as a loan for projects to be identified by Namibia.The EDRMS project team evaluated various appropriate software solutions and found that the system offered by Chinese outfit CA-China SS Software Technology would be best suited for the requirements of the Namibian public service.'The system is not only government user friendly, but also offers easy-to-use interfaces and robust application software that will link up with already familiar public service platforms to ensure records and archival compliance,' Information Minister Netumbo Nandi-Ndaitwah told reporters last week.Cabinet therefore endorsed the EDRMS under the auspices of the Office of the Prime Minister on condition that it complies with tender procedures.Cabinet instructed the Office of the Prime Minister, the Ministry of Finance and the National Planning Commission to discuss the conditions, terms, modality of accessing the preferential loan and credit facility to finance the EDRMS and other priority projects in Namibia with the Chinese Government.Cabinet also granted approval for the arrangement of the grant and the use of the concessional loans for the EDRMS project by the Export-Import Bank of China, subject to concurrence by the Chinese Government.The company CA-CSS is a joint venture formed by New York-based commercial software associates (CA) and China National Computer Software   Technology Service Corporation (CS S).The primary goal of the joint venture was to explore the huge potential presented by the Chinese software market by leveraging the resources and expertise from both parties.The company's head office is in Beijing, China.//Bilateral trade aside, the visit to Namibia in 2007 of Chinese President Hu Jintao during his historic tour of several African countries, resulted in China offering Namibia concessional loans amounting to RMB1 billion. And it also generously extended a preferential line of credit that is interest-free to the tune of US$100 million.From the concessional loan, an amount of RMB41 million was used for the procurement of software and for the implementation of the e-governance project for Namibia, while RMB300 million was used for the procurement of X-ray equipment from China.RMB645 million from the concessional loan funded three developmental projects including for the implementation of one of the phases of the Northern Railway Line as well as the upgrading of the Oshakati State Hospital in northern Namibia, which she noted: 'was very run down and needed to be upgraded'.Part of these funds was used to give a facelift and expansion of the Namibian Broadcasting Corporation (NBC), whose facilities were built during the colonial era.'The Namibian side is satisfied with the implementation of these projects,' she said.She said since her deployment as Chinese Ambassador to Namibia, she has worked tirelessly to ensure that the eight areas of cooperation measures promised by President Hu Jintao at the China Africa Summit held in Beijing in 2006 such as the provision of full support to African countries, that such as assistance to rural schools and hospitals are fulfilled.'Since I came to Namibia, I have been working very hard to implement the eight measures promised by President Hu Jintao at the China-Africa Beijing Summit. Since my arrival, my job was to consolidate different relations and to further the friendship and areas of cooperation. Since my arrival, our mutual trust has grown,' she said.The eight measures announced by the Chinese president included the doubling of grant assistance and providing US$3 billion soft loans and US$2 billion preferential buyer's credit in three years setting up a China-Africa development fund which will be injected with US$5 billion to encourage Chinese companies to invest in Africa.Other measures are: building a conference centre for the African Union, cancelling debts owed by heavily indebted and the least developed African countries, further opening up China's vast market to Africa by largely increasing the number of African export items to China that receive zero-tariff treatment and strengthening cooperation in the fields of agriculture, human resource enhancement, health and education.The inception of the Forum of China-Africa Cooperation (FOCAC) brought tangible benefits to Namibia such as the building of the regional council buildings in Rundu and Outapi, the New State House, the fishery laboratory at Kamutjonga Inland Fisheries Institute in Kavango, the Defence Academy (Okahandja), and the Youth Training Centre.China also availed grants amounting to RMB20 million and it helped to fund a large hospital at Omuthiya where a groundbreaking ceremony has occurred.She said China has provided over 300 training opportunities to Namibians in various fields while at the same time it has seconded a medical team at the Katutura State Hospital. There are several Chinese experts working at grassroots level while rural women and youth empowerment projects have all benefited from China's generosity.At current exchange rates, US$1 is equivalent to RMB6.8.//No18, 2011 (The Namibian/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- THE Ministry of Works and Transport has drawn Government into taking a Chinese loan that was rejected two years ago as 'onerous' in a road-building contract that has also bypassed official open tender process.The Permanent Secretary in the ministry, George Simataa, told The Namibian that the construction of the two roads - between Omakange and Ruacana and between Omafo and Outapi in northern Namibia - will be funded with a Chinese loan but that the Ministry of Finance is yet to apply or approve the loan. The roads are expected to cost about N$1 billion.The Namibian has it on good authority that the loan in question is the same controversial package that the Government ditched in 2009 after Teko Trading, a company owned by two Namibians and a Chinese national now facing corruption charges, was exposed as having received kic-backs of N$120 million from China when the Government bought customs scanning equipment for N$550 million.Teko Trading was said to be the 'local representative' for Nuctech (the Chinese company) although the Ministry of Finance said it had no knowledge of the company's dubious middle-man role.Teko Trading, owned by Public Service Commissioner Teckla Lameck, Kongo Mokaxwa and Chinese national Yung Fan, were supposed to be the 'local representatives' for China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export, and were experted to earn at least 10 per cent 'commission' from the N$1,1 billion tender to complete the 65km northern railway line between Ondangwa and Oshikango.Government dropped that loan agreement, with then Permanent Secretary of Finance Calle Schlettwein calling it 'onerous' and Simataa arguing in documents that the loan was 'risky because of foreign exchange fluctuations'.In a series of e-mails this week, Simataa said two Chinese firms, China Gezhouba Group International Engineering and China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export, have been selected to build the two roads mentioned earlier.While his reply on Tuesday was categorical that the two companies were selected to do the job, after he was asked to elaborate or give definite answers, on Wednesday he changed saying they still have to negotiate and agree on pricing after which they will sign technical and framework agreements.'It is only at that stage that the Ministry of Finance will be approached to apply for a loan from the Chinese Government,' Simataaa said in an e-mail on Wednesday.Asked if it is a condition of the loan that the work be given to Chinese companies he was evasive, saying 'these are Chinese-financed projects. One of their conditions is that the projects should be carried [out] by Chinese firms'.Having already gone ahead with the project, Simataa would also not say for certain whether the ministry was given tender exemption for the work, saying only that proper tender regulations were followed. When pressed if the construction of the two roads were put out on official and open tender Simataa said 'no', citing Chinese loan conditions that Chinese companies be used on the projects. Simataa and the Ministry of Works have been named in research documents as the main culprits in regularly demanding and getting exemptions from public tender regulations.It is unclear why Simataa and the ministry have decided to return to the Chinese loan that they criticised a couple of years ago. There are no indications this time that Teko Trading would be involved.The China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export northern railway line contract was cancelled after it was challenged in the High Court because of alleged tender irregularities.

title: Phase One Education
description: (PPIAF) Previous description: Oil-backed loan to repair damaged infrastructure, mainly railway tracks bombed in the country's civil war. The money will also lay roads and electrify slum areas of the capital, Luanda, and also fund rehabilitation of the water supply systems Updated description: On March 2, 2004 the first Credit Accord with the Eximbank of China was signed for a financial package of two billion US Dollars and meant for the financing of projects of Angola's public investment. The first package was implemented in two different phases, with each taking one billion US Dollars. The first phase involved 27 contracts, corresponding to 50 projects, of which 21 have been completed. These projects focused on areas of electricity, water, health, education, public works, each of which taking about 20 percent of the total amount released.The second phase included 13 contracts and 52 projects that are underway. These contracts are in the areas of telecommunications, fisheries, health, education and public works.A contract is near approval to complete the second phase. The contract is called EDEL III, plus another two in final stage of negotiation, also in the sector of electricity and waters.The balance at the end of September 2007, according to the Finance Ministry, is of Usd 7.1 million, of which Usd 1.6 million are for the first phase of the financing and Usd 5.4 million for the second phase.The total amount disbursed until the end of September is Usd 932.9 million, being 733.1 million for the first phase and 199.8 for the second phase.As a result of the positive evaluation made by the two parties concerning the first package of two billion US Dollars, a memorandum of understanding was signed on June 20, 2006, between the Angolan Finance Ministry and China's Eximbank, for the granting of a new financing of the same amount.; Contractor Comment: Tied to the loan, is the agreement that the public tenders for the construction and civil engineering contracts will be awarded primarily to Chinese state-owned enterprises approved by the Chinese government. Exim Bank has compiled a list of 3; Political/Resource Considerations: Oil (China was to receive 10,000 barrels of oil per day. Sinopec wins a license for a large oil-production block previously held by Total of France. Sinopec then formed a joint venture to bid on other oilfields in Angola.); Chinese Commitment: USD 30 Million; PPIAF-ID:15
donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency

title: Aid to Gabon Tri-Service Military General Hospital: treatment, training (Duplicate of 11756)
description: 4月28日，由广州军区武汉总医院医护人员组成的中国援助加蓬军医组一行9人，完成为期一年的医疗援助任务返回武汉。援非期间，他们先后救治病患6000多人，为加蓬三军总医院培训医护人员300多人次，指导开展新技术新业务10余项，加蓬总统和国防部长曾分别为军医组成员授勋。图为加蓬国防部秘书总长为军医组成员佩戴勋章的情景。 李玉宝、余 敏摄影报道

title: Alumina refinery construction
description: In December of 2006, a Greek company 3PL, which has a joint bauxite exploration venture with Aluminium Corp. of China Ltd. (CHALCO) in Guinea signed a deal to build a 1.2 million ton alumina refinery in the northeast of the country. It is still unclear what the status of the project is, but the project could potentially be tied. STAFF_NOTES: It appears 3PL acted independently in this venture, without the involvement of CHALCO. Therefore, the record has been made inactive.
donor_agency_count: Aluminum Corporation of China (CHINALCO), State-Owned Company; 3PL, Private Sector
recipient_agencies: Aluminum Corporation of China (CHINALCO), State-Owned Company

title: Overhauling Libreville's Electricity Grid
description: On October 18, 2010 an overhaul of the Libreville power grid began. The project involves the design of the new power grid, equipment supply, and construction. Overall, three new substations will be built on top of the expansion of four existing ones. Three new overhead transmission lines and two underground cable transmission lines will also be added. The first part of the project began on October 21 when the management workers came to the work site to start the renovation process. The project should take 2 years to complete. The Chinese have loaned Gabon the money through a $130 million US dollar loan for 20 years with 2.5% annual interest. The construction faced difficulties in acquiring adequate lands from private property, and it was thus delayed for actual construction until 2012.

title: China gives grant to Liberia Inactive
description: China lends Mozambique another R418.6-m103 words4 March 2009FT NowFTNOWEnglish(c) 2009 Now Media (Pty) Ltd. All Rights Reserved.   The Mozambiquan and Chinese governments signed three agreements in Maputo, under which China is to provide a total of R418.6-million in loan and grant finance. News agency AIM reports that the largest sum is a loan of R224.2-m for the fourth funding phase in the construction of Mozambique's new national sports stadium. A second loan, for R183.6-m, is to support agricultural projects in the Zambezi Valley, while the third agreement is for a grant of R30.6-m to be used in basic development sectors yet to be identified.

title: Chinese government to build two schools in Uganda (Duplicate)
description: China Pledges More Financial Assistanceby David Muwanga293 words3 October 200805:17 AMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2008 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedKampala, Oct 03, 2008 (New Vision/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- China will continue supporting Uganda's economic and social development, the Chinese ambassador, Sun Heping, has said.'Since the forum on China-Africa cooperation in November 2006, eight policies announced by president Hu Jintao to support Africa's development have been implemented in Uganda,' Heping said at a reception held at the Sheraton Kampala Hotel to mark the 59th anniversary of the Peoples Republic of China.'Those that have been implemented include expansion of aid, debt relief, tariff exemption and increase ofassistance and input to Uganda's social development,' he said.'The government of China is to build two schools, a hospital, a centre for malaria treatment and prevention, an agricultural technology demonstration centre and a government office block in the near future.'Heping said China's gross domestic product (GDP) share of the world economy and global trade rose to 5% and 8% respectively from 1% in 1978.'China's development has opened a huge market for international capital, attracting over $780b of net foreign investment, while direct overseas investments by the Chinese are also growing.'According to the Uganda Investment Authority, over $35m has been invested in Uganda by theChinese from June 30, 2007 to June 30, 2008. Also, the Chinese government has given over $85m inaid over the last four years.Heping said China has become the world's third largest import market and the largest import market in Asia.It contributes over 10% to global economic growth and over 12% to expansion of global trade.'China's average annual import volume has reached close to $560b since 2001, generating 10 million jobs for the trade partners.'Document AFNWS00020081003e4a30006j

title: Rice farming project in Uganda (Commitment year too early)
description: 18 June 2009Last year, China sunk sh304b ($141m) in Uganda. This came alongside a $17.5m (sh36b) debt write-off, and over $100m loan for the Government's e-government project, and another loan of $11m for sanitation equipment for the Kampala City Council.In the health sector, China has sent in scores of health experts over the years. In April, Uganda received a consignment of malarial drugs worth sh860m ($400,000) from China.In education, too, China is extending its support. There are currently about 100 Ugandan students inChina and Beijing has provided some 35 scholarships in the last few years.And then, there is Chinese involvement in the agricultural sector they know best: rice growing. The Chinese started the first rice farming project in Uganda, the 1,721 acres farm in Kibimba, Eastern Uganda....Document AFNWS00020090618e56i000ke

title: Chinese rice paddy project in Uganda (Duplicate)
description: China's Entry Into the Scramble for Oil Could Benefit Continentby Prof A.B.K. Kasozi2360 words24 December 200905:32 AMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2009 AllAfrica, All Rights Reserved...In Uganda, the case of Kibimba Rice Scheme presents a different picture. Before this Chinese project, the knowledge of paddy (wetland) rice growing was not practiced and, I think, well known.But this changed after the Chinese project at Kibimba was implemented. Wetland rice growing knowledge gradually radiated from Kibimba to the surrounding districts and many Ugandans now grow rice.

title: Stadium construction- duplicate with 2372
description: Guinean website assesses ties with China ahead of bilateral commission talks613 words13 April 201111:10 AMBBC Monitoring AfricaBBCAPEnglish(c) 2011 The British Broadcasting Corporation. All Rights Reserved. No material may be reproduced except with the express permission of The British Broadcasting Corporation.Excerpt from report by Cisse Aboubacar entitled 'The world-Diplomacy: The state of Chinese-Guinean cooperation' published on Guineenews website based in Canada but with editorial team in Guinea on 12 AprilDiplomacy: the state of the Chinese-Guinean cooperation on the eve of the opening of the fifth joint bilateral commission of cooperation of the countries in Conakry.The fifth session of the joint grand commission of bilateral cooperation between China and Guinea will take place in Conakry on 13 and 14 April 2011. The high powered delegation led by the Chinese deputy minister of trade, Fu Ziyinc, which will take part in the discussions, is arriving by a special flight from Peking on this 13 April for a session which is beginning with the visit to the construction site of the 50,000 seating capacity stadium at Nongo and the commissioning of the Kipe International Hospital which are both donations from China.According to the technicians at the Ministry of International Cooperation of our country, 'the Chinese-Guinean diplomatic ties which date back to October 1956 and the dominant characteristics of which are discreet, are achieved mainly through interest free loans, completed by financial grants, donations of food and pharmaceutical product, budgetary aids and military assistance'. Several accomplishments are also among this cooperation on the level of agriculture, industry, handicraft, infrastructure, trade, energy, health, education, training and telecommunications among others. They are achievements that contributed greatly to the socio-economic development of Guinea.On the education level, for instance, China gave Guinea 300 scholarships in the areas higher and post-university education and in the fields of architecture, mathematics, food technology, biochemistry, agriculture and health in the last 13 years. However, in the case of health, 22 Chinese medical missions have been circulating between Conakry, Labe, Faranah and N'Zerekore on the basis of a biannual renewable contract from 1968. The training of over 140 health workers of all categories is also in this programme.On the trade level, statistics show that commercial exchange between our two countries which were up to the tune of 43m dollars in 2002 rise to about 200m dollars currently. With the admission of Peking in 2004 into the World Trade Organization (WTO), the Chinese authorities gave a quota of 87 products to Guinea from the following year under special customs preferential tariff treatment.It should be noted that Guinea received from China in cash and kind a total sum of nearly 7m dollars from 1984, under the terms of this donation, for the purchase of rice seeds, tractors, learning materials for the deaf and dumb, building and telecommunications materials and fertilizers etc.Under infrastructures, the Sekhoutoureya Presidential Palace, the Kinkon and Tinkisso hydroelectric plants, the Kipe International Hospital, the People's Palace, the RTG [state-owned Guinean Radio-Television] Broadcasting House at Koloma, the Chinese-Guinean Friendship Schools at Coyah, the 50,000 sitting capacity stadium at Nongo which is being built are among the showpieces of this cooperation.We should note finally that about 40 Chinese technical assistants are currently working on various Chinese-Guinean cooperation projects, without speaking of the multitude of Chinese private companies which give birth to a massive presence of Chinese nationals in our country.It is therefore in this favourable atmosphere that the discussions on the fifth session of the Chinese-Guinean joint grand commission of bilateral cooperation is opening on Wednesday [13 April], which is the harbinger of bright prospects for the deepening and diversification of this over five decade old cooperation based on a win-win policy.Source: Guineenews website in French 12 Apr 11adaa7181Document BBCAP00020110413e74d002e5

title: Chinese commitment to renovate Ugandan hospital (Duplicate)
description: China to Partner with Ugandaby Brian Mayanja258 words4 February 201010:35 AMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2010 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedKampala, Feb 04, 2010 (New Vision/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- CHINA is committed to work with Uganda in development programmes, the ambassador has said.Sun Heping said his country had established channels through which the two countries will carry out trade and investments.He made the remarks recently at the three-day workshop at the Uganda Management Institute forChinese and Uganda educationists.The workshop focused on China's Partnership with Africa on aid for policy effectiveness.The Chinese government announced the eight areas of partnership with African countries.They include agriculture, trade promotion, debt relief, medical care and education.Heping said his government was committed to completing projects like renovating Naguru Hospital, an agricultural demonstration centre and the office block building for the Government.He added that for the past three years, over 390 Ugandan technical personnel had travelled to China for training on various subjects.He added that the Chinese had also come to Uganda to learn more.'Ugandans go to China to learn modern agriculture like using modern irrigation methods.'Chinese fishery experts are working with the Ministry of Agriculture to help local people improve their products and enhance productivity,' he noted.The head of the Chinese delegation from Tsinghua University, Prof. Lan Xue, refuted claims by some African politicians that China supports dictatorship.'China was the first country to take aid to Haiti. We are not interested in who is in power but rather focusing on improving the welfare of the poor,' he stressed.Document AFNWS00020100204e624000m4

description: 28 October 2010　　China National Offshore Oil Co Ltd intends to build Uganda's first oil refinery, the head of Uganda's Ministry of Energy was cited by media as saying.The oil refinery will have a daily capacity of 200,000 barrels when it is put into operation.Other companies which have expressed interest in building the refinery include India's Essar Group and France's Total S.A.No further details have so far been disclosed.Document BJEIND0020101028e6as0002v

title: Acquisition of oil exploration rights (Duplicate)
description: CNOOC to acquire one-third of 3 exploration areas in Uganda for 1.47 bln USDjiangtingting369 words30 March 201109:00 AMXinhua News AgencyXNEWSEnglishCopyright 2011. Xinhua News Agency. All rights reserved.BEIJING, March 30 (Xinhua) -- China National Offshore Oil Company Limited (CNOOC Ltd.) said on Wednesday that it has signed an agreement with U.K.-based Tullow Oil plc (Tullow) for a one-thirdinterest in three exploration areas in Uganda for 1.467 billion U.S. dollars.The transaction, which is subject to regulatory approvals by authorities in Uganda and China, is expected to be completed in the first half of 2011.According to CNOOC Ltd., TOTAL S.A. (TOTAL) of France has also signed agreements with Tullow for the acquisition of another one-third stake in the three exploration areas.The exploration areas, 1, 2 and 3A are located in the Lake Albert Rift Basin in Uganda, which is one of the most important prospective basins in Africa. As estimated by Tullow, more than one billion barrels of P-50 recoverable volume of oil has been discovered since 2006.Upon the completion of the two transactions, CNOOC Ltd., Tullow and TOTAL will each hold a one-third stake in the three exploration areas.CNOOC Ltd., Tullow and TOTAL are looking to coordinate operations and integrate development plans across the three exploration areas in the Lake Albert Basin. It is expected that more than 200,000 barrels of oil will be produced each day in the area.Yang Hua, the Chief Executive Officer of CNOOC Ltd., said that the transaction to gain entry into the Lake Albert Basin signifies another milestone for the company in its expansion of its overseas business. The area is one of the key frontier basins in East Africa.Li Fanrong, the President of CNOOC Ltd., said that the project is expected to become one of the largest oil and gas developments inAfrica in recent years.The agreement will help CNOOC Ltd. establish its second major production area in Africa following Nigeria. The deal is also expected to contribute to the long-term growth of the company, he said.CNOOC Ltd., which is listed in Hong Kong and New York, is a subsidiary of China National Offshore Oil Corporation, China's largest offshore oil producer.Enditem08Document XNEWS00020110330e73u004sa
donor_agency_count: TOTAL S.A. (TOTAL), Private Sector; China National Offshore Oil Corporation (CNOOC), State-Owned Company

title: China donates computers to Zambia police
description: China donates raincoats and computers to Zambia police.198 words11 September 2003Xinhua News AgencyXNEWSEnglish(c) Copyright 2003 Xinhua News AgencyLUSAKA, Sept. 11 (Xinhua) - The Chinese government has donated 1,000 raincoats and 10 sets of computers and printers to Zambia Police Service.Zambian Inspector General of Police Zunga Siakalima said at the handover ceremony held here Thursday that the raincoats could not have come at a better time than now when the rain season is just around the corner.    He thanks the Chinese government for its all-weather friendshipto Zambia.   Siakalima said the Zambia Police Service has embarked on a  program of computerization of its stations, units and sections. So he believed the donation of computers and printers will undoubtedly go a long way in complementing this program.Chinese Ambassador to Zambia Peng Keyu said the police plays a significant role in any country, in maintaining social security and stability, which is of crucial importance in the development of national economy.    Peng said it is not possible to expect any economic developmentwithout a safe and stable social environment.   He strongly believed it is the continuous efforts of the ZambiaPolice that make this beautiful country a safe place forforeigners to live in, to work and invest.

title: Oil Pipeline (Duplicate of 1996)
description: 'BEIJING, June 05, SinoCast -- Chinese oil titan China National Petroleum Corporation (PetroChina Group) plans to invest USD 5 billion in the following three years to develop Niger's Agadem oil block jointly with the Nigerian government, in line with an agreement signed on June 2, 2008, said China's Ministry of Commerce yesterday.The Agadem oil block is the largest one in the African country and is proven to have considerable oil reserve, according to the Chinese ministry. PetroChina Group will also build a plant capable of refining 1 million tons of crude oil every year and also a 2,000-kilometer pipeline in the country.Zhang Shengli, an official from the Chinese ministry, said there was not any third party in the project.PetroChina Group is expected be benefited in terms of profitability by forming a complete industry chain from exploitation to oil transportation in the project, said Guotai Junan Securities analyst Yang Wei.The Chinese oil titan has been prospecting the Blima block and the Tenere block in Niger. '

title: Drilling a Duster Oil Well (Duplicate of 137)
description: 265 words2 March 2007International Oil DailyIODEnglish(c) 2007 Energy Intelligence Group Inc. All rights reserved.China National Petroleum Corp. (CNPC) has drilled a duster at the remote Tenere Block in eastern Niger, Canadian junior partner TG World Energy said Thursday.The Tenere Block is operated by CNPC affiliate CNPC International (Tenere), which conducted drill stem tests over two intervals on the Saha-1 well. 'Although oil flowed from one such interval, water was also encountered during the test and the well will not be capable of commercial production,' TG World, which has a 20% interest in the block, said. The test over the second interval was incomplete.TG World will be carried by CNPC for most of its share of the work program, which includes the drilling of three exploration wells and all seismic acquisition, processing and interpretation until the end of the second well. Some 3,780 km of new 2-D seismic has been acquired and interpreted so far, TG World said.CNPC is now preparing to move to the second drilling location, Fachi West-1, in the next few days.The Tenere Block covers 71,200 sq km (27,500 sq miles) and contains the northern half of the Termit-Tenere Rift. The southern half is beside the Agadem contract area held by Exxon Mobil and Malaysia'sPetronas, where six oil discoveries and one gas discovery have been made. But Exxon says it would require a find of at least 1 billion bbl to justify a 1,000 km plus link to the crude export pipeline in neighboring Chad, or a new line crossing North Africa to the Mediterranean.Document IOD0000020070309e3320000u

recipient_agencies: China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC), State-Owned Company

title: Second Tenere Oil Well (Duplicate of 137)
description: 175 words11 April 2007Global Insight Daily AnalysisWDANEnglishCopyright 2007, Global Insight Limited. All Rights Reserved.The China National Petroleum Corp. (CNPC) has spudded a second exploration well in Niger. Drilling at the Fachi West-1 well on the Ténéré Block began on 7 April. TG World Energy Corp.holds a 20% interest in the CNPC-operated concession. TG World's previous exploration well Saha-1 was announced a duster last month (see Niger: 13 March 2007:). The Operator mobilised the rig northwards across lateral dunes from the Saha-1 location approximately 27 km overland to the second location.Significance: TG World President and CEO Cliff James stated that analysis of the Saha-1 data suggests that the Fachi West-1 location remains a compelling prospect. TG World is being carried by CNPC for its 20% share for the first three exploration wells. Niger has proven reserves of 300 million barrels of oil yet the country is landlocked and needs to find considerable reserves of at least one billion barrels of oil for the construction of a new pipeline to be made viable.Document WDAN000020070411e34b00034

title: Uranium Deposit Development (Duplicate of 256)
description: 400 words18 May 200703:57 AMReuters NewsLBAEnglish(c) 2007 Reuters LimitedBEIJING, May 18 (Reuters) - China Nuclear International Uranium Corp. said on Friday it has signed an agreement with Chinese iron ore miner and trader Sinosteel Corp. and investment conglomerate CITIC to explore for and develop uranium resources in China and abroad.The firm plans to develop a uranium deposit in Niger in cooperation with that country's government, and is looking for other partners for projects elsewhere, Liu Xuehong, the company's deputy general manager, told a power industry conference.'Even though domestic reserves can meet our needs, in the long term we need to develop overseas supply sources,' she said.China will need more than 8,000 tonnes of uranium to feed its planned nuclear power generation capacity, which is expected to reach 40 gigawatts by 2020, she estimated.Anticipation of rising demand has driven up spot uranium prices to about $120 a pound from $10/lb a few years ago, and is fuelling new mining projects world-wide.Niger, the world's third-largest uranium producer, this week approved more than $60 million in additional budget funds to confront nomadic Tuareg rebels in the arid north, home to many of its uranium concessions.Part of the funds derived from contractual payments by Chinese oil and uranium companies, Niger's minister of internal relations said.CNIUC, or SinoU, was established at the end of last year to develop overseas uranium resources for its parent, China National Nuclear Corp.It would develop Niger's Tiguidda deposit in Azelik, she said.CNNC last July won the rights to a 12,790 tonne deposit along the Azelik fault. It also holds rights to the 6,190 tonne Madaouela deposit, according to the World Nuclear Association.China's primary domestic uranium deposits lie in the Yili and Tuha basins, both in the far western desert region of Xinjiang, and in the Erdos region of Inner Mongolia, Liu said.Demand for uranium will outstrip 'fairly substantial' production capacity coming up in the next five years, said Andrej Karpinski, executive chairman of exploration firm Korab Resources Ltd. and of its spin-off Uranium Australia Ltd.He predicted uranium prices could rise as high as $200/lb this year or next, before settling between $70/lb and $120/lb as new mines begin production.CHINA-URANIUM|LANGEN|ABN|C|MTL|GRO|SOF|O|OILDocument LBA0000020070518e35i001fl

title: An accord on mining South Africa's rich uranium deposits and developing peaceful nuclear technology
description: Guardian International PagesChinese premier boosts trade with seven-nation Africa tour: Booming economy spurs hunt for natural resources: Oil is chief interest but nuclear accord also likelyRory Carroll, Johannesburg923 words22 June 2006The GuardianGRDN19English© Copyright 2006. The Guardian. All rights reserved.China's economic and diplomatic push into Africa has gone into overdrive this week with a seven-country tour by its premier, Wen Jiabao, to secure trade deals.After warm welcomes in Egypt, Ghana, the Democratic Republic of Congo, and Angola, Mr Wen arrived in South Africa yesterday for two days of talks on nuclear power, textile imports and regional alliances. The visits form part of what Beijing foreign policy officials have dubbed the 'year of Africa', a drive for access to the continent's natural resources to fuel China's booming economy.Mr Wen was greeted at the Tuynhuys presidential office in Cape Town with a red carpet, two lines of cabinet ministers and a South African navy brass band. It was his fifth such ceremony in as many days, with two more later this week in Tanzania and Uganda.The pomp reflected a burgeoning influence in Africa, which is rapidly catching up with that of the United States and the old colonial powers, Britain and France. Mr Wen said China's relations with Africa were based on mutual benefit and posed no threat to US interests.China's trade with the continent reached a record $39.7bn (pounds 21.5bn) last year, almost four times the figure in 2001. As ubiquitous as Chinese technicians building roads and railways are Chinese-run shops and restaurants. Schools have started teaching Mandarin and direct flights to Beijing and Shanghai are proliferating.Mr Wen, the first Chinese premier to visit South Africa in half a century, was due to sign a pact on textiles to ease a trade imbalance blamed for the loss of 25,000 South African jobs, a touchy issue that has soured feelings towards Chinese immigrants. After talks with the South African president, Thabo Mbeki, the premier was due to meet oil executives and expatriate Chinese business leaders.An accord on mining South Africa's rich uranium deposits and developing peaceful nuclear technology, with both countries sharing French-designed reactors, was also expected.Further talks are scheduled for today to cover climate change, peacekeeping and the alleviation of poverty, a sign that China's engagement has broadened beyond a hunt for raw materials.The Asian giant signalled its ambitions in January by publishing an Africa policy paper, followed by a tour of three countries by the president, Hu Jintao. In November Beijing will host a China-Africa summit that is expected to attract about 40 heads of government and state.Mr Wen's tour is a showcase of Chinese deal-making. Accords in Egypt on oil, natural gas and telecommunications were followed by a $66m loan to Ghana for a telecommunications project and hints of $600m for a hydroelectric dam. Congo was offered economic, commercial and technical cooperation. Tanzania and Uganda are expecting fresh credit lines and infrastructure projects.There was no doubting the trip's chief interest: oil. With an economy that grew by 10.3% in the first quarter of this year, China's need is ravenous. Worried by Middle Eastern instability, it wants more oil from Africa, which already accounts for up to a third of its supply.Mr Wen's visit to Angola consolidated last month's $1.4bn deal between China's state-owned giant Sinopec and the host's state-owned oil producer, Sonangol, to develop new fields. Angola recently overtook Saudi Arabia as China's biggest oil supplier.Without giving details, a joint communique said China would extend more credit and expand technical assistance for Angola's postwar reconstruction.The president, Jose Eduardo dos Santos, praised the lack of preconditions. 'We hail China's pragmatism towards Angola, which has allowed us to speed up the country's reconstruction.'Watchdog groups said that was a euphemism for China turning a blind eye to the Angolan government's corruption and human rights abuses. Similar criticism has been levelled at Beijing's dealings with Sudan and Zimbabwe.Chinese diplomats say it is a matter of respecting sovereignty. Privately they add that their approach is more honest than the west's, which chides some regimes but ignores allies' abuses.guardian.co.uk/china >Sunday 18 JuneEgyptCll: 5,493Exports to china as a % of total: 2.27% Signs agreements on energy and telecoms china also agrees to %50m loan provides $10m to build an investment centreMondayGhanaCll 5.034, extremeExports to China: 3% Commits to low-interest loan of $66m. Beijing may also fund $600m hydroelectric damMonday/TuesdayCongoCll 1.271, extremeExports to China: 70.5%Signs economic and health agreements. Brazzaville agrees to buy two Chinese-made aircraft. Congo produced est 267,000 bpd of crude last yearTuesdayAngolaCll: 1.393, extremeExports to China : 37%Signed cooperationa agreements and a further credit deal, following $3bn oil-backed loan. Angola is sub-saharan Africa's second largest oil-producerWednesdaySouth AfricaCll: 4.527, highExports to China: 6.23%Due to sign agreement to co-operate on peaceful nuclear technology and will discuss a deal on textilesThursday/FridayTanzaniaCll: 5.404, mediumExports to China: 0.32%Likely to discuss deals on textiles and projects to build highways and bridgesUgandaCll: 5.823, mediumExports to China: 1.72%Likely to discuss details on textiles and projects to build highways and bridgesDocument GRDN000020060622e26m0001j© 2012 Factiva, Inc. title: Oil Well Investments (Duplicate of 2137)
description: 203 words3 June 200801:10 PMAgence France PresseAFPREnglishCopyright Agence France-Presse, 2008 All reproduction and presentation rights reserved.Niger has granted China's national oil company rights to prospect, explore and produce petroleum in the northern Agadez region, state radio reported Tuesday.The pact, signed Monday between the Niger government and the China National Oil and Gas Development and Exploration Corporation (CNODC), will see the company invest about 300 million dollars (194 million euros) to explore and drill 18 new wells in the coming eight years.Western companies have been prospecting for oil in Niger's Agadem region in the northern area of Agadez since 1985.They have concluded that the estimated 324 million barrels there were not lucrative enough to prospect and drill.The Chinese firm has also pledged to invest 1.2 billion dollars in Niger's petroleum sector to build a pipeline and a refinery near the second city of Zinder with a daily capacity of 20,000 barrels.It will sell a part of its production locally at 'affordable' prices, according to the contract.Since 2006, China has reinforced its economic ties with Niger helping the former French colony to tap its vast uranium wealth, one of the largest in the world.bh/jlh/ach/rtNiger-China-oilDocument AFPR000020080603e46300aj7
donor_agency_count: China National Oil and Gas Exploration and Development Corporation (CNODC), State-Owned Company

title: Not a project: Preferred Destination Status
description: 557 words23 January 200209:54 AMOn January 23, 2002, Despite the problems caused by the events of September 11, travel andtourism group, The Tourism Investment Corporation Limited (Tourvest) issharing in the benefits of South Africa's newfound popularity as a costeffective and safe destination.Commenting on the impact of the season on Tourvest's operations, chiefexecutive Carol Scott said that inbound tourism was excellent. 'Asignificant number of tour operators are switching their programmes fromother destinations to South Africa and certain operators are consideringcharter programmes for the first time. We have received very positivefeedback from the operators regarding future growth and have had manyenquiries for quotations for large numbers of passengers for both 2003 and.2004.'Ms Scott said that the USA and Asian markets were significantly affected bythe events of September 11, which resulted in passenger volumes remainingstatic for the six months from July to December. 'In spite of this decline,margins and the overall performance of the inbound division improved.Confirmed volumes for the next six months are heartening and all being well,this division should finish the year on a good note.'Following the terror attacks certain companies put an embargo on travellingoverseas for three months which caused a decline in outbound passengers, butMs Scott reports that the domestic corporate market is showing signs ofimprovement. In the past few moths there has been a substantial drop in thenumber of outbound leisure passengers which can be attributed to both.September 11 as well as the depreciation of the Rand.Ms Scott said that it is vital that South Africa extends the tourism seasonbeyond its current five months, as any marked increase in tourist volumeswill be impacted by the availability of airline seats and accommodation.'As a country we need to make a concerted and tourism-wide effort tosubstantially improve service standards if we want to entrench SouthAfrica's position as a high quality, affordable destination.'Tourvest's merchandise, duty free, outbound and financial services divisionwhich includes American Express Foreign Exchange is performing well.'The only division under pressure at the moment is the outbound division butwe are addressing this and are gaining new accounts through more aggressivemarketing and service.'According to Ms Scott, the European market, particularly the British market,will grow substantially. However, the market with the greatest potential isthe Chinese market, since the Chinese government has awarded South Africapreferred destination status. 'Although we anticipate the main benefits ofthis will be felt in the latter part of 2002, we are already experiencinglarge increases in numbers from China and other parts of Asia over theprevious year.'Ms Scott concluded that potential exists to grow revenues from all ofTourvest's businesses, particularly its retail and merchandising divisionwhich secures a large portion of its business from the internationaltourist. There is also potential revenue growth in both inbound and foreignexchange. Tourvest will continue to seek new acquisitions that it could.logically and easily integrate into its fold.The Tourvest interim results for the six months to December 31 will bereleased towards the end of February.EndsDate: 23/01/2002 04:53:00 PM Produced by the JSE SENS Department.Document jsexch0020020123dy1n001up'319 words22 February 200212:24 PMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) Distributed via COMTEX News.Nelspruit, Feb 22, 2002 (African Eye News Service/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) - Mpumalanga is determined to prevent attacks on tourists, like the attack two years ago on an American honeymoon couple reportedly related to former US president Bill Clinton.Chief executive of the Mpumalanga Tourism Authority (MTA) Elliot Ndala said at a tourism safety function in Nelspruit on Friday that the MTA would spend R4 million to develop tourism awareness in the region.The MTA, departments of safety and security and environmental affairs, gaming and tourism, Kruger National Park and police signed a memorandum of understanding after a spate of hijackings on tourists in 2000, adopting an attitude of zero tolerance for attacks on tourists.New York state attorney Scott Newman and his wife Lesley, who are reportedly related to Clinton, were the victims of one of three hijackings of foreigners near the Kruger National Park that year.Ndala said the function on Friday aimed to cement relations between signatories to the memorandum and reinforce the crime against tourism strategy.MEC of finance and economic affairs, Jacob Mabena said that the month of June would focus on youth and that youngsters should be made aware of the importance of tourism and the negative impact of crime on the industry.He said some good news was that China had awarded South Africa approved destination status and that up to 50 000 Chinese tourists would be encouraged to visit the country each year.'This will only be possible if tourists are not mugged and robbed,' said Mabena.Seven men arrested after the attack on the Newmans, who were on honeymoon in South Africa, will be in the Nelspruit regional court on March 1. They have pleaded not guilty to charges of armed robbery.by Fortunate MabuzaCopyright African Eye News Service. Distributed by All Africa Global Media(AllAfrica.com)KEYWORD:    South Africa.Document afnws00020021107dy2m00r8x'

title: MOU With China Television, TV show
description: 439 words4 August 200005:41 AMBBC Monitoring MediaBBCMMEnglish(c) 2000 The British Broadcasting Corporation [date of publication]. All Rights Reserved. No material may be reproduced except with the express permission of The British Broadcasting Corporation.Text of report from South African newspaper `Business Day' web site on 1st AugustThe MIH group has signed three memorandums of understanding with the national television network of the People's Republic of China, in a move MIH says will strengthen their relationship and lay the foundation for further cooperation.Multichoice communications GM Lebogang Hashatse said that the MIH group had vast experience in converging technologies, a highly experienced pay television network, a vast subscriber base and the ability to market its products to that base.'They want to start exporting their own content and we have the platforms and ability to package that. So with the two together, it is a very exciting situation,' said Hashatse.The China Central Television (CCTV) network serves more than one billion viewers, making it the largest television network in the world.Hashatse said the value of the deal was secondary to the benefits of cooperation. 'This represents the road to the friendship, but we will be able to assess the costs once production has begun,' he said. The agreements involve cooperation as well as content sharing.The first of these is the Beyond the Rainbow agreement to co-produce a large-scale musical and cultural performance of South African and Chinese artists and musicians. The show will be staged in South Africa in October.The second is to produce the Face of China, the Chinese version of M-Net's Face of Africa competition. MIH said the focus would be on 'discovering young beauties and encouraging authentic and modern Chinese fashion design', with the aim of broadcasting this beyond China's borders.The third agreement involves children's television programming and will culminate in a series of six episodes for each country, being filmed, broadcast and distributed initially in China, Asia, South Africaand the rest of Africa.In terms of the first agreement between MIH and CCTV, signed in 1997, the broadcaster's international channel, CCTV 4, is broadcast on DStv to Chinese audiences in Africa and Europe.The latest agreements were signed yesterday by MIH Holdings CEO Cobus Stofberg and CCTV president Zhao Hua Yong.CCTV broadcasts on eight channels, plus one English channel, and produces 62 per cent of its own content. It maintains regular contact with 273 television organizations in 140 countries.MIH Holdings, which owns Nasdaq-and Amsterdam-listed MIH Limited, consists of television platforms including M-Net, Supersport and Multichoice Africa, technology businesses including OpenTV and Mindport, and global internet applications through M-Web.Source: `Business Day' web site, Johannesburg, in English 1 Aug 00.Document bbcmm00020010804dw84001rn

description: 83 words13 April 2005Xinhua News AgencyXNEWSEnglish(c) Copyright 2005 Xinhua News AgencyHEFEI, April 13 (Xinhua) -- Anqing, a city of east China's Anhui Province, and Ladysmith, a city of South Africa's Kwazulu- Natal province, signed a memorandum of establishing sister-city relations at an investment meeting held recently.Ladysmith lies between South Africa's major airport and major export port, with an urban population of 200,000. title: Comprehensive Local Textile Adjustment Package
description: Mail and Guardian619 words4 September 2006ISI Emerging Markets AfricawireLQAFEnglish© Copyright 2006. Internet Securities, Inc. All rights reserved.An agreement to limit Chinese clothing and textile imports has brought mixed reaction, with labour in the textile industry welcoming the opportunity to rebuild the industry and the Democratic Alliance (DA) saying it will bring price increases.The opposition party said it will ask the minister of trade and industry whether concerns of the clothing and textile retail industry were considered, as well as the implications for consumers and employment.The South African Clothing and Textile Workers' Union (Sactwu) said on Monday that 55Â 000 new jobs could be created.'We need to use the space created to ensure we make our factories state-of-the-art and improve training of workers on a scale that will develop South Africa into a world-class producer,' said general secretary Ebrahim Patel.'Over the past four years, the local fashion-manufacturing industry has lost approximately 67Â 000 jobs, largely as a result of a surge of imports from China,' said Patel. 'Over the same period, the five big retailers have recorded R18,1-billion in pre-tax profits. It is now time for retailers to work with the local manufacturing industry to place the country and employment before profits.'He said the vast volumes of imports from China have had a devastating impact, with factory closures in the poorest parts of the country such as Dimbaza in the Eastern Cape, which have become industrial ghost towns.'Even the United States, the European Union and Brazil had quotas imposed on Chinese imports, even though they had not yet been as adversely affected by imports as those in South Africa.'Since 2002, clothing imports from China rose by 480%. At the end of last year, our trade balance with China was R23-billion, meaning that South Africa had a negative trade of R23-billion.'Opposition On the other hand, the DA said 'firing off trade restriction like buckshot' could lead to price increases of 20% to 25% as well as stock shortages over the coming festive season, according to industry analysts.DA trade and industry spokesperson Pierre Rabie suggested a targeted approach that makes assertive use of the more positive options provided by the World Trade Organisation (WTO) framework.Recommendations include, firstly, obtaining a commitment from China to assist in supporting South Africa's local textiles and clothing firms through comprehensive adjustment packages. These packages should facilitate restructuring and reorientation of firms to identify and service niche markets successfully, said Rabie.'This would certainly signify a willingness to encourage the involvement of the Chinese in our economy.'Secondly, the government should clearly assert its willingness to invoke WTO safeguards against dumping if it is necessary. 'It should also explore the possibility with China of setting a minimum value on items of clothing that may be exported here without restraint.'Thirdly, together with China, the government should investigate the WTO-sanctioned option of limiting the extent to which China may increase its annual exports to South Africa to no more than 7,5%.The China-South African agreement follows more than a year's negotiations and was first initialled in June by visiting Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao and President Thabo Mbeki.It sets quantitative targets on specified clothing and textile products and will be effective from next month to the end of 2008. -- SapaRelated articlesWoolworths criticises clothing quotas Blogs linking to M G Online | Blogs linking to this articleSave this page on del.icio.us | What is del.icio.us?Add M G Online news to your website or blogGet M G Online news in your RSS readerFor more news, go to the M G Online home pageDocument LQAF000020060905e29400007

China held many training sessions in their country for African officials, but there is no information affirming that a 20 million document was signed.
