title: Programme of Cooperation on Deepening the Strategic Partnership Between China and South Africa
description: Chinese premier discusses cooperation with South African vice-president712 words23 June 200604:59 AMBBC Monitoring Asia PacificBBCAPPEnglish(c) 2006 The British Broadcasting Corporation. All Rights Reserved. No material may be reproduced except with the express permission of The British Broadcasting Corporation.Text of report entitled: 'Wen Jiabao 22 June meets in Cape Town with South African Vice-President Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka and Firmino Mucavele, chief executive of the Secretariat of the 'New Partnership for Africa's Development'', carried by official Chinese news agency Xinhua (New China News Agency)Cape Town, 22 June: On 22 June, State Council Premier Wen Jiabao met in Cape Town respectively with South African Vice-President Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka and Firmino Mucavele, chief executive of the 'New Partnership for Africa's Development'.Wen Jiabao told Mlambo-Ngcuka: My visit to South Africa has been highly successful. An extensive consensus has been reached between President Thabo Mbeki and myself on promoting cooperation between China and South Africa; and a series of important agreements, including the 'Programme of Cooperation on Deepening the Strategic Partnership Between China and South Africa', have been signed between the two sides. China and South Africa have been promoting bilateral relations in adherence to the principle of mutual trust, equality, and mutual benefit; and relations between the two countries enjoy a solid foundation as a result. I believe that along with the all-round implementation of the 'Programme', relations between China and South Africa will surely undergo further consolidation and development.Wen Jiabao indicated: China and South Africa are partners in seeking common growth. The Chinese side supports the 'Accelerated and Shared Growth Initiative for South Africa' that aims at promoting economic and social development, and is willing to provide assistance for the South side in the area of human resources development.Mlambo-Ngcuka said: The South African side is happy about the major accomplishments achieved during Premier Wen Jiabao's visit in South Africa; and believes that the documents signed between the two sides, including the 'Programme of Cooperation on Deepening the Strategic Partnership Between China and South Africa', have opened up a broad prospect in the future cooperation between the two countries. The implementation of the 'Programme' will provide impetus for the 'Accelerated and Shared Growth Initiative for South Africa', and this embodies China's support and assistance for the development of a new South Africa. The South African side expresses appreciation and gratitude for this, and is willing to cooperate with China in a number of prioritized fields, such as infrastructural construction, mineral products, and human resources development.During his meeting with Mucavele, Wen Jiabao indicated: The Chinese side has regards its cooperation with the 'New Partnership for Africa's Development' as an important content in China-Africa friendly cooperation. Ever since the establishment of the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation in 2000, the Chinese side has adopted a series of pragmatic cooperative measures towards Africa, including granting tax and tariff exemptions and stepping up personnel training; and has increased its aid to Africa, and has carried out cooperation with African nations in diversified forms in the prioritized fields under the 'New Partnership for Africa's Development', including infrastructural construction, aid-the-poor programme, prevention and control of contagious diseases, human resources development, and agriculture. There have been huge potentials for cooperation between the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation and the 'New Partnership for Africa's Development', as the two share the same goal of promoting mutually beneficial cooperation and promoting common development while the prioritized fields set by the two also coincide with each other. With a view to promoting the pragmatic cooperation between the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation and the 'New Partnership for Africa's Development', I hope that the two sides will step up contacts and coordination, and establish a long-acting cooperation mechanism. The Chinese side will, through bilateral and multilateral channels, extend greater support towards the prioritized fields under the 'New Partnership for Africa's Development'.Mucavele thanked China for assigning great importance to Africa and for extending support to the 'New Partnership for Africa's Development'. He indicated that African nations looked forward to stepping up cooperation with China and hoped that China would continue to follow Africa's development with close interest and would become a partner to Africa in the latter's efforts to extricate itself from poverty and realize development.Source: Xinhua news agency domestic service, Beijing, in Chinese 1534 gmt 22 Jun 06a4a06223Document BBCAPP0020060623e26n000pd

title: Merger of South African and Chinese banks (duplicate of 16439)
description: Chinese and South African Bank Join Hands 13 October 2008Market, page 20The realignment and restructuring in South Africa’s Standard Bank, after a merger with China’s Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) in March this year, would lead to extra profit generation of USD 50 million by July next year, according to Standard Bank chief executive officer Jacko Maree. The merger was the largest foreign direct investment made by a Chinese company abroad, ICBC had bought 20% stake in the African bank at USD 5.2 billion. The investment was also the only profitable one to date made by Chinese financial institution oversea, according to ICBC top management.

title: China and South Africa Agree to Work Together in Mining
description: China, SAfrica agree to work together on mining   251 words26 September 200711:55 AMReuters NewsLBAEnglish(c) 2007 Reuters Limited   BEIJING, Sept 26 (Reuters) - Companies from China and South Africa will be able to tap the China-Africa Development Fund for investment in minerals, energy and other industries, the two countries said in a joint communique on Wednesday.   The two countries will 'explore ways to enhance capacity building in mining, construction and other industries' according to the communique, issued during a visit to the Chinese capital by South African Deputy President Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka.   In June, Beijing launched the $5 billion China-Africa Development Fund, with initial capital of $1 billion, to help finance Chinese investments in Africa, part of Beijing's pledge to double its aid to the continent.   Beijing is increasingly using its massive foreign reserves to lend to Africa, paving the way for its state-owned firms to bid on mining and infrastructure projects as it tries to secure raw materials supply for its booming economy.   The countries also agreed to expand exchanges and cooperation in a variety of fields, particularly aquaculture and agricultural products. China increased the number of scholarships offered to South African students.   'The Chinese side noted with appreciation the position taken by South Africa and other countries, against Taiwan's bid for U.N. membership during the 62nd session of the U.N. General Assembly,' the communique said.   CHINA-SOUTHAFRICA|LANGEN|AFA|CSA|LBY|RWSA|RWS|REULB|GNS|G|RBN|ABN|M|D|AFN|SF|C|MTL|GRO|SOF|RNP|DNP|PGE|SXNA

title: 112 bed hospital (Duplicate)
description: 新华网内罗毕8月5日电 （记者宋晨）中国为肯尼亚无偿援建的露西·齐贝吉医院移交仪式5日在内罗毕举行。　　肯尼亚医疗服务部长彼得·尼翁戈表示，肯尼亚感谢中国政府为肯所做的一切。他说：“从此以后，住在内罗毕东部地区的居民，再也不用穿越整个城市，大老远地跑去肯雅塔医院看病了。有了这所医院，我们将能为肯尼亚人提供更加现代化的医疗保健服务。”　　中国驻肯尼亚大使馆临时代办延秀生说，露西·齐贝吉医院是中肯两国在医疗领域合作的具体体现。中国希望尽己所能，帮助肯方更好地改善医疗设施和服务水平。　　医院院长奥加图说，“等移交仪式结束后，我们就开始收治病人”，医院将全天24小时接诊。　　该医院以肯尼亚“第一夫人”露西·齐贝吉女士的名字命名，位于内罗毕东部的卡优勒地区。该地区是内罗毕最贫困落后的地区，医疗资源匮乏。医院建筑总面积7020平方米，拥有床位112张。目前医院拥有150名员工，待完全投入运营后，员工总数将达到690人。　　露西·齐贝吉医院是中国政府为肯方无偿援建的医院，是中国政府落实中非合作论坛北京峰会相关承诺的具体举措，总投资额达4650万人民币，于2009年6月开工建造。全部建成后，中方还将分两批向医院捐赠价值达2000万人民币的医疗设施，包括最先进的CT扫描仪。

title: Kayole Hospital (Duplicate)
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jun 30 – The construction of a Sh544 million Nairobi East District Hospital is due to be completed by August next year, authorities said on Tuesday.Speaking during the groundbreaking of the facility in Kayole, Acting Chinese Ambassador Zhou Pingjian said Sh117 million will go into equipping the facility which is being constructed with his government’s support.He said despite the economic crisis, the Chinese government remained committed to honour its pledges.“Everybody nowadays is taking about what effect the global financial meltdown will have on the donor community, and they ask us how we will meet our projects. We just tell then that china will not back down on our commitments”Medical Services Minister Anyang Nyong’o said the ministry plans to rehabilitate some 23 district and sub-district hospitals and two provincial hospitals in the country.“We have realised that over the last 20 years, we have not had very good investment in our hospitals. To improve equipment, infrastructure and provide adequate personnel,” said Prof Nyong’o.The Minister said it’s incumbent on the government to ensure affordable and accessible healthcare to Kenyans as they all pay their taxes to facilitate service delivery.Prof Nyong’o said the ministry was working on reforms in the healthcare sector that would reduce key issues such as high maternal and child morbidity and mortality, malaria, tuberculosis, as well as HIV and AIDS.“We cannot continue to recite endlessly; so many people are living below the poverty line so many people are dying every day that’s not a very good profession.”He said the facility will ease pressure on Kenyatta National Hospital and improve the delivery of health services adding that the ministry aims to turn all provincial hospitals into referral facilities in the next three years.“When this facility is done accessibility won’t be the issue, because since we are working on a comprehensive social health insurance scheme, affordability will not be the issue. Because with an insurance scheme which covers all by 2017, both in and out patient, we are sure that the urban poor will not worry to access this facility.”Prof Nyong’o said this will release some resources and energies at both KNH and Moi University hospitals to concentrate on research, teaching and handling of only special cases.---------Engineers work at the construction site of the Kayole hospital in Nairobi, capital of Kenya, June 4, 2010. The hospital, which is built with China's preferential loans, will help improve local's medical care and health. [Xinhua]

The Zimbabwean government was represented by Acting Minister of Finance and Economic Development Herbert Murera and the Chinese government was represented by Vice-Minister of Commerce Wei Jianguo.

title: Zimbabwe Purchases Chinese Fighters and Missiles
description: Zimbabwe Purchases Chinese Fighters and MissilesForecast International/Missile Forecast231 words14 April 2005Forecast International Defense Intelligence NewslettersFORCSTEnglish(c) 2005 Forecast International, Inc./DMS.NEWTOWN, Conn. - News sources in the U.S. and Africa are reporting that Zimbabwe has ordered Chinese fighter aircraft. Zimbabwe's state-controlled radio network announced the purchase of six fighters from China. The aircraft were purchased 'to deal with any challenges,' according to Zimbabwe state radio. New air-to-air missiles are expected to be part of this arms package.Where Zimbabwe got the money to purchase these aircraft when hundreds of thousands of its citizens are going hungry is unknown. A report by the South African Mail and Guardian newspaper estimated the cost of each aircraft at about $20 million.Giles Mutsekwa believes the aircraft were purchased to reward the Zimbabwe military and maintain its support for President Robert Mugabe's regime. Mutsekwa is the shadow Minister of Defense for Movement for Democratic Change, Zimbabwe's main opposition party. Mugabe has been repeatedly criticized for trying to turn Zimbabwe into a one-party state with himself as president-for-life.The aircraft being provided to Zimbabwe appear to be K-8 trainers, a Chinese copy of the British Hawk. Hawks were provided to Zimbabwe by the United Kingdom in 1980. British Prime Minister Tony Blair placed an embargo on spare parts for these aircraft in 2000. A few years ago, Zimbabwe acquired three used MiG-23 fighters from Libya.Document FORCST0020050415e14e0000a

title: Public sanitation works contract (duplicate #2417)
description: In February, the Mauritanian government gave a Chinese firm the contract to carry out public sanitation works in Nouakchott, at an estimated cost of 199 million dollars (147 million euros). It is unclear what the project involved and which companies were affiliated with it.

title: upgrade Eldoret Hospital
description: Wikileaks reports state that in May 2002 Kenya signed a 10 year loan with the Chinese government equivalent to Ksh 50.9 million to upgrade Eldoret Hospital. However, official Kenyan debt documents state that in 1998 Kenya accepted a loan of the same amount, intended to upgrade Eldoret Hospital. Although I was unable to find any explicit announcement of the project's completion, I believe the project to have reached completion because the Embassy of Kenya webpage (updated in 2012) lists the upgrade of Eldoret hospital as a project.

title: $2 billion for Hydro-electric power station
description: In 2011, President Banda of Zambia commissioned the construction of a $2 billion USD Kafue Gorge Lower Hydro-electric Power Station, which will add another 750 mW of power to the national grid upon completion in 2017. The project is being implemented under the public-private partnership made up of Zesco, Sino Hydro Corporation and the China Africa Development Fund. Sinohydro will be constructing the project; work began in July of 2011. The project will entail building new roads, homes, hospitals, and schools, and rehabilitating/expanding existing infrastructure. Minister of Energy and Water Development Kenneth Konga assured that the project would be carried out efficiently. The project appears to be untied.

title: Debt cancellation (Duplicate of 1361)
description: In July 2001, China agreed to partial debt cancellation for Tanzania. According to bilateral agreements, the Chinese government agreed to exempt Tanzania from the obligations of paying back 15 batches of interest-free loans to the value of US$ 19.2 million which had matured by the 31stDecember 1999. The debt relief accounted for one third of Tanzania's total debt owed to China in this period.10

title: (DUPLICATE) China has granted Zimbabwe a 200 million dollars buyer's loan
description: On June 30, 2009'We know that there are many other challenges that we will continue to face in terms of power generation, in terms of our transport network and in terms of supply of our water and we will continue to look to our friends, including the Republic of China, to assist us in investing in these areas so that we can deliver these enablers to industry,' Ncube said.China has helped Zimbabwe overcome its difficulties over the years and has donated an agriculture technology demonstration centre, a hospital and two primary schools, all of which are near completion. It has funded an orphanage just outside Harare, where it will also donate another primary school to accommodate 800 pupils.China has granted Zimbabwe a 200 million dollars buyer's loan and another favourable loan to support key sectors, in particular, agriculture.Recently, China provided 5 million dollars in cash aid and another 5 million dollars worth of food. At the height of the cholera epidemic in Zimbabwe last year, China donated 500,000 dollars to help ease human suffering.More funding has been provided for the refurbishment of the National Sports Stadium in Harare, while the Chinese community is involved in the Care Action project initiated by Ambassador Yuan, in which they help the disadvantaged, orphans and those affected and infected by HIV/AIDS.Source: Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in English 1726 gmt 30 Jun 09aa4f069cThe British Broadcasting CorporationDocument BBCAPP0020090630e56u003s5

title: China-Zimbabwe sign loan for telecom infrastructure
Chinese loan to Zimbabwean company Farmers' World
description: President Mugabe Hails China789 words8 July 201008:35 AMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2010 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedHarare, Jul 08, 2010 (The Herald/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- Zimbabwe and China should establish more areas of co-operation as bilateral relations between Harare and Beijing continue to grow from strength to strength, President Mugabe said yesterday.The President; who was speaking at State House yesterday where visiting Chinese Vice Minister Jiang Zengwei and his delegation paid a courtesy call on him; said there was need for China and Zimbabweto explore investment opportunities in the areas of energy, agriculture, infrastructure development and mining among others as Beijing could rely on the educated and skilled manpower among Zimbabweans.He said Harare would learn from China's technological advancement.Vice Minister Jiang had earlier during the day attended the eighth session of the Zimbabwe-ChinaPermanent Joint Commission where discussions to explore ways of co-operation were discussed.During the session, Mr Jiang signed a US$ 1,5 million facility with Health and Child Welfare Minister Dr Henry Madzorera for the construction of a hospital at Mahusekwa and supply of medical drugs.'The land, which was in the hands of the British, was taken and it is now in the hands of our people. But they now need equipment and the necessary capital to capacitate them. We need investment in agriculture, the sub-sectors mainly tobacco, cotton, maize, livestock and horticulture,' President Mugabe said.The President said through increased co-operation, Zimbabwe needed beneficiation of its products to realise maximum value.He said Zimbabwe is endowed with natural resources but their exploitation was being hindered by poor infrastructure such as bad roads.'We need some expansion that requires capital investment, irrigation schemes must be improved, we have a number of rivers, a criss-cross of rivers large and small but since we are a tropical country, we receive rains once a year and water goes,' he said.He said while Zimbabwe was more industrialised than some average African countries, more still needed to be done to improve the manufacturing sector.Turning to the diplomatic relations between Zimbabwe and China, the President said Harare would continue to strengthen ties with its allies and ignore Western countries that sought to unjustifiably vilify it.'They imposed sanctions on us and travel bans. I have no appetite for America, but I have an appetite for my country and my friends like China,' he said.He scoffed at the decision by the United States administration to place him and the First Lady Amai Grace Mugabe on the list of individuals believed to have funded terrorists.President Mugabe said former US president George W. Bush should instead be regarded as a terrorist for causing the death of former Iraq leader Saddam Hussein under the pretext that he harboured weapons of mass destruction.'There are people in Washington who think they have the divine right to judge on people. To say these are the good people of the world, these are the bad people, to say Zimbabwe is on the axis of evil together with Cuba, that is Bush acting as God,' he said.'We will stand by what is right even if we are to fall. Mao (Zedong) taught us to stand by that which is right, principles.'In his response, Mr Jiang hailed Zim-China bilateral relations saying Harare had remained resolute in pursuit of democracy.'Zimbabwe has got great respect because of its history in fighting colonialism,' he said.Mr Jiang said China had continued to encourage Chinese companies to invest in Zimbabwe, particularly in engineering.He said negotiations were underway between Zimbabwe and Chinese companies for joint ventures in the tobacco and cotton indus-tries, among others.'In the near future, Exim Bank (the Export-Import Bank of China) will send a delegation to Zimbabwe for discussions on investment. We also need to deepen co-operation on mining, (and) tourism,' he said.In his speech at the official opening of the Joint Commission, Foreign Affairs Minister Simbarashe Mumbengegwi outlined the support Zimbabwe had received from China.This includes the US$200 million Buyer's Credit Facility extended by China's Exim Bank to procure agricultural equipment.The bank also extended a US$60 million concessionary loan to Farmers' World to buy more farming implements.'The payment of the arrears and extension of the repayment period on the US$200 million Buyer's CreditLoan have paved the way for increased co-operation between Zimbabwe and China,' he said.Zimbabwe had also benefited from the eight measures announced by Chinese President Hu Jintao, whose implementation has seen the construction of two primary schools in Bindura and Warren Park, the Agricultural Demonstration Centre at Gwebi College and the state-of-the-art Sino-Zimbabwe Friendship Hospital in Mahusekwa.All Africa Global MediaDocument AFNWS00020100708e678000uu

title: China grants Comoros 4.3m US dollars in financial aid (Inactive: Duplicate #412)
description: MORONI, Jan. 25 (Xinhua) - China grants the Comoros a financial assistance worth 30 million yuan (4.3 million U. S. dollars) under an agreement signed on Sunday evening during a visit by Chinese Vice Foreign Minister Zhai Jun to Moroni, capital of the Indian Ocean island nation.According to the visiting Chinese diplomat, the Comoros will come up with a list of priority projects to benefit from the funding.Upon his arrival on Sunday morning, Zhai was received by President Ahmed Abdallah Sambi, Speaker of the National Assembly Bourhane Hamidou and Minister for External Relations Ahmed Ben Said Jaffar.In their talks, Zhai and Jaffar discussed the cooperation between the two countries, especially cultural exchanges ranging from an increase of Chinese scholarships to the assistance to the young Comoros University.Accompanied by Chinese Ambassador to the Comoros Tao Weiguang, the Chinese vice-minister paid a courtesy call to Speaker Hamidou. In their talks, Zhai urged continued support from the Comoros to the one-China policy.

title: Chinese businessman supplying ZANU-PF directly with money- not a project
description: Zanu PF Propped Up By Controversial Chinese Businessmanby Alex Bell730 words14 March 201105:06 PMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2011 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedMar 14, 2011 (SW Radio Africa/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- ZANU PF is reportedly being propped up by a controversial Chinese businessman, who has been supplying the Central Intelligence Organisation (CIO) with the means to keep Robert Mugabe in power.According to South Africa's Sunday Times newspaper, elusive business magnate Sam Pa and CIO chief Happyton Bonyongwe have struck a deal, which sees Pa financing 'a covert operation whose purpose is to sustain President Robert Mugabe's regime.'The newspaper quotes 'disillusioned intelligence officers and party officials,' who are said to be 'unhappy' about how Zimbabwe's natural resources are being traded for 'personal and electoral gain.'These sources allege that in return for Zimbabwe's diamonds and other mineral resources, Pa has provided funds and equipment to the CIO to enable it to deliver ZANU PF an electoral victory.The money is reportedly being used to train and deploy militias who are harassing and intimidating Zimbabweans across the country. It is also understood that Pa has provided the technology to rig election outcomes in ZANU PF's favour, a tool the party has repeatedly used to 'win' previous elections.The Sunday Times reports that Pa is also responsible for personally providing the CIO with fleets of cars and, in early 2010, he offered to match the salaries of the entire staff of the CIO, the police and the armed forces to ensure their loyalty to ZANU PF.Bonyongwe meanwhile stands accused of keeping this relationship well oiled, after 'negotiating' Pa's involvement in the Chiadzwa diamond fields.Pa is said to be behind the creation of the joint-venture Sino Zim Development, which was recently granted a licence to mine at Chiadzwa. The sources told the Sunday Times that using different aliases, Pa had flown out of Harare and military airbases last year with about 60 000 carats of high quality diamonds and 69kg of the industrial kind. Quoting 'renegade CIO sources,' the Sunday Times said that Pa himself 'is part of the grand plan to use (Chiadzwa) diamonds to prop up the regime.'The business magnate, described as 'elusive' and 'canny', is reported to have made similar arrangements in other African countries. Oil-rich Angola is described by the Sunday times as 'a prime example.' Pa has also invested heavily in mineral-rich Guinea and Tanzania, while Madagascar has also been linked to the Hong Kong based businessman.Political analyst Professor John Makumbe told SW Radio Africa that ZANU PF's involvement with such a character is not surprising.'It is typical of ZANU PF to be linked to the likes of Sam Pa, people who are involved in shady business deals, people who deliberately avoid transparency,' Makumbe said.China's influence in Zimbabwe is strengthening all the time, and it is understood that the Development Bank of China is planning US$10-billion worth of investments in Zimbabwe over the next five years.Last week, Chinese merchant Sinotex announced a US$500-million cotton production deal, set to benefit the ZANU PF beneficiaries of Robert Mugabe's land grab. At the same time, Zimbabwe's biggest tobacco buyer is a Chinese firm, Tian Ze, while the Chinese agribusiness Beidahuang Group is said to be negotiating for Zimbabwe's cane and forestry estates. The China National Nuclear Corporation is also said to be prospecting for uranium in Zimbabwe.The groups are all set to be exempt from ZANU PF's indiginisation plans, with tobacco firm Tian Ze already confirmed to be spared from handing over 51% ownership to Zimbabweans. South Africa's Mail   Guardian newspaper recently asked ZANU PF's Empowerment Minister Saviour Kasukuwere how companies qualify for such exemptions, and he said: 'We look at their disposition towards our people.'Makumbe said that ZANU PF will make every effort to maintain its relationship with the Chinese, not only because the country is one of Mugabe's key supporters on the United Nations Security Council. China has used its position as a permanent member of the Security Council to block any action against the ZANU PF regime.'It is a mutually beneficial arrangement, especially because ZANU PF is desperate for survival. They won't win an election without electoral rigging and they need people like Sam Pa to make that happen,' Makumbe said.All Africa Global MediaDocument AFNWS00020110314e73e0020j
donor_agency_count: Central Intelligence Organisation (CIO), Government Agency; Zimbabwe African National Union – Patriotic Front (ZANU-PF), Political Party

title: Diamond mining certificates in Zimbabwe granted to Chinese company Sino-Zimbabwe (Duplicate 22479)
description: Three New Diamond Miners Licensedby Martin Kadzere392 words9 November 201012:12 AMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2010 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedHarare, Nov 09, 2010 (The Herald/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- GOVERNMENT has licensed three more diamond investors to extract the gems in Chiadzwa, a senior official has said.Economic Planning and Investment Promotion Minister Tapiwa Mashakada told a pre-budget seminar in Victoria Falls last week that the licences were granted to Sino-Zimbabwe, a joint commercial entity between the Chinese government and Zimbabwe with business interests in various sectors.Another Chinese company Anjil and Pure Diamonds were also given concession in Chiadzwa diamond fields, said the minister.Mbada Diamonds and Canadile Mining were the only two companies mining in Chiadzwa in partnership with State-owned Zimbabwe Mining Development Mining Corporation.Government, however, pulled out of the Canadile joint venture amid allegations that key shareholders of its partners, Core Mining, could have been involved in blood diamond deals.'We now have five mining companies operating in Chiadzwa diamond field,' said Minister Mashakada, stressing the need for accountability so that Zimbabweans can fully benefit from diamond revenues.Prime Minister Morgan Tsvangirai had earlier told the same meeting that revenue from diamonds sales has not meaningfully contributed to the fiscus.'There were high expectations, but let me tell you that Chiadzwa diamonds have not produced 'eldorado',' said Prime Minister Tsvangirai.After the first batch of the diamonds stockpile was auctioned and raked in only US$56 million when many people had expected over a billion United States dollars, the belief that Chiadzwa was a treasure trove suffered considerably.At some point there was strong belief that the diamond sector could be the panacea to Zimbabwe's liquidity constraints, which have constrained economic recovery as capital challenges choked projects key to rebuilding the economy.Mbada and Canadile started operations in Chiadzwa late last year and auctioned the first batch of the gems in August this year.Experts say Zimbabwe could become the world largest producer of diamonds by 2013, with an expected volume of 40 million carats per year to be produced from the rich deposits in Chiadzwa.The export of 40 million carats provides annual revenue of about US$2 billion.Zimbabwe's mining sector, which needs at least US$5 billion to restore viability, is expected to grow by 44 percent next year on the strong performance of diamonds, platinum gold and nickel.All Africa Global MediaDocument AFNWS00020101109e6b900069-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Another Chinese Firm at Chiadzwaby Indiana Chirara331 words14 March 201108:49 AMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2011 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedMar 14, 2011 (Zimbabwe Standard/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- THE Zimbabwe Mining Development Corporation (ZMDC) has given another Chinese company a licence to mine diamonds in the controversial Chiadzwa area, a senior ZMDC official has said.Godwills Masimirembwa, the ZMDC chairman told Standardbusiness in an interview last week that Sino-Zimbabwe had joined Anjin, another Chinese company already in Chiadzwa prospecting for diamonds.A third company, Pure Dian from the United Arab Emirates, was also granted a license to join Mbada and Marange Resources, which already run mines in the area in partnership with the ZMDC.'Currently there are only two companies which are mining, that is Mbada and Marange,' he said.'The other three, which are Sino-Zimbabwe, Anjin and Pure Dian, are carrying out exploration though they have the licenses.'Masimirembwa said the ZMDC continued to receive a flurry of applications from both local and foreigninvestors who wanted licences to start mining operations in Chiadzwa.'We have more than 150 applications for mining licences from potential investors and this shows that as Zimbabwe, we have the resources and we have the capability of growing economically,' he said.'Financial and technical capacity are some of the conditions that determine the approval of a mining licence but it's not an easy road.'Masimirembwa said under normal circumstances, the sale of diamonds from Chiadzwa could rake in US$85 million a month but only US$20 million was being realised because of sanctions.'The production of diamonds is under very difficult circumstances and the sale of the mineral is at a very slow pace, which is not good for the economy,' he said.ZMDC is currently under pressure to account for proceeds from diamond sales after Finance minister Tendai Biti indicated that most of the money was not reaching government coffers.Masimirembwa and Zanu PF symphathisers have in turn accused Biti of trying to expose how Zimbabwe evades Western sanctions.All Africa Global MediaDocument AFNWS00020110314e73e00117---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Zmdc to Probe Sino-Zim Move318 words16 May 201111:15 PMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2011 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedMay 16, 2011 (The Herald/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- THE Zimbabwe Mining Development Corporation says it will send a team to investigate circumstances surrounding the recent temporary suspension of operations by Sino-Zimbabwe at the Chiadzwa diamonds fields.Sino-Zimbabwe laid off most of its workers amid concerns that its mining claims in the diamond area may not hold enough alluvial diamonds to operate a viable mine.ZMDC chairman, Mr Godwills Masimirembwa, at the weekend, said the parastatal was never informed on the development.Sino-Zimbabwe is a joint venture between China and the Government of Zimbabwe through the ZMDC.'We were not formally advised as the ZMDC and we do not have full details. We are sending a team to carry out a review at Sino-Zimbabwe,' Mr Masimirembwa said.'As far as we are concerned, they (Sino-Zimbabwe) are still on the ground.'Mr Masimirembwa said diamond production at Chiadzwa had not gone down but the problem was that companies mining the gems were unable to sell them on the international market freely.'The diamond resource is significant and claims to the contrary are totally untrue. What we, as ZMDC and the Government of Zimbabwe, are crying for is permission to sell our diamonds. If companies are not allowed to sell diamonds, it affects production and at the moment companies are finding it difficult because of the US policy on us. That is the real issue,' Mr Masimirembwa said.The US is leading a campaign to stop Zimbabwe from selling its diamonds on the international market citing unfounded human rights abuses.This is despite the fact that the Kimberley Process Certification Scheme recently gave the country the green light to trade in its gems.Sino-Zimbabwe, alongside Mbada Diamonds, Marange Resources, Pure Diamonds and Anjin are the five companies licensed to mine diamonds at the Chiadzwa diamonds fields.All Africa Global MediaDocument AFNWS00020110517e75h0001u

title: Cultural cooperation- likely duplicate with 16422
description: On August 26, 2002 an official Chinese delegation led by Prime Minister Zhu Rongji signed several agreements. One agreement provided for the dispatch of a Chinese medical team to Algeria. First medical team to Algeria.Under the fourth agreement, China will send more doctors to join the Chinese medical team already in the country, surgeons in particular  #21879Other agreements include an economic and technical agreement with Algeria that regulates a USD 6mn (although some sources say 7mn) loan with 25 years maturity from China #272, an agreement that provides for the construction of a new mosaics unit in Guelma #324, an agreement to rehabilitate and modernize a Chinese-built factory started over in 1999 #22429, and an agreement to enhance the existing cultural cooperation, which covers the 2002-2004 period.

title: wireless (CDMA) phone technology for CAMTEL
description: On January 31, 2007 Chinese President Hu Jintao signed a number of deals including a 40 million yuan grant. Cameroonian President Paul Biya commented on the deals. It appears that the grant  funded projects of the government of Cameroon's choosing, which according to sources, 'included wireless (CDMA) phone technology for CAMTEL (developed by Huawei Technologies), a potable water project for Douala (#315, and several small agricultural projects.' The extent to which this money funded these projects (or whether it did at all) is currently unclear, as well as the specifics of each project. This appears to be an ideal project to follow up on with in-country contacts. The project is likely linked to #11939, a 2007 preferential loan for telecommunications projects.
donor_agency_count: Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd., Private Sector
recipient_agencies: Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd., Private Sector

title: Advanced medical facilities and technologies (Not a specific Project)
description: On June 4, 2011, He Daofeng, executive vice president of China Foundation of Poverty Alleviation (CFPA), -- A Chinese charity organization has helped Sudan improve its maternity and family health care system, supporting the establishment of hospital in Abu Ushar, Gezira State.China Foundation of Poverty Alleviation (CFPA) has joined a five-year charity program, which will donate 60 million yuan (9.3 million U.S. dollars) to equip Sudan with more advanced medical facilities and technologies.The China-Sudan Abu Ushar Friendship Hospital, 140 kilometers south of Sudan's capital city of Khartoum, was the first project completed under the charity program, according to the CFPA.He Daofeng, executive vice president of CFPA, said when addressing a CFPA-hosted ceremony on Thursday to celebrate the hospital's establishment that the charity program in Sudan will be extended to other African nations.'The CFPA will give 200 million yuan over the next five years to international assistance programs,' he said.Now the CFPA is recruiting eight to 10 medical volunteers to work as doctors of obstetrics and gynaecology at Abu Ushar Friendship Hospital, according to a bulletin on the CFPA's official website.

title: 24 Chinese Agriculture Experts Arrive in Liberia (Inactive: See project #1830)
description: On June 5, 2012 twenty four agriculture technicians from the People’s Republic of China arrived in Liberia and pledged their commitment to working with the Government and people of Liberia and the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) in developing Liberia’s agriculture sector.The Chinese experts and technicians include agronomists, agro machinery operators, aquaculture specialists, animal experts, horticulturists, engineers, and advisors. They are assigned to work in Liberia for two years under the South-South Tripartite Agreement between FAO, the Government of Liberia, and the Government of the People’s Republic of China. They are taking up assignments in  Montserrado, Bomi, and Bong Counties performing technical, knowledge-sharing, and skills-transfer role with their Liberian counterparts. Li Zhigong is the Coordinator of the South-South 24-member team and Jean-Alexandre Scaglia is the FAO Country Representative.

title: PPIAF - Trans-Kgalagadi railway linking Botswana with Namibia (Proposed)
description: An October 25, 2011 report in the Zimbabwean stated that at the time of writing, no formal agreement had been made between Botswana and China on this railroad.According to Botswana Transport Hub coordinator, Mr. Thapelo Leareng, the Trans-Kgalagadi railway line is estimated at P70 billion. The proposed project will follow the Trans-Kgalagadi highway route. The project will provide a new trade route to the Atlantic Ocean in Namibia, and will open up development opportunities in the 1,500km corridor. Leareng said Botswana will engage private companies in the construction of the railway line. (PPIAF) Assistant Minister of Works and Transport has asked the Export-Import Bank of China to consider helping Botswana to construct the trans-Kgalagadi railway that would link Botswana with Namibia. Mr. Li urged Botswana to provide China with a package of projects for assistance.; Political/Resource Considerations: Coal (ailway that would help to transport coal to China via Namibian ports.); PPIAF-ID:48

title: PPIAF - Aluminium refinery on Konkoure River
description: (PPIAF) In 2007, two Chinese mining companies were engaged in discussions with the Guinean authorities to build an aluminium plant with an annual capacity of 240,000 tons. If the deal is successful, Hongpeng Sinozoto Mining Investment and the Luneng Jinbei Aluminium Group planned to invest over $2.9 billion USD towards the refinery and smelting works. In compensation for the investment, Guinea will secure 500 million tons of bauxite, the amount required to satisfy the demand of the refinery. It will also secure the use of existing infrastructure for transporting the aluminum. It is unclear what the status of the project is. Hongpeng Sinozoto Mining Investment does not appear to be an actual corporation. PPIAF-ID:375

title: Eximbank loan- many projects; better use as an aggregate estimate
description: President Beya of Cameroon met with the President of the Exim Bank of China, Li Ruogu, the Senior Branding Manager of Huawei Technologies co. Ltd Eddie Liou and Zhengfeipen, Founding President of CGC Overseas Construction Co. Ltd (CGCOC). Following this meeting, the Exim Bank that it was ready with a sum of 37 billion FCFA to invest in Cameroon.The project likely overlaps with other projects already recorded in this database. Reports mention that the leaders discussed the provision of potable water in Douala, which became an Exim Bank funded project in 2007 #315. This project record would best serve to indicate the Exim Bank's overall funding in Cameroon, and may prove useful in outreach stages or once other projects have been researched in estimating aggregate funding, and calculating the amount of funding promised by the Exim Bank currently unaccounted for. This funding may have gone towards projects that have been implemented and for whom the funding party is unknown. It may also not have yet been fully spent.

title: Infrastructure Projects in Burundi (Duplicate of a bunch)
description: 'China alone pledging to cancel Burundi's debt as well as build hospitals, schools, and a presidential palace, and rehabilitate a hydroelectric dam.'

title: Construction of elementary schools in Burundi (Duplicate)
description: 'Text of report by Burundi news agency ABPBujumbura, 9 October: The economic context of Sino-Burundian cooperation is marked by six priority projects in various sectors, ABP has learnt from the department in charge of Asia at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.These projects include the construction of the presidential palace, the rehabilitation of the Mugere Hydroelectric Station, the construction of three rural elementary schools, including two in Karusi Province (eastern central Burundi) and another at the Bujumbura Town Hall, the construction of a general hospital, the installation of a malaria prevention and treatment centre and the supply of anti-malarial drugs.At the conclusion of the 10th session of the Joint Sino-Burundian Commission held from 11 to 13 September 2007, when both parties went through cooperation in the financial, technical and commercial plans with a fine tooth comb, it emerged that an agreement for a donation of 30m yuan, or 4,414,050 US dollars, was signed for the rehabilitation of Mugere Hydroelectric Station.In addition, the session ended with a draft agreement relating to the cancellation of Burundi's debts to China of 137,470,000 yuan, equivalent to [approximately] 15,210,455 US dollars.The two governments are currently in negotiation over the Mpanda power generation hydroelectric and irrigation project which is being built by the Chinese company Gezhouba Water and Power (Group) Company Limited (CGGC). This project was to be financed through a preferential loan, will be carried out at a cost of 40,920,157 US dollars. The Burundian Foreign Ministry department in charge of Asia stresses that Sino-Burundian cooperation is very diversified and also touches the education and health sectorsIn 2008 China offered to 10 scholarships to Burundi for post-graduate studies.In the medical field, China sends medical teams every two years to assist the Burundian people.Source: ABP news agency, Bujumbura, in French 1027 gmt 9 Oct 08a8f2d59fDocument BBCAP00020081009e4a9001xj'

title: River Dja hydroelectric dam
description: 'YAOUNDE, Cameroon (Dow Jones)—China has offered the Cameroon government a loan of 22 billion CFA francs ($47.2 million) for the construction of a new hydroelectric dam on the River Dja that will produce 12 megawatts of electricity.An agreement for the project was signed Thursday by China's Ambassador to Cameroon, Huang Changqing, and Cameroon's Minister of Economic Planning and Regional Development, Louis Paul Motaze.The total cost of the dam project is estimated at XAF27 billion, with the remaining XAF7 billion coming from the Cameroon government.Cameroon acutely needs energy to boost its alumina industry and kick-start iron ore production.The dam will take three years to build, according to the accord, and will hold an estimated 940 million cubic meters of water, which will provide power as well as a yearly output of 500 metric tons of fish when finished.-By Emmanuel Tumanjong, contributing to Dow Jones Newswires, +237-9655-6261, +237-7773-1930, tnuel@yahoo.com [ 07-01-10 1524GMT ]'

title: Loan (Inactive: this loan went towards Project ID# 359)
description: 'China's foreign minister signed a multimillion dollar (euro) loan deal with the island nation of Cape Verde, his first stop on an eight-day African tour aimed at strengthening ties with the resource-rich continent.Chinese Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing signed the deal with Cape Verdean Foreign Minister Victor Borges, the Portuguese news agency Lusa reported late Wednesday. The interest-free loan is worth US$2.4 million, or about euro2 million.In Beijing, Chinese officials said Thursday that Africa's abundant natural resources, including oil, timber and iron ore, were essential to powering China's exploding economic development.China is helping Cape Verde build its first hydroelectric dam and renovate public buildings, Lusa reported. Li and Borges declined to address local media reports that Cape Verde hopes to develop natural gas reserves said to have been found in the former Portuguese colony's waters.'

title: $24m for wireless network in Chad
description: In September 2007, Chinese and Chadian officials signed a $257 million USD economic agreement to fund a cement factory, a telecommunications project, a road network, and a new electronic records system for the Chadian government. $24 million USD was designated for the wireless network, to be implemented by ZTE. Phase 1 was completed in 2007, and covered 10,000 lines in N'Djamena, while phase 2 will cover an additional 19 million lines nationwide. STAFF_NOTES: See project ID#396, ID#397, ID#400, and ID#401 for sister projects. The suspicious button was used for this project due to the general lack of confident information.

title: Wireless Network (Not a project)
description: Zhongxing Technologies (ZTE) and Huawei Technologies, both of China, have been awarded two contracts worth a total of $18 million by state- owned Telecom Egypt (TE) to install code division multiple access (CDMA) wireless local loop (WLL) networks in rural and remote areas including Upper Egypt, the Suez Canal region, the Mediterranean coast and the Sinai. The networks will provide services to 100,000 subscribers. Both companies have been pursuing an aggressive policy of expansion in North Africa recently, and in February were awarded two financing assistance packages worth $1,100 million in total by the Export-Import Bank of China to support their foreign sales programmes. The latest awards come nine months after Huawei signed a partnership agreement with TE subsidiary Egyptian Telephone Company to manufacture and market WLL terminals in the domestic market under the Quicktel brand. ZTE in January was awarded contracts to install a WLL network in Libya (MEED 23:1:04; 16:1:04).Document QEDMEE0020040518e05e0000r' '在開羅舉行的『2004國際電信聯盟非洲展覽會』上，中興通訊股份有限公司和深圳華為技術有限公司分別於4日和6日與埃及電信公司簽署了合同總額達2000多萬美元的CDMA無線接入網絡協議。　　據埃及電信公司主席阿基勒介紹，這是埃及電信公司與外國公司簽署的第一個有關CDMA項目的合同，中興和華為兩家公司將共同承擔該項目的建設，項目完成後可為10萬埃及用戶提供無線接入網絡服務。QQ休閑交流群:49846326 編輯： 陳舒 　'

title: Oil rig production (Duplicate)
description: '(c) 2006 Dow Jones Reuters Business Interactive LLC, trading as Factiva  CAIRO (Reuters) - An Egyptian-Chinese company will start producing oil rigs in Egypt next year, the Egyptian Oil Ministry said in a statement on Wednesday.' 'China and Egypt have agreed to three new memoranda of understanding (MoU) on energy-sector co-operation. The first of these concerns the establishment of a joint rig manufacturing company, which would manufacture three rigs in 2007 and a further seven in 2008, reaching a total of 20 rigs by 2010. The second agreement concerns the involvement of China's Chinook company for oil exploration in Egyptian acreage. The company would also work with Egyptian companies, including Enppi and Petrojet, on projects in other African states. The third agreement concerns drilling by Sinopec, both inside and outside Egypt.Significance: Chinese oil companies have been relatively slow off the mark in Egypt, compared with other African states, although the last year has seen a more significant 'push' for new investment. This has seen the state start-up Tharwa form a drilling venture with Sinopec, possibly the same agreement referred to in the third MoU (see Egypt: 7 July 2006: ).The Chinese-Egypt MoU is notable for the technical aspects of the projects under consideration, with Egypt very much keen to extract the maximum benefits from state-backed investors, in terms of boosting domestic technical capacity and realising employment opportunities. Strong interest from other international players has strengthened Egypt's hand in this regard.' ' 埃及和中国签订了三份石油和天然气合作协议，将在2007年前共建3所石油钻塔。    综合外电10月23日报道，埃及和中国签订了三份石油和天然气合作协议，其中主要合作方式为建立石油钻塔。    《生活日报》（Al-Hayat）22日的报道称，埃及石油部长法赫米（Sameh Fahmy）与中国石油化工股份有限公司（China Petroleum   Chemical Corp., 或称Sinopec, 简称：中石化）签订了一份协议，将创建一家埃及和中国合资的搭建石油钻塔的专业公司。    这所名为中石化--塔尔（Sino-Tharwa）的公司将在2007年前搭建3所石油钻塔，在2008年前搭建另外7所钻塔，并计划提高产量以在2010年前搭建20所钻塔。    该报援引自法赫米的报道称，鉴于对钻塔需求的增长和租赁钻塔成本增加，这些钻塔将有助于推进埃及的开采活动。    第二份协议是在法赫米近期访问中国期间签订的，旨在国际竞标方面进行合作。    第三份协议是同中石化签订的，内容为增加中石化在埃及的活动，并在两年内将石油钻塔由2所增加至7所。（责任编辑：郭彩萍）'

title: China Provides US$1.2m Grant to Gabon- needs follow up
description: Reports indicate that in February of 2012 a number of other accords were expected to be signed in the course of Hu's visit, including on economic and technical co-operation, which will provide a grant of US$1.2m to the Gabonese government.The offer at the grant reportedly would come at the same time as an offer of an interest-free loan of US$6m, #580.This project needs follow up to determine whether it occurred and how.

title: China Grants US$5m in aid- duplicate with 586
description: Beijing grants $5 million in aid as President Bongo continues his one-week visit to China. Chinese President Hu Jintao has put forward proposals for developing sustainable relationship between China and Gabon. The Chinese leader held talks Wednesday in Beijing with visiting Gabonese President El Hadj Omar Bongo Ondimba. He said China is ready to work with Gabon to maintain the good momentum of the development of bilateral relations. In order to promote these relations, Hu proposed that the two countries push forward political communications and people-to-people exchanges, saying the two sides should further exchange mutual understanding and friendship so as to lay a solid foundation for the long-term development of bilateral relations. Secondly, President Hu said the two countries should further tap into the potential of trade and economic cooperation and expand the scale of cooperation. He said China will continue to encourage strong and prestigious Chinese enterprises to invest and do business in Gabon. He hoped the two sides will reinforce cooperation in such resources development areas as oil, mining and reforestation. Also he hoped that both sides explore such cooperative areas as agriculture, water conservation and fishing. Thirdly, President Hu said the two countries should deepen exchanges and cooperation in such fields as education, culture and public health; and step up collaboration in human resources development under the framework of the China-Africa Forum. Finally, Hu insisted that the two countries should give a bigger role to the political consultation mechanism between their foreign ministries so as to maintain sound cooperation and coordination on international affairs. President Bongo agreed with Hu on his comments on bilateral relations. He reiterated Gabon's stance on firmly sticking to the one-China policy and its support to China's cause of reunification. President Bongo briefed Hu about the current situation of Africa and the existing hot issues. Noting that China is a true friend of Africa, he said Gabon and other African states wish to deepen cooperation with China and hope that China will play a bigger role in resolving the hot issues in Africa. After the talks, the two presidents attended the signing ceremony of some documents between their governments, including the agreement on economic, technological cooperation and an aid package of $ 5 million (about CFA 2.7 billion) granted by Beijing for for development projects in Gabon.

title: 1.9 billion dollar deals with unnamed African countries
description: At a summit in Beijing, 12 Chinese firms and African governments and companies sign deals worth $1.9 billion involving 11 African countries covering areas such as infrastructure, telecoms and technological equipment, mineral resource development and insurance

title: Emergency relief assistance (Duplicate)
description: In talks with Prime Minister Meles Zenawi, the vice-foreign minister, Jang Wenchang, said that his country was donating 5,000 metric tonnes of emergency relief assistance to the drought-induced food shortage in Ethiopia
sector: Humanitarian and Disaster Relief and Preparation

title: Polyester factory (Duplicate)
description: Within the framework of his current visit to China, Dr. Mahmoud Mohieldin, minister of investment, has held a series of discussions with a number of Chinese officials. The discussions have presented areas of cooperation between the two countries as well as available investment opportunities in Egypt which the Chinese can take part in.Mohieldin has met with Mr. Chi Jianxin, the (CADFund) CEO in a meeting attended by the Egyptian Ambassador to China, Mr. Ahmed Rizq. A number of heads of private and public companies and establishments, as well as representatives of some ministries participating in the visit and the Chief Director of the Promotion Agency at the COMESA were also present.During the meeting, Mohieldin proposed five topics including the Egyptian- Chinese cooperation at the North-West Suez Gulf Economic Zone, which is witnessing notable Chinese investment, and is being developed by Egypt Teda, a Chinese company. Minister Mohieldin also stressed the importance of encouraging the Chinese to invest in that zone. This is a manifestation of the Chinese concern to invest in Africa. The China-Africa Development Fund seeks to establish five economic zones in Africa, the North-West Suez Gulf Economic Zone is the first one of them.CEO of the China-Africa Development Fund has confirmed that China is interested in increasing its investments in the North-West Suez Gulf Economic Zone. There have been talks with a number of Chinese companies to invest in the zone. These companies include a company for producing tractors, a second for motorbikes, and a third for non-woven fabric.The second topic discussed an invitation to the Chinese side to invest in projects along the Upper Egypt-Red Sea Road, which links three Upper Egypt governorates to the Red Sea ports. This road created new projects for containers and developing ports.China is interested in such projects, especially those of the Red Sea ports, he said, adding that he would pay a visit to the Red Sea ports to closely get acquainted with the available projects.In the third topic, Mohieldin stressed the importance of promoting the Egyptian-Chinese investment relations through increasing the Chinese investments in Egypt and vice versa. If the Egyptian investments in China increased, this would, accordingly, boost the bilateral trade exchange and increase Egypt''s exports to China. The bilateral trade exchange is $6200 million, of which $500 million only are Egyptian exports.In the fourth topic, Mohieldin stressed the African dimension in the Egyptian-Chinese relations through cooperation with COMESA and the Nile Basin countries. Egypt and China should establish joint projects in Africa in the fields of infrastructure and roads, either financed by Egypt or CADFund.The Fund CEO has stressed that China supports investment in Africa, adding that the Fund opened a branch in South Africa and studies to open another one in North Africa.Egypt will be hosting this branch. Furthermore, CDB owns a representation office in Egypt.The fifth topic tackled preparations for the Chinese African Forum to be held in Sharm el-Sheikh and opened by President Mubarak. It would be attended by China''s prime minister. The forum emphasizes the powerful Chinese African relationships It coincides with China''s 60th birthday celebrations.The COMESA Investment Promotion Agency chief, Hiba Salama, has reviewed the key investment opportunities available in COMESA member states. The Chinese side promised to consider them.The minister also met with the Chinese deputy minister of trade in the presence of Egypt''s ambassador to China and representatives of a number of public and private companies.The minister pointed to China''s investment growth. He said China has 865 companies in Egypt, 80% of which was set up during the past five years. In 2008, China was the largest investor in Egypt and occupied the 23rd position among the largest investors in Egypt since 1970.Minister Mohieldin presented the investment opportunities available in Egypt, particularly in Upper Egypt, plus 52 projects recently announced by the government with total investments of $25 billion. They are expected to be implemented in the coming three years.The minister and the Chinese official also discussed grants and technical aid that China extends to Egypt such as the polyester factory in Kafr el-Dawar, which opens soon. Part of the factory production would be export-oriented to China.They discussed the Chinese loan project for building Cairo Exhibition City implemented by Egypt''s Trade and Industry Ministry. A $200-million loan has been provided for the first phase of the project.The minister was interviewed by the Chinese Radio and Chinese TV network. He expressed Egyptians'' appreciation to the Chinese nation on the occasion of China''s 60th birthday. He said China has introduced a model for development and successfully overcome the obstructions it has been facing. It also made a revolution in fields of industry, agriculture and poverty reduction through a clear and definite growth strategy, giving hope to the developing countries to follow in China''s suit in its experiment. International reports tend to place China on the top of global economy in the future.'

title: Not a project: Capacity building training in the field of auditing
description: Addis Ababa, Apr 26, 2006 (The Ethiopian Herald/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- The Head of China's National Audit Office Li Jinhua and Ambassador of China to Ethiopia Lin Lin visited the Office of the Auditor General here yesterday. Speaking on the occasion Chinese Auditor General Li Jinhua said that his country has plans to provide capacity building training for Ethiopians in the field of auditing. Jinhua also said the objective of the visit of the Chinese delegation is to explore the possibilities of cooperation and sharing practical experience with its Ethiopian counterpart. Federal Auditor General Lemma Argaw on the occasion said the visit of the Chinese delegation is encouraging as it would pave the way for cooperation between the two countries in improving the auditing profession. Lemma said his Office has been striving to improve its auditing system and develop its human power within the limits of available resources. The seven-member Chinese delegation led by Jinhua is on a three-day official visit to Ethiopia beginning April 24, 2006. Meanwhile, Speaker of the House of Peoples' Representatives, Ambassador Teshome Toga received and held talks with the Chinese delegation led by Chinese Auditor General, Li Jinhua. Speaking on the occasion, Ambassador Teshome said Ethiopia and China enjoy long-standing relations, adding, the experience sharing between the two countries in the field of auditing would step up the existing bilateral relations. The Speaker said Office of the Federal Auditor General was established based on the constitution and is responsible to monitoring government expenditures. The Office, which is accountable to the House of Peoples' Representatives, is one of the efficient auditing offices in Africa, he added. Ambassador Teshome also expressed belief that the visit by the Chinese delegation would have paramount importance in building the capacity of the Office. Chinese Auditor General, Jinhua on his part said the long-standing relations between his country and Ethiopia is currently in a very good shape. He added that the Chinese Audit Bureau would exchange experience with its Ethiopian counterpart and provide technical training for Ethiopians in the field of auditing. An agreement that would enable to conduct pre-shipment inspection on goods Ethiopia imports from China was also signed in the Chinese capital Beijing yesterday, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said. In a statement it sent to ENA, the ministry said the agreement is signed between Ethiopian Minister of Trade and Industry Girma Birru and the Chinese Quality Control, Inspection and Quarantine Administration Minister Chang Jiang. The agreement enables to conduct control and inspection on goods imported and exported from both countries in accordance with the pertinent rules and regulations of the two countries and established international laws. It was indicated that the agreement would also enable to implement successful practices that help improve the quality and price of goods that are imported from China to Ethiopia, the statement said. The ministry also said Ethiopia and China have agreed to work in cooperation to facilitate trade relations between the two countries in way that promote their economic interest. According to the statement, the pre-shipment inspection would allow for the importation of Chinese goods that meet Ethiopian quality standards and the rules and regulations of the two countries. The agreement is believed to transform the growing trade relations between the two countries into a new chapter. The ministry said quoting the Ethiopian Embassy in Beijing that the delegation led by Trade and Industry Minister Girma Birru would travel to the Chinese province of Jiangxu and visit the quality control institutions, bureaus and export factories.
sector: Trade, Tourism, Banking and Financial Services

title: Rebuilding the telecommunication network
description: In October and November of 2003, two projects on rebuilding the telecommunication network and repairing some parts of Angolan railways in three Angolan provinces were carried out. The projects were funded by the Chinese government. Further details on the project are unclear. This project is a possible update for project ID#206.

title: Grant to boost Lesotho broadcast media (Duplicate with 734)
description: China will help finance a 100m rand (15m dollars) project to boost television and radio in the tiny kingdom of Lesotho, which has one of the patchiest communication systems in Africa, a minister said today. Under the project, due to start in January, China will give 30m rand (4.5m dollars) worth of equipment and technical assistance in installing transmitters, towers, antennas and generators to keep the system running, the kingdom's Minister of Broadcasting Tom Thabane told state-owned Radio Lesotho. The project will enable Lesotho to rent bandwidth on existing satellite networks for both television and FM radio broadcasts, as well as improving power infrastructure. A long-term partnership with the South African Broadcasting Corporation (SABC) allows the broadcast of the big neighbour's radio and television to Lesotho homes. Multichoice, the pay-TV subsidiary of South African media firm Naspers also has a significant subscriber base with Direct Service pay-TV (DSTV) in the country.

title: Dam promised on Geba River (sketchy)
description: In November 2006, China announced it was going to fund the construction of a dam on the Geba river, in the east of the country at Saltinho at a cost of $60 million. Since the initial report, the dam project has been often referred to in the media, but it is unclear as to wether the project actually occurred. The sketchy button has been deployed on this project, as a diplomatic cable referred to this project as only costing 'USD 5 million for a hydro-electric dam on the Geba River.'

title: Road construction grant (China or Taiwan?)
description: On May 23, 2000 China announced that it would provide funding for road construction. In 2008, as part of a $287 million USD aid package, China provided funding for the Karonga-Chitipa.The road will connect the northern town of Karonga, which borders Tanzania, to the town of Chitipa near Malawi's border with Zambia.The China Road and Bridge Corporation began implementing the highway project in 2008 in place of earlier Taiwanese construction companies. The 106 km highway is set for completion on October 31, 2012. The estimated project costs and China's contributions are confusing and vary by years. According to some sources, China provided a $15 million grant for the road. According to others, the project cost estimates total $38 million. Some say that the African Development Bank has provided an $18 million loan, while the balance will be made available by the Malawi government.中国援建马拉维的公路项目举行施工合同签字仪式                晟华                     【摘要】：正2008年7月3日,由中国援建的马拉维卡隆加—奇提帕公路项目举行13 km路段施工合同签字仪式。马拉维交通公共工程部常务秘书Francis Chinsinga和中国路桥坦桑尼亚分公司经理郭庆分别代表马拉维政府和                  【关键词】：              公路项目  施工合同  签字仪式  中国援建  高质量  公共工程  施工单位  路桥  交通  中国政府  【分类号】：F541【正文快照】：          2008年7月3日，由中国援建的马拉维卡隆加一奇提帕公路项目举行13 km路段施工合同签字仪式。马拉维交通公共工程部常务秘书Francis Chinsinga和中国路桥坦桑尼亚分公司经理郭庆分别代表马拉维政府和项目施工单位在施工合同上签字。马拉维交通公共工程部长班达、中国驻马拉维马拉维工程部部长、中国驻马大使视察公司卡 — 奇道路工程                          信息来源： 　 发布日期：2011-6-15 　 阅读次数:1024次                              6月8日上午10时，中国驻马拉维大使潘和钧、经参处参赞胡玉杰、马拉维工程部部长Sidik Mia阁下及随行人员在公司驻马拉维办事处总经理及项目经理的陪同下参观、视察了我公司承建的中国援马拉维卡隆加 — 奇提帕道路工程项目。   马工程部部长对工程进度和质量给与了高度肯定，他称赞到，“中国路桥公司完成了99%的路基土石方和桥涵工程，打通了两城市间的道路，使两城市的行驶时间由原来的5小时缩短到1个半小时”。潘大使对工程进度和质量也给与了高度肯定，他表示，当地政府部门与承包商之间良好的合作关系确保了工程有序进展，相信在大家的共同努力下，整个工程将尽快完工。最后，潘大使就工程目前面临的项目燃料、拆迁和基层材料等问题向工程部长进行了强调。

title: National Assembly (Inactive: same as #740)
description: Guinea-Bissau's President Malam Bacai Sanha on Wednesday inaugurated his government's new 25-million-dollar headquarters, entirely built with Chinese funding.The building, situated in the north of the capital Bissau, took 18 months to build and consists of three large blocks that can accommodate 12 ministries.It is 'a symbol of the fruitful cooperation long held with China who we thank from the bottom of our hearts,' said Sanha at the inauguration.At Sanha's side was the Chinese ambassador to Guinea-Bissau, Li Bao Jun.'It is the fruit of frank and enduring cooperation,' said Li.China has already played a hand in other projects in Bissau including the National Assembly, built in 2000 for six million dollars, a military hospital with 200 beds that cost 12 million dollars, as well as a 25,000-seat stadium.Beijing has also financed renovation work on barracks, hospitals and has invested in the west African country's agriculture sector.China is interested in offshore oil exploration and the vast forest and fishing wealth of Guinea-Bissau.But the country has been chronically unstable since independence from Portugal in 1974 with coups, army mutinies and political murders. It has also in recent years been turned into a drug trafficking hub by South American barons targetting European markets.

title: Development package grant- likely a duplicate or cancelled
description: In August, 2005 reports show that President Mwai Kibaki traveled to China. During his visit, China and Kenya signed a framework agreement on provision of a concessional loan. Within this agreement, China agreed to extend to Kenya a grant of 600m Kenya shillings for projects of the government's choice. However, it seems likely that the grant may not have been followed through, or may duplicate other projects. Virtually no information is available about the grant, although a list of major Chinese-Kenyan projects includes a disbursement amount for the grant's sister project #808, a concessional loan project. The grant may or may not be linked with other agreements signed during President Kibaki's visit to China, including the agreement on economic and technical cooperation and the collaborative agreement between the Central Administration of Quality Supervision, Inspection and Quarantine of the People's Republic of China and the Kenya Bureau of Standards.

title: Antimalaria drug donation (Duplicate)
description: On April 28, 2006 the Chinese president extended a grant of 440 million Kenyan shillings for Kenya to buy anti-malaria drugs. Present at the signing were Kenyan Cabinet ministers Amos Kimunya (Finance), Mukhisa Kituyi (Trade), Maina Kamanda (Sports), Henry Obwocha (Energy), head of civil service Francis Muthaura and Education permanent secretary Karega Mutahi. Also present were ministers John Michuki and Mutahi Kagwe and attorney-general Amos Wako, as well as the Chinese First Lady and other top Chinese government officials.No further details about the grant are currently known.

title: Electoral equipment- duplicate with 853
description: Text of report in English by official Chinese news agency Xinhua (New China News Agency)[Xinhua: ' China Offers Aid To Cote D'Ioire's No. 29 Election']ABIDJAN, Sept. 28 (Xinhua) - China has offered materials in support for the presidential elections scheduled for No. 29 in Cote d'Ioire, the West African country's Independent Electoral Commission (CEI) said in its latest statement.'This aid follows a formal request by CEI during the meeting with the Chinese ambassador in Cote d'Ioire in the month of September 2008,' the commission announced on Sunday, in reference to the equipment ranging from mobile phones to sun lamps from China.Meanwhile, the CEI expressed satisfaction that part of the proposed 7 million euros (10 million U. S. dollars) for the electoral process had been released by the Ministry of Economy and Finance.Apart from China, partners both at home and abroad have offered assistance to the CEI or are planning to do so, the statement said.The United Nations Operation in Cote d'Ioire (ONUCI) has carried out the mission to move ballot boxes and other electoral materials from the port of Abidjan to the interior of the country since August.An estimated 6.5 million nationals were registered during the voter identification operation. The publication of the polling list, originally set for Sept. 15, failed to materialize, but is expected to be done in the coming days, according to the CEI.Cote d'Ioire is in the run-up to the election to end the crisis that has divided the country since 2002.

title: Total annual investments from China- inactive
description: Marcel Gossio, the director-general of the autonomous port of Abidjan, Kadio Kouame, the head of the Societe de Developpement Minier (SODEMI) and Kassoum Fadika, the head of PETROCI, moved heaven and earth in recent months in their efforts to get the Chinese to help Laurent Gbagbo, but to no avail. The Chinese were not distancing themselves from Iory Coast’s political crisis. For the moment, the country simply isn’t one of their priorities. Chinese investments in Iory Coast were a mere $1.5 million in 2010, making the country China’s fifth partner in Africa.NOT A PROJECT

title: Health, agriculture, fisheries and public works projects (Inactive: same as #872)
description: LISBON, Dec 15 (AFP) - President Kumba Yala of Guinea-Bissau said Sunday he would seek financial aid from China during his current visit to the country to help pay public servants' salaries and hold early legislative elections.'Our immediate priorities are to secure financial aid for the public service and the organization of elections,' he said following a meeting with immigrants from the tiny west African nation in Beijing, the Lusa news agency reported.Yala has said an exact date for the poll will be set after he returns to Guinea-Bissau on Wednesday, with the election taking place within the first three months of 2003.A parliamentary election had not been due in the former Portuguese colony until the end of 2003, but Yala on November 15 dismissed a government which he accused of incompetence and dissolved the National Assembly, citing a 'ery serious economic crisis'.The country, one of the poorest in the world, has since been run by a caretaker cabinet dominated by members of Yala's Social Renovation Party (PRS).The PRS does not have a majority in the outgoing parliament which had been elected in 1999.Under the constitution, a parliamentary election should be held within 90 days of the dissolution of the National Assembly.The country's National Electoral Commission said last month it was ready to hold elections as early as February but needed 2.2 million euros (dollars) to prepare the poll.Yala, who arrived in Peking on Saturday on the start a five-day official visit to China, said he would also seek aid for infrastructure projects, particularly those that develop the nation's communication network.He is scheduled to meet with Chinese President Jiang Zemin on Monday in Beijing and will travel on Tuesday to the coastal city of Shanghai for a meeting with Prime Minister Zhu Rongji.China currently aids the small country of 1.3 million people with numerous development projects in the areas of health, agriculture, fisheries and public works.China and Guinea-Bissau re-established diplomatic ties in 1998 after an eight-year hiatus, following the recognition of Taiwan by Bissau's then president Joao Bernardo Vieira.Guinea-Bissau held its first multiparty legislative elections in 1994, 20 year after gaining independence from Portugal, but its transition back to democracy has been complicated by its crippled economy, which was devastated in a civil war.

title: The Chinese government donates de-mining equipment (Duplicate)
description: Chinese official urges more nations to support inhumane conventional weapons ban.445 words12 December 200009:46 AMBBC Monitoring Asia Pacific - PoliticalBBCAPPEnglish(c) 2000 The British Broadcasting Corporation [date of publication]. All Rights Reserved. No material may be reproduced except with the express permission of The British Broadcasting Corporation.Text of report in English by official Chinese news agency Xinhua (New China News Agency)Geneva, 12th December: China supports the international treaty that bans and restricts the use of inhumane conventional weapons and is encouraging more countries to accept it, a senior Chinese disarmament official said on Monday [11th December].At the Second Annual Conference of High Contracting Parties to the Amended Protocol II, the head of the Chinese delegation, Sha Zukang, brought up the Convention on Prohibitions or Restrictions on the Use of Conventional Weapons Which May Be Deemed Excessively Injurious or to Have Indiscriminate Effects.'The Chinese delegation has noted that, since the last annual conference, the number of countries that have acceded to the amended protocol has increased from 45 to 58,' said Sha. 'This shows that more and more countries attach importance to the protocol, which is the first international legal instrument to address this issue of humanitarian concern. Now, almost all major land mine producing and using countries have acceded to the protocol.'However, Sha said 58 states are too few. 'Lack of universality will undercut the protocol's significance,' he stressed. 'And no matter how perfect an international legal instrument is, its influence and effectiveness will be limited in the absence of universal participation.'He urged the states to follow the protocol in earnest.Sha announced that the Chinese delegation is strongly opposed to any proposal for further amending the protocol at the current stage.However, he said, states may on a voluntary basis take the lead in implementing technical specifications as outlined in the proposed amendments and provide gratuitous technical assistance, equipment and training to developing countries.On humanitarian de-mining, Sha said that the Chinese government is continuing to cooperate with the Mine Action Service of the United Nations Department of Peacekeeping Operations by co-sponsoring another training workshop on de-mining technology from May to June this year, with trainees from Angola, Ethiopia, Mozambique, and Rwanda.The Chinese government is pressing rapidly ahead with its donations of de-mining equipment to Cambodia, Angola, Mozambique, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Rwanda and Namibia, he added.'We hope this conference will strengthen exchanges and cooperation on de-mining technologies for reducing and ultimately doing away with land mines Sha said [as received].He emphasized that the Chinese government stands ready to cooperate and exchange with interested countries and inter-organizations in the field of humanitarian de-mining assistance and that China is also willing to join other states and explore ways to streamline the de-mining process.Source: Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in English 1308 gmt 12 Dec 00.Document bbcapp0020010804dwcc007hc
