title: Economic and Tehnological Cooperation 11/2006 (DUPLICATE)
description: Beijing, 1 November: China would work with Guinea-Bissau to promote traditional friendship and increase bilateral cooperation, said President Hu Jintao here Wednesday [1 November].Hu made the remarks during the talks with his counterpart of Guinea-Bissau Joao Bernardo Vieira, who was here on a state visit to China and would also attend the upcoming Beijing Summit of the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation (FOCAC).'China and Guinea-Bissau in recent years have enjoyed fruitful cooperation in various fields,' Hu said, noting that the two nations supported each other in international affairs and witnessed sound development of bilateral friendly cooperation.China appreciated Guinea-Bissau's adherence to the one-China policy and its support for China's reunification, the president said.To develop stable and cooperative relations between China and Guinea-Bissau accords with the fundamental interests of both nations and both peoples, Hu said.In order to enhance the China-Guinea-Bissau friendly cooperation, Hu suggested the two nations maintain the momentum of high-level visits and increase exchanges and cooperation between the two governments, parliaments and political parties.The two nations should work hard to implement current economic and trade cooperation projects and expand cooperation in fishery, agriculture, infrastructure, personnel training, culture, education and health, Hu said.Hu hoped the two nations would strengthen cooperation under the FOCAC framework, and enhance consultations and cooperation in international affairs, in an effort to jointly safeguard the legal interests of developing countries and to make contributions to the construction of a harmonious world.Vieira said China was a friendly nation of Guinea-Bissau. He expressed appreciation for China to provide Guinea-Bissau with assistance to improve people's lives and help his country's social and economic progress.Vieira reiterated that Guinea-Bissau would firmly stick to the one-China policy.Vieira said Guinea-Bissau would push for the existing friendly cooperative relations with China, and deepen mutually-beneficial cooperation in fishery, agriculture and energy.Vieira also hoped that the two nations would strengthen coordination in international affairs, since both sides shared common or similar views on such issues as reforms of the United Nations, poverty reduction and anti-terrorism.Hu and Vieira agreed to make joint efforts to assure a complete success of the upcoming Beijing Summit scheduled for 4-5 November.After the talks, the two presidents attended a signing ceremony of documents concerning bilateral economic and technological cooperation.Source: Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in English 0927 gmt 1 No 06

title: PROPOSED electric power development and water reservoir construction
description: During a visit to China to attend the Summit of Forum on China-Africa Cooperation in November 2006, Guinea-Bissau President Joao Bernardo Vieira proposed two projects: electric power development and water reservoir construction. 'Please draft out the cooperation plans immediately. What Guinea-Bissau needs most is development, especially better infrastructure facilities,' said the President at the China Machinery and Equipment Import and Export General Corporation (CMEC). It appears that these projects remained a proposal and never received funding.

title: cancel debts that matured at the end of 2005
description: BEIJING, No. 4 (Xinhua) -- Chinese President Hu Jintao met with Ethiopian Prime Minister Ato Meles Zenawi on Saturday, highlighting comprehensive and cooperative partnership between the two countries. Hu met Meles on the sidelines of the ongoing Beijing Summit of the Forum on the China-Africa Cooperation (FOCAC), which opened earlier Saturday. China and Ethiopia have increased exchanges between their governments, ruling parties, legislatures, localities and people, expanded trade and two-way investment and witnessed fruitful cooperation in areas including agriculture, personnel training and infrastructure construction, said Hu. The two countries have also maintained consultations and coordination in international affairs, Hu added. 'Ethiopia has actively participated in the affairs of the FOCAC and played an important role in implementing the follow-up actions of the forum and in preparing for this summit,' Hu said. Meles, whose country co-chairs the forum, said the two countries share common aspirations for developing friendly bilateral cooperation as the exchanges between governments and peoples get closer. Meles expressed his appreciation for Hu's announcement of eight aid measures for Africa, vowing to make continued efforts to promote a new type of China-Africa strategic partnership. At the opening ceremony of the two-day summit, President Hu announced a package of major assistance, investment, trade and other key cooperation projects with Africa in an effort to strengthen China-Africa cooperation in more areas and at a higher level. In the eight-step package, China will double its 2006 assistance to Africa by 2009 and will provide 3 billion U.S. dollars of preferential loans and 2 billion U.S. dollars of preferential buyer's credits to Africa in the coming three years. China will also cancel debts in the form of all the interest- free government loans that matured at the end of 2005 owed by the heavily indebted poor countries and the least developed countries in Africa that have diplomatic relations with China. Oer the next three years, China will train 15,000 African professionals, Hu said. While addressing the opening ceremony of the summit, Meles said the China-Africa partnership forged 50 years ago must be renewed to address immediate challenges of fighting poverty and backwardness and seeking economic independence. Meles said African and Chinese economies are highly complementary. 'Africa provides to the growing Chinese economy a reliable field for investment, trade and the utilization of natural resources for mutual benefit. China provides for Africa a source of successful development experience, technology transfer, trade and investment.' The prime minister said the African people had 'ery high expectations' from the renewed Sino-African strategic partnership and 'welcomed' China's tremendous progress in the economic and other fields. Hu, 41 heads of state or government and senior officials of 48 African countries that have diplomatic ties with China, as well as representatives from regional and international organizations, attended the milestone gathering highlighting 'friendship, peace, cooperation and development'.

The development centre will be funded by the Chinese government with an initial investment of Rmb10m (US$1.29m) and is scheduled for completion in 2010, according to the Academy of Agricultural Sciences of Hunan province, the institution responsible for the hybrid strain’s initial development. >> >

title: Telecommunications equipment donation (Duplicate)
description: 'Chinese producers of electronic home appliances, agricultural machinery and small machinery are investing in Kenya with an eye on the greater EA market.A HIGH POWERED KENYAN trade delegation led by Finance Minister David Mwiraria was set to leave for Beijing, China on March 19, courtesy of the Chinese embassy in Kenya.The trip marks the end of the five-year tour of duty of Zhu Xiaochuan, China's economic and commercial counsellor to Kenya, whose tenure has seen an unprecedented influx of Chinese businesses, including state-owned firms, into the country.In the past two years alone, over 50 Chinese investors have pitched tent here. Among them are Jiangsu International Economic and Technological Co-operation Co, Sichuan International Economic and Technological Co-operation Co Ltd and China Road Bridge Construction (Group) Corporation and China Import and Export (Group) Corporation for Complete Sets of Equipment.The coming of Chinese firms into Kenya, says Mr Xiaochuan is very much by design. 'China is positioning itself to capture the greater regional market and Kenya with its superior infrastructure and internal and external trade policies that conform to international standards is our gateway,' he told TheEastAfrican last week. He further said that China regards Kenya as an important partner and is striving to promote economic co-operation by encouraging more Chinese companies to not only export their products to Kenya but also invest here.TWO CHINESE FIRMS based in Nairobi's Industrial Area - Content High Tech Corporation, a manufacturer of coloured televisions, and Khorasan Trading Company, a dry cell manufacturer - are already selling the bulk of their products in the regional market. 'The two companies sell 80 per cent of their products as far afield as the Democratic Republic of Congo,' said Mr Xiaochuan. China, he added has been encouraging enterprises, especially in the assembling and production of electronic home appliances, agricultural machinery and small machinery and electronic products, to invest in Kenya.Mr Xiaochuan is proud of the fact that the Chinese embassy in Kenya has built a $3 million ultra-modern China Trade Centre on Ngong Road, in Nairobi, where Chinese firms and individuals exhibit and sell their products. 'This is the biggest shopping window of Chinese products in the region,' he said. The largest tenant at the centre is Horizon Iato supermarket, which is one of China's four large-scale supermarket chain with a presence in Madagascar, Togo and Mozambique.Mr Xiaochuan says that the chain store was designed to promote the exports of Chinese commodities and boost bilateral economic and commercial contact between China and Africa.Last month, Telkom Kenya received communication equipment worth Ksh144 million ($1.9 million) from China's largest listed communications firm, Zhongxin Telecommunication Equipment Communications (ZTE). The 'gift' will help Telkom Kenya to expand its services countrywide. ZTE Communications in a joint initiative with Telkom Kenya has launched a digital exchange in Thika, north of Nairobi, which has a 4,000 fixed-line capacity. The exchange will increase Thika's telephone capacity from the current 5,300 to 9,300, expandable on demand.However, some experts warn that gifts from the East are not always what they seem. 'Indeed, many African countries have welcomed the countries from the East because they see them as a means of reducing dependence on the West, especially the US and the UK,' says Dr Zephania Ong'ata, programme director, East Africa Centre for Economic Policy Analysis, a regional research institute on macroeconomic policy, inequality poverty and globalisation.Donated equipment demands that it installed and maintained by the donor and also creates a market for the donor's products. Dr Ongata is urging Kenya and other African countries to look the gift horse in the mouth.CHINESE CUSTOMS figures show that China-Kenya trade increased by 34.4 per cent year-on-year in the first seven months of 2003, to $127 million, and China's imports from Kenya nearly doubled year-on-year.By June 2003, Chinese enterprises' investment in Kenya amounted to $22.8 million.Since the 2000 China-Africa Co-operation Forum, the Chinese government has allocated special funds to support Chinese enterprises to make investments in Africa and carry out co-operative projects for mutual benefit.Dr Ong'ata points out that many of these projects are 'sweeteners,' designed to clinch not just the contract at hand, but others down the line.Trade volumes between China and Africa rose 53.9 per cent year-on-year to $20.5 billion in the first nine months of last year, according to the Chinese government.This includes a 33.2 per cent increase in exports to Africa and a 78 per cent increase in exports from Africa to China. While a proportion of this is made up of manufactured goods from South Africa, it includes crude oil and unprocessed agricultural goods from other African countries - which simply replicates the traditional trading relationships with Western countries that are so often criticised by Africa.'
donor_agency: Zhongxing Technologies (ZTE), State-Owned Company

title: $500 mn for various development projects (Duplicate)
description: Like other African leaders, Ethiopian Prime Minister Meles Zenawi returned home from a three-day summit in Beijing with enthusiastic praise for his hosts and an armful of new economic agreements. More Ethiopian agricultural products would be allowed into China duty-free, he revealed, and China had pledged some $500 mn for various development projects in Ethiopia. 'China is an inspiration for all of us,' he added. 'What China shows to Africa is that it is indeed possible to turn the corner on economic development.' Fifty years after China established its first diplomatic ties with an African country, the third summit of the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation was held 3-5 November. It marked the biggest-ever gathering between Chinese and African leaders. All 48 African countries that have diplomatic relations with China took part - with most of their delegations led by presidents or prime ministers. In addition, hundreds of African businesspeople went for a two-day trade exhibit immediately following the summit, eager to explore new market outlets in the most populous country in the world, which has one of the fastest growing economies.

title: road- and school-construction aid (Not project level)
description: (Copyright (c) 2007, Dow Jones   Company, Inc.) BEIJING -- An attack that killed nine Chinese oil workers in Ethiopia's desolate Ogaden Desert has provided a bloody reminder that China's world-wide pursuit of raw materials has taken it into some rough neighborhoods -- and that goodwill proclamations may not be enough to avoid getting caught up in local conflicts. Exposure to the military and political struggles that convulse Africa is one of the prices this fast-developing country is paying for its growing power and profile on the world stage. It is a new sensation for most Chinese, who are used to considering their country an economic actor that, unlike traditional powers, avoids interference in the domestic affairs of other nations. The nine Chinese were among 74 people reported killed shortly after dawn Tuesday in the desert of eastern Ethiopia. In addition, Chinese authorities said, seven Chinese oil technicians were kidnapped by the ethnic-Somali rebels who launched the raid. [But the group said it is only holding six Chinese workers, according to an Associated Press report on Thursday.] The captives joined a growing list. Already this year, 16 Chinese oil workers have been kidnapped in Nigeria and a Chinese engineer was killed and another injured in Kenya. The questions facing Chinese President Hu Jintao's government are twofold: how to better protect the four million Chinese working abroad and how to preserve the growing value of Chinese investments in places such as Ethiopia, where governments face instability. [On Thursday, China said it won't stop investing in Africa but plans to boost security measures, the AP reported.] 'China now faces the dilemma of any country that undertakes an active foreign policy, particularly one with a foreign policy in no small part based on the acquisition of resources,' said an analysis by Stratfor, a security-consulting firm based in Austin, Texas. 'It must now decide how much to get involved in other countries' internal security issues.' He Wenping, head of Africa studies at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, said safety issues were becoming increasingly important as the number of Chinese working abroad multiplies. Ms. He suggested to Beijing's Global Times newspaper Wednesday that Chinese companies evaluate the security situation before starting a project abroad. This is a sensitive political issue here. The Chinese public seems increasingly to demand that compatriots abroad be taken care of, even as the government expresses a determination to avoid involvement in local conflicts. Moreover, the urge to prop up endangered governments to preserve Chinese investments would go against its long tradition of noninterference. Reflecting the sensitivities, Communist Party censors sought Wednesday to limit comment on Internet sites about the killings in Ethiopia, according to site operators. But some telling observations got through the filters. 'If you want to make money there, why wouldn't you send your own troops to provide security?' one contributor wrote. 'It seems we should learn from the early colonial powers.' The Foreign Ministry, however, has long contended that China's economic activities in Africa are designed to benefit African countries and that China has no stake in the local political situation. Chinese officials repeatedly have said they have no desire to repeat the exploitative policies of colonial powers, which subjugated Africa to serve as a reliable source of raw materials and a market for exports. This was a major theme of a China-Africa summit in Beijing in November, when nearly 50 African heads of state and ministers gathered to proclaim friendship with China and discuss investment and aid. It also has been a major theme for Chinese leaders on frequent visits to Africa, including Mr. Hu's tour of eight countries in February. The pledge was repeated this week by Jia Qinglin, a member of the Politburo Standing Committee, shown on the front pages of official newspapers Tuesday -- the day of the Ethiopia attack -- being greeted by dancing women on arrival in Kenya. 'Chinese economic activities in African countries are on the basis of cooperation and friendship,' said Liu Lide, a retired ambassador who spent 22 years as a Chinese envoy in Africa. 'That's the context in which we encourage Chinese companies to go to Africa and invest. We want to work not only with African governments but also with African people, particularly businessmen.' As China's economic footprint grows, however, its policies have brought increasing criticism from African opposition groups that contend China's noninterventionism props up unpopular governments. In Tuesday's attack, the target was an exploratory drilling site run by a subsidiary of the China Petroleum   Chemical Corp., known as Sinopec that has operations in a dozen countries. The oil field was guarded by a 100-strong contingent of Ethiopian soldiers. China was Ethiopia's largest trading partner in 2006, with $450 million in exchanges. Chinese firms have invested more than $70 million in Ethiopia, and Beijing has provided road- and school-construction aid. 'These people had bad intentions,' said Mr. Liu, the former ambassador, speaking of the rebels who carried out the attack. 'Their goal was to sabotage China's relations with the Ethiopian government.'

title: PPIAF - Financing for Kpong Water Supply Expansion Project
description: (PPIAF) In 2010, the Chinese government agreed to provide Ghana with preferential buyer's credit worth $260 million USD for the execution of the Kpong Water Expansion Supply Project to help boost water delivery systems in the country. The facility has a grace period of five years, repayment duration of 15 years, maturity period of 20 years, interest rate of 2 percent per annum, a commitment fee of 0.75 percent per annum, a management fee of 1 percent flat, and a grant element of 37.08 percent. The total project cost is $273 million, with the remaining $13 million USD provided by the Ghanaian government. The project when completed, would increase water supply from Kpong Head Works to Accra and Tema to improve the reliability of potable water delivery to domestic, commercial and industrial customers. The project is expected to be completed in 2014. As of July 2012, the project was 30 percent complete. PPIAF-ID:149

title: PPIAF - Telecom portion of the second phase of 2004 two bln loan from Exim Bank of China
description: (PPIAF) On March 2, 2004 the first Credit Accord with the Eximbank of China was signed for a financial package of two billion US Dollars and meant for the financing of projects of Angola's public investment. The first package was implemented in two different phases, with each taking one billion US Dollars. The first phase involved 27 contracts, corresponding to 50 projects, of which 21 have  been completed. These projects focused on areas of electricity, water, health, education, public works, each of which taking about 20 percent of the total amount released.The second phase included 13 contracts and 52 projects that are underway. These contracts are in the areas of telecommunications, fisheries, health, education and public works.A contract is near approval to complete the second phase. The contract is called EDEL III, plus another two in final stage of negotiation, also in the sector of electricity and waters.The balance at the end of September 2007, according to the Finance Ministry, is of Usd 7.1 million, of which Usd 1.6 million are for the first phase of the financing and Usd 5.4 million for the second phase.The total amount disbursed until the end of September is Usd 932.9 million, being 733.1 million for the first phase and 199.8 for the second phase.As a result of the positive evaluation made by the two parties concerning the first package of two billion US Dollars, a memorandum of understanding was signed on June 20, 2006, between the Angolan Finance Ministry and China's Eximbank, for the granting of a new financing of the same amount.; Contractor Comment: Tied to the loan, is the agreement that the public tenders for the construction and civil engineering contracts will be awarded primarily to Chinese state-owned enterprises approved by the Chinese government. Exim Bank has compiled a list of 3; Political/Resource Considerations: Oil (China was to receive 10,000 barrels of oil per day. Sinopec wins a license for a large oil-production block previously held by Total of France. Sinopec then formed a joint venture to bid on other oilfields in Angola.); Chinese Commitment: USD 200 Million; PPIAF-ID:16
donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency

title: Concessional loan
description: ''The president of China, Hu Jintao, pledged nearly $100 million in grants and soft loans to Cameroon on Wednesday as he kicked off his latest tour of Africa, a growing supplier of oil and raw materials to his country. China has been offering low interest loans, debt relief and other incentives to increase its influence on the world's poorest continent in return for access to the natural resources it needs to feed its booming economy. 'China and Africa have developed mutually respectful and beneficial relations over the years,' Hu said at a banquet thrown by President Paul Biya of Cameroon, in a speech broadcast on state television and radio. 'China and Africa have never tried to impose their social and economic development models on others,' Hu added. Hu, who also toured Africa last year, met Biya to discuss social aid programs for clean drinking water and cheap housing, as well as a greater role for China in the local oil industry and other resource sectors.'Through you, I invite Chinese companies to come and invest in Cameroon, especially in hydrocarbons such as gas and oil, mineral exploitation and forestry, where numerous opportunities exist,' Biya said at a working session with Hu.Hu, the first Chinese head of state to visit Cameroon, was greeted by singing, dancing and flag-waving children. Citing the World Bank, Biya told Hu that since receiving debt relief under the so-called Heavily Indebted Poor Countries initiative, Cameroon had become 'one of the best risks in Africa.'Hu arrived in Cameroon late Tuesday on the first leg of an eight- country tour that will also take him to Liberia, Sudan, Namibia, South Africa, Seychelles, Zambia and Mozambique.Hu and his group, which includes the minister of commerce, Bo Xilai, the foreign minister Li Zhaoxing and other senior policy makers, signed eight accords with Cameroon. Those deals included a 40 million yuan, or $5.15 million, grant and 30 million yuan interest-free loan for economic and technical cooperation, as well as two concessionary loans of 350 million yuan each, one for telecommunications projects. Hu also canceled Cameroon's debt to China - whose value was not specified - and signed agreements to build two schools and a hospital in Cameroon's commercial capital, Douala.China's trade with Cameroon, which has reserves of oil, bauxite and iron ore, doubled to $338 million in the first 11 months of 2006.At a special China-Africa summit in Beijing in November, Hu offered $5 billion in loans and credit to Africa and pledged to double aid, keen to demonstrate that China's ties with Africa went beyond thirst for its oil and raw materials.Trade between China and Africa jumped 40 percent to $55.5 billion in 2006, with the balance of trade $2.1 billion in Africa's favor, according to Chinese Trade Ministry data published this week by Xinhua, the official press agency.'Many African nations cannot look to the U.S. or Europe as models for development because they are simply too advanced,' said Hu Biliang, a senior economist with the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, a government research group based in Beijing. 'China is a developing nation and ideologically similar,' the economist added. 'Oil and energy trade offer China and Africa a mutual opportunity to gain through trade, but more importantly China offers many African states an example of development, a road to follow.'But some Africans have warned that poor African countries may ultimately lose from expanding trade with China unless they carefully examine bilateral deals and protect their weak manufacturing sectors from inexpensive Chinese clothes and household goods. This means Hu may face a more guarded reception than in the past.Some Western leaders and analysts have criticized China for offering trade, aid and investment with no strings attached, saying it undermines efforts by Western donors to promote democracy and human rights through conditional aid.Hu's trip will also take him to Sudan, where civil war in the Darfur region has killed an estimated 200,000 people and forced 2.5 million more from their homes in violence that Washington has labeled as genocide. China has resisted sanctions and other pressure on Sudan, from which it buys crude oil, saying they will not help to solve the conflict in Darfur. But it said Wednesday that it would support a joint UN-African Union peacekeeping mission to Darfur.Document INHT000020070201e32100023''　据喀麦隆《论坛报》30日报道，喀麦隆政府将拨款240亿非洲法郎（约合5200万美元），帮助西北省“杀人湖”尼奥斯湖移民安居乐业和进一步治理“杀人湖”。　　该报援引喀麦隆西北省省长库帕·伊萨的讲话称，这笔资金将主要用于建设尼奥斯湖的毒气检测和排放系统以及移民迁入地区的水电供应系统和医疗卫生设施。　　伊萨说，喀麦隆政府“决定投入240亿非洲法郎，其中80亿非洲法郎已到位”。　　1986年8月21日夜，超量的二氧化碳气体突然从尼奥斯湖中喷出，掀起80多米高的水浪。随着闷雷般的轰响声，这股强大的气体在湖区周围迅速扩散和蔓延，仅半小时就使沿湖1746名居民和6000多头牲畜窒息死亡。　　尼奥斯湖为火山湖，海拔1091米，长2500米，宽1500米，平均水深200米，湖中存积着巨量二氧化碳和二氧化硫等有害气体，如遇地震或地层变化，便可能发生剧烈的喷发或爆炸。距离该湖不远的莫努恩湖于1984年8月15日也曾喷发过毒气，夺去数百人的生命。（记者陆遥）''新华网雅温得1月31日电（记者 钱彤 陆遥） 正在对喀麦隆进行国事访问的国家主席胡锦涛1月31日在雅温得同喀麦隆总统比亚举行会谈。双方就中喀关系、中非关系和其他共同关心的重大问题交换了意见，达成重要共识，一致同意共同努力，推动中喀友好合作关系和中非新型战略伙伴关系深入发展。    胡锦涛表示，建交36年来，中喀两国人民的传统友谊不断加深，两国友好合作关系稳定健康发展，取得了丰硕的成果。政治交往和合作有力地增强了双方政治互信，成为中喀友好合作关系的基础；多种形式的经贸合作不断深化，成为双方加强合作的优先领域；社会人文合作增进了两国人民的相互了解和友谊，成为双方深化合作的重要方面。喀麦隆政府坚定奉行一个中国政策，在台湾、人权等问题上给予中方宝贵支持，中方对此深表赞赏。    胡锦涛指出，实践证明，中喀友好合作关系有力促进了双方发展进步，符合两国和两国人民的根本利益。胡锦涛结合落实中非合作论坛北京峰会成果，就发展中喀关系提出建议：一、增强政治互信和合作，加强各层次往来和交流，在涉及各自利益的重大问题上继续相互支持和帮助。二、拓展互利双赢的经贸合作，确保在建合作项目按期保质完成，发挥经济互补优势，重点加强农业、初级产品加工、基础设施、能源、电信等领域的互利合作。三、密切社会人文领域的交流合作，加强教育、卫生、文化、体育、旅游等社会人文领域的交流，鼓励两国妇女、青年组织扩大交往。四、加强多边领域的协调和配合，在重大国际和地区问题上保持沟通和协调，维护发展中国家正当权益，共同推动建设持久和平、共同繁荣的和谐世界。 '

title: Kipsigak-Serem-Shamakhokho road project- duplicate with 108
description: 'NAIROBI, Oct. 24 (Xinhua) - Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi launched Thursday the construction of a China-funded highway in western Kenya, which is one of the most important Chinese government assistance projects in Kenya as well as in sub-Sahara Africa.The 54-km-long highway starts from Kipsigak in Rift Valley Province and ends in Shamakhokho in Western Province, a major farming region of Kenya.This project was agreed upon between the two governments in 1999. Up to date, the Chinese government has provided three batches of funding for the project amounting to some 1.5 billion shillings (about 18 million US dollars).Addressing hundreds of residents and government officials in the Kaptumo Business Center in Rift Valley Province, Moi thanked the Chinese government for financing the construction of the road, saying that this project further reflects the cordial relations that exist between the two nations.He said that China has been supporting the development of Kenya in various ways, and such assistance is true in nature, as China has never interfered with Kenya's internal affairs.He expressed his belief that such relations will continue togrow to the benefits of the two friendly countries.Also speaking at the launching ceremony, Chinese Ambassador toKenya Du Qiwen said that China and Kenya enjoy cordial and friendly relations, which is best manifested by, among other things, this road project.'As a developing country, we know only too well the importance of good roads and communication facilities,' Du said, adding that he hoped that the road will contribute significantly to the social and economic development in this region, and bring direct benefits to the people of local communities.'

title: HIV/AIDS Medical Workers
description: 25 January 2008Lesotho Aims To Increase HIV/AIDS, Health Cooperation With China, Ambassador SaysLesotho hopes to increase cooperation with China on HIV/AIDS treatment and other health issues, Lesotho's ambassador to Beijing, Anthony Thibeli, said on Wednesday, Xinhua/CRIEnglish.com reports. China's first medical team to Lesotho arrived in 1997, and the second team arrived in 1999. A team of 15 Chinese doctors currently is working in health care centers throughout Lesotho. 'Fifteen is a small number,' Thibeli said, adding that Lesotho needs 'more Chinese doctors to help us.' Lesotho's Minister of Health and Social Welfare last year visited China to discuss cooperation between the two countries on the use of Chinese herbal medicines as HIV/AIDS treatments, doctor training and telemedicine.Lesotho has decreased its HIV/AIDS prevalence to an estimated 26% from 31%, largely because of efforts to increase voluntary HIV testing, as well as access to no-cost counseling and treatment for people living with the virus, according to Thibeli (Xinhua/CRIEnglish.com, 1/23).

title: Government flood relief donation (Duplicate)
description: 'NAIROBI, May 22 (Xinhua) - China Red Cross Society, through the Chinese embassy in Kenya, Thursday donated relief goods to Kenyan flood victims.The donations, including blankets, mosquito nets, jerry cans, soap and other necessities, all purchased locally, are worth 10, 000 US dollars.Guo Chongli, Chinese Ambassador to Kenya, said during the handover ceremony that 'to express deep sympathy and friendly feelings of the Chinese government and people to the Kenyan government and people, China Red Cross Society entrusts our embassy here with donating relief supplies to the Kenyan victims of floods.''It is our sincere hope that these supplies, although not very much in quantity, can help brotherly Kenyan people when they are in difficulties,' Guo said.'China is a developing country and also suffering greatly from SARS and floods, however, we regard Kenyans as friends and we believe in a saying which goes 'a friend in need is a friend indeed,'' the ambassador added.Chris Murungaru, Kenyan minister for provincial administration and national security, thanked China for its assistance, saying that Kenya has been enjoying special friendly relations with China.Zhongxing Telecommunication Equipment Corporation, one of the major and successful Chinese telecommunication companies which is now operating in Kenya, also donated relief goods worth 5,000 US dollars during the ceremony.Torrential rains, flash floods and mudslides have been sweeping much of central and western Kenya over the past weeks, claiming more than 50 lives, including a member of parliament, and causing one million others displaced.The Kenyan government has declared the floods a national disaster and appealed for international assistance.'

title: Exploration of iron ore resources (Duplicate of 1012)
description: Hong Kong Wisco Guangxin Kam Wah Resources (Wisco Guangxin), an indirect subsidiary of central China’s major steelmaker Wuhan Iron   Steel, has successfully bid for the exploration and mining rights for iron ore resources in Soalala, Madagascar, Steel Business Briefing learns from a stock exchange of Hong Kong announcement on 15 September.Wisco Guangxin won the bid through a global public tender inoling more than 20 international companies to explore the area of about 430 square kilometers which is one of the largest iron ore resere regions in Madagascar.Wisco Guangxin is expected to enter into a binding contract with the government of Madagascar soon. Wuhan Iron   Steel will take a leading role in the technology, operation and management of the project.Wisco Guangxin is 51% owned by Wisco Kam Hing Resources and 49% by Hongkong Guangxin Yuehua Resources Deelopments. Wisco Kam Hing is a 60:40 joint venture between Wuhan Iron   Steel and Hong Kong-listed Kam Hing International Holdings.An iron ore trader in eastern China tells SBB that oerseas inestments by Chinese mills have become more and more mature therefore the success rate is likely to be higher than before. But he predicts it will take quite a long time before iron ore production could start. “The mining plan will be subject to the impurities and other metals’ distribution in the resere, which is ery complicated,” he says.For questions about editorial content, or to subscribe call +44 (0) 20 7626 0600, info@steelbb.com© Steel Business Briefing 2009 香港武钢广新锦华资源有限公司马达加斯加苏拉拉铁矿项目中标结果公示                      类别：中标信息-服务招标                                      地区：武汉市  更新时间：2010-7-21 浏览次数：287                                                                                                                                            湖北省成套招标有限公司受业主的委托, 于2010年7月4日，在湖北省成套招标有限公司会议室，对其《马达加斯加苏拉拉铁矿》项目公开开标。经评标委员会专家评审，招标人确认，现将中标结果公示如下：招标编号：HBCZ-1001211-100341/2中标内容：后续资源接替区地质普查设计及施工等中 标 人：中国冶金地质总局中南地质勘查院中标金额：玖佰肆拾肆万陆仟柒佰 美元（USD 9，446，700.00） 对上述公示的中标结果若有异议者，请在公示期2010年7月21日～2010年7月26日内与湖北省成套招标有限公司联系。联系人：高玉玲联系电话：027-87316021同时，感谢各投标人对本次招标工作的支持，（湖北招标信息网www.hbzbw.com整理）并希望在以后的招标工作中继续合作。  特此公告！

title: China Gives Mozambique Assistance with Dams and Irrigation systems (Duplicate of 1211)
description: Mozambican President Joachim Chissano is in the middle of a visit to Beijing that appears to herald a new phase in co-operation between the two countries. Among the issues discussed and agreements made were the following: Assistance with dams and irrigation systems;

title: China to help Mozambique boost agricultural production (Duplicate of 1211)
description: Mozambican President Joachim Chissano is in the middle of a visit to Beijing that appears to herald a new phase in co-operation between the two countries. Among the issues discussed and agreements made were the following: Assistance with dams and irrigation systems; possible Chinese involvement in reconstructing the Sena rail line, which was destroyed in the civil war; the reactivation of the Moatize coal mines; the resumed construction of the (formerly East German financed) Mocuba textile factory; assistance with increased agricultural production, especially of cash crops such as cotton and cashews; and parliamentary exchanges to deepen the relations between the two countries. The episode was sealed with a small cash gift of US$3.6m in development aid.Significance: Chissano praised China's aid in very warm terms - the country's re-awakened interest in Africa is good news for Mozambique, which can access cost-effective cooperation and take advantage of China's extensive expertise in large-scale infrastructure projects. It is worth noting that Chissano also called China's support 'genuine... not conditioned to certain interests as happens with some other countries'. China's non-judgemental attitude towards democracy and human rights issues make it an attractive alternative to the highly conditional aid packages offered by the EU and US. But what does China get in return? In the case of Mozambique, a foot in the door of one of the continent's most promising economies. In a wider sense, the chance to build up global diplomatic prestige at a low cost. And in the short-term, support on the Taiwan issue: The Xinhua news agency reported Premier Wen Jibao as praising Mozambique's 'One-China' position.

title: Road project to ease Nairobi traffic congestion- duplicate with 1027/1112
description: 'The president of Kenya, Mwai Kibaki, has launched a US$30-million road reconstruction project, funded by China, aimed at improving roads around the congested capital city, Nairobi. The total project includes the financing of three city bypasses, connecting the northern and southern corridor inter-regional road links, and reconstructing the main road leading from the airport to the industrial area. The project is the largest the Chinese have undertaken in Kenya and constitutes part of a US$86-million development package negotiated with China during the Beijing summit in 2006.Significance: Kenya’s dilapidated road system has been one of the main barriers to growth within the country. With Kenya acting as the supply corridor for Rwanda, Uganda, and southern Sudan, most freight traffic has to pass through the Nairobi city centre on its way to these countries, putting considerable pressure on the city’s infrastructure.The new bypass aims to divert this through traffic away from Nairobi's centre, improving transportation times as well as city infrastructure and traffic. The improvement of the northern and southern corridor connections will significantly facilitate inter-regional trade in a region where rail transportation is uncompetitive and grossly underdeveloped.' 'Once known as East Africa's green 'City in the Sun', Nairobi is so choked with traffic that Kenya's architects suggest moving to a new capital and angry business leaders say the booming economy is under threat.A combination of bad drivers, ramshackle vehicles, overloaded trucks, potholed roads and corrupt traffic police make one of Africa's biggest cities resemble the dodgems on a good day and, when things get really bad, reduce it to gridlock.Swarming minibuses, known as matatus, are the only option for most Nairobi commuters, but they are notorious for their drivers' kamikaze tactics and their crumbling mechanical condition -- which often means no lights at night.Matatus, weaving wildly from lane to lane, account for 80% of public transport and are a major cause of congestion.Fatal crashes are common. The Sunday Nation newspaper called a recent spate of matatu accidents a 'national slaughter'.Kenya's crumbling roads and the chaotic traffic have become a political issue ahead of elections in December, denting the popularity of President Mwai Kibaki.A recent survey said traffic jams were costing Nairobi drivers up to 50-million shillings (R5,2-million, $746 000) a day through increased fuel consumption, mechanical damage and pollution.'The amount of fuel used is astronomical, just sitting in traffic idling away, ' said Betty Maina, head of the Kenya Association of Manufacturers.'Things are delayed, you don't accomplish as much, it takes longer getting to meetings and events. You get up earlier trying to beat the traffic but sometimes you just cannot beat it.'She said the turnaround time for trucks and vans had doubled and some companies were increasing the sizes of their delivery vehicles because of the delays, compounding the problem.Shift capital? The Architectural Association of Kenya (AAK) last month asked the government to move the capital elsewhere.'Nairobi was designed half a century ago for a population of half a million people while the population today is three million. This has overstretched entirely all the services of the whole city,' AAK chairperson Gideon Mulyungi said in a speech.City traffic is worst on Friday evenings, especially near pay day. When rain turns the potholes into ponds, there is chaos.The jams are regularly compounded by a string of accidents and breakdowns, many involving ancient trucks which have a tendency to roll backwards down Nairobi's many hills.Nairobi's traffic lights are largely ignored.The police, known for being more interested in bribes from harassed motorists than untangling the jams, often overrule the lights anyway and their efforts can make the hold-ups worse.Yet experts, including Japanese road engineers who did a two-year study, say Nairobi's problems are not insurmountable and nothing like as complex as some cities.While traffic has expanded -- some estimates say by 300% in a decade -- the roads have not.'The problem is the growth of vehicles compared to the rate of developing the road network. For some time this has not been developing while traffic expanded,' city engineer Charles Chiruri said.There is only one road, the Uhuru Highway, running right through the city and it is punctuated by a string of roundabouts acting as anarchic traffic traps.The highway is used not only by most commuters but also by heavy trucks transiting to all parts of the country, including from the port of Mombasa to Uganda and Central Africa.'Missing links' Plans to overcome Nairobi's congestion -- bypasses, overpasses and 14 'missing links' to avoid long detours -- began 30 years ago. Nothing was done.The reason, say experts, was systematic corruption during the 24-year rule of former President Daniel arap Moi, who was replaced in 2002 by Kibaki.For the decade after 1994, foreign donor funding, essential for building new roads, dried up because of the huge graft.'By 2002, things were so bad that what was happening was there was no competitive tendering at all. Just a cartel of five cowboy contractors,' said a former government engineer who asked not to be named.'They quoted whatever they liked and then doubled or tripled it. They got paid and did not do the job and then claimed more because of bad weather.'By the end of the Moi era only 20% of the country's roads were in adequate condition.It is taking years to overcome the backlog. Een now, five years later, about 57% of the network is in poor shape, while the booming economy puts even more cars on the road.Big donor countries privately express frustration that the comprehensive 2006 Japanese plan for solving Nairobi's road and traffic problems has still not been implemented.Roads Ministry spokesperson Richard Abura said it had taken time to find donors to fund the work. 'Early this year we started implementing the report. We are going to concession the bypasses as soon as we get some funding.'In April, President Kibaki announced plans for a two billion Kenyan shilling (R209-million, $30-million) Chinese project to widen the Uhuru Highway and link it to the west of the city.But some Western donors complain this is not coordinated with the Japanese plan and many people remain sceptical at the pace of change.'I don't think this is going to improve in the short term. The issue with Nairobi is that there just isn't a comprehensive plan in place yet,' said Maina of the manufacturers' association. - Reuters ' 'Expansion and reconstruction works on the Jomo Kenyatta International Airport (JKIA), Uhuru Highway to Gigiri road is set to begin.This follows the signing today of additional funding for the road at a ceremony at State House Nairobi witnessed by President Mwai Kibaki and Mr Jia Qinglin, the chairman of the National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference.Today's signing of an economic and technical cooperation amounting to 532m Kenya shillings brought the total commitment by China on construction of the JKIA-Gigiri road to 2.1bn shillings.President Kibaki and Mr Qinglin will this Thursday 26th April, 2007 officially launch construction work of the road at Nyayo National Stadium, Nairobi West. The construction will include street lighting, an extra lane on some sections of the road, while some landmark roundabouts, that Nairobi residents and visitors have been accustomed to will be discarded.During the occasion, Finance Minister Amos Kimunya on behalf of the Kenya government and Chinese Trade Minister Wei Jianguo on the Chinese side also exchanged notes on a project of cooperative archaeological investigation on Lamu Archipelago amounting to 177m shillings, a feasibility study on a project to build a hospital in Kenya and a feasibility study on a project to build two rural schools.Earlier, President Kibaki and the visiting chairman of the National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference held bilateral talks where the two leaders lauded the cordial relations existing between the two countries.President Kibaki thanked the Chinese government for its continued financial support to Kenya's development, noting that China is one of Kenya's major development partners.The president recalled that Kenya and China have signed various bilateral agreements and memorandum of understanding on projects that have gone a long way to improve the lives of Kenyans.On his part, chairman of the National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference commended President Kibaki's leadership, saying that during the short time he has been in office the relationship between Kenya and China has improved significantly.In this regard, Mr Qinglin assured President Kibaki that China will continue supporting Kenya's development endeavours in the spirit of cooperation.Also present were ministers Simeon Nyachae, Raphael Tuju, Prof George Saitoti and Suleiman Shakombo, the head of public service and secretary to the cabinet Amb Francis Muthaura, several permanent secretaries and senior government officials. ' 'NAIROBI, Jan 31 (Reuters) - China has lent Kenya 8.55 billion shillings ($120 million) to build two new roads to improve traffic flow in the east African nation's normally congested capital, a government statement said.The money will be used to construct the Eastern and Northern bypasses whose total length will be about 70 km (44 miles).The government has had a long-standing plan to construct four bypasses outside the central business district to check road congestion which usually brings Nairobi traffic to a crawl.'The Kenyan government approached the Chinese government to request for funds to construct the project roads,' a statement by the roads ministry seen by Reuters on Thursday said.'The Chinese government responded positively to fund the project through the Export Buyer's Credit.'The Chinese government will pay contractors China Road and Bridge Corporation, C88, Zhonglu Plaza and Andingmenwai Dajie directly, the statement said.Post-election turmoil has killed over 850 people and hurt Kenya's image as a stable country in a troubled region and led to threats by western donors to freeze aid.Analysts however say western powers pressing newly re-elected President Mwai Kibaki to find a solution to the crisis do not have much leverage as China is increasingly playing a bigger role in Africa and can provide an alternative source of investment and political support. (Reporting by Helen Nyambura-Mwaura, editing by David Christian-Edwards) '

title: Telecom firm contracted to provide 3G equipment
description: 'NAIROBI, July 7 Asia Pulse - China's largest network and telecommunications equipment supplier Huawei Technologies has signed a multi-million dollar deal with Kenya to provide 3G equipment to its Safaricom, the leading mobile network operator in the country.A statement from Safaricom said on Friday that Huawei will provide modern and high quality equipment to enable Safaricom to have one of the best telecommunication infrastructure in the world.Huawei Technologies Vice President Kevin Tao said that like in Germany and other leading economies where Huawei has launched its unified 3G technology, the cost of telecommunications has reduced in the long-term.'Safaricom's subscriber base has increased to 11 million and there is potential for more market share penetration which makes the co-operation between us and Safaricom more meaningful,' Tao said.Safaricom CEO Michael Joseph said the mobile phone operator has invested a total of US$30 million in license fees and infrastructure development to launch the service.Joseph said the partnership for the 3G equipment has been reached after detailed analytical evaluation. 'The 3G equipment are superior, high quality and of modern technology,' Joseph said.'The 3G is the future. We need state-of-the-art products with the highest speeds,' he added.Safaricom has already launched the broadband internet services with speeds of between 3.2 Megabytes per second (Mbps) and 7.2 Mbps in Mombasa and Nairobi.'／／中国华为技术有限公司近日与肯尼亚最大移动通信运营商萨法利通信公司签署协议，将向萨法利通信公司供应一批3G通信设备。    萨法利通信公司首席执行官迈克尔?约瑟夫在一份声明中说，该公司在经过分析评估后决定与华为签约，因为华为的3G设备性能先进、质量可靠。    萨法利通信公司今年5月底正式推出3G服务，可以为用户提供最高每秒7.2兆字节的无线数据传输速度，这使肯尼亚成为东非地区继坦桑尼亚之后第二个推出这一服务的国家。    作为肯尼亚最大的移动通信运营商和最大上市公司，萨法利通信公司拥有约1100万用户，占肯尼亚全国手机用户总数的一半以上。英国沃达丰公司目前是该公司的最大股东，拥有40%的股份。

title: Loans for Infrastructure Development (Duplicate of 1152)
description: INTERVIEW-Mauritius to benefit from cheap Chinese loans-PMBy Ed Harris505 words21 July 200708:07 AMReuters NewsLBAEnglish(c) 2007 Reuters LimitedPORT LOUIS, July 21 (Reuters) - Mauritius is set to benefit from $113 million in cheap Chinese loans and grants to develop roads and communications, the Indian Ocean island's prime minister said on Saturday.Speaking to Reuters less than a week after visiting China, Navin Ramgoolam said the trip had also yielded the promise of a series of private sector investments.'China has put at our disposal 3.5 billion rupees ($113.1 million), so that we can proceed with our development plans especially on infrastructure,' he said in an interview.Ramgoolam said although Mauritius -- with a population of 1.3 million people and a roughly $6.5 billion economy -- was a minnow next to China, it offered advantages for investors.The politically stable nation is working hard to improve its investment climate. As a member of trade blocs such as COMESA and SADC, it offers a gateway to African markets comprising half a billion people.'That gives China a springboard for entry into Africa,' Ramgoolam said.One of his aides said several Chinese companies were expected to invest or to increase their investment in Mauritius, and may use some of the $10 billion of development funds that China has earmarked for Africa.He said China's State Administration of Foreign Exchange is set to invest in Mauritian treasury bonds, while the China Development Bank planned to open an office in Mauritius.Construction was due to begin in October on a planned $500 million Chinese investment to build a trade development zone -- the largest ever foreign direct investment into Mauritius.Ramgoolam said despite his country's lack of natural resources, he had persuaded Beijing to adopt Mauritius as a focus of Chinese investment in Africa.'It was a question of persuasion, but you have to build on the relationship that you have,' he said, noting Mauritius' decision in 1972 to support Beijing with its one-China policy.Since Ramgoolam won elections in July 2005, the government has tried to improve the investment climate by speeding up procedures for business and registration permits and introducing flat rates of corporate and income tax at 15 percent.Ramgoolam said he had asked China for its continued support with Mauritian sovereignty claims on the Chagos Islands, part of Mauritius until independence. Claimed by Britain, one of the islands -- Diego Garcia -- houses a major U.S. military base.Facing the end of preferential trade deals on its key sugar and textile sectors, Mauritius is opening and diversifying its economy to attract foreign direct investment.Asked whether he feared an increased Chinese presence might hit the Mauritian textiles sector even further, Ramgoolam said his country had no other choice than to reform its economy.'With the WTO (World Trade Organisation) and the globalised world, we have to make efforts to restructure our economy,' he said. 'We cannot buck the market.'CHINA-MAURITIUS/ (INTERVIEW)|LANGEN|ABN|M|D|AFN|AFA|CSA|LBY|RWSA|RWS|REULB|GNS|SXNADocument LBA0000020070724e37l0018g

title: Soft Loan for Infrastructure (Duplicate of 20162 and 1099)
description: Following an official visit by Mauritian PM Ramgoolam and Finance Minister Sithanen to China, the country was granted a 3.5 billion MUR concessional loan to develop roads and communications. The current statuses of the projects to be financed with this loan are unknown.Mr Speaker, Sir, during the visit of the Prime Minister to China in November 2006, the Chinese authorities offered to provide highly concessionary financing of an amount of RMB 800 m. Yuan for project financing. Some RMB 220 m. Yuan has been committed as complementary finance for the Plaines Wilhems Sewerage project while the balance of RMB 580 m. Yuan would finance projects to be mutually agreed upon. This concessionary financing would have expired by the end of 2009. At the 8th Session of the Sino-Mauritian Joint Commission held in Beijing in September 2009, it was agreed that this balance of RMB 580 m. would be used to finance the Bagatelle Dam project. The financing package offered by the Chinese Government was highly concessionary at 2% fixed rate basis as compared to around  4% prevailing rate.  They further offered a moratorium of 5 years and repayment period  of minimum 10 years negotiable for a longer period. Mr Speaker, Sir, as for part (c), one of the conditions of the loan from Exim Bank of China is that the works should be undertaken by Chinese contractors.

title: Chinese Economic and Trade Zone Project Update (Duplicate of 1153)
description: China Starts Work on New Mauritian Economic and Trade Co-Operation ZoneTimothy Armitage245 words17 September 2009IHS Global Insight Daily AnalysisWDANEnglishCopyright 2009, IHS Global Insight Limited. All Rights Reserved. Work on a planned US$820-million economic and trade co-operation zone, backed by China, has started in Mauritius. The zone was originally called the Tianli Economic and Trade Cooperation Zone but has been renamed the Jinfei Economic and Trade Cooperation Zone after two new investors, Taiyuan Iron and Steel Company and the Shanxi Coking Coal Group, took up 50% and 30% stakes in the development, reducing Tianli's stake to 20%. According to Prime Minister Navinchandra Ramgoolam, quoted by Reuters, the trade zone, once finished, is projected to boost current exports by over a third. The investment remains China's largest in the country.Significance: Mauritius is currently undergoing a programmed structural change, partly forced by the removal of both the multi-fibre agreement and preferential sugar prices.With government support the diversification of the county’s services and goods export base, as well as the fundamental growth industries’ interest in investing in planned trade and economic zones, has sprung up over the last couple of years. The original project (initially US$500 million) brought forward by Tianli was expected to attract around 40 Chinese companies within the 210-acre project and adding around 500 jobs to the domestic economy. With Tianli already established in the Mauritian textile industry, the company is expected to attract engineering, computer science, electrical, pharmaceuticals, food processing, handicraft, and textile companies to the zone.Document WDAN000020090917e59h0002c毛里求斯总理等对晋非合作区发展寄予厚望2009-09-21 22:35  文章来源：毛里求斯快报文章类型：编译  内容分类：新闻　　毛里求斯晋非经贸合作区于9月16日正式开工，毛政府高层对合作区项目高度关注，对中方所做的工作给予了高度评价并对合作区今后发展寄予厚望。　　毛总理拉姆古兰在开工仪式上表示，晋非合作区是毛迄今为止规模最大、吸收外资最多的项目，将对毛经济向着现代化、多元化方向发展起到积极的推进作用。　　毛副总理兼财长拉•西塔南对合作区开工表示由衷高兴，他指出，中国选择在资源匮乏的毛建立经贸合作区显示了其对毛国经济发展的信心，合作区的开工建设将帮助毛摆脱经济危机的不利影响，山西太原钢铁集团、山西焦煤集团的加入和中非发展基金的支持将进一步增强合作区总体实力。　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　驻毛里求斯使馆经商参处　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　二〇〇九年九月二十一日　　（信息来源：驻毛里求斯经商参处子站）白培中赴毛里求斯考察经贸合作项目                                                                                 号:[ 大　中　小 ]                                    发布时间:2009-07-14                                                                          来源:山西焦煤集团网站                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              6月29日至7月6日，由山西省商务厅厅长王淑珍带队，集团公司董事长、党委书记白培中、太原钢铁集团、山西天利实业集团有关领导组成的考察团赴毛里求斯进行了经贸合作专题考察。    毛里求斯政府对毛里求斯经济贸易合作区建设和山西代表团的来访非常重视。在毛期间，毛总理拉姆古兰委托其首席高级幕僚接见了考察团主要成员。毛里求斯副总理兼财长思达南与考察团主要成员进行了会晤。毛投资促进局总经理拉米，贾杜及其高级顾问等会见了考察团全体成员，双方举行了正式会谈，就项目的深入推进交换了意见，达成了广泛共识。     考察团一行围绕未来经贸合作园区定位、发展规划的进一步优化、争取毛政府的政策支持等主题内容，对毛政治、经济、人文状况特别是投资环境进行了全面细致的实地考察，掌握了第一手资料。     考察团还访问了中国驻毛大使馆，拜会了大使、经济参赞及经商处有关专家，征求他们对当地经济合作园区建设的意见和建议；考察了毛南部水产养殖基地、市政规划建设；拜访了毛里求斯侨界社团主要负责人。                                                                                                                                                                               责任编辑: 高玉洁

title: Mozambique Signed a Cooperation Agreement with the Exim Bank of China Duplicate
description: The same report on allAfrica.com says Mozambique signed a cooperation agreement in April according to which the Exim Bank of China would lend 2.3bn US dollars (nearly 15bn Namibian dollars) for work on the Mepandua N'kua and Bue Maria dams.Duplicate with 1164

title: Joint Ventures in Strategic Sectors (Duplicate of 1168)
description: Agreements Reached With Chinese Companies533 words5 June 200610:28 AMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2006 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedMaputo, Jun 04, 2006 (Agencia de Informacao de Mocambique/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) --The visit by a Chinese business delegation to Mozambique ended on Saturday with the signature of memoranda of understanding, under which three Chinese companies will invest in central and northern Mozambique.The companies are Zhen Hua Harbour Construction Company, China Minmetals, and Construction and Agriculture Machinery Import and Export. They will undertake activities in the northern port of Nacala, in exploiting mineral resources, and in supplying agricultural equipment.Sergio Vieira, Director of the Zambezi Valley Planning Office (GPZ), who headed the Mozambican side to the talks, said that the agreements should be implemented as quickly as possible.He expected them to take effect later this year.'Cooperation with China will bring Mozambique the equipment we need, with the advantage that it is cheaper than from other sources', Vieira said.For Wang Cheng An, General Secretary of the Forum for Economic and Commercial Cooperation between China and the Portuguese Speaking Countries, the three memoranda mark the beginning of business cooperation in the areas concerned, which he regarded as important for the economic development of Mozambique.The upgrading of Nampula port, situated on the best natural deep water harbour on the east African coast, would be a good sign for the development of trade, he said, while the supply of Chinese agricultural equipment could play a significant role in increasing Mozambican agricultural production.Neither the Mozambican nor the Chinese delegation put any figures on the amount of Chinese investment involved, with Vieira only speaking of 'important financial sums'.Vieira also took the opportunity to deny that China will pay Mozambique's debt to Portugal, arising from the transfer of the Cahora Bassa dam on the Zambezi from Portuguese to Mozambican majority ownership.The sum is around 950 million US dollars, and some reports have appeared that the Chinese Exim Bank (represented on the delegation) will pay this sum.Vieira replied that, although the Exim Bank has signed an agreement to finance another dam on the Zambezi, at Mepanda Ncua, some 70 kilometres downstream from Cahora Bassa, it is not involved in the Cahora Bassa negotiations at all.A memorandum of understanding on Cahora Bassa was signed in Lisbon in November, under which the shareholding structure of the dam operating company, HCB, will be radically altered. Currently the Portuguese state holds 82 per cent of the shares, and Mozambique just 18 per cent. Under the November arrangement the positions would be reversed, with Mozambique holding 85 per cent of the HCB shares, and Portugal 15 per cent.But the deal has not yet been finalised, despite initial hopes that everything could be wrapped up by the end of 2005.Discussions on supposedly 'technical' issues have dragged on for months, and so far not a single share has been transferred from Portugal to Mozambique.The Mozambican government has declined to state where it will obtain the funds to pay Portugal for the shares - but a loan should not be difficult to arrange, given that HCB is now a profitable company, and there should be no difficulty in repaying a loan from Mozambique's share in those profits.
recipient_agencies: China Minmetals Corporation, State-Owned Company; China National Construction & Agricultural Machinery Import & Export Corporation (CAMC), State-Owned Company; Shanghai Zhenhua Heavy Industries Co., Ltd, State-Owned Company

title: China Gives Interest-Free Loan to cover deficit in Stadium Construction Inactive
description: Interest Free Loan From China154 words14 January 201001:02 PMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2010 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedMaputo, Jan 14, 2010 (Agencia de Informacao de Mocambique/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- Mozambique has received an interest free loan of 14.7 million US dollars from China, to cover the deficit in funding the new national stadium under construction in the outer Maputo suburb of Zimpeto.To this end, Mozambican Finance Minister Manuel Chang and the Chinese Trade Minister Chen Deming signed on Wednesday in Maputo the loan agreement to cover the additional costs of the stadium.The also signed a grant agreement under which China will provide 7.3 million dollars to fund projects to be agreed between the two governments.Chang declared that the grant and the interest free loan 'means for us, not just sums of money, but an unequivocal expression of links of friendship and cooperation, and the desire of China to see public investment projects come to fruition in our country'.Document AFNWS00020100114e61e001p8
sector: Trade, Tourism, Banking and Financial Services

title: Loan for purchase of trains
description: In November of 2005, Namibian President Hifikepunye Pohama and Chinese Politburo member Li Chang Chun witnessed the signing of a 250 million Yuan loan to be used for purchasing locomotives and trains for a new railway being built in the north. The loan was granted by the Export-Import Bank of China, but the trains and locomotives have already been purchased, and TransNamib will deliver the first four machines for $12 million USD each. From a report in 2008, it appears that TransNamib ultimately purchased 17 red Chinese-made locomotives in addition to the four blue ones originally purchased. However, these purchases appear to be a strain on the company because of chronic mechanical problems. The project is untied.

The doctors will arrive by the end of the month, and they will be committed for 2 years. This is the 18th such group sent to Mozambique. Duplicate of project #1230.

The logistics and project as a whole are lumped together as one continuous loan fulfillment, making this project a duplicate of Project #1240.

title: Chinese Donation for Military Hospital (too late)
description: Chinese Donation for Military Hospital284 words28 February 201211:36 AMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2012 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedMaputo, Feb 28, 2012 (Agencia de Informacao de Mocambique/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- The Chinese government has pledged to donate equipment to the Maputo Military Hospital to the value of 20 million yuan (about 3.2 million US dollars), under an agreement signed in Maputo on Monday.The agreement was signed by the Permanent Secretary of the Mozambican Defence Ministry, Maj-Gen Teofilo Joao, and the director of military cooperation in the Chinese Defence Ministry, Qian Li Hua.Speaking at the end of the ceremony, Qian said the donation includes both medical and office equipment, and should arrive in Maputo within six to eight months.'Our cooperation with Mozambique has a long history, and this equipment is part of our cooperation', he said. 'Based on the needs of Mozambique, we shall grant more aid to the Mozambican government to equip its army'.Mozambican Defence Minister Filipe Nyussi, who witnessed the ceremony, said the donation is a continuation of the cooperation agreements and memoranda that Mozambique has been signing with China.'This time we decided that our cooperation should cover complete equipment for the Maputo Military Hospital', he said. 'Thus the Military Hospital will be equipped, and later the staff who will handle this equipment will be trained'.Nyussi added that his meeting with the Chinese delegation was also 'a moment of reflection' about how to make the Mozambican army sustainable, rather than dependent on outside support.'With our brother army of China, we are seeking ways of making the Mozambican army sustainable, so that it can advance on its own', he said.The Minister said that the hospital equipment includes X-ray machines, scanners and ultrasound machines.All Africa Global MediaDocument AFNWS00020120228e82s00168

title: Geothermal energy development (duplicate with ID: 606)
description: 'NAIROBI, April 13 (Reuters) - Kenya received on Tuesday a 7.5 billion shilling ($97.15 million) loan from the Export-Import Bank of China to drill geothermal wells for production of 140 megawatts of energy.The east African country has geothermal power potential estimated at 7,000 MW and hopes to tap 5,000 MW of it by 2030.The money will be used to drill 26 steam production wells at the Olkaria IV geothermal field in Kenya's Rift Valley, Finance Minister Uhuru Kenyatta said during the signing ceremony.'In consideration of the present energy situation, high fuel prices and over dependence on hydropower production, the government of Kenya now recognises the need to diversify sourcing of power generation through environmentally friendly sources,' Kenyatta said.China is one of Kenya's main bilateral partners with cumulative development assistance of 29.45 billion shillings, Kenyatta said without elaborating.Last month, Kenya received a 23.4 billion shilling loan from Japan for another 140 MW at its Olkaria I plant. Energy Minister Kiraitu Murungi said that the new Olkaria IV plant would cost $714 million. [ID:nLDE62T0FY]Geothermal power is renewable energy produced by steam from underground water heated by the earth's core and used to turn turbines. (Reporting by Helen Nyambura-Mwaura; Editing by Sue Thomas)'／／2010年4月13日，肯尼亚副总理兼财政部长乌胡鲁·肯雅塔（前左二）在内罗毕与中国进出口银行副行长朱鸿杰签署优惠贷款协议。当日，中国进出口银行在这里与肯财政部和能源部共同签署优惠贷款协议并举行新闻发布会。该协议为由中国石油长城钻探工程公司在肯承建的奥卡瑞四号地热区钻井项目提供资金支持，通过帮助肯尼亚开发地热资源，缓解这个东非国家的能源及电力供应紧张问题。肯中加大地热资源合作对于促进双边关系发展意义重大“肯尼亚低收入及失业人口众多，生态环境十分脆弱，国际市场日趋看涨的石油价格及传统能源对环境的影响，使可再生能源对肯尼亚乃至非洲经济发展显得尤为重要。肯尼亚与中国加大在地热等可再生能源方面的合作对于促进肯中双边关系发展意义重大，”肯尼亚能源部常务秘书长帕特里克•尼奥伊凯4月9日接受新华社记者专访时说。尼奥伊凯说，肯尼亚目前水力发电装机容量为1330兆瓦，水力发电量占发电总量的55%。肯尼亚用电峰值达1200兆瓦，这意味着一旦肯尼亚出现干旱等缺水现象，其他发电量根本无法满足用电需求。像去年，肯国内遭遇大面积旱灾，电力部门便不得不使用昂贵的液化石油气发电，“这不仅对环境造成很大破坏，很多贫困人口也因价格高昂而无法用电”。截至目前，肯国内仅有24%的农村人口能从国家电网获得电能，全国88%的人口还无法享受电力“光明”。肯尼亚政府已制定新动力发展计划，目标是到2030年使国家电网能惠及国内90%的人口。“为实现这一目标，肯尼亚尝试过很多发电方式，如生物能源、太阳能、沼气以及石油发电等，但这些方式或破坏当地植被和环境，或不符合居民生活习惯，或过度依靠能源进口，效果都不理想，”尼奥伊凯坦言。最终实践证明，地热发电是肯尼亚未来20年最便宜的发电方式。尼奥伊凯说，地热发电有两大好处：一是地热资源可利用量不受气候因素影响；二是地热发电价格不受国际原油价格波动影响。肯尼亚蕴藏巨大的地热资源，更多开发这种新型可再生能源将是肯尼亚实现经济“绿色转型”，满足国内日益增长的用电需求及提升农村和山区用电比例的关键。有统计显示，随着肯尼亚经济发展和人口增长，其电力需求到2012年预计将增至1500兆瓦，2030年增至9000兆瓦。据可探明储量估算，肯尼亚地热发电潜力为7000兆瓦，目前已开发量仅为200兆瓦左右。2006年，中国石油长城钻探工程公司曾在肯尼亚获得总额约为2300万美元的地热发电钻探项目，项目完成后可为肯尼亚增加70兆瓦发电量。随后两年内，该公司又和肯方签订了25口地热井的钻探项目。尼奥伊凯说，这成为中国帮助肯尼亚发展新能源的良好开端。据了解，根据去年中国政府与肯尼亚签订的能源合作领域框架协议，中国进出口银行不久将率团访问肯尼亚，与中国石油长城钻探工程公司合力从资金、技术两方面“双轨”推进肯尼亚地热能源的开采和利用，此次合作项目计划帮助肯尼亚钻探26口地热井。尼奥伊凯说，新协议的达成将成为肯中地热资源开发合作的新节点。他表示，在未来10至15年，肯尼亚能源发展战略将主要集中在加速地热资源利用方面，并同时探索核电资源的开发机会。肯尼亚希望中国能够为肯尼亚在地热开发领域提供长期支持，在资源勘探、地热井建设以及相关技术人员培训等方面提供必要且有针对性的帮助。肯尼亚希望肯中关系能够通过地热开发等可再生能源合作达到新高度。//本报讯 中国进出口银行代表近日在肯尼亚首都内罗毕与肯尼亚财政部和能源部官员签署优惠贷款协议,为由中国石油长城钻探工程公司在肯承建的奥卡瑞四号地热区钻井项目提供资金支持,帮助肯尼亚开发地热资源,以缓解这个东非国家能源及电力供应紧张问题。根据协议,项目预计于今年内开工,长城钻探工程公司将帮助肯方钻探26口地热井,工程完工后将能为肯尼亚国家电网输送140兆瓦电力。工程预计耗资75亿肯尼亚先令(1美元约合77肯尼亚先令)。

title: Tanzanian president inaugurates China-funded water project (Duplicate of 115)
description: Tanzanian president inaugurates China-funded water project107 words20 May 2004Xinhua News AgencyXNEWSEnglish(c) Copyright 2004 Xinhua News AgencyDAR ES SALAAM, May 20 (Xinhua) -- Tanzanian President Benjamin Mkapa Thursday inaugurated a major water project aimed at providing drinking water to residents in Chalinze, some 110 km west of the capital Dar Es Salaam.The project, which was started in Oct. 2001, has the capacity of producing 7,200 cubic meters of water daily and will benefit about 62,000 villagers in the region at present and over 105,000 people by 2015.The Chinese government has donated 23.65 billion Tanzanian shillings (about 21 million US dollars) for the project under an agreement signed with the Tanzanian government.

title: $6.2 million dollar interest free loan (duplicate of 19020)
description: Text of report by Namibian television on 22 December[Presenter] During President Pohamba's state visit to the People's Republic of China a number of cabinet ministers, other senior government officials and chief executive officers of parastatals signed various agreements with their Chinese counterparts.Justice Minister and Attorney-General Pendukeni Iivula-Ithana and the director-general of the National Planning Commission, Helmuth Angula, signed the extradition treaty and the construction of the Namibian Military School respectively. [as heard][Unidentified NBC reporter] This was the Justice Minister and Attorney-General Pendukeni Iivula-Ithana signing the agreement on the extradition treaty with the Chinese Foreign Affairs Minister Li Zhaoxing. The treaty allows the two nations to surrender a wanted person residing within their jurisdiction to be prosecuted in the country of origin. This accord was necessitated by an increasing influx of China and Namibia following the strengthening of their relations in various fields. [Sentence as heard]Iivula-Ithana told NBC News that the extradition treaty not only seeks to enhance cooperation between the two nations, but also makes it possible for the pursuing of any fugitives of either country.[Iivula-Ithana] If they run away to the People's Republic of China, the Namibian government will be able to pursue them through the legal channels and get them to stand trial in Namibia. Vice-ersa, if fugitives run away from this country to Namibia and the Chinese government requests them to be extradited to stand trial in China, then arrangements can be made.[Reporter] Meanwhile, National Planning Commission Director-General Helmut Angula also signed other agreements, such as the free interest loan of 50m renminbi [about 6.2m dollars] of Chinese convertible currency to provide for the financing of government projects. According to Angula the Namibian government still needs to come up with initiatives as to what types of projects should be set up.[Angula] It was bilateral cooperation agreements, which provides for specific areas of cooperation between the two governments. I signed that with the vice-minister of foreign, I mean, of commerce.[Reporter] A security study for the construction of a military school by China has already been completed with the construction expected to start early next year.Source: Namibian Broadcasting Corporation TV, Windhoek, in English 1800 gmt 22 Dec 05

title: Loan to Rehabilitate dams (Duplicate with 1164)
description: Text of report by Dani Booysen entitled 'Chinese eager to help with power network' published by Namibian newspaper Republikein on 15 June Last week a Chinese government-owned company was in the country for talks with State House and NamPower [government-owned power utility] on assistance with the construction of a power line from Zambia. The 400 megawatts of electricity Namibia is planning to import via the Caprivi line from Zambia by 2009 represents more than double the amount of power the country is generating itself at the moment. With the completion of projects such as the Kudu Gas Field even further on the horizon, this line may bring in cheaper electricity than from South Africa to meet the ever-increasing demand. The chief technical adviser of NamPower, Rainer Jagau, confirmed that a delegation of the Chinese national corporation for the construction and import and export of agricultural machinery [CAMC] had held talks with the national power utility. However, he stressed that, as was the case with other offers from various places, NamPower would carefully compare the proposals with conditions elsewhere on the open market. Ms Liu Jianling, managing director of the department for business development of the Chinese company CAMS, paid a courtesy call on State House together with the economic adviser of the Chinese Embassy last week. The next day they were scheduled to meet the new chief executive officer of NamPower. Before the talks began behind closed doors, one of Pohamba's officials described the project to be discussed as a 'ery urgent project.' According to the Chinese they are in a great hurry to finance a contract after the signing of a general cooperation agreement with the Namibian Government during the State visit of the president to China in December last year. According to Mr Jagau it is however not a settled thing that CAMC would be a partner in the Caprivi project. The link of northern Namibia over Sesheke and Livingstone to the power network of the Zambia Electricity Supply Corporation [Zesco] will according to reports cost about 3 billion Namibian dollars. The ability to supplement Namibia's power demands on a large scale from this quarter depends amongst others on upgrading in Zambia, which has been topping the agenda of Zesco for the past years. In the inner rooms of State House it is speculated that the Inga Project, which eventually will use the same infrastructure, is probably the only long term solution to the region's electricity predicament. This project will according to plans assist the whole of Southern Africa with power from the Democratic Republic of Congo. The annual turnover of CAMS, established in 1982, amounts according to their website to about 200m US dollars, which is 1.3bn Namibian dollars. Between 40 and 60 per cent of this money is obtained from overseas contracts. At the end of May the Chinese government-owned company, according to the Mozambican Information Agency, was on the agenda of a high-level business conference in Maputo. The same report on allAfrica.com says Mozambique signed a cooperation agreement in April according to which the Exim Bank of China would lend 2.3bn US dollars (nearly 15bn Namibian dollars) for work on the Mepandua N'kua and Bue Maria dams. According to Mr Jagau the infrastructure for the Caprivi line should be completed by 2009. He therefore stressed that NamPower's strategy for the next years, like in South Africa and Zambia, would be to economize.
donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
verified: NamPower, State-Owned Company
