title: Water supply projects (Duplicate of 115 and 238)
description: 1 May 2000Dar Es Salaam (TOMRIC Agency, May 1, 2000) - China has earmarked a total of Tshs11 billion for construction of low-cost houses in Zanzibar and water supply projects in two Mainland regions.The rest, Tshs9 billion in grant form have been earmarked for water supply projects in Dodoma and Coast regions. The house construction project comes at the time when there is a big shortage of dwelling units in the country.

title: Zanzibar Debt Cancellation (Duplicate of 1361)
description: China cancels Zanzibar debt worth 7bn shillings.281 words11 June 200101:33 AMBBC Monitoring Africa - PoliticalBBCAPEnglish(c) 2001 The British Broadcasting Corporation [date of publication]. All Rights Reserved. No material may be reproduced except with the express permission of The British Broadcasting Corporation.Text of report by Tanzanian newspaper The Guardian web site on 11 JunChina will cancel all debts, amounting to over 7bn shillings, the Revolutionary Government of Zanzibar owes it, the Ministry for Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation has announced in Dar es Salaam.The ministry said in a statement issued yesterday that the Chinese prime minister, Zhu Rongji, made the pledge to cancel the debts in his meeting with the minister for foreign affairs and international cooperation, Jakaya Kikwete, who is touring China and other countries in the Far East.In China, Kikwete also met the Chinese foreign minister, Tang Jiaxuan.The statement also said China also has extended over 200m shillings to Tanzania as a gesture to the existing good relations between the two countries.China also intends to cancel some debts Tanzania owes it, the statement said.Tanzania's debts to China include loans extended during the first phase government to finance the construction of Tanzania-Zambia Railway (TAZARA), the Urafiki textile mill, the Ubungo Farm Implements (UFI) factory and Mbarali rice farm project.Kikwete and his counterpart, Jiaxuan, also signed an agreement for the establishment of a political consultative mechanism under which cabinet ministers from the two countries would be meeting every year to discuss issues in politics, economy and international relations.Kikwete and his delegation left Tanzania on 23 May for a tour of Far East countries, including China, India, Vietnam and Hong Kong.The minister visited farm projects and industries and met businessmen from the countries he toured.He is expected back home this week.Source: The Guardian web site, Dar es Salaam, in English 11 Jun 01.Document bbcap00020010710dx6b005o6

title: Water projects (Duplicate of 115 and 238)
description: China donates about 2.8m dollars for water projects.327 words28 February 200201:12 AMBBC Monitoring Africa - EconomicBBCAEEnglish(c) 2002 The British Broadcasting Corporation [date of publication]. All Rights Reserved. No material may be reproduced except with the express permission of The British Broadcasting Corporation.Text of report by Tanzanian newspaper The Guardian web site on 28 FebruaryTanzania yesterday received over 2.2bn shillings [about 2.8m dollars] from the Chinese government under an arrangement for financing the two on-going water supply projects.Speaking at the signing ceremony in Dar es Salaam yesterday, Deputy Minister for Finance Dr Festus Limbu said the total Chinese grant worth over 16.4bn shillings was for financing water supply projects in Dodoma Municipality and Chalinze in the Coast Region.Dr Limbu signed the agreement on behalf of the Tanzania government while the Chinese deputy minister for foreign trade and economic cooperation, He Xiaowei [name as published], signed on behalf of the Beijing government.The 2.2bn shillings committed yesterday was part of over 16.4bn shillings committed by the Chinese government for meeting costs of the two water projects, he said.Dr Limbu said the Chinese government had previously disbursed over 10.9bn shillings for the Chalinze project. 'China has also extended over 3.3bn shillings for financing Dodoma water project,' he said.Dr Limbu said China was one of the major donors to Tanzania. He commended the Chinese government for continued support and strengthening existing bilateral relations.'We hope the Chinese government will consider granting further assistance for priority areas in Tanzania, especially in the context of the poverty reduction strategy,' Dr Limbu said.On his part, the Chinese deputy minister for foreign trade and economic cooperation, Xiaowei, reaffirmed that his government would continue offering assistance to poor countries, including Tanzania.'Ours is also a poor country. There is a great need for poor countries to assist each other towards realization of sustainable economic development,' Xuaowei said.The Chinese minister and his entourage arrived in Dar es Salaam last Tuesday [26 February]. They are scheduled to leave Tanzania for China tomorrow.Source: The Guardian web site, Dar es Salaam, in English 28 Feb 02.

title: China to donate vehicles to Tanzania (Duplicate of 1493)
description: China to donate vehicles to Tanzania.138 words14 November 2002Xinhua News AgencyXNEWSEnglish(c) Copyright 2002 Xinhua News AgencyDAR ES SALAAM, No. 14 (Xinhua) - The agreement on the Chinese government donating five jeeps to Tanzanian Police was signed here on Thursday.Chinese ambassador to Tanzania Wang Yongqiu, signed the agreement with Tanzanian Minister of Home Affairs Mohammed Seif Khatib.The five jeeps, valued at around 154 million shillings (about 157, 000 US dollars), were mainly for the police to 'strengthen its capability, and in a better position to fight against criminals that are threatening the social stability of Tanzania.'Khatib hoped that the two countries can 'expand the cooperation further in the Home Affairs Ministry field for the mutual benefit of two peoples.'The minister also hoped that China, as a long-time friend toTanzania, can assist Tanzania with more equipment to strengthenthe capability of its police forces.Document xnews00020021114dybe003kh

title: Not a project/duplicate: Interest in Power Plant
description: See project #1833ABUJA, No 13 (AFP) - Nigeria's Vice President Atiku Abubakar on Tuesday welcomed China's willingness to invest in the country's under- performing power sector.Chinese firm North China Power Corporation has expressed interests in a power project in the northern Nigeria.The Mambilla power project, estimated to cost six billion naira (44.8 million dollars), is expected to boost electricity supplies to residents of Africa's most populous country.Receiving a delegation from the Chinese firm here Tuesday, Abubakar said the deal, when completed, will facilitate the transmission and distribution of electricity in the country.He therefore urged officials of the company to open discussions with Nigerian power officials to facilitate the deal.Abubakar said the government is worried that the state-run electricity company NEPA has been unable to meet the demands of the people.The company's performance has been so bad for so long, with hours- long shutdowns occuring everywhere daily and many areas experiencing power cuts for weeks.President Olusegun Obasanjo last year ordered NEPA to strengthen its system and double power output to around 4,000 megawatts by the end of this year.The government has also sent a bill to parliament to break up the company into power generation, transmission and distribution.
donor_agency: North China Power Corporation, State-Owned Company

recipient_agencies: North China Power Corporation, State-Owned Company

title: Food Aid to famine victims, Niger (Exact Duplicate of 2382)
description: 'Aug 24, 2001 (UN Integrated Regional Information Network/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX)-African countries have made the greatest contributions to Niger since its food appeal in January for 3.8 million people threatened by famine, a government official told IRIN on Thursday.Algeria, Egypt, Libya and Nigeria have donated corn, millet and sorghum amounting to 8,400 mt. France, Luxembourg and the European Union have donated close to 5,000 mt, the official, Ada Chaifou, said from Niamey. Chaifou, an adviser within the prime minister's Food Crisis Unit, said non-governmental organisations CARITAS, the local Red Cross, World Vision and a consortium of US NGOs had also responded well to the appeal. The Roman Catholic Church donated 1,230 mt of millet.China, the Swiss Cooperation, Niger's members of parliaments, private investors and others have contributed money. The bulk of aid is destined for residents of Difa, Maradi, Tillaberi and Zinder who were the most hungry. Eight months after the appeal, Chaifou said, 'there are no signs of distress.' He added that the government programme enabling the hungry to buy cereals cheaply had effectively warded-off the threat of famine and the drift of rural folk to urban areas.Some 53,000 mt have been sold under this programme, expected to end on 30 October.More donations are expected by the end of the year, he said, especially after a recent World Food Programme appeal. Meanwhile, he said, the government is thinking of introducing irrigation rather than depending on rain-fed agriculture.Copyright UN Integrated Regional Information Network. Distributed by All Africa Global Media(AllAfrica.com) '
sector: Humanitarian and Disaster Relief and Preparation

title: Not a project: Development of Potash Mine
description: China Mining United Fund (中礦聯合基金), which was launched in May last year as China's first private equity fund focused on mining-related investments, is likely to receive funding form China Investment Corporation (CIC, 中國投資有限公司) to develop a potash project in Ethiopia.According to China Mining's Web site, the potash project is one of the largest in the world, with projected output of about 200 million metric tons. It has inked an agreement with Canada's Allana Potash Corp to develop the project jointly. China Mining United Fund raised RMB 500 million (US$73.2 million) in its first phase of fundraising, but sources said the project needs much more capital investment.Allana Potash signed a strategic agreement in November with an affiliate of China Mining United Fund, China Mineral United Management Ltd., to place shares worth 2 million Canadian dollars (US$1.96 million) to the fund. The proceeds of the initial investment will be used to finance exploration and development of the potash project in Danakil Depression in northeastern Ethiopia.Under the agreement, China Mineral would acquire 20% of the total potash production of the project and finance 35% of its construction costs, estimated at around US$280 million, Allana said on its Web site. It said the Chinese mining fund is closely linked to one of the largest fertilizer companies in China, but didn't name the company.CIC, China’s US$300 billion sovereign wealth fund, is studying whether to take a stake in the potash project, or finance part of the project's construction costs.Uncertainty still surrounds the project as mining giant BHP Billiton Ltd, which has exploration licenses in Ethiopia, reportedly shows interest in it.CIC’s Deals in Resources Noble Group Limited (commodities)       US$-858-millionPT Bumi Resources Tbk (coal)    US$1.9 billion SouthGobi Energy Resources Ltd (coal)   US $500 million  Nobel Oil Group based in Russia (integrated, upstream petroleum)        US$ 300 million  JSC KazMunaiGas Exploration Production (oil)    US$939 million Teck Resources Limited (metal, metallurgical coal and molybdenum)       US$ 3.5 billion BBMG Corporation (cement) Yingde Gases Group Company Limited (gases)
donor_agency: China Investment Corporation, Private Sector
donor_agency_count: China Mining United Fund (CMUF), Private Sector
recipient_agencies: China Investment Corporation, Private Sector; China Mining United Fund (CMUF), Private Sector

title: Lesotho Highlands Water Project (LHWP) Money Request (inconclusive)
description: Business Report Chinese tapped for Lesotho dams ayanda mdluli 228 words 11 May 2011 Cape Times CAPTIM E1 19 English © Copyright 2011 Independent Newspapers (UK) Limited. All rights reserved. Various consortiums are jostling for a stake in the second phase of the the Lesotho Highlands Water Project (LHWP) ahead of a Chinese business delegation scheduled to arrive in the country next week.Speaking at a media briefing in Johannesburg yesterday, Mabitsela-Kotsekgolo 'MK' Malefane, the international investment and business development adviser at Imexpo, said a delegation of 75 Chinese nationals representing various interests would take part in the Southern African Development Community (SADC) and China trade fair and investment forum starting on May 18.The LHWP would be among the ventures discussed and developers would seek funding from the Chinese.Malefane was tight-lipped about the details of the project, and would not reveal which South African companies could benefit from this lucrative deal.The LHWP is a bilateral venture between South Africa and Lesotho worth $2 billion (R13.5bn). It is an ongoing water and power supply project, with a hydropower component led by Lesotho and dam development led by South Africa.The Lesotho Highlands Development Authority says the purpose of the project is to provide an income to Lesotho by 'transferring water from the catchment of the Senqu/Orange River in Lesotho' to meet South Africa's demand.The project is scheduled to be completed in 10 years' time after the construction of five different phases.Document CAPTIM0020110511e75b0002x

title: PPIAF - Information and Communication Technologies Agreement [duplicate of ID#146]
description: In 2003, Ghana Telecom and Alcatel Shanghai Bell signed a $150 million USD contract to provide 650,000 telephone lines, introduce broadband services, centralize a billing system, process and improve the quality of GT's services over the following three years. Ghanaian Minister of Communications Albert Kan Dapaah, Chinese ambassador to Ghana Lu Yonjshou, CEO of GT Oystein Bjorge, and Chairman of Alcatel Shanghai Bell Yuan Xin are all familiar with the project. In December 2003, the project was suspended because of a lawsuit against GT by Malaysian G-Gom. According to reports in 2005, the project was continued with the installation of 250 radio antenna to serve about 400,000 mobile phone users. 60 Chinese engineers are participating in the project. It is still unclear if the project was completed, but it appears to be untied. Phase 1 of the project appears to have been completed with the help of 60 Chinese engineers. Sources confirmed that Phase 2 was beginning in 2005.(PPIAF) In 2005, Ghana Telecom signed a buyer credit agreement with Societe Generale Corporate and Investment Bank (SG CIB) worth $67 million USD. The agreement carries a maturity of 6 years. Funds will be used to upgrade and expand Ghana Telecom's networks, financing the import of equipment from Alcatel Shanghai Bell. The loan is insured by Sinosure, the Chinese export credit agency.  Phase 2 of Ghana telecom project includes the supply of fixed network exchanges, mobile network equipment, and optical transfer equipment. Sinosure prevented default on this deal, after receiving preliminary notice of potential default in February 2007. There is some confusion that this might be a 50-50 Chinese-French joint venture. The total cost for Phase 2 appears to be $80 million USD, and the Chinese will commit $67 million USD. PPIAF-ID:141

title: Ghana Railway Company investment request {not a project}
description: Accra, Jul 14, 2003 (Accra Mail/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) - The Minister of Ports, Harbours and Railways, Professor Christopher Ameyaw-Akumfi has said the government is looking for a concessionaire to inject capital into the operations of the Ghana Railway Company.He said the concessionaire, which is expected to be selected through a bidding process by February next year is to revamp the railway system in the country. Speaking at the inauguration of a seven-member Technical Advisory Committee on GRC Lands, Prof. Ameyaw-Akumfi said the Committee would take care of Railway lands and their associate problems.The Committee would also trace all land allocations and illegal developments on such lands, especially, in areas like Accra-Tema, Kumasi and Sekonddi-Takoradi. He said Chinese Government, one of Ghana's development partners had indicated to the government its willingness to help expand rail to the north.A Chief State Attorney, Ms. Ama Banful chairs the Committee whose other members include Mr. George Mensah, Town and Country Planning Dept., Mr. Appiah-Adu, Lands Commission and Mr. Agyei Tabi, Ministry of Local Government. Others are Mr. D.K Osei, AMA, Mr. Albert Adjei, Shama Ahanta East Metro Assembly and Mr. Ampong of KMA.It has been two months now since the Ghana Railway Company sacked traders from the railway tracks at Kantamanto, Accra. A source told ADM that the absence of the traders from their premises has been a big relief to them.The source said some of the traders made the place into homes, doing all kinds of things like cooking which had burnt the wood supporting the tracks. There were exposing themselves to grave risks, he said, and 'even a train had cut one of the traders' leg some time ago.'One of the traders, who used to sell goods on the railway tracks, told the ADM that seven months ago, the G.R.C. served them with ejection notices. The trader said they petitioned the ministry, which oversees the operations of the GRC. The ministry promised to relocate them but suddenly the railway authorities sacked them.Another rail track market woman said they now find it very difficult to get a place to sell, 'We do not have a place to sit and do our selling' and added that when they sell on the pavements the Accra Metropolitan Assembly guards also drive them off and seize their wares.by Grace Akrasi Asare, InternCopyright Accra Mail. Distributed by All Africa Global Media(AllAfrica.com) KEYWORD:          Ghana.Document afnws00020030714dz7e0055

title: Not a project: Solar Power
description: 'Abuja, Apr 22, 2002 (This Day/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) - Chinese investors who arrived Nigeria at the weekend have pledged to raise the electricity output of Benue and Akwa Ibom States through Solar energy to make industrialisation in the two states realisable.The visit was at the instance of the two states and being facilitated by Dudu Consulting, a firm of financial and investment consultants.Leader of the six-man Chinese investment delegation for the one-week fact-fnding tour, Mr. Ton Gtse, said his team would explore investment opportunities in solar energy, agriculture, fertilizers and paint manufacturing.Gtse, the chairman of Tjanjon Teleinfo Technical Development Company, explained that the group consisted of several experts in various fields and from different companies, but that they were prepared to undertake foreign investment in Nigeria.'With the population of the country of Nigeria, we believe we can have good market. Immediately we move into Nigeria to establish our project, we are starting with Benue and Akwa Ibom but we believe that if we have the right investment environment, we will immediately establish our business in the other states,' he said.Head of team, Dudu Consulting, Dr. Mike Aderonmu, said the decision by both Benue and Akwa Ibom to go into solar energy production was based on wanting to empower ttheir rural population.According to him, solar energy remained the most economical means of independent power generation for rural settlement.On the fertilizer plant, Aderonmu pointed out that Benue State, reputed for food production, could have optimal output if farmers have fertilizers to aid their farming activities. '
donor_agency: Dudu Consulting Nigeria Ltd., Private Sector
verified: Dudu Consulting Nigeria Ltd., Private Sector

title: Investment Deal
description: In February 2002, Chinese investors signed a business agreement in Lagos with Lagos-based Clog Oil Group. According to the chairman of Clog Oil Group, Chief Benson Akingboye, the joint agreement would ensure that the Chinese investors supply their capital and expertise to contribute to the country's economic growth. The details of the specific projects were to be unfolded after the Chinese investors' thorough survey of Nigeria's potential. The status of the projects is uncertain.
donor_agency_count: Clog Oil Group, Private Sector
verified: Clog Oil Group, Private Sector

title: Planning Joint Railway Management (of #195 RR)
description: See ID# 1809'Jul 02, 2002 (Daily Trust/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) - China and Nigeria are planning go into a joint venture for the management of Nigeria's railways, the News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) has reported.Chairman of China Civil Engineering and Construction Company (CCECC), Mr. Di Yu Chung, said during a reception yesterday for Vice-President Atiku Abubakar in Beijing that the proposed deal was in respect of Lagos/Kano rail link.Although he did not give details, he said that the deal would be practicable after the rehabilitation work on Nigeria's rail system has been completed by CCECC.Apart from the joint venture, Di said that his company was interested in establishing workshops in Nigeria where rail slippers would be manufactured.According to him, the effort is aimed at ensuring that rail networks would be maintained after the rehabilitation programme.Furthermore, he said that such workshops would serve as a means of transferring Chinese rail technology to Nigeria with the motive of encouraging self-sustenance.On future investment profile for Nigeria, Di said that CCECC has its mind in the nation's power sector as it intends to invest in hydro-power development of the country.He said that Nigeria deserved a lot of technological and economic development because of its importance in Africa.Responding, Abubakar assured his host of the support of the Federal Government in ensuring the success of the joint venture business of railway management.He expressed satisfaction at the capacity of the Chinese company to deliver, saying that he was impressed by the achievements of CCECC.Also speaking, Minister of State for Transport, Alhaji Isa Yuguda, said that the joint venture being proposed by CCECC would not cost the government any money.According to him, Nigeria's contribution to the deal would be the provision of its locomotives, while CCECC would provide spare parts.He gave the assurance that the proposal which had reached the level of a memorandum of understanding (MOU) would be in Nigeria's favour when implemented. '
donor_agency_count: China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation (CCECC), State-Owned Company
recipient_agencies: China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation (CCECC), State-Owned Company

title: TAZARA - Tazara Gets $5 Million Worth of Equipment (Duplicate of 2276)
description: Tazara Gets $5 Million Worth of Equipmentby OSEPH MWAMUNYANGE657 words30 October 200604:06 PMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2006 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedNairobi, Oct 30, 2006 (The East African/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) --The Tanzania-Zambia Railway Authority (Tazara) has received new equipment and machinery worth $5 million to improve its operations.Tazara spokesman Clement Mwiya last week told The EastAfrican that the Authority has, throughout its existence, received assistance in the form of interest free loans advanced to the two Contracting States - Tanzania and Zambia by the Chinese government.'It is no a secret that Tazara is today beset with problems arising from the lack of sustained capital injection,' he said.The acquisition of 50 light truck trolleys, 50 sets of 50 tonne covered wagons and lifting equipment consisting of four sets of 10 tonne forklifts, with spares, will greatly enhance Tazara's efficiency and help it meet demands from both passenger and freight markets.Other equipment includes four sets of eight tonne mobile cranes, with spare parts and 20 sets of 80 tonne hydraulic jacks, also with spares.Mr Mwiya said that the wagons and equipment would be a big boost and 'could not have come at a better time than now when we just embarked on the rehabilitation of mainline locomotives, for increased capacity and efficient services.' General Electric of the US is rehabilitating the engines.He said that, with the support from the Chinese government and the Contracting States, the volume of traffic moved on Tazara is expected to grow from the current annual of 600,000mt to 800,000mt for freight and one million to 1.2 million passengers over the next five years. 'This will increase total revenue from the current $35 million to $55 million per annum, helping the railway to become profitable,' said Mr Mwiya.In view of the fact that there has been lack of sustained capital injection, the company has in the last few years been transporting just about 650,000 tonnes of cargo, and one million passengers per annum, almost half of what it used to move at its peak in the late 1980s or indeed at the peak of copper production in Zambia.On the last aspect of copper movement, Mr Mwiya said that Tazara was expecting more of the metal from Zambia because of huge investments made in the landlocked country in opening new mines.Tazara has since last year been collaborating with Zambian copper mining company Konkola Copper Mine in the rehabilitation of its rolling stock, which includes wagons and engines.Mr Mwiya told The EastAfrican mid last year that they were expecting an upswing in the amount of cargo shipped from and to neighbouring Zambia's mining companies and thus would collaborate with Koncola to acquire spares and ensure speedy movement of goods.Tazara is gearing for what he termed as 'an upswing in the amount of copper and cobalt exports from Zambia because of increased copper production from the present mines and new mines like Kansanshi in north-western Zambia.' More than 10 years ago, when Zambia started privatising its mines, many firms from outside the landlocked country arrived on the scene.The big companies include Mopani Copper Mines, First Quantum Minerals, Cyprus Amax Zambia Corporation, Caledonia Mining.Before this, the mines were under the Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines Ltd, after they were nationalised from Roan Mine Corporation and Rokana Mine Corporation, which were under Anglo-American Corporation.Tazara is receiving more enquiries from Zambia, where more companies want to transport their cargo through Dar es Salaam. 'This is because of an improvement in both, the transit time to Zambia and speedy clearance of goods at the port of Dar es Salaam. It is worth noting that services at the port have improved tremendously, especially with containerised cargo,' said Mr Mwiya.One of the mining companies that have made enquiries is First Quantum Minerals, which runs Bwana Mkubwa Mines one of the oldest mines in Zambia, on the outskirts of Ndola.Document AFNWS00020061031e2au0002a

title: Eximbank Loan for Investment Authority of Egypt- Chinese article (Duplicate)
description: '吴思科大使出席中国进出口银行与埃及投资部优惠贷款协议签字仪式（驻埃及使馆供稿）2005/11/20　　20日，正在埃及访问的中国进出口银行行长李若谷同埃及投资部长毛希丁签署了中国政府向埃及提供1630万美元贷款的协议。埃及国际合作部长纳佳、中国驻埃及大使吴思科、经商处公参崔明谟等出席了项目签字仪式。吴思科大使出席签字仪式　　根据协议，中国进出口银行将向埃及棉纺织控股公司提供优惠贷款，帮助该公司对其下属的亚历山大聚酯厂进行改造。这是埃方首次使用中国政府提供的优惠贷款，这个协议也是为落实胡锦涛主席去年访埃期间与穆巴拉克总统达成的全面发展两国合作伙伴关系计划的一部分。吴思科大使出席李若谷行长同埃投资部长毛希丁会谈         '

title: China releases loan for major road construction in Ghana
description: In 2003, China pledged $28 million USD to be used over the following 3 years to finance portions of the Accra-Kumasi trunk road rehabilitation project. The Chinese vice minister of Foreign Affairs Yang Wenchang and President John Agyekum Kufuor signed the agreement. The contracting firm is China Railway Engineering Corporation. Work started on the project on December 29 at Amasaman in the Ga District regarding the section of the Accra-Kumasi road from Ofankor to Nsawam. The road is aspaltic dual carriage way. The project includes the construction of a 20 meter fly-over bridge over the rail line near Ofankor. The design can handle 13 tons. The construction of the road was started by the New Patriotic Party administration under former president Kufuor via Internally Generated Funds. In 2009, when the NPP left office, most of the road had been completed, but the Apedwa portion of the road was still under construction. The project is untied. It appears that the project is still under construction.

title: Not Bilateral : Construction of light rail network in Addis Ababa
description: Addis Ababa, March. 30 -- India and China will help build a railway network across Ethiopia that would significantly improve the east African nation's transport system. India has pledged $300 million for the national rail network construction while China's Export and Import (EXIM) Bank has inked a deal to finance 85 percent of the cost of a light rail network in the capital city of Addis Ababa at $490 million. The cost of the rail network across the country has been estimated at $6 billion, according to an initial estimation. 'India has pledged to provide us with $300 million for the project as part of its assistance to the infrastructure development of African countries,' Ethiopian Transport Minister Diriba Kuma told the Capital newspaper. 'We have asked India for another $300 million for the project,' he said. The rail network is part of the country's Growth and Transformation Plan that sets a target of construction of a 2,395-km national rail track.The Addis Ababa track would be 36.5 km long. Diriba told parliament every kilometre of the national track would cost $2-3 million. Based on this calculation, the average cost for a prioritised 1,808-km network would amount to around $4.5 billion. The Addis Ababa rail network, supplemented by buses and taxis, would help in solving the ever-increasing transportation problems the city was facing, officials said. China has also given four buses, whose manufacturing would be emulated locally as part of the government's plan to deploy 500 new buses in the capital.Published by HT Syndication with permission from Indo-Asian News Service.
donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency

title: Hydropower stations plans
description: On March 24, 2003, Chinese Ambassador to Nigeria Liang Yinzhu announced plans to introduce small-scale hydropower stations in Nigeria on his farewell visit to the Minister of Agriculture and Rural Development, Mallam Adamu Bello. The status of the projects is uncertain.

title: MoU for loan amounting to 5.2bn birr (Duplicate)
description: Text of report in English by state-owned Ethiopian news agency ENA websiteAddis Ababa, 5 December: Ethiopia and China here on Monday [5 December] signed a loan agreement amounting to 6.9bn birr [nearly 400m dollars] to be used for upgrading safe water provision in Addis Ababa and also achieving the [national five-year] Growth and Transformation Plan (GTP).According to the agreement, 1.7bn birr of the stated sum will be utilized to drill water wells in selected areas of the city.Finance and Economic Development Minister Sufyan Ahmad and the vice-president of Exim Bank of China, Zhu Hongjie, signed the agreement.Similarly, the Commercial Bank of Ethiopia (CBE) and Exim Bank of China signed a Memorandum of Understanding under which Exim Bank agreed to provide loan amounting to 5.2bn birr.The fund will be used for implementation of various projects planned under the GTP.CBE President Bekalu Zeleke and Exim Bank Vice-President Zhu Hongjie signed the agreement.Source: ENA website, Addis Ababa, in English 5 Dec 11
donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency

title: N$50,000 for sewing equipment by Jiangsu Eastern China Non-ferrous Metal Investment Holding
description: Windhoek, Apr 21, 2011 (New Era/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- Dr Sam Nujoma Cluster School, a rural school east of Katima Mulilo would soon start making its own school uniforms, thanks to a donation from Namibia East China Non-ferrous Investments (Pty) Ltd.The Namibia-registered company, which opened is doors in June 2009, is also a shareholder in Jiangsu Eastern China Non-ferrous Metal Investment Holding (ECE), a Chinese state-owned company.ECE is a well-known mineral exploration and development group in China, which in July last year bought 65 percent shares in Berg Aukas Mine from Weatherly International Plc.Handing over a N$50000 donation to buy sewing equipment and materials for the Caprivi school, Li Ming said ECE cares about social and public welfare and would support education.ECE made the donation in response to the plight of 195 orphans and vulnerable children at the school in Caprivi Region, who cannot afford to pay school development funds. The school's Kalikumbete tailoring project would use the donation to buy sewing machines for the students to learn how to make their own uniforms.Meanwhile, in its support for education, ECE has so far helped with the establishment of the Dr Sam Nujoma Sciences Scholarship Scheme at the University of Namibia to support Unam students to pursue their Masters and Doctors degrees. The company donated N$500000 to Unam in 2010, and would again donate another N$500000 next month year towards the scholarships.
sector: Humanitarian and Disaster Relief and Preparation
donor_agency: Jiangsu Eastern China Non-ferrous Metal Investment Holding Co. Ltd, State-Owned Company; Namibia East China Non-ferrous Investments Ltd., Private Sector
recipient_agencies: Jiangsu Eastern China Non-ferrous Metal Investment Holding Co. Ltd, State-Owned Company; Namibia East China Non-ferrous Investments Ltd., Private Sector

title: Approved Destination Status (Not a project)
description: China-Africa forum ends, action plan adopted463 words17 December 200307:13 AMBBC Monitoring AfricaBBCAPEnglish(c) 2003 The British Broadcasting Corporation [date of publication]. All Rights Reserved. No material may be reproduced except with the express permission of The British Broadcasting Corporation.Text of report in English by official Chinese news agency Xinhua (New China News Agency)Addis Ababa, 16 December: The two-day Second Ministerial Conference of the China-Africa Cooperation Forum ended here Tuesday [16 December] after adopting the Addis Ababa Action Plan.The action plan, with the emphasis on performance-based and result-specific cooperation, puts forward a series of new measures for increasing exchanges and cooperation in various areas between China and African countries.According to the action plan, China has decided to grant zero-tariff treatment to some commodities of least developed African countries for their access to the Chinese market.The Chinese side will, starting from 2004, negotiate lists of tariff-free goods and the rules of origin with the countries concerned on a bilateral basis.China will, in the next three years, further increase its financial contribution to the African Human Resources Development Fund for the training of up to 10,000 African personnel in different fields.China has also decided to grant Approved Destination Status ( ADS) to Mauritius, Zimbabwe, Tanzania, Kenya, Ethiopia, Seychelles, Tunisia, and Zambia, to further enhance China-Africa tourism cooperation.The annual international art festival 'Meet in Beijing' to be held in 2004 will feature Africa and its arts, the action plan said, adding that eight to 10 African art troupes will be invited to perform and a number of African art exhibitions will be staged in China.In addition, under bilateral cultural exchange programmes, China will send its performing, acrobatic and martial arts troupes to Africa and stages a Chinese Art Festival.To encourage people-to-people contacts and exchanges, China has also proposed a 'China-Africa Youth Festival' to be celebrated in China in 2004, which will serve as a channel for collective dialogue and cooperation between Chinese and African youth organizations.The Second Ministerial Meeting of the China-Africa Cooperation Forum, the first of its kind held in Africa, had the participation of China and more than 40 African countries.Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao attended the opening ceremony of the conference and delivered a speech. Also present at the opening ceremony were more than 10 African heads of state or government.Ministers in charge of foreign affairs and international economic cooperation from China and the African countries, and representatives of some international and regional organizations took part in the meeting.Participants reviewed the implementation of the Beijing Declaration and the Programme for China-Africa Cooperation in Economic and Social Development, two documents adopted during the First Ministerial Meeting of the forum held in Beijing in 2000.They discussed cooperation in such key areas as human resources development, agriculture, infrastructure, trade and investment.Source: Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in English 1529 gmt 16 Dec 03
sector: Trade, Tourism, Banking and Financial Services

title: Duplicate: Construction of bridge
description: As for the visit to Mali, Zhai Jun said, Mali is one of the first Southern African countries that established diplomatic relations with China. China and Mali maintained good relations over a long time. President Hu will visit Mali from 12 to 13 February. During the visit, he will hold talks with president Toure, and will meet with Speaker Traore [as received], exchanging opinions on bilateral relations and Sino-African relations. President Hu will attend the inaugural ceremony of the third Bamako bridge, a construction project with Chinese aid, and will call on members of the Chinese medical team in Mali. He will also attend the inaugural ceremony of an anti-malaria centre, which was constructed with Chinese aid.As for the visit to Senegal, Zhai Jun said, Senegal is a country recently restoring diplomatic relations with China. Since China and Senegal restored relations in October 2005, bilateral relations have been developing smoothly. President Hu will visit Senegal from 13 to 14 February. During the visit, he will hold talks with President Wade, meet with Senate President Diop and National Assembly Speaker Sake, exchanging opinions on bilateral relations, on the implementation of the results of the Beijing Summit, and on other international and regional issues of common interest. President Hu will also visit construction projects using Chinese aid.As for the visit to Tanzania, Zhai Jun said, Tanzania is China's traditional friendly country. This year will mark the 45th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations between the two countries. President Hu Jintao will visit Tanzania from 14 to 16 February. During the visit, he will hold talks with President Kikwete of Tanzania, and meet with President Karume of Zanibar, exchanging opinions on such issues as bilateral relations, the conditions of the implementation of the results of the Beijing Summit of the Forum on China-African Cooperation, and the international financial crisis. President Hu will also attend the completion ceremony of the National Stadium built with Chinese aid, pay a visit to the tombs of Chinese experts, and give a speech at a welcome rally held by Tanzanian people from all social circles.As for the visit to Mauritius, Zhai Jun said, since China and Mauritius established diplomatic relations in 1972, relations between the two countries have been developing smoothly, and substantial results have been achieved in the economic, trading, and other fields. President Hu will visit Mauritius from 16 to 17 February. During the visit, he will hold talks with Prime Minister Ramgoolam, meet with President Jugnauth and other Mauritian leaders, exchanging opinions on bilateral relations and on international and regional issues of common interests, such as coping with the international financial crisis. President Hu will also visit the Chinese Culture Centre.Zhai Jun said: Leaders and governments of the five above-mentioned countries all attach great importance to President Hu's visit, and have made careful arrangements for ensuring that significant results will be achieved by the visit. It is believed that with the joint efforts of all parties concerned, this visit will certainly be completely successful, and will make contributions to advancing cooperation between China and other developing countries and consolidating relations between China and Saudi Arabia and between China and Africa.When answering a question about China's aid to Africa, Zhai Jun said: At the 2006 Beijing Summit, President Hu announced that in the next three years, China would double its aid to Africa, and this target will be achieved within this year. During the visit, President Hu will exchange ideas with leaders of the five countries on the issues of common interest in economic and trading cooperation, and will also provide new assistance to the African countries. Consultations on the concrete arrangements are under way.When answering a question about the implementation of the eight measures China announced at the Beijing Summit of the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation, Zhai Jun said: The eight measures are scheduled in the period from 2007 to 2008, and this year is the last year for the implementation of the eight measures. So far, the eight measures have been implemented rather smoothly. During the 2007 UN General Assembly, the Chinese foreign minister and his counterparts in the African countries held their first round of political consultation, and thus started the foreign minister-level political consultation mechanism between China and Africa. China has completely fulfilled the measure of exempting all tariffs for the products exported by the least developed African countries to China. The work of exempting part of the due debts owed to China by poor African countries with heavy debt burdens and with diplomatic relations with China has also basically completed. The China-Africa Development Fund has been smoothly started, and has been invested in 20 projects so far. The China-funded project of construction the assembly building for the African Union was officially started last December, and the project is going on smoothly. Up to the end of 2008, China provided training for 11,000 people of all types in African countries, dispatched 125 young volunteers to work in Africa, selected 100 senior agricultural specialists, and is now sending them to Africa continuously. The China-funded projects of hospitals, anti-malaria centres, and schools are smoothly under construction. By the end of this year, the Chinese side will smoothly fulfil President Hu Jintao's eight promises of offering aid to Africa.When answering a question about the impact of the financial crisis on the China-Africa cooperation and China's countermeasures, Zhai Jun said: As the financial crisis has affected all countries in the world, it certainly may also affect African countries and China as well, and may produce certain impact on China-Africa cooperation. In particular, some Chinese enterprises may encounter difficulties in their African business operation. The Chinese side has paid close attention to this issue, and is taking a series of measures to enhance cooperation with African countries, to jointly face such challenges and strive to lower the adverse impact to a minimum. The Chinese side will make greater efforts in work to fulfil the eight measures announced by President Hu, will fulfil the promises of offering aid to Africa by meeting the qualitative and quantitative standards as scheduled, and will continue to encourage and support Chinese enterprises to make investment and launch business ventures in African countries. It is believed with the joint efforts of both sides, we will be able to smoothly cope with the impact of the financial crisis on the China-Africa cooperation.When answering a question about Chinese leaders' visits to Africa, Zhai Jun said: Chinese leaders paid many visits to Africa, because relations between China and Africa are good. China and African countries have profound traditional friendships. Both sides share similar experience in history, and also face common development tasks in the new period. The Chinese government and Chinese leaders always attach great importance to developing a friendly and cooperative relationship with African countries, take African countries as our good friends, good partners, good brothers. We treat each other with sincerity, pursue mutually beneficial cooperation, and make common development. The fact that Chinese leaders paid many visits to African countries fully showed the important position of developing cooperation and friendship with Africa in China's foreign policy.Zhai Jun said: With the exception of Saudi Arabia, four of the five countries that President Hu will visit this time are not rich in energy and resources. This fully shows that China-Africa relations are not merely energy and resources relations. Energy and resources cooperation is a component of the China-Africa cooperation, but not the whole of such cooperation. We have profound traditional friendship with these four African countries, and also have a very good condition of mutually beneficial cooperation in various aspects.Source: Xinhua news agency domestic service, Beijing, in Chinese 1502 gmt 6 Feb 09 BAMAKO: Thousands of people cheered and banged drums here on Friday as President Hu Jintao and his Malian counterpart Amadou Toumani Toure laid the foundation stone for the city's third China-funded bridge across the Niger River.'The bridge represents a new level of cooperation between China and Mali,' Hu said at the laying ceremony.'Although we haven't given a name to the bridge, today we can officially name it Bridge of Malian-Chinese Friendship,' Toure said.Local people had every reason to celebrate, as the new bridge is designed to ease traffic congestion in the city.'The third bridge will be very good for us,' Nene Rokiatou Thiam, an employee of Hotel L'Amitie, said.Toure talked with Hu about Bamako's need for a third crossing during their meeting three years ago at the Beijing Summit of the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation, the Malian president said on Friday.In 2007, Toure was told that China was willing to finance the bridge, and soon after teams of Chinese and Malian engineers began working on its design.About 40 Chinese engineers and technical workers arrived in Bamako three months ago to start construction.China hopes to build a 'top-level' bridge and 'a new bridge of friendship', Hu said.The structure, about 10 km from downtown Bamako, will be almost 2.3 km long and 24 m wide and carry four traffic lanes, Ma Jiangquan, deputy engineer general of the No 2 Co of the China Gezhouba Group International, which is building it, said.The project will cost almost 346 million yuan ($51 million).The firm plans to send about 70 managers, engineers and technicians to work on the it, as well as employing between 500 and 1,000 local workers.'We try to make the best use of all local resources,' Shi Li, vice-president of China Gezhouba Group International Engineering Co Ltd, told China Daily.'This will help alleviate unemployment and improve the skills of local workers.'The bridge is expected to take about 40 months to complete.'The advent of China and other emerging players as important financiers (in infrastructure building) represents an encouraging trend for Africa, given the magnitude of its infrastructure deficit,' a report entitled Building Bridges China's Growing Role as Infrastructure Financier for Africa said.The report, commissioned by the World Bank and released last year, also said the investments made by these emerging financiers are unprecedented in scale, and in their focus on large-scale infrastructure projects.Eer since Mali won independence in 1960, its population has grown fast, especially in Bamako, home to about 2 million people.Along with steady economic development, the city has also witnessed a steady increase of motor vehicles growing. During the daily rush hours, its roads are packed full with minibuses, trucks, cars and motorcycles.(Copyright 2001 by China Daily)

title: Medical aid team
description: Beijing, 6 Feb (Xinhua) - The Ministry of Foreign Affairs held a news briefing for Chinese and foreign reporters. Zhai Jun, assistant minister of foreign affairs gave a briefing on the relevant arrangements of President Hu Jintao's upcoming visit to five countries, namely, Saudi Arabia, Mali, Senegal, Tanzania, and Mauritius, from 10 to 17 February.Zhai Jun said: Currently, the impact of the international financial crisis is still expanding and spreading, and has spread from developed countries to emerging market countries and developing countries, and from the financial domain to the real economy, posing an increasing challenge to the developing countries, including China, Saudi Arabia, and African countries. The Chinese side calls for alleviating the impact of the crisis on developing countries to the maximum extent, and is willing to enhance cooperation and coordinate action with the international community, including the vast developing countries, so as to jointly tide over the hard times.Zhai Jun said: Since China and Saudi Arabia established diplomatic relations in 1990, bilateral relations have been developing smoothly. In particular, in recent years, relations between the two countries developed rapidly in all aspects, and the two sides have established strategic friendly relations. Saudi Arabia has been China's largest trading partner in Western Asia and Africa for many years running. The collective cooperation between China and the Gulf Cooperation Council has also made positive progress.Zhai Jun said: In recent years, especially after the Beijing Summit of the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation, Sino-African relations developed rapidly. As both sides of China and Africa attached great importance and made close cooperation, all follow-up measures after the summit were implemented steadily. Sino-African political relations became closer, pragmatic cooperation developed deeply, both sides further strengthened mutual support and cooperation in international affairs. The implementation of the eight measures adopted by China for cooperation with Africa has made positive progress. This year is the last year for implementing the results of the summit meeting. In the fourth quarter, the fourth ministerial-level meeting of the forum will be held, so Sino-African relations exist at an important development stage.Zhai Jun emphasized: The coming visit will be President Hu Jintao's first foreign visit in 2009, and also his second visit to African countries after the 2006 Beijing Summit of the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation. Hopefully, the visit will consolidate the strategic friendship between China and Saudi Arabia, promote the collective cooperation between China and the Gulf Cooperation Council, promote the implementation of the results of the Beijing Summit of the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation at the last stage, further deepen the new-type strategic partnership between China and Africa, enhance friendly cooperation with the four African countries, and promote common development.As for the visit to Saudi Arabia, Zhai Jun said, President Hu will visit Saudi Arabia from 10 to 12 February. During the visit, he will hold talks with King Abdullah, and deeply exchange opinions on further consolidating and strengthening strategic friendly relations between the two countries and on international and regional affairs of common interest. President Hu will meet with Attiyah, secretary general of the Gulf Cooperation Council, and exchange opinions on enhancing the collective cooperation between China and the Gulf Cooperation Council. President Hu will also visit the cement production line, built by a Chinese contractor-enterprise, of the Saudi Riyadh Cement Corporation.Zhai Jun said: This will President Hu's second visit to Saudi Arabia in the last three years. Relations between China and Saudi Arabia are developing very well, and the bilateral cooperation is multi-faceted and multi-tiered. Energy cooperation is an important component. Saudi Arabia is the largest energy supplier to China. Last year, China imported more than 36 million tons of petroleum from Saudi Arabia. Energy cooperation will be an important subject in the talks between President Hu and King Abdullah. The two sides will also talk about the concrete cooperation documents to be signed.As for the visit to Mali, Zhai Jun said, Mali is one of the first Southern African countries that established diplomatic relations with China. China and Mali maintained good relations over a long time. President Hu will visit Mali from 12 to 13 February. During the visit, he will hold talks with president Toure, and will meet with Speaker Traore [as received], exchanging opinions on bilateral relations and Sino-African relations. President Hu will attend the inaugural ceremony of the third Bamako bridge, a construction project with Chinese aid, and will call on members of the Chinese medical team in Mali. He will also attend the inaugural ceremony of an anti-malaria centre, which was constructed with Chinese aid.As for the visit to Senegal, Zhai Jun said, Senegal is a country recently restoring diplomatic relations with China. Since China and Senegal restored relations in October 2005, bilateral relations have been developing smoothly. President Hu will visit Senegal from 13 to 14 February. During the visit, he will hold talks with President Wade, meet with Senate President Diop and National Assembly Speaker Sake, exchanging opinions on bilateral relations, on the implementation of the results of the Beijing Summit, and on other international and regional issues of common interest. President Hu will also visit construction projects using Chinese aid.As for the visit to Tanzania, Zhai Jun said, Tanzania is China's traditional friendly country. This year will mark the 45th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations between the two countries. President Hu Jintao will visit Tanzania from 14 to 16 February. During the visit, he will hold talks with President Kikwete of Tanzania, and meet with President Karume of Zanibar, exchanging opinions on such issues as bilateral relations, the conditions of the implementation of the results of the Beijing Summit of the Forum on China-African Cooperation, and the international financial crisis. President Hu will also attend the completion ceremony of the National Stadium built with Chinese aid, pay a visit to the tombs of Chinese experts, and give a speech at a welcome rally held by Tanzanian people from all social circles.As for the visit to Mauritius, Zhai Jun said, since China and Mauritius established diplomatic relations in 1972, relations between the two countries have been developing smoothly, and substantial results have been achieved in the economic, trading, and other fields. President Hu will visit Mauritius from 16 to 17 February. During the visit, he will hold talks with Prime Minister Ramgoolam, meet with President Jugnauth and other Mauritian leaders, exchanging opinions on bilateral relations and on international and regional issues of common interests, such as coping with the international financial crisis. President Hu will also visit the Chinese Culture Centre.Zhai Jun said: Leaders and governments of the five above-mentioned countries all attach great importance to President Hu's visit, and have made careful arrangements for ensuring that significant results will be achieved by the visit. It is believed that with the joint efforts of all parties concerned, this visit will certainly be completely successful, and will make contributions to advancing cooperation between China and other developing countries and consolidating relations between China and Saudi Arabia and between China and Africa.When answering a question about China's aid to Africa, Zhai Jun said: At the 2006 Beijing Summit, President Hu announced that in the next three years, China would double its aid to Africa, and this target will be achieved within this year. During the visit, President Hu will exchange ideas with leaders of the five countries on the issues of common interest in economic and trading cooperation, and will also provide new assistance to the African countries. Consultations on the concrete arrangements are under way.When answering a question about the implementation of the eight measures China announced at the Beijing Summit of the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation, Zhai Jun said: The eight measures are scheduled in the period from 2007 to 2008, and this year is the last year for the implementation of the eight measures. So far, the eight measures have been implemented rather smoothly. China has completely fulfilled the measure of exempting all tariffs for the products exported by the least developed African countries to China. The work of exempting part of the due debts owed to China by poor African countries with heavy debt burdens and with diplomatic relations with China has also basically completed. The China-Africa Development Fund has been smoothly started, and has been invested in 20 projects so far. The China-funded project of construction the assembly building for the African Union was officially started last December, and the project is going on smoothly. Up to the end of 2008, China provided training for 11,000 people of all types in African countries, dispatched 125 young volunteers to work in Africa, selected 100 senior agricultural specialists, and is now sending them to Africa continuously. By the end of this year, the Chinese side will smoothly fulfil President Hu Jintao's eight promises of offering aid to Africa.When answering a question about the impact of the financial crisis on the China-Africa cooperation and China's countermeasures, Zhai Jun said: As the financial crisis has affected all countries in the world, it certainly may also affect African countries and China as well, and may produce certain impact on China-Africa cooperation. In particular, some Chinese enterprises may encounter difficulties in their African business operation. The Chinese side has paid close attention to this issue, and is taking a series of measures to enhance cooperation with African countries, to jointly face such challenges and strive to lower the adverse impact to a minimum. The Chinese side will make greater efforts in work to fulfil the eight measures announced by President Hu, will fulfil the promises of offering aid to Africa by meeting the qualitative and quantitative standards as scheduled, and will continue to encourage and support Chinese enterprises to make investment and launch business ventures in African countries. It is believed with the joint efforts of both sides, we will be able to smoothly cope with the impact of the financial crisis on the China-Africa cooperation.When answering a question about Chinese leaders' visits to Africa, Zhai Jun said: Chinese leaders paid many visits to Africa, because relations between China and Africa are good. China and African countries have profound traditional friendships. Both sides share similar experience in history, and also face common development tasks in the new period. The Chinese government and Chinese leaders always attach great importance to developing a friendly and cooperative relationship with African countries, take African countries as our good friends, good partners, good brothers. We treat each other with sincerity, pursue mutually beneficial cooperation, and make common development. The fact that Chinese leaders paid many visits to African countries fully showed the important position of developing cooperation and friendship with Africa in China's foreign policy.Zhai Jun said: With the exception of Saudi Arabia, four of the five countries that President Hu will visit this time are not rich in energy and resources. This fully shows that China-Africa relations are not merely energy and resources relations. Energy and resources cooperation is a component of the China-Africa cooperation, but not the whole of such cooperation. We have profound traditional friendship with these four African countries, and also have a very good condition of mutually beneficial cooperation in various aspects.Source: Xinhua news agency domestic service, Beijing, in Chinese 1502 gmt 6 Feb 09

title: West African Council for the Promotion of Peaceful Reunification of China -- NOT A PROJECT
description: 'LAGOS, July 9 (Xinhua) -- The West African Council for the Promotion of Peaceful Reunification of China (WACPPRC) was founded here on Friday.At the inauguration ceremony in Lagos, Nigeria's commercial capital, the WACPPRC in a declaration called on the Chinese people in west African countries and other parts of the world to unite, adhere to the 'one China' principle and strongly oppose the ' independence of Taiwan' to promote the peaceful reunification of China.WACPPRC Chairman Cha Jimin addressed the meeting, saying that the establishment of the WACPPRC 'is a bridge linking the Chinese people in west Africa and other parts of the world to strengthen friendship between them and further expand exchanges in the fields of economy, trade, sciences and technology and culture.'In his address to the meeting, Wang Changyu, deputy secretary general of the China Council for the Promotion of Peaceful National Reunification, said the establishment of the WACPPRC ' will surely play an important role in enhancing unity and great union among the Chinese people and carry forward the global movement to oppose the 'independence of Taiwan' and promote the peaceful reunification of China.'The Nigerian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Nigeria-China Friendship Association, the China Council for the Promotion of Peaceful National Reunification, the All African Council for the Promotion of Peaceful Reunification and the peaceful reunification councils in many other countries sent greeting messages to the meeting to mark the establishment of the WACPPRC.In its message of goodwill to the WACPPRC, the Nigerian Foreign Ministry said that 'Nigeria believes that the pursuit of a policy of peaceful reunification is not only in the best interest of the government and people of China, but also in the interest of world peace, security and development.'More than 200 Chinese people in west African countries and from other parts of the world, including Chinese Ambassador to Nigeria Wang Yongqiu and Lagos Consul General Liu Yinghai attended the conference.In the last three years and more, over 120 peaceful reunification councils have been set up in more than 80 countries around the world. They have so far convened world conferences on peaceful reunification of China in Berlin, Washington, Panama, Tokyo, Sydney, Rio de Janeiro, Moscow and South Africa. '

title: Oil exploration
description: On November 12, 2004, SINOPEC and Nigeria National Petroleum Company (NNPC) signed an agreement for the exploration of oil in the Chad Basin. The agreement was signed by NNPC Group Managing Director, Funsho Kupolokun, and the VP of SINOPEC at the presidential villa. SINOPEC won the oil exploration contracts for Blocs 64 and 66 in the Chad Basin, following the government's decision to offer 27 oil blocs to investors in order to boost oil production quota 2.6 billion to 4 million barrels per day by 2010. China planned to drill the first barrel of oil from the oil blocs within eight months of signing the agreement. The status of the oil blocs is uncertain.

title: Chinese peacekeeping troops in Liberia (Inactive: see #1552)
description: China began deploy peacekeeping troops to Liberia in early 2004, contributing to a U.N. peacekeeping operation. Since 2004, it appears that China has regularly dispatch peacekeeping forces to Liberia. The sketchy button has been deployed for this project, as state media reports of the number of deployments of Chinese peacekeeping forces clash with those of international media reports. Chinese state media reported that in 2012, China dispatch its 13th deployment of peacekeeping forces to Liberia, were as another 2012 report stated that China was sending its 5th deployment that year.

title: Repairs and Renovations to a SKD Sports Complex
description: 2007年7月3日，中国驻利比里亚大使林松添邀请利副总统兼参议长博阿凯、众议长泰勒、临时参议长尼耶纳博、副众议长穆尔巴等议会参众两院领导层及全体议员集体参观了中国政府援建维修、即将正式交付使用的SKD体育场和庆祝香港回归10周年图片展。利议员、青体部代部长等政府官员和驻利使馆主要外交官以及当地媒体记者等约150人参加。//新华社蒙罗维亚９月２６日电　中国援建的利比里亚首都蒙罗维亚可容纳３·５万人的国家体育场，２６日开始动工重建，总投资７６０万美元。    在开工典礼上，中国驻利比里亚大使林松添说，利比里亚体育场的重建将会有力地“推动爱好体育运动的利比里亚国家的和解、团结和民族尊严，也将进一步加强中利两国间的友谊”。    林松添说，２００３年８月和平条约签署以来，利比里亚发生了重大变化，“在国际社会和联合国的支持下，１４年的内战已经过去，和平重新回到了利比里亚。中国政府将不遗余力地采取特别措施，鼓励中国公司到利比里亚开展互通有无的经贸合作，以求共同发展。”    林松添表示，自从２００３年恢复邦交关系以来，中国对利比里亚开展了体育设施、人力资源开发、农业开发、卫生、道路等多方面的友好合作。    　利比里亚过渡政府首脑布赖恩特对中国的援助十分感谢，他说：“中国的这项工程是‘历史的里程碑’，将进一步加强利中两国的关系。”    据负责重建利比里亚体育场的中国湖南建筑工程集团公司副总裁郑玉柱介绍，整个重建工程将历时一年零八个月，“通过重建，我们不仅要把在战争中遭到破坏的体育场修好，更要把建筑技术传授给利比里亚人”。    利比里亚国家体育场是中国１９８６年援助的项目，经过１４年内战的破坏，已破烂不堪，目前用来安置由于内战而无家可归的难民。  /* Font Definitions */@font-face{font-family:Cambria;panose-1:2 4 5 3 5 4 6 3 2 4;mso-font-charset:0;mso-generic-font-family:auto;mso-font-pitch:variable;mso-font-signature:3 0 0 0 1 0;} /* Style Definitions */p.MsoNormal, li.MsoNormal, div.MsoNormal{mso-style-parent:'';margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt;mso-pagination:widow-orphan;font-size:12.0pt;font-family:'Times New Roman';mso-ascii-font-family:Cambria;mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-fareast-font-family:Cambria;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-hansi-font-family:Cambria;mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-bidi-font-family:'Times New Roman';mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;}@page Section1{size:8.5in 11.0in;margin:1.0in 1.0in 1.0in 1.0in;mso-header-margin:.5in;mso-footer-margin:.5in;mso-paper-source:0;}div.Section1{page:Section1;}-->The Samuel Kanyon Doe (SKD) Complex is a sports complex built in 1986 in Paynesville, Liberia just outside Monrovia. In 2004, the Chinese Embassy and the Liberian Foreign ministry signed an agreement to repair and renovate the sports complex.  The project commenced in September, 2005 and was officially turned over from the People’s Republic of China to the Government of Liberia on July 21, 2007. The renovation project covered the scope of repairing, reprising, upgrading and the additional building of the facilities ranging from studio contraction to digital scoreboard; public address system; core and track; lighting system; fire fighting system; monitoring system and telephone system. Chinese Ambassador Lin Songtian put the total implementation cost to over 9 million United States dollars. However, google search results yielded a total cost of 7.6 million US dollars.  The peoples Republic of China said the stadium was a special Gift from the Chinese Government for Liberia’s 160 Independence anniversary celebration.

title: US$4b loan (duplication with project 1629)
description: In 2006, China's Ex-Im Bank signed on to provide Mauritania with $4 billion USD in loans, while new oil blocks were also set aside for Chinese explorers. It appears that the project was untied.

title: Grant for humanitarian aid (Duplicate)
description: Khartoum, 2 February: President of the Republic Field Marshal Umar al-Bashir and Chinese President Hu Jintao attended at the Friendship Hall in Khartoum Friday [2 February] the signing of seven agreements between the two countries in the various fields of economic and technical cooperation.They included agreement on humanitarian aid to Darfur, a grant from the Chinese government amounting to 40m Yen (4.8m dollars). The two sides also signed a loan agreement for new presidential palace project of some 100m Yen and 90m Yen loan agreement from the old loans extended by China to the government of Sudan. The agreements also included a protocol on pardoning part of Sudan due debts to China amounting to some 470m Yen and 19m dollars. The agreements further included zero-tariff agreement, which is a preferential one covering 44 Sudanese commodities exported to China. The two countries also signed agreement on implementation of two schools in the rural areas in Sudan and another one for establishment of a centre for agricultural technology. Source: Suna news agency website, Khartoum, in English 2 Feb 07
sector: Humanitarian and Disaster Relief and Preparation

title: US$200 million to restore ties (hearsay?)
description: Taiwan's Foreign ministry spokesman Michel Lu alleged that China had offered Senegal up to $200 million USD in aid to restore ties, including an underwater tunnel linking the nation with Gambia. It is likely that this is an accumulation of aid over many years and a rough estimate of total aid granted to Senegal.

title: Chinese supply of equipment to the Ministry of Finance [duplicate of 1511]
description: Among ongoing projects that the Chinese government is currently sponsoring are the reconstruction of the Ofankor-Nsawam dual carriage-way, the construction of the Kumasi Youth Centre, the construction of an office complex for the Ministry of Defence and the supply of equipment to the Ministry of Finance and Economic Planning.Dr Ashong said all those forms of assistance 'clearly demonstrate the Chinese government's commitment to the development efforts of Ghana, especially in improving the vital sectors of the economy'.He expressed the government's gratitude for the assistance and appealed to the Chinese government to consider Ghana's request to it for additional HIPC relief by way of debt stock cancellation of some of the country's outstanding debt.That, the minister said, was to accelerate the country's development agenda by implementing the Ghana Poverty Reduction Strategy (GPRS).Dr Ashong noted that under Positive Change Chapter Two, more resources would be channelled into the social sector to achieve the goals of the GPRS.He said the focus of the GPRS would be on deprived regions such as the Northern, Upper West, Upper East and Central Regions.For his part, the Chinese Ambassador, Mr Zhang, lauded the bilateral co-operation between Ghana and China and expressed the hope that it would be expanded to cover more sectors of the two countries, particularly the area of good governance.He congratulated the government and people of Ghana on the conduct of a peaceful election.Document LQAF000020041220e0ck00041
