title: Ghana signs deal with China for electrification
description: **IS THERE A PROJECT FOR THE $300M??**In 2011, the Ministry of Energy and the Hunan Construction Engineering Group Corporation of China signed a $120 million USD commercial loan agreement for the extension of electricity to 500 communities in the northern region. The sector minister, Dr Joe Oteng-Adjei, signed on behalf of the government of Ghana (GoG) while the general manager of the Overseas Project Department of the group, Mr Yu Guohui, initialled for his organization. The government of Ghana is contributing 18m dollars for the project.Dr Oteng-Adjei said the execution of the project was in fulfilment of a promise President J E A Mills made to the people of the northern region when he visited parts of the area last year on a familiarisation tour.The project, he added, formed part of the 300m dollars to be used to connect about 1400 communities in the Northern, Upper East and Upper West [Northern Ghana] to the national grid.He explained that the move to improve the electricity capacity in the three regions was based on a recent assessment carried out by the ministry, which revealed that those areas fell below the national average. [Passage omitted]To that end, Dr Oteng-Adjei stated that the government had resolved to raise the electricity accessibility rates of those region to that of the national average in line with the policy of the national electrification programme which was aimed at extending electricity to all parts of the country by the year 2020.Mr Guohui, for his part, pledged the commitment of his outfit to execute the project to the expectation of the government. [Passage omitted]Source: Daily Graphic, Accra, in English 20 Jan 11ad3ce555Document BBCAP00020110120e71k001jn
donor_agency_count: Hunan Construction Engineering Group Corporation of China, State-Owned Company
verified: Ghana Ministry of Energy, Government Agency

title: $18 million in favorable loans for assembly lines (check with ID1953)
description: XIAMEN, October 14, SinoCast -- A midsize bus assembly line built by Xiamen Kinglong United Automotive Industry Co., Ltd. for Senegal started production in Thies, a western city in the country, on October 13, 2009.Chinese President Hu Jintao inked an agreement on the project in February during his visit to Senegal, part of China's effort to help West African countries in their development of the traffic and transportation industries. The Export-Import Bank of China (China Eximbank) provided favorable loans for the assembly line, which had a total investment of USD 18 million.Actually, in February, Senegal placed an order for 406 city buses from Kinglong. Four of them were ordered in the form of complete cars while the other exported to the country in complete knock down (CKD).In recent years, Kinglong extended reach from Southeast Asia and Middle East to Europe, South America and Africa. It exports both complete cars and components to countries in the above regions.
donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency

title: China to provide Zambia with 3.6m dollars in aid [signed in 1999, not a project]
description: China to provide Zambia with 3.6m dollars in aid.206 words5 January 2000BBC Monitoring Service: Asia-PacificBBCFEEnglish(c) 2000 The British Broadcasting Corporation [date of publication]. All Rights Reserved. No material may be reproduced except with the express permission of The British Broadcasting Corporation.Source: Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in English 1507 gmt 29 Dec 99Text of report in English by official Chinese news agency Xinhua (New China News Agency)Lusaka, 29th December: The Chinese government will provide Zambia with 30m renminbi (about 3.62m US dollars) aid without any conditions according to an agreement signed here on Wednesday [29th December].According to the agreement signed by Chinese Ambassador Peng Keyu and Zambian Finance Minister Katele Kalumba their respective governments, the money will be channelled to the interior decoration of Zambia's new government complex for most of the government ministries.At the signing ceremony, the Chinese ambassador said the assistance from China does not attach any conditions.'We are making more and more efforts on promoting bilateral economic cooperation in all areas between our two countries by exploring the great economic potentials in trade and investment,' Peng said.On his part, Kalumba expressed profound gratitude to China for providing various types of assistance to his country.The minister appreciated the long and fruitful relations between the two countries and expressed his hope that this cooperation will continue in the new century.(c) BBC Monitoring Summary of World Broadcasts.

title: Construction of a Qarre I power station (Duplicate)
description: On November 16, 2000, the Sudanese Energy Minister Awad Ahmed al-Jaz and the Harbin Electricity Company signed an agreement for the Chinese company to build a 212 megawatt gas-fired power station 45 kilometers north of Khartoum at the cost of 149 million USD. China's central bank agreed to finance the construction of the power plant. China's Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing and Sudanese Electricity Minister Ali Temim Fertak inaugurated the Qarre I plant on January 5, 2004. The terms of the loan and the start date are unknown.

title: Second Anti-malarial drugs (Inactive: Duplicate #13947)
description: 25 June 2008 02:02 PMBBC Monitoring Africa BBCAP English (c) 2008 The British Broadcasting Corporation. All Rights Reserved. No material may be reproduced except with the express permission of The British Broadcasting Corporation. Excerpt from report by state-owned Radio Togo on 25 June[Presenter] The Togolese government has benefited from an important batch of anti-malarial drugs. The handing over of the donation took place at took place yesterday, Tuesday at the place at the centre for the purchase of patented and generic drugs in Lome. The donation is made up of oral and injectable drugs especially against malaria and valued at over 33m CFA francs [approximately 80,000 dollars]. [Passage omitted]The Chinese ambassador in Togo, Mr Yang Min, presented the drug to the minister of state, minister of health, Charles Kondi Agba.[Min] I am very happy to present to the Togolese Ministry of Health anti-malarial drugs. These drugs are being offered freely by the government of the People's Republic of Chine to the government of the Togolese Republic. In fact, this is the second batch of drugs that China that China has offered to Togo, according the measures proclaimed by the Chinese government during the Beijing summit, during the forum on the Sino-African cooperation in November 2006. And it is with the aim of reinforcing cooperation between China and Africa. These drugs can help the people of Togo to fight malaria.Source: Radio Togo, Lome, in French 0600 gmt 25 Jun 08

title: china donates 4,500 metric tons of non-GMO yellow maize to Zambia (duplicate)
description: China donates fertilizer, maize to Zambia.253 words16 September 2003Xinhua News AgencyXNEWSEnglish(c) Copyright 2003 Xinhua News AgencyLUSAKA, Sept. 16 (Xinhua) - The Chinese government has donated 7,780 metric tons of fertilizer valued at 20 million RMB Yuan ( about 2.5 million US dollars) and 4,500 metric tons of non-GMO yellow maize to Zambia.While officiating at the handover ceremony held here Tuesday, Zambian Agriculture and Cooperatives Minister Mundia Sikatana said he is grateful for the assistance the Chinese government has continued to render to Zambia and in particular in the development of the agricultural sector.Sikatana said the donation has not only come at the right time but that it will assist Zambia in expanding coverage in terms of input support and in assisting the country's vulnerable households access food.'The fertilizer we are receiving today will supplement government efforts in reaching out to many of our small scale farmers,' he said.'The food we are receiving today will add value to the nutritional status of our people particularly, in those areas prone to disasters,' he added.    Sikatana reaffirmed the Zambian government's commitment to thecontinued good relations with China.   Chinese Ambassador to Zambia Peng Keyu said the consignment ofmaterials is provided by the Chinese government to promote theagricultural development of Zambia.   Peng said the donation deeply expresses the friendly feelingsof the Chinese government and people to the Zambian government andpeople.   He hoped the two countries can further strengthen the bilateraleconomic cooperation and make new contribution to the commoninterests of the two peoples.  Document XNEWS00020030916dz9g001e4

title: China donates raincoats to Zambia police [duplicate]
description: China donates raincoats and computers to Zambia police.198 words11 September 2003Xinhua News AgencyXNEWSEnglish(c) Copyright 2003 Xinhua News AgencyLUSAKA, Sept. 11 (Xinhua) - The Chinese government has donated 1,000 raincoats and 10 sets of computers and printers to Zambia Police Service.Zambian Inspector General of Police Zunga Siakalima said at the handover ceremony held here Thursday that the raincoats could not have come at a better time than now when the rain season is just around the corner.    He thanks the Chinese government for its all-weather friendshipto Zambia.   Siakalima said the Zambia Police Service has embarked on a  program of computerization of its stations, units and sections. So he believed the donation of computers and printers will undoubtedly go a long way in complementing this program.Chinese Ambassador to Zambia Peng Keyu said the police plays a significant role in any country, in maintaining social security and stability, which is of crucial importance in the development of national economy.    Peng said it is not possible to expect any economic developmentwithout a safe and stable social environment.   He strongly believed it is the continuous efforts of the ZambiaPolice that make this beautiful country a safe place forforeigners to live in, to work and invest.

title: 1 Billion Dollar Railway (Duplicate 2278)
description: '1428 words5 September 2008Middle East Economic DigestMEEDEnglish© 2008, Emap Communications. All rights reservedWith the cost of air travel soaring, Cairo, Tripoli and Algiers are finally taking steps to overhaul their dilapidated railway infrastructure after years of underinvestmentHugh TomlinsonUnlike Saudi Arabia, where three huge projects are set to give much of the kingdom a rail connection for the first time since the Hejaz railway at the beginning of the 20th century, North Africa has a legacy of rail from colonial times.However, much of that legacy has been squandered over the subsequent decades of underinvestment, to the point where national rail networks have largely fallen into disrepair or been abandoned completely.The region’s governments have now woken up to the fact that without functioning passenger and freight links around the country, their national rail infrastructure network is in danger of being permanently consigned to history. The high cost of air travel means it is out of reach for many, and fares are rising as fuel prices soar. Rail investment is back in the spotlight.Morocco already has good rail infrastructure, and its programme to upgrade its existing network to provide high-speed links between the kingdom’s major cities will bring the network up to the best of modern standards. Tunisia too boasts impressive road and rail links between its main cities, and the small size of the country makes further upgrades relatively straight-forward, so long as there is money to invest.But in the larger states that lie between the two countries, it is a different story. The old rail networks in Libya and Algeria have fallen into disuse, while Egypt’s 5,000-kilometre network is poorly maintained and has a poor safety record.Rebuilding plansAll three countries are now trying to turn the situation around. In February, Russian Railways was awarded a contract to build a modern rail transport hub in the Algerian capital Algiers. The project covers the rebuilding and upgrading of 14 suburban stations, the dismantling of 58.5km of existing tracks and laying about 95km of new line, the electrification of 52km of track, and associated works including a 38km telecommunications system and the construction of a modern rail control centre.Libya, which has had no railway in operation since 1965 after the old narrow-gauge system fell apart in the years following the Second World War, is now capitalising on its substantial oil wealth to build a multi-billion-dollar network from the roots up.'We have no rail in Libya, not even one metre,' says one official at the government’s Railway Executive Board (REB). 'We need new railways to develop the economy of the country.'Libya’s readmission into the international community has prompted a new impetus to improve the country’s tourism infrastructure. There are plans for a railway running the entire length of Libya’s Mediterranean coast, from Tunisia to the Egyptian border.This year alone, it has taken several huge steps forward. Earlier this year, China Railway Construction (CRC) and Russian Railways were awarded the two construction packages on the $4bn high-speed rail project along Libya’s Mediterranean coast. The Chinese will build a double-track, high-speed line between Khoms and Sirte, while the Russian firm will continue the line to the country’s second city, Benghazi.CRC will also build a $1bn, 800km minerals railway running north to south between the mines near Sebha and Misurata on the coast. Once the line is complete, products will be transported rapidly and in bulk. As with the North-South railway in Saudi Arabia, the line should dramatically increase the speed and capacity of the country’s minerals export business.Improving tradeThe new network 'will improve trade links to Tunisia and Egypt and the minerals railway will improve industry in the country,' says the REB official. 'We want to bring more tourists to the country and the railway from Tripoli to Benghazi means they can travel along the coast.'The proposed extension of the high-speed track from Khoms to the capital is still in the design phase, but the REB says it hopes to issue a construction tender for this package by the end of the year. With France’s Aeroports de Paris starting work on a $1.3bn refit of Tripoli International airport, Libya is at last building an integrated transport system to support the country’s embryonic economic redevelopment and diversification plans.However, questions remain over whether Libya has sufficient engineering expertise within the country to plan and roll out this network. 'Libya, like the Gulf, has a lot of money at the moment,' says an official at one Western contractor closely involved in the North African market. 'What it has not got is the level of expertise to deliver on projects of that kind at the moment.'However, there are factors that work in Libya’s favour. 'Tripoli to Benghazi is mostly flat stony desert, so it should be fairly easy to deliver,' says the contractor. 'If they hand these projects over to foreign contractors on a turnkey basis, it is possible they could bring that expertise in.'The REB is aware of its skills shortage and has issued a tender to find an international consultant to supervise construction on each of the rail packages under way. The companies appointed will work alongside Germany’s De-Consult, which has been working closely with REB for the past four years.'We would like to bring in three consultants, one for each project: Khoms to Sirte, Sirte to Benghazi and Sebha to Misurata,' says the official.Sourcing financeThe REB hopes to appoint a separate consultant for each of the three sections of the rail project by early November. Another tender was issued in early August for the design of a 450km, high-speed line between Benghazi and Tobruk, close to the Egyptian border, which is likely to cost close to $2bn.Unlike the billions being spent across the border in Libya, Cairo has chosen to renovate existing lines rather than build new ones. However, the £E5bn ($932m) budget for this is unrealistic at a time when the cost of delivering major infrastructure projects is rising worldwide. In a sign of the times, a recent tender to overhaul the 1,300 level crossings along the Egyptian rail network is to be retendered after the bids came in substantially over budget.'The infrastructure in Egypt is in a very poor state,' says one source close to the bidding process. 'There is old equipment in use on the commuter lines and safety issues everywhere. There are 1,300 official crossings, but certainly many more than that. Egypt has a densely populated countryside down the Nile. This means you have farm traffic crossing all over the place. The cost of upgrading this is going to be huge.'Egyptian Railways (ER) and the Transport Ministry are looking around for new sources of revenue. World Bank funding of £E500m is being sought for work on the country’s signalling systems, and ER is planning to offer packages of railway stations for privatisation. A contractor buying them will be able to build commercial facilities on the surrounding land in exchange for redeveloping the stations themselves, an approach used with limited success on the Tehran Metro.There has also been talk of new, privately financed lines, including a high-speed link between Cairo and Alexandria, and one from Cairo to the Red Sea, but investors have so far shown little appetite for the proposals. Plans for a new £E3.5bn railway between Obour City and 10th of Ramadan City appear to have stalled while ER reviews the financing of the project.'The issue is how to make it attractive to investors,' says the source. 'Can they rely on traffic volumes? If they rely on the Egyptian public, they cannot raise fares high enough.'A further problem the government faces is how to develop and retain staff of sufficient quality throughout the network.'Egypt Rail employs about 80,000 staff, and drivers are only earning about $100 a month,' says the source. 'The ministry needs to raise salaries, but is faced with the same problem as in other areas: how to slim the workforce at a time when unemployment is already high, to increase the wages of those critical staff.'Algeria, Libya and Egypt will all face substantial challenges in the years ahead as they endeavour to revamp rail networks that have fallen into varying degrees of disuse and disrepair. But each has taken the first step along the way.Document MEED000020080908e4950000x''600 words3 March 2011China Daily - Hong Kong EditionCHNDHK2EnglishCopyright 2011 China Daily Information Company. All rights reserved.Chong Hing net income jumpsChong Hing Bank Ltd more than doubled full-year net income to HK$476 million, according to a statement to the Hong Kong Stock Exchange from the company Wednesday.Dragonair to boost mainland flightsCathay Pacific Airways Ltd's Hong Kong Dragon Airlines Ltd unit will increase flights to Taiwan and mainland cities on rising travel demand.The carrier will increase services to Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan to six flights a day from March 27, Dragonair said in an e-mailed statement Wednesday. On the mainland, Xiamen services will rise to four a day and Ningbo flights will increase to 10 a week, it said. The airline will also boost capacity or flights to Nanjing, Chengdu, Chongqing and Hangzhou.Hang Seng CEO: US rates to remain lowHang Seng Bank Ltd Chief Executive Officer Margaret Leung said US interest rates are likely to remain low this year, and that will keep rates down in Hong Kong as well.It's 'difficult' to say if there's a property bubble in Hong Kong, she said in an interview with Bloomberg TV Wednesday. Property prices have gone up 'a lot', she said.China Railway Libya projects suspendedChina Railway, the country's biggest railroad builder, said it was suspending its three projects in Libya as it evacuates workers due to escalating violence in the African nation.The total contract value of the three rail projects is $4.24 billion, of which $3.55 billion worth of construction has not been completed, the firm said on Tuesday.The contract value of the uncompleted work in Libya accounts for 2.3 percent of its overall portfolio of unfinished jobs. The firm won bids in 2008 to build a 352-kilometer west-to-east coastal railway and a south-to-west railway that would facilitate the transportation of iron ore from the southern city Sebha to Misurata.Its third project is a 172-kilometer railway that extends from Tripoli, Libya's capital, to the key Ras Jedeir port in the west, the firm said.Eergrande predicts net income riseEergrande Real Estate Group Ltd's net income for the year ended Dec 31 may have a 'significant increase' from a year earlier, the company said in a statement to the Hong Kong Stock Exchange Wednesday, without giving details.Shimao to issue $350m notesShimao Property Holdings Ltd said on Wednesday it would issue $350 million senior notes due 2018, raising capital to finance redemption of a floating rate note and to repay other debt.In a filing with the Hong Kong bourse, the Chinese property developer said proceeds would also be used to finance existing and new property development projects, and to enhance liquidity.The notes will carry an interest rate of 11 percent per annum payable semi-annually. Morgan Stanley and Standard Chartered Bank are handling the issue.Speculation 'closely' monitored: HKMAThe Hong Kong Monetary Authority is monitoring speculation in the housing market 'ery closely', deeming asset-price increases the biggest threat to the city's economy, Deputy Chief Executive Eddie Yue said.The authority and the government are reviewing policy 'regularly' after stepping up efforts to curb housing prices that have risen more than 60 percent since the start of 2009, Yue said Wednesday in an interview at a conference in New York. Housing rentals make up 26 percent of the local consumer price index, which gained 3.6 percent in January. The government forecasts consumer prices will increase 4.5 percent in 2011, up from 2.4 percent last year.Bloomberg - ReuterDocument CHNDHK0020110302e7330005l© 2012 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.

title: Zambia reaffirms friendship with China after fatal accident (duplicate)
description: Zambia reaffirms friendship with China after fatal accident351 words24 April 2005Xinhua News AgencyXNEWSEnglish(c) Copyright 2005 Xinhua News AgencyKITWE, Zambia, April 24 (Xinhua) -- The fatal accident Wednesday at a Chinese-owned industrial explosive plant in Zambia' s Copperbelt province won't affect the traditional friendship and cooperation between Zambia and China, Zambian President Levy Mwanawasa said Sunday.The president made the remarks in Copperbelt province capital Ndola while meeting a Chinese government delegation that arrived in Zambia Saturday to convey the condolence of the Chinese government and people to the families and relatives of those killed or injured in the blast at BGRIMM Explosive (Zambia) Ltd., Kalulushi city, which killed 46 people and injured two others.President Mwanawasa thanked the Chinese government for sending the senior delegation headed by assistant commerce minister Chen Jian.China has shown its concern and sympathy to the unfortunate accident. Zambian people appreciate and is encouraged by the visit of the delegation, he said.He also thanked the Chinese government for offering an emergency aid of 500,000 US dollars in cash in addition to material assistance including food and blankets after the accident and for providing various support and assistance to Zambia over the years.China's assistance commerce minister Chen Jian conveyed the condolence to the victims of the accident and their families on behalf of Chinese President Hu Jintao, the Chinese government and people.China greatly regrets the heavy loss of people in the accident and is willing to provide any technical assistance to find out the cause of the accident, he said.Chen said relations between China and Zambia have stood the test of time and difficult situations, and that China is ready to work together with Zambia to further promote friendly cooperation between the two countries.After the meeting in Ndola, President Mwanawasa and Chen Jian inspected the accident site and met with families of the deceased at a local school.The Chinese delegation also paid a visit to one of the injured persons at the China-Zambia Friendship Hospital in Kitwe.C. Bwalya, 24, is one of the two persons injured in the accident. The other one has been discharged.Document XNEWS00020050424e14o006pq
sector: Humanitarian and Disaster Relief and Preparation

title: Not bilateral: Small hydropower plant on the Bankasoka River
description: Under an agreement signed in Beijing yesterday by UNIDO Director-General Kandeh K. Yumkella and Chen Huan, Deputy Director-General of the China CDM Fund Management Centre, the two bodies will implement schemes – including transitioning to a low-carbon economy and expanding the transfer of adoption and technology – over the next three years.The CDM allows industrialized countries to generate credits through investment in emission reduction projects in developing countries.Also yesterday, Mr. Yumkella entered into an agreement with Chinese and Sierra Leonean officials to build a small hydropower plant on the Bankasoka River in the West African nation, with construction slated to begin next month and be completed by the end of 2009.The project hopes to pave the way for further trilateral cooperation under UNIDO’s Lighting-up of Rural Africa initiative, which aims to reverse the lack of access, low purchasing power and over-dependence on traditional fuels currently characterizing the continent’s energy situation.No 7 2008 2:10PMendsNR.20081109141143.99886@scoop.co.nz | 200811091411.e5669434Document SCCONZ0020081109e4b900007'中国援塞拉利昂坡特洛科小水电站项目施工合同在弗里敦签署　12月20日，我援塞拉利昂坡特洛科小水电站项目施工合同签字仪式在中国驻塞使馆经商处举行。塞能源部部长戴维森和湖南建工驻塞负责人周剑波，分别代表中、塞双方在施工合同上签字，中国驻塞使馆经商处刘玉林参赞等中国外交官和塞能源部部分官员十余人参加了签字仪式。　　戴维森部长在讲话中对中国政府向塞提供的大力援助表示感谢，高度赞扬中国政府和人民对塞国民经济发展的推动作用，希望中塞双方紧密合作，推动该水电站项目尽早开工。刘玉林参赞表示，中国政府愿继续在基础设施建设方面向塞提供力所能及的帮助，推进中塞两国在贸易、承包、投资等领域的合作。　　该项目建设场址位于塞北方省坡特洛科地区，总装机容量为2000千瓦，新建溢流坝、挡水土坝、溢洪道、输水系统和发电厂房，输变电线路全长1.6公里，工期26个月。该项目建成后，将增加塞发电能力，改善坡特洛科地区的供电状况。

title: Magbass Sugar Complex [1980s]
description: Another project the Chinese are revisiting is the Megabass Sugar Complex - the country's only sugar-producing enterprise. China helped to establish the facility, which consists of a sugar-cane farm and mill, in the 1980s and it produced a yearly output of about 6,000 tonnes a year.In January 2003, a lease contract was signed between the government and the Chinese National Complete Plant Import and Export Corporation and production is expected to start again this year.There is also long-standing and increasing interest in other areas of agriculture, such as rice technology where Sierra Leone is making progress toward meeting food production targets. In fisheries too China has a historic presence, two companies having signed contracts of mutual benefit in the mid-80s. China also cites a tractor assembly factory at a former brick works in the east of the capital as one of its big investments.But the real focus of interest is this month's opening of a trade zone in the area of the former National Workshop in the eastern Cline Town district of Freetown. The scheme has involved the specialised refurbishment of a transport depot and metal workshop by China's Henan Guoji.Fifteen or more Chinese companies are eventually to occupy the site. A number already do with activities as diverse as the manufacture of building materials, pharmaceuticals, mattress-making and garage diagnostics.However, Henan Guoji's next project, a Dollars 266m scheme to revitalise the ocean-front of Freetown's Lumley beach area is possibly the most ambitious and certainly largest development project so far planned for the country.An agreement signed with the national tourist board in May 2004 outlines a plan to build a 250-bed luxury hotel complex and conference centre, holiday apartments, town houses and a promenade. Plans in the pipeline also include the building of a mini sports stadium in the southern provincial capital of Bo.The relative boldness of China to jump in where other countries fear to tread has puzzled some commentators, not least in Sierra Leone itself, and has been the subject of speculation over a possible long-term strategic interest in oil.However, the Chinese themselves and government ministers point to a number of factors. Chief among these are the long-standing ties between the two governments, aided by the willingness of Sierra Leone to help China return from the diplomatic wilderness three decades ago. 'Bilateral relations are very good,' says Zhao Zhongqui, the Chinese embassy's economic and commercial counsellor. 'Sierra Leone helped China re-enter the United Nations in the 1970s and the Chinese people will never forget friends like these. They have supported us on many important issues,' he says.Such a relationship seems to provide the bedrock of Chinese investment with all activity appearing to be coordinated at governmental level and facilitated by an series of high-level diplomatic and trade missions. But there is also a sense of a shared understanding of developmental issues, which other countries may lack.Mr Zhongqui adds: 'Both have been developing countries, and now we are helping Sierra Leone to develop quickly to maximise prosperity. Thirty years ago China's gross domestic product per capita was lower than Sierra Leone's is now, so we understand the issues.'Of course Chinese investment does not arise purely out of political and altruistic motivation. Although much of the investment is characterised by Sierra Leoneans as high risk, there appear to be a number of factors at play. The Chinese are clearly taking advantage of a low cost base in terms of cheap basic labour and the low cost of many raw materials. This sometimes has to be weighed against the added cost of Sierra Leone's much publicised infrastructure problems.Perhaps most importantly, the Chinese appear to have a definite 'first in' approach to the different sectors in which they are interested, which has been used to leverage coveted special inducements from the government. Such an approach, combined with similar initiatives in other West African countries, allows Chinese companies an early domination of fledgling domestic and regional markets as well as certain competitive advantages on the wider international stage.'Government policy was very encouraging. We found companies at an early stage were given very preferential policies. The early bird catches the worm.'While Chinese investment is broadly welcomed in Sierra Leone, there are some reservations about the special incentives awarded Chinese companies as well as the limited training of indigenous workers and the extent to which the Chinese might be using the country as a dumping ground for cheap goods.Chris Jasabe, managing director of the Sierra Leone Export Development and Investment Corporation is one of those with concerns. 'All investors should be treated the same,' he says. The problem is that investors come in and take risks and demand concessions that might not be applicable. Then everyone else starts asking for them. We are trying to put a stop to this.' The greatest downside is Sierra Leone's reliance upon Chinese investment and what happens if renewed instability prompts a complete withdrawal.20050214S506.234Document FTFT000020050214e12e0005j'
recipient_agencies: China National Complete Plant Import & Export Co., Ltd., State-Owned Company

title: NOT a project (multilateral): donation from the Chinese government to the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) program in Somalia
description: >NAIROBI, April 1 (Xinhua) - A donation from the Chinese government to the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) program in Somalia is making a significant contribution to assisting disadvantaged communities and improving the lives of children and women in the African country, the UNICEF said here Thursday.>> >>China donated gift of items, including mosquito nets, blankets and cooking pots to the UNICEF program in July 2003, is worth about 121,918 US dollars.>> >>During a hand-over ceremony held in Kenya's capital Nairobi on Thursday, Jesper Morch, the UNICEF Somalia representative, paid tribute to the generosity of China in responding the expressed needs of vulnerable population in Somalia.>> >>'The support that the international community continues to direct in humanitarian relief operations in Somalia is helping to alleviate the circumstances of children and women living in some of the most harsh and desperate conditions in the world,' Morch said.>> >>Chinese Ambassador to Kenya Guo Chongli said at the ceremony, ' It's our sincere hope that the donated materials can be of help in reducing the Somali people's sufferings.'>> >>'As a permanent member of the Security Council of the United Nations, China is in full support of work done by the United Nations. The Chinese government is willing to continue to play its part in promotion of peace in Somalia,' Guo added.>> >>The donated items have been distributed within Somalia for use at health centers and when emergency relief measures are being put in place, the Nairobi-based UNICEF Somalia Support Center said.>> >> >>   Somalia dissolved into chaos after the 1991 ousting of>>strongman Mohammed Siad Barre.>>   The transitional national government, set up in 2000, controls>>only part of the capital and parts of the rest of the country.>>   In February 2004, Somali faction leaders and the Transitional>>National Government signed an agreement to establish a new>>national parliament that in turn will elect a president in the war->>torn country.>>  >> >>Document XNEWS00020040407e0410018t'>
sector: Humanitarian and Disaster Relief and Preparation
donor_agency_count: United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), Multilateral

title: China-invested copper leach plant officially launched in Zambia (possible update)
description: China-invested copper leach plant officially launched in Zambia363 words8 September 2006Xinhua News AgencyXNEWSEnglish(c) Copyright 2006 Xinhua News Agency KITWE (Zambia), Sept. 8 (Xinhua) -- Zambian President Levy Mwanawasa officially commissioned on Friday a copper leach plant, Sino-Metals Leach Zambia, which is capable of producing 8,000 tons of copper cathodes per annum. The leach plant, owned by three Chinese companies led by China Nonferrous Mining Corporation (CNMC), has a total investment of 15 million U.S. dollars. In his keynote address, President Mwanawasa said the launch of the plant marked another step in the long journey of friendship between Zambia and China. State-owned CNMC has invested a total of 160 million dollars since it launched three years ago the operation of the Chambishi Mine which is located in Kitwe, 400 km north of Lusaka, in the copper-rich Copperbelt province. The mine has created more than 2,000 job opportunities for the local people, said CNMC vice president Zhu Yiwu. The new leach plant, together with a acid plant which is scheduled to be put into operation later this month, will add another 300 job opportunities for local people, Zhu said. The acid plant, the Sino-Acid Products Zambia, has an investment of 5 million dollars and is capable of producing 40,000 tons of acid annually which will be supplied to the leach plant in close vicinity. Moreover, CNMC will further pump 200 million dollars into the mine to set up a copper smelter plant so as to add value to the locally excavated mine ores through downstream processing. According to Chinese Ambassador to Zambia Li Baodong, China is planning to invest more to construct a nonferrous industrial zone in Kitwe which will create tens of thousands of more employment opportunities. Li said China and Zambia have established tight relations of economic cooperation in recent years owing to the long friendship shared between the two countries. So far, more than 180 Chinese companies have invested in Zambia with a total investment of more than 300 million dollars and over 10,000 Zambians are working with these Chinese companies, Li added. China has become the third largest investor in Zambia after South Africa and Britain, according to the Zambia Investment Center. Document XNEWS00020060908e2980070t
donor_agency_count: China Nonferrous Metal Mining (Group) Co., Ltd. (CNMC), State-Owned Company

title: Chinese investment in smelter at Chambishi (duplicate #156)
description: In November of 2006, state-owned China Nonferrous Metal Mining Co. Ltd. signed an MoU with the Zambian government to establish a 150,000mt/year of crude copper smelting plant at the Chambishi mine in Zambia. The signing ceremony was in the presence of President Levy Patrick Mwanawasa, Chinese Ambassador to Zambia Li Baodong, and Zambian Ambassador to China David Saviye. CNMC will invest $220 million USD at the Chambishi Mine in Zambia. Zambian Minister of Foreign Affairs Mundia Sikatana signed the MoU and welcomed the investment of Chinese companies. The smelter will be put into operation at the end of 2008. The project appears to be tied.

title: US$400 million to expand power station
description: In 2007, Chinese company Sino Hydro agreed to spend $400 million to expand the Kariba North bank power station. 85% of this will be provided by Exim Bank of China. Sino Hydro will install two generators with a total capacity of 360 mW of power, increasing the capacity of the station. Zesco, state-owned power company will provide 15% of the expansion budget. As of 2011, the project costs $430 million USD and hopes are that the project will be completed by December 31, 2011. However, the project hit a snag regarding the water levels near the dam. The project is to be continued. title: TAZARA - TAZARA Wagons Deal (Duplicate of 845）
description: Chinese Firm Secures U.S.$5 Million Tazara Wagons Dealby Mike Mande435 words19 October 201009:56 AMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2010 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedNairobi, Oct 19, 2010 (The East African/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- A Chinese firm has secured a $5 million contract to build 90 wagons for the regional Tanzania-Zambia Railway Authority (Tazara).The Chinese Civil Engineering and Construction Company (CCECC) will secure the 50-tonne container open wagons, assisted by China South Locomotive and Rolling Stock Corporation and Meishan Company, a subsidiary of CCECC. The open wagons will be delivered in eight months.Akashambatwa Mbikusita-Lewanika, managing director of Tazara, said last week that these type of wagons are used in transporting containerised cargo and metals such as copper and manganese.Mr Mbikusita-Lewanika said Tazara urgently needs various equipment to turn it around.'These developments will complement Tazara's efforts to meet customer expectations in the delivery of quality transport services,' he said.The $5 million is part of a $40 million loan that the Chinese Government granted Tazara, through the governments of Tanzania and Zambia, under the 14th Protocol in December 2009.The signing of the supply contract follows the arrival last week of technical experts from China to assess and repair loading equipment, as part of the implementation of the 14th Protocol Agreement.Other components of the Protocol that are expected to follow include the supply of six new mainline locomotives, rehabilitation of three shunting locomotives and training of staff.Conrad Simuchile, public relations manager of Tazara, said the wagons will move cargo from the port southwards. That way, wagons earmarked for picking up copper exports from Zambia and cement from Mbeya will not be empty while travelling from the port of Dar es Salaam.To match the tonnage being transported to Dar, Tazara is looking for up to 200 containers per week to Mbeya and Kapiri-Mposhi.Currently, Tazara can move up to 100 containers to Mbeya and 100 to Kapiri-Mposhi every week. It can also transport the same volume to Dar es Salaam.Tazara is this year targeting to move 700,000 tonnes of freight and 900,000 tonnes of passenger traffic.In July this year, Tanzania, Zambia and China signed a $39.2 million (Tsh 51 billion) deal to enable Tazara to acquire six new locomotives and repair 1,200 coaches.The grant has not been fully settled. The Chinese government is said to have offered a discount on the loan, besides cancelling unspecified outstanding debt.The railway line was built between 1970 and 1975 by Tazara to serve landlocked Zambia as an alternative to rail lines via Zimbabwe, South Africa and Mozambique.Document AFNWS00020101019e6aj0016w
donor_agency_count: China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation (CCECC), State-Owned Company; Tanzania-Zambia Railway Authority (TAZARA), State-Owned Company

title: Tazara railway (duplicate of 845)
description: Chinese Government To Lend Tanzania-Zambia Railway $39M -Paper164 words31 December 200907:39 AMDow Jones Commodities ServiceDJCSEnglish(c) 2009 Dow Jones   Company, Inc.NAIROBI (Dow Jones)--The Chinese government is set to lend $39 million to the Tanzania-Zambia railway, known as Tazara, as part of a strategy to bail out the jointly owned railway line, The Guardian newspaper reported Thursday citing Tanzania's infrastructure development minister''China spent about $500 million to build Tazara's infrastructure in the 1970s, so it has agreed to extend the loan rehabilitate it,' the daily quotes Shukuru Kawambwa as saying.Kawambwa was among six ministers from Tanzania and Zambia who went to China last week for talks with the Chinese government on ways to save Tazara from total collapse, the Tanzanian independent daily says.The line is used to transport such metals as copper and gold from mainland Tanzania and Zambia to the Indian Ocean port of Dar es Salaam.-By George Mwangi, contributing to Dow Jones Newswires; +254 735 781 853; gmwangi0@gmail.com [ 12-31-09 0739ET ]Document DJCS000020091231e5c0006g

title: Telimele bauxite prospecting- duplicate with 2357
description: Chinese Lobbying Pays Off328 words7 March 2007Africa Mining IntelligenceAMIN151EnglishCopyright 2007 Indigo Publications All Rights ReservedChina’s projects to mine bauxite have hardened up in Guinea, a country rocked in recent weeks by a general strike. style='BACKGROUND-COLOR:#FFFF00'>The China Exim Bank, which has committed itself to a plan to build a hydropower complex at Souapiti, won a bauxite prospecting license from the government. It concerns the former Telimele concession which was awarded to the Greek concern 3PL Trade SA on March 12, 2005 but was cancelled last No. 24 because no work had been done on it. style='BACKGROUND-COLOR:#FFFF00'>Located near the coast, the concession is also close to the future hydropower dam which is to be built by Sinohydro. In addition, the site could finally house an aluminum smelter, which is on China’s drawing board at present. The permit was awarded following a strong lobbying push on China’s part. Li Ruogu, managing director of Exim Bank, was in Conakry last October with experts from Sinohydro to examine details of the future dam which is to cost an estimated USD 1 billion.Previously, the China Aluminum Group (Chalco), which had briefly been interested in buying the alumina refinery at Friguia, said it wanted to take part in upgrading Guinea’s natural resources. In November, 2005, Chalco was awarded 21 bauxite prospecting licenses that cover a total of 10,488 sq km. and lie between the regions of Kindia, Mamou, Dalaba and Mali. Similarly in November, 2005, the deputy Chinese prime minister Jung Ju, who had turned up in Guinea, told prime minister Cellou Dalein Diallo he was doing his “utmost” to see that China helped Guinea in making the most of its mining resources. According to our sources, Beijing launched its lobbying campaign in the sector after several vain attempts to buy surplus production from the Compagnie des Bauxites de Guinee (Alcan/Alcoa) for its plants in China. After being brushed off by CBG, the Chinese began talks with Compagnie des Bauxites de Kindia (CBK) owned by Rusal.26856503Document AMIN000020070326e33700001
recipient_agencies: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency

title: ZTE wins bid for sake in Niger state telecom company (Duplicate of 122)
description: 'NIAMEY, No 8 (Reuters) - Chinese telecoms firm ZTE Corp made the highest offer for a majority stake in Niger's state telecoms company, Sonitel, outbidding rival France Telecom , the economy ministry said on Thursday.According to the national commission at the ministry charged with analysing the offers, ZTE bid 11.8 billion CFA francs ($16.1 million) while a consortium made up of France Telecom and Senegal's Sonatel offered 6.5 billion francs.Niger relaunched the privatisation procedure for Sonitel in September, nine months after a previous sale fell through when it failed to attract bids. Privatisation Minister Trapside Fatima said Niger would keep 34 percent after the privatisation.The landlocked former French colony, the biggest country in West Africa, has a population of 10 million.Sonitel's fixed-line network capacity is 25,000 lines. Niger said last year it wanted to boost that number to 77,000 by 2010.Shenzhen-based ZTE Corp is run by the state and is China's largest listed telecoms manufacturer. It has expanded overseas by exporting networking products, setting up joint ventures and investing in local communication operations.Earlier this year, ZTE won a tender to convert Sonitel's mobile arm to the GSM standard, making it the third mobile operator with a GSM licence along with Telecel and Celtel.The Chinese company is now set to take a 51 percent stake in both Sonitel and its mobile arm, Sahel Com, through reserved capital increases. Sonitel is currently 98 percent owned by the state and employs 1,300 people. ' 'With a $16.1m offer, Chinese telecoms firm ZTEhas won the bidding war for a majority stake in Niger's state telecoms company, Sonitel, outbidding its rival bid from the France Telecom and Senegal's Sonatel who offered just $8.86m. Previously, in August, ZTE also won a contract to convert Sonitel's mobile arm to the GSM standard, making it the third mobile operator with a GSM licence along with Telecel and Celtel.The Shenzen-based and state owned ZTE is China'slargest listed telecoms manufacturer and has embarked on an aggressive programme of expansion in developing markets by exporting networking products, establishing joint-entures and investing in local communication operations.'The African market will be our next business hub,' Li Taifong, ZTE chairman said in October last year, highlighting the opportunities as African countries are upgrading their basic telecoms infrastructure. ZTE has established a presence in more than half a dozen African countries including Kenya, Libya, Sudan and Congo. '

title: China to fund second bridge over Niger river into Niamey  (Duplicate of 135)
description: 'China will fund the construction of a second bridge into Niamey over the Niger, Africa's third longest river, a Niger diplomatic source said Tuesday.China has granted 20 million yuans (two million euros, 2,5 million dollars) and an interest-free loan of 30 million yuans to finance the project.It will send experts to Niger to conduct feasibility studies on the building of another bridge to ease congestion on JF Kennedy memorial bridge, built more than 30 years ago.Kennedy Bridge, built by the United States in the 1970s, is the only route to the capital Niamey across the river.The often congested 710-metre (775 yards) long bridge provides landlocked Niger's only access from Niamey to the sea via Ghana and Benin.Niger established diplomatic ties with Beijing in 1960, but broke them in 1994 for three years when it recognised the Taiwan.The bridge financing deal was concluded on July 18 during a visit to Beijing by Niger Foreign Minister Aichatou Mindaoudou.The Niger river is the continent's third longest after the Nile and the Congo and runs through five west African countries, Guinea, Mali, Niger, Benin and Nigeria. '

title: Establishment of a centre for agricultural technology (Duplicate)
description: 2 February 2007 02:41 PMBBC Monitoring Middle East BBCMEP English (c) 2007 The British Broadcasting Corporation. All Rights Reserved. No material may be reproduced except with the express permission of The British Broadcasting Corporation. Text of report in English by Sudanese news agency Suna website Khartoum, 2 February: President of the Republic Field Marshal Umar al-Bashir and Chinese President Hu Jintao attended at the Friendship Hall in Khartoum Friday [2 February] the signing of seven agreements between the two countries in the various fields of economic and technical cooperation. They included agreement on humanitarian aid to Darfur, a grant from the Chinese government amounting to 40m Yen (4.8m dollars). The two sides also signed a loan agreement for new presidential palace project of some 100m Yen and 90m Yen loan agreement from the old loans extended by China to the government of Sudan. The agreements also included a protocol on pardoning part of Sudan due debts to China amounting to some 470m Yen and 19m dollars. The agreements further included zero-tariff agreement, which is a preferential one covering 44 Sudanese commodities exported to China. The two countries also signed agreement on implementation of two schools in the rural areas in Sudan and another one for establishment of a centre for agricultural technology. Source: Suna news agency website, Khartoum, in English 2 Feb 07

title: Humanitarian assistance materials (Duplicate)
description: Khartoum, May 23 (Xinhua) - The Chinese government handed over to Sudan Wednesday a new batch of humanitarian assistance materials for the displaced people in the western Sudanese region of Darfur.The hand-over documents were signed by Sudanese Minister of Humanitarian Affairs Kosti Manibi and Chinese Ambassador to Sudan Zhang Dong, with the presence of visiting Special Representative of the Chinese Government for Darfur Liu Guijin. This is the second of the four batches of humanitarian assistance materials which the Chinese government had promised to offer for the Darfurian people since 2005, Liu said at the signing ceremony. The Chinese special representative said that his current visit to Sudan was the first one since he was appointed to the present post, which was aimed at 'getting acquainted with the Sudanese officials and listening to view points regarding the Darfur problem'. Liu said that he was 'deeply impressed' by his trip in the Darfur region on Tuesday, during which he visited the cities of Fashir and Nyala as well as three camps for displaced people. 'Due to efforts of the Sudanese government, with the help of the international community, the situation in Darfur is basically stable despite of some problems,' the Chinese envoy added. For his part, Sudan's Manibi described the hand-over ceremony as 'an important event which will promote the Sudanese-Chinese relations'. China is playing an expanding role of helping push forward the peace process in Darfur, praised the Sudanese minister, adding that we appreciate the Chinese government for its support for Sudan's development and infrastructures in general and for the humanitarian purposes in particular. Liu and his delegation arrived in Sudan on Saturday on a five-day visit. Source: Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in English 1054 gmt 23 May 07    16 August 2007 06:59 AMBBC Monitoring Asia Pacific BBCAPP English (c) 2007 The British Broadcasting Corporation. All Rights Reserved. No material may be reproduced except with the express permission of The British Broadcasting Corporation. Text of report in English by official Chinese news agency Xinhua (New China News Agency) ['Humanitarian Aid From China Leaves for Sudan's Darfur' - Xinhua headline] Tianjin, Aug. 16 (Xinhua) - The fourth batch of materials for humanitarian aid worth 20m yuan (2.6m US dollars) from the Chinese government left for Sudan on Thursday from north China's port of Tianjin. The pumps, tents and blankets will arrive in Port Sudan late next month and help residents in the Darfur region improve their living conditions. The fifth batch of aid worth 40m yuan, including board-houses for at least 120 schools, generators, vehicles and pumps, will be shipped on Aug. 25 from the same Chinese port. The Chinese government pledged to offer five batches of humanitarian aid to Darfur to ease the humanitarian problems caused by conflicts in the area in western Sudan. Wang Shichun, an official in charge of foreign aid with the Ministry of Commerce, said the Chinese government had consistently strived for the solution to the Darfur issue. 'The Chinese government's basic standpoint is the early realization of peace, stability and economic reconstruction via negotiations in the Darfur region,' Wang said on Thursday at the shipping ceremony. China had sent three batches of aid, including tents, blankets, medical and agricultural equipments with a total value of 20m yuan. Mirghani Mohamed Salih, Sudanese ambassador to China, expressed thanks on behalf of the Sudanese government for the timely aid from China which helped the region's residents overcome temporary difficulties. Source: Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in English 1043 gmt 16 Aug 07
sector: Humanitarian and Disaster Relief and Preparation

title: Aid for development in east Sudan (Duplicate)
description: 2 December 2010BEIJING, Dec 2 (Reuters) - The Chinese government will donate 154 million yuan ($23.11 million) for aid projects in the strategic and once restive eastern part of Sudan, China's special representative to Darfur was quoted as saying on Thursday.The east is crucial to Sudan's oil-driven economy as it contains the only commercial port and miles of pipeline.The Beja Congress, an east Sudanese party, signed a peace deal with Khartoum in 2006, ending a lingering insurgency in the region, and its leader became a presidential assistant. But it has complained that the government has continued to neglect the region since the accord.Liu Guijin, Beijing's top diplomat in charge of tackling the conflict in Sudan's restive Darfur region, said development in eastern Sudan was crucial to stability.'The situation there is generally stable and there has been some economic progress,' China's Foreign Ministry paraphrased Liu as saying at a donor's conference in Kuwait.'But this region's advantages in natural resources have yet to be truely transformed into a development advantage,' he added.China had already made 'many contributions' to developing eastern Sudan, and would now donate a further 154 million yuan to build water supplies, bridges and other infrastructure, Liu said.'China is willing to continue playing a constructive role in maintaining peace and stability in Sudan,' he added.Chinese companies are major investors in Sudan's oil, and China is Khartoum's top arms supplier, something long criticised by human rights activists and Western governments, especially because of the conflict in Darfur.But China, sensitive to criticism about its role in Sudan, has sent peacekeepers to Darfur and appointed its own special representative to the region to try and bring peace there.The conflict in Darfur flared in 2003 when mostly non-Arab rebels took up arms against the government, accusing it of neglecting the region. A series of cease-fires, negotiations and international campaigns has failed to end the fighting and law and order has collapsed in most of the region.The United Nations estimates up to 300,000 people died in the humanitarian crisis after Khartoum mobilised militias to quell the revolt. Khartoum puts the death toll at 10,000. ($1=6.663 Yuan)(Reporting by Ben Blanchard; Editing by Sanjee Miglani)

title: Joint venture construction plans for 2 proposed oil-from-coal plants [in China, not a project]
description: In 2004, Shenhua Group Corp. Ltd. and Sasol Ltd. planned to build China's first oil-from-coal. A Sino/South African joint venture is currently gearing-up to build China's first oil-from-coal plants. The partners in the planned undertaking include the local SHENHUA GROUP CORP. LTD. and SASOL LTD. of South Africa. As things currently stand, SHENHUA recently received approval from the Beijing government to raise the capital necessary to build the plants based on SASOL's technology. Official sanction for SHENHUA's planned $1,200,000,000 initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong and New York comes as SASOL, the Chinese government and a consortium of 6 Chinese firms finalize a letter of intent to build 2 oil-from-coal plants in energy-hungry and coal-rich China. SASOL presently operates the world's only commercial oil-from-coal operation at its 155,000 barrels per day plant at Secunda, South Africa. As things currently stand,. Chinese Vice-President, Zeng Qinghong, was expected to arrive in South Africa in late June 2004 to sign a letter of intent with SASOL regarding the synfuel plants. SHENHUA employs a total staff of about 100,000 involved in the provision of coal mining services through 10 subsidiaries. The company is responsible for the overall planning, development and operation of the massive Shenfu Dengsheng coalfield as well as the related railway, power station, coal terminal and shipping fleet. It is also active in developing domestic and overseas investment and financing and trading businesses in the aforesaid fields of activity. . SASOL employs a total group workforce of approximately 31,000 and operates as a holding company. The group is engaged in the mining and distribution of coal as well as being acknowledged to be a world leader in the conversion of coal to oil and gas. In addition, it is involved in the production of petrochemicals, plastics, fertilizers and mining explosives. title: Donation for training, poverty alleviation (duplicate)
description: Hu kicks off Africa tour 456 words 30 January 2007 Morning Star Online MOSTAR English Copyright 2007. People's Press Printing Society Limited CHINESE President Hu Jintao arrived in Africa on Tuesday on a mission to help the world's least developed continent realise its economic, social and cultural potential. President Hu, who is expected to meet the leaders of Cameroon, Liberia, Sudan, Zambia, Namibia, South Africa, Mozambique and Seychelles, will sign debt relief agreements with 33 African countries. Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Liu Jianchao did not reveal the total value of the loans to be written off, but he said that they are heavily indebted countries or are among the world's least developed nations. According to Mr Liu, China plans to double free aid and interest-free loans to African countries to help with social, cultural and public welfare projects over the next three years. Preferential loans worth $3 billion will be provided to help African countries develop infrastructure, purchase technological equipment and establish production enterprises and a 50,000-square-metre international convention centre will be built for the African Union free of charge. Mr Hu also intends to use his Africa tour to strengthen China's co-operation with African countries in human resources, agriculture, medical care, social development and education over the next three years. China plans to build general or special hospitals with 100 to 150 beds for countries that have poor medical facilities and anti-malarial medicines will be provided to 33 countries. China also aims to help African countries build a total of 100 primary schools before 2009, each of which will be able to accommodate at least 300 pupils. Refuting Western assertions that China is engaged in 'neo-colonialism' in Africa, Mr Liu pointed out that 'China's ultimate goal is to achieve common development, improve the living standards of the Chinese and the Africans and subsequently promote world peace and prosperity.' 'No African government or people have ever blamed China for practising 'neo-colonialism' in Africa,' Mr Liu noted, adding: 'Africans were once enslaved by colonists and they know better than anyone else what colonialism is all about.' South African Deputy Foreign Minister Aziz Pahad agreed, saying: 'There is no sinister agenda - they just realise the potential for Africa.' In South Africa, which has complained that the influx of cheap Chinese clothes could devastate the textile industry, Mr Hu will make a donation of $2.6 million as part of efforts to help the country in skills training and poverty alleviation. United States International University in Nairobi Professor Macharia Munene said that Africa's enthusiasm over its new links with China was driven in part by the terrible deals that it has received from the West. 'The Chinese are agreeing to reciprocity and that is why they look very attractive,' Mr Munene observed.

title: Aid to Gabon Tri-Service Military General Hospital: treatment, training (Duplicate of 11756)
description: 4月28日，由广州军区武汉总医院医护人员组成的中国援助加蓬军医组一行9人，完成为期一年的医疗援助任务返回武汉。援非期间，他们先后救治病患6000多人，为加蓬三军总医院培训医护人员300多人次，指导开展新技术新业务10余项，加蓬总统和国防部长曾分别为军医组成员授勋。图为加蓬国防部秘书总长为军医组成员佩戴勋章的情景。 李玉宝、余 敏摄影报道

China donates 60 trucks to Uganda (Duplicate)
description: China Donates 60 Trucks To Uganda. 227 words 13 May 2000 01:52 PM All Africa AFNWS English (c) Distributed via COMTEX News. Kampala (New Vision, May 13, 2000) - China has given the Uganda Government 60 Jiefang tipper trucks worth US$3.2m for road maintenance in the country. The trucks were yesterday handed over to state minister for works, Andraule Awuzu by the Chinese ambassador to Uganda, Mr. Zhang Xujiang at the ministry's headquarters at Entebbe. Jiang Li, the managing director of China Jiefang (U) Ltd. distributors of Jiefang vehicles, and the permanent secretary Charles Muganzi witnessed the hand-over. Awuzu said the trucks, to be distributed to all districts, will be used in the rehabilitation of feeder, community and urban roads. He said road rehabilitation would cover slightly over 22,000 kms of the feeder road network in the country. Awuzu thanked the Chinese Government, saying that rehabilitation of these roads will play a big role in improving the living standards of the Ugandan people. Awuzu cautioned the district leaders who are the direct beneficiaries of the grant, to put the trucks to proper use and observe timely and prompt maintenance. The ambassador said the trucks, which are produced by the first automobile factory in China, have been tested and found to be working very well in China. He said the trucks would boost the development of Uganda. Copyright 2000 New Vision. Distributed via Africa News Online.

title: China to cancel 1.2 billion dollars of African debt
description: China to cancel 1.2 billion dollars of African debt ATTENTION - ADDS quotes /// 622 words 11 October 2000 Agence France-Presse AFPR English (Copyright 2000) BEIJING, Oct 11 (AFP) - China pledged on Wednesday to cancel 1.2 billion dollars of debt owed by African nations over the next two years and called for increased trade with the continent. Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation Minister Shi Guangsheng said the move on debt would help alleviate poverty and provide a much- needed boost to Africa's development. 'Since China is willing to make contributions to alleviate the debt burden of African countries, it will reduce and exempt debt worth 10 billion yuan owed by those heavily indebted poor countries and the least developed countries in Africa in the coming two years,' Shi said. He was speaking to some 80 African leaders representing 44 countries at the first China-African Cooperation Forum being held in Beijing. China would also continue to provide assistance of various kinds and 'gradually expand the scale of assistance as its economic development level rises and comprehensive national strength builds up,' Shi said. Chinese companies would be encouraged to invest in Africa, and Beijing would set up an Africa Human Resources Development Fund to help African nations 'train professional talents,' he said. Officials at the ministry declined to detail which countries would be eligible for debt reduction or specify the extent of African indebtedness to Beijing. The gesture was seen as a sign that China was ready to take on a donor nation role on the global stage, after years of being a major recipient of international and bilateral aid and preferential economic and financial policies. Philip Asiodu, the chief economic adviser to Nigerian President Olusegun Obasanjo described the Chinese initiative as 'a very significant gesture,' and urged the OECD and the London and the Paris clubs of creditor nations to follow Beijing's lead. The debt covered by China's move is a drop in the ocean compared with Africa's total debt, which is estimated at some 350 billion dollars. In recent years, Washington has proposed that Beijing increase its financial contributions to the United Nations, while Japan, a major contributor of aid and preferential loans to China, insisted in August that Beijing clarify its developmental aid program to other countries. China was the major recipient of World Bank loans for most of the 1990s and was recently removed from the list of countries eligible for preferential borrowing. Shi said China has invested in 47 African countries, while Africa has largely been a buyer of Chinese textiles and electronics equipment. According to Chinese statistics, bilateral trade with African nations totalled 6.48 billion dollars in 1999, with Chinese exports accounting for 4.1 billion dollars and African imports standing at 2.37 billion dollars. By the end of June 2000, some 480 Chinese companies had been set up in 47 African nations, with a total contractual investment of 820 million dollars, of which 530 million dollars was Chinese capital. South Africa's Trade and Industry Minister Alec Erwin admitted that the trade relationship between Africa and China left much to be desired. 'The trade relation between China and Africa is one of the oldest in history, but it is not strong,' he said. 'Our enterprises don't really know the markets of China and Africa.' Shi's announcement was largely seen as the highlight of the landmark summit, which has been billed as China's effort to align itself with Africa and the developing world in an effort to confront domination by the West. At the opening of the forum on Tuesday, Chinese President Jiang Zemin urged Africa to cooperate with Beijing to demand political and economic equality on the global stage and establish a 'new world order.'

title: KCC to get 30 garbage trucks from China (Duplicate)
description: KCC to Get 30 Garbage Trucks from China. 277 words 11 October 2002 10:20 AM All Africa AFNWS English (c) Distributed via COMTEX News. Kampala, Oct 11, 2002 (New Vision/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -KAMPALA city residents who in the past have had a rough time inhaling foul vapours from nearby garbage skips should now take heart. Kampala City Council (KCC) is soon to acquire 30 new Jiefang trucks from China to collect garbage in the city. The trucks are to be purchased under a Chinese grant of 12m Yuan (US$1.5m). The Chinese ambassador to Uganda, Mr. Li Qiangmin and Minister of State for Finance, Sam Kutesa, signed an agreement yesterday under which China will finance the truck purchase. 'We continue to value your aid to the various sectors of the economy. We hope the trucks will help to keep Kampala cleaner,' Kutesa said. The mayor, John Sebaana Kizito, his deputy, Takuba Kabuye and the town clerk, Gordon Mwesigye, attended the function at the finance ministry boardroom. Sebaana said he could not believe the deal would go through, saying his team made a request to the Chinese government as a trial. He said KCC would try to make Kampala shine as the Chinese capital city, Shangai. Shangai has 23m people while Kampala has about 2m people. The ambassador said, 'I hope the trucks will make Kampala cleaner and the environment more beautiful.' KCC has about two trucks for each of its five divisions, making the collection of the 1,000 tonnes of garbage accumulated per day impossible. Kutesa said Uganda would appreciate similar assistance to other towns. Published on: Friday, 11th October, 2002 by Geoffrey Kamali Copyright New Vision. Distributed by All Africa Global Media(AllAfrica.com)

title: Construction of tractor plant (Not a Project)
description: rt by Radio Uganda on 27 OctoberThe Chinese government has expressed interest in establishing a tractor assembling plant in Uganda which will go a long way in promoting modernization of agriculture.   The outgoing Chinese ambassador to Uganda, Fan Guijin, made the remarks while biding farewell to the prime minister, Prof Apollo Nsibambi at his office in Kampala.   The premier hailed China for her excellent relationship with Uganda especially in the areas of commerce and trade and bilateral aid which has resulted in the construction of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs building and now the president's and the prime minister's office.   The ambassador said Uganda is the only country with zero tariff on processed coffee in the Chinese market, adding that Uganda is also exporting processed leather to China.   He encouraged Uganda to export more processed goods to China and also thanked the Government of Uganda for supporting him during his term of service in Uganda.

title: Loan for communication infrastructure (Duplicate)
description: (c) 2007 The British Broadcasting Corporation. All Rights Reserved. No material may be reproduced except with the express permission of The British Broadcasting Corporation. Text of report by Joyce Namutebi and Milton Olupot entitled 'MPs allow govt to get sh48b loan' published by Ugandan newspaper The New Vision website on 5 July Parliament has allowed the government to borrow 30m dollars (about 48bn shillings) from China to improve the communication sector. The money, to be borrowed from the Export and Import Bank of China, will fund the National Data Transmission Backbone Infrastructure project. 'The purpose of the project is to improve the communication infrastructure in the country, reduce the cost of communication and improve communication within the government,' the finance minister, Ezra Suruma, told parliament on Tuesday [3 July]. Under the first phase of the project, e-government infrastructure will be established in Kampala, Entebbe and Jinja, according to the national economy committee that scrutinised the loan request. The committee added that the project would be extended to other districts by 2010. The chairman, Ibrahim Lubega Kaddunabbi, noted that through the e-government infrastructure, the flow of information to citizens would be timely and credible. He explained that district headquarters would also be connected to the Internet and information and communication access points would be established at sub-counties. However, the legislators were concerned that the government had already signed a memorandum of understanding with a Chinese contractor, M/S Huawei Tech Co. Ltd, who had started working on the project before parliament had approved the loan. They further noted that the loan terms were not in line with the National Debt Strategy and the International Development Association acceptable concession terms, which require all such loans to have a repayment period of 40 years with 10 years grace period. The loan repayment period is 40 years with a five-year grace period. Source: The New Vision website, Kampala, in English 5 Jul 07
donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
