title: (INACTIVE) Soft loan
description: 'BEIJING (Dow Jones)--China Civil Engineering Construction Corp. in late October signed a $8.3-billion deal with Nigeria's Ministry of Transportation to build a railway in the West African country, in what would mark the largest overseas engineering project by value for China.Spanning 1,315 kilometers, the planned railway will link the southern city of Lagos with Kano in the north, said the Chinese railway builder in a statement posted on its Web site.The deal was signed just before Nigeria's President Olusegun Obasanjo flew to Beijing for a historic China-Africa summit held this weekend.Chinese policy bank Export-Import Bank of China will provide $1 billion in soft loans to fund the project, according to the statement.The Chinese builder in July also signed a $300-million contract to build a 132-kilometer expressway in Nigeria.Following years of under-investment, Nigeria's internal transportation system is known to be poor, unsafe and unreliable.China has launched a sweeping effort to expand its access to Africa's oil and markets, pledging billions of dollars in aid and loans as dozens of African leaders attended the Beijing conference over the weekend aimed at building economic ties.Nigeria is Africa's largest oil producer. '
recipient_agencies: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency

title: 2.6 million dollar grant pay one month of salary arrears (Duplicate)
description: 'Copyright Agence France-Presse, 2003 All reproduction and presentation rights reserved.China has given the impoverished Central African Republic a grant of nearly two million dollars to help its new government sort out public finances, national radio said Tuesday.The donation 'attests once again to our friendship and solidarity with the people of the Central African Republic,' said China's ambassador in Bangui, Wang Ci Fa as the one billion CFA franc (1.9 million dollar) agreement was signed Monday.The accord is the second of its kind following a 2.6 million dollar grant in April, which allowed the government of President Francois Bozize to pay one month of salary arrears inherited from his predecessor Ange-Felix Patasse, ousted in a March coup.China is also helping the impoverished landlocked country to organize a census in December.In September, building began of a 20,000-seat stadium in Bangui with Chinese financing, and a 100-unit public housing project is nearing completion just outside the capital Bangui.acp/mdb/gd.Document AFPR000020031111dzbb0020n'

title: Debt Cancellation (Duplicate of  2380)
description: 5. Minister of Equipment Harouna, Mayor Abdoulaye Issa of Niamey Commune IV (location for the new bridge) and Governor of Niamey Region Tahirou Amadou all had glowing remarks for GON President Tandja, citing Tandja's personal engagement and perseverance in securing a partner to build a second bridge that had been awaited since the early 1980s.  All spoke of the 'dynamism of the Sino-Nigerien relationship' and emphasized that 'the new, second bridge' will provide much needed relief to the congestion on 'the first bridge', a contribution that will enhance the economic and commercial vitality of Niamey and the corridor leading from Niamey to the Burkina Faso border.  Several recent, ongoing and future initiatives were cited, such as construction of a new, larger PRC Embassy (with completion reportedly months away) to make room for a larger Chinese diplomatic/official presence in Niger, the completed water treatment plant in Zinder, the General Seyni Kountche Sports Stadium (built by the PRC for the 2005 Francophonie games and which will be refurbished by the Chinese), a housing complex, electrification projects in Bilma, microcredits to women groups, a couple hundred tractors to farmers, US$1.4 Million for two rural schools (in areas to be determined), US$450 Thousand to construct a Sino-Nigerien Center to Combat Malaria, a medicine donation (valued at US$200 Thousand) to combat malaria over a two-year period, agreement to increase from 190 to 442 duty-free categories of potential exports of Nigerien goods to China and cancellation of approximtely US$12 Million debt for Niger. //奥马鲁祝贺中国成功举办北京奥运会、残奥会。他说，长期以来，中国帮助尼日尔建设供水工程，提供粮食援助，免除尼日尔所欠债务，为尼日尔发展提供了许多宝贵支持，尼日尔人民对此非常感激。尼日尔正致力于消除贫困，希望继续得到中国支持，期待同中国加强基础设施建设、资源能源开发等领域合作。

title: PPIAF - Develop manganese mine near industrial town Kabwe (possible duplicate, see ID:94)
description: (PPIAF) As of 2005, Chiman, a private firm from China's Liaoning Province, was in the process of developing a manganese mine in Zambia's old industrial town Kabwe. The mine had a proven deposit of 4 million tons. Chiman Manufacturing's mine was the first manganese mine opened in  Zambia. Chiman Manufacturing Ltd. has started processing manganese in 2007. $10 million had been invested in the processing plant and more investments into new equipment and construction of a new smelter to reach peak production of 50,000 tonnes were planned. title: build four factories producing leather goods (Not a project)
description: ADDIS ABABA, Aug 13 (Reuters) - A Chinese company has signed a $34 million deal with Ethiopia to build four factories producing leather goods north of the capital Addis Ababa.A statement issued by the Ethiopian government on Wednesday said the firm, Sino-Oerseas Leather Products, had bought 50,000 square metres of land for the plants.It said the first factory, a tannery, was due to be completed before the end of the year and would produce more than 1 million square metres of finished leather annually.The other three will make gloves, shoes and jackets.Last month, Ethiopia's government said Chinese investors had built the country's first glass factory, worth some $15 million. The Chinese have been investing heavily in Africa, especially in resource rich areas.Also last month, ZTE Corp , China's second-largest telecoms gear maker, said it had agreed to build a national network covering 14 major cities in Ethiopia. (Reporting by Tsegaye Tadesse; Editing by Daniel Wallis) (For full Reuters Africa coverage and to have your say on the top issues, visit: href='http://africa.reuters.com/'>http://africa.reuters.com/ [href='http://africa.reuters.com/'>http://africa.reuters.com/])
donor_agency_count: Sino-Overseas Leather Products

title: Vocational training school [duplicate of ID#1734]
description: Jun 19, 2002 (Ghanaian Chronicle/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) - THE CHINESE government has donated an amount of $8million (about o56million) to the Dangbe East constituency to build a hospital. They are also going to help in the construction of some portions of the Accra-Kumasi road. This was disclosed in Accra when China's vice Minister for Foreign Affairs in charge of Africa, H.E Yang Wenchang, held bilateral talks with Ghana's deputy Minister for Foreign Affairs, Hon. Alhaji Mustapha Ali Idris. Hon. Ali Idris expressed satisfaction on the excellent bilateral relations between Ghana and China which was established four decades ago and which has been characterised in recent times by the visits of the vice president, Mr Jinn Jintao, in January 1999. He stated that the minister's visit is an illustration of the continued desire of both countries to strengthen their bonds of friendship. China financed a vocational school located in Dansoman, but it is unclear what the commitment year was, how much the project cost, and when the project was completed. The Afife Irrigation project, the National Theatre in Accra, construction of new housing units at police and military barracks and Dangbe East district hospital and vocational training school at Dansoman are all examples of Chinese projects from which Ghana has benefited. The deputy minister further expressed gratitude to the Chinese government on the cancellation of debts owed to China arising from loans given to Ghana from 1972 to 1998 and also the agreement in principle to provide financial support for the construction of 17.6 kilometre two-way lane and 40.5 kilometre dual carriage portions of the Accra-Kumasi road within three years. Explaining the NEPAD initiative to the vice Minister of Foreign Affairs, the minister said it is about Ghana's efforts to strengthen peace and security with good governance through NEPAD and efforts by the leaders of the sub-region to achieve a meaningful and sustainable development. He commended China for her contribution to Africa's development and hoped that the establishment of the Sino-Africa conference will offer more opportunities for Africa and China to continue to consult in the interest of concerted action aimed at addressing the wide range of issues of mutual concern and deepening the solidarity which is essential for addressing the common challenges presented by globalisation. The Chinese foreign minister on his part said Ghana is one of the sub-saharan countries to welcome China, with the leaders having a very profound relationship between them. He continued that despite the leadership changes, their relationship is still very cordial in the sense that their assistance to Ghana will not change because it is not directed to a particular government but to the people of Ghana. The foreign minister re-assured that the Chinese government is ready to work with the Kufuor administration since Ghana and China are all developing countries. He supported the NEPAD initiative and the preparedness of his government to join in its implementation. He hinted that a certain amount of money has been given to the Ghana government but the amount was however not known. by Linda Akrasi Copyright Ghanaian Chronicle. Distributed by All Africa Global Media(AllAfrica.com) KEYWORD:          Ghana. Document afnws00020020620dy6k000xd

title: China extracts 1.9 million tonnes of raw material [not a project]
description: INTERVIEW-UPDATE 1-China Minmetals scours for deals globally 437 words 11 June 2009 03:27 AMReuters News LBA English (c) 2009 Reuters Limited * Eyes acquisition targets in Mauritania's iron ore sector* Not ruling out more deals in Australia* Welcomes shareholders' approval on OZ Minerals bid(Adds details, quotes)By Lee Chyen YeeTAIPEI, June 11 (Reuters) - China Minmetals is looking for acquisition targets in Mauritania, and possibly more deals in Australia after its successful bid for debt-ridden OZ Minerals , a senior company official said on Thursday.China has been scouring the globe to invest in or acquire companies that produce ore and concentrates as the country guzzles raw materials at a heady pace to fuel its growing economy.'We are interested in acquiring companies in Mauritania that produce iron ore. We're talking to potential companies right now, but I can't give you too many details,' Feng Guiquan, a senior vice-president at Minmetals, told Reuters in Taipei.China and Mauritania already have some trade and investment ties in iron ore.China, which buys the bulk of its iron ore and concentrates from Australia, Brazil and India, imported 1.9 million tonnes of the raw material from Mauritania between January and April, nearly double the level in the same period a year earlier. [ID:nSHA70770]Minmetals has a joint venture with Mauritania's state-owned Societe Nationale Industrielle et Miniere (SNIM), which is the world's seventh-largest supplier of iron ore.Other than iron ore in Africa, Minmetals President Zhou Zhongshu last year said the company, which posted sales of 180.9 billion yuan ($27 billion) last year, was also looking at chromium in South Africa and bauxite in the Caribbean.'We are not ruling out Australia as well if there are other opportunities, although we are not in a hurry,' Feng said.'Sometimes things can get complicated when there are corporate interests or political considerations involved in such deals,' he said.China's state-owned metals conglomerate Chinalco suffered a major setback last week when Rio Tinto spurned its planned $19.5 billion investment in favour of a tie-up with BHP Billiton . [ID:nSYD73514]But Minmetals was more fortunate.Earlier in the day, shareholders in Australian miner OZ Minerals approved Minmetals' sweetened $1.4 billion deal to purchase most of the indebted miner's assets. [ID:nSP488757]'That's good news,' Feng said. 'We'e already settled our funding. Part of it will come from our own capital, while the rest will be from banks.'(Additional reporting by Lin Miao-jung; Editing by Chris Lewis)MINMETALS/ (UPDATE 1, INTERVIEW)|LANGEN|Table|ABN|E|RBN|Z|C|MTL|GRO|SOF|AUF|AFN|BNXDocument LBA0000020090611e56b000j2

title: Boali three hydroelectric dam (Duplicate)
description: 'Text of report by state-owned Central African Republic radio on 17 SeptemberMembers of the inter-ministerial committee in charge of following up the declaration of the third China-Africa forum met in the conference hall of the Planning Ministry in Bangui on the first semester report and the implementation of the declaration today. The goal of the meeting was to assess the implementation level of the projects in accordance with the eight poles of China-Africa cooperation and the recommendations to the members of the inter-ministerial committee.Among projects meant for Central African Republic, there are the rehabilitation of the Bimbo transmitting antenna of Radio Centrafrique, and the rehabilitation of Boali three hydro-electric dam. The meeting was chaired by the minister of planning, economy, and international cooperation, Sylvain Maliko. Then, the Chinese ambassador, Sui Hoo, reassured the government on these projects. Let us listen to him.[Begin Hoo recording] For the project of construction of the Boali hydro-electric dam, a Chinese technical team was on the ground, we drafted a plan, we submitted a quotation estimated at US$117 million. Our global fund is about US$7 billion. If the construction of the hydro-electric dam costs about US$117 million, based on the global fund of US$7 billion, I have to tell you the truth, the means of the Chinese Government are limited. And with the current economic growth of China, I am sure that the Chinese Government's assistance will significantly increase in favour of African sisters and brothers. I am sure that by next year, even by the end of this year, we will see, China will deploy agricultural experts, or volunteers, to help you develop agriculture or other sectors. [end recording] ''根据公司与中非共和国能矿部签订的总承包合同约定，应公司邀请，经浙江省外办报请外交部，并获得国务院批准后，中非共和国财政、矿产、能源和水利部部长级代表让.克里索斯托姆.梅孔东戈先生率领的中非共和国专家代表团一行六人于8月26日来华，与公司就中非博阿里水电项 目商务合同后的技术合同进行洽谈，对项目的技术规范、初步设计方案、可行性研究报告等工作进行了审查、确认。并在公司领导的陪同下拜访了国家商务部和中国进出口银行，就本项目的融资和优惠贷款向中国政府提出了申请。期间，代表团一行还参观和考察了公司及公司建设的北仑电厂和桐柏抽水蓄能电站。    8月27日，公司组织相关专业技术人员与中非代表就中非博阿里水电项目的技术条款、合同补充条款以及业主权利、责任和义务进行了深入讨论。会上，我方提交了《中非工程变电站设计技术规范书》、《中非博亚利项目水电站部分设计技术规范书》、《输电线路设计技术规范书》、《中非共和国Boali水电站及输电工程项目可研报告》、《需中非方解决和协助解决的几类问题》的资料，并对输电线路、水电站、变电所三个部分进行了概要介绍。中非方经过详细的审查，双方针对主要问题也进行了详细的讨论，签订了补充的合同条款，将原合同中由美元计价结算改成因优惠贷款而需要的人民币计价结算。还与中非方讨论了有关设备物资办理免税、中转、运输和储存、设计标准采用、自动操作系统计算机显示以及设计文件有疑义等问题，经过几天的详细的沟通，于9月1日形成最终会议纪要并签署。    8月28日－30日，中非代表团由公司领导陪同专程赴京，在中非驻华使馆等的协助下，拜会了中华人民共和国商务部，与商务部有关领导就博阿里水电站及输电工程项目进行了交流；还拜访了中国进出口银行的有关领导，向进出口银行提出了该项目使用中国政府优惠贷款的申请。同时，中非部长级代表向进出口银行提出由我公司代为转交申请中国政府优惠贷款所需要的资料。拜会商务部及进出口银行期间，中非部长级代表对公司在前期工作中所做的大量工作表示感谢。    中非代表团回到宁波后，考察了公司的办公场所并前往公司参建的北仑电厂和桐柏抽水蓄能电站进行参观，现场的参观给中非代表团留下了很深的印象，也打消了对公司施工能力的顾虑，中非部长级代表表示十分愿意同公司就博阿里水电站项目及以后的开发项目进行合作。'

title: Military Hospital (Inactive: same as ID#745)
description: Guinea-Bissau's President Malam Bacai Sanha on Wednesday inaugurated his government's new 25-million-dollar headquarters, entirely built with Chinese funding.The building, situated in the north of the capital Bissau, took 18 months to build and consists of three large blocks that can accommodate 12 ministries.It is 'a symbol of the fruitful cooperation long held with China who we thank from the bottom of our hearts,' said Sanha at the inauguration.At Sanha's side was the Chinese ambassador to Guinea-Bissau, Li Bao Jun.'It is the fruit of frank and enduring cooperation,' said Li.China has already played a hand in other projects in Bissau including the National Assembly, built in 2000 for six million dollars, a military hospital with 200 beds that cost 12 million dollars, as well as a 25,000-seat stadium.Beijing has also financed renovation work on barracks, hospitals and has invested in the west African country's agriculture sector.China is interested in offshore oil exploration and the vast forest and fishing wealth of Guinea-Bissau.But the country has been chronically unstable since independence from Portugal in 1974 with coups, army mutinies and political murders. It has also in recent years been turned into a drug trafficking hub by South American barons targetting European markets.

title: Joint venture to finish hydroelectric dam (Duplicate)
description: Jul 25, 2006 (Addis Fortune/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- Foreign Affairs Minister, Seyoum Mesfin, appears to be having an exhilarating moment with Girma Birru, minister of Trade and Industry, and Fikru Desalegn, state minister of Capacity Building and board chairman of EEPCo. The signing of the 15 billion Br contract with Salini on Wednesday, July 19, is believed to be a milestone in the 55-year history of the state-owned utility monopoly. The high profile nature of Gilgel Gibe III hydroelectric power project is not only evident from how much it will have cost when construction is completed in five years. The unusual turnout of four senior ministers of Prime Minister Meles Zenawi's administration at the singing ceremony for the 15 billion Br contract on Wednesday, July 19, speaks volume on what the project means to this government. When Meheret Debebe, general manager of the Ethiopian Electric Power Corporation (EEPCo), signed this deal in the Lalibela Ball Room of the Sheraton Addis with Claudio Lautizi, Salini's general manager for International Division, Seyoum Mesfin, minister of Foreign Affairs, appeared for the first time ever at such an event. Normally, public works contract signings crave to even have a state minister in the audience. Also in attendance Wednesday were Girma Birru, minister of Trade and Industry, Alemayehu Tegenu, minister of Mines and Energy, and Hassen Abdella, minister of Labour and Social Affairs, joined by 150 other guests of high standing from both the public and private sector. This project is dear to Prime Minister Meles, said a senior minister. He follows its developments closely for he believes that without taking advantage of its own natural power generation capacity, Ethiopia is heading nowhere, said the official. 'In the global picture where oil is getting scarce and ever more expensive, hydropower is the white oil of Ethiopia: clear and renewable,' said Mr. Lautizi, confirming the Prime Minister's passion for mega constructions geared for power generation. Indeed, it is under the administration of this Prime Minister that Ethiopia has experienced a record high power generation capacity. When he took power 14 years ago, the country was generating only 455mw, compared to the 750mw it generates today. Still, this capacity only covers 17pc of the country's area. A few major hydro electric projects were completed in the past decade: Tis Abay II (80mw) and Finchaa IV (34mw). The largest to date, however, is Gilgel Gibe I, built by Salini and the Spanish NESCO near the town of Jimma, in Oromia Regional State, at a cost 2.2 billion Br. It generates 184mw in electrical power. It is to be supplemented with the follow-up project (Gilgel Gibe II) that added tunnels to generate 425mw. At a projected cost of 400 million Br, Gilgel Gibe II is currently under construction by Salini Costrottori SPA. Salini is also building another hydroelectric power project on the Belesa River, Amhara Regional State, at a cost of 5.4 billion Br, believed to have a projected generation capacity of 460mw upon completion. Up in the north, a Chinese and Ethiopian (Sur) joint venture is undertaking a 1.9 billion Br project to finish a hydroelectric dam on the Tekeze River, which will be generating 300mw when it is completed in 2008. 'EEPCo never had four live projects going at the same time in its 51 years history,' said an official. As part of its 25-year power sector expansion master plan, developed two years ago, EEPCo has designed a five-year strategic plan to expand the electric coverage to 50pc by 2010, generating over 4,000mw electric power. The five-year plan will cost an estimated 53 billion Br. The successful completion of Gilgel Gibe III alone is believed to help it accomplish 40pc of this target. The wonder of Gilgel Gibe III, strangely named for it will not be built on the river of Gilgel Gibe, is not only the size of its investment or its projected generation capacity of 1,870mw: it is rather how it came into being. 'It is concluded passing through the most efficient feasibility study and design completion,' Meheret told a stunned audience. The Italians clearly used insight and understanding of Ethiopia's resources, accumulated during their brief colonial time, in preparing for the Gilgel Gibe III project. What would have taken a minimum of 15 years to identify and develop has taken the consulting firm, Coyne Et Bellier (ELC), a mere 18 months. Meheret himself did little to contain his incredulity at how the engineering, procurement and construction contract process was completed in such a short time. 'This project is a fast-track record even for us,' said Mr. Lautizi. The financing is the most attractive part for the government, according to officials. Not only did Salini approach it with the project proposal and conduct all the studies by itself, it also came with a scheme to find 65pc of the project value, to be borrowed from the European Investment Bank. The country's balance of payment and foreign cash reserves are not touched. The remaining balance is to be covered by EEPCo's own local sources, through borrowing. The construction of this project on the Omo River, in the Southern National, Nationalities and Peoples State, will include a 270m high dam that will hold 14.7 million cubic meters water. It will be the first dam in the country to contain 10 turbine units, accessed by five kilometres of tunnels. Each unit is projected to generate 187mw of electric power, the equivalent of what Gilgel Gibe I generates today. The project also involves the extension of 550Km of transmission lines from the generation plant to Wolayta, and from Wolayta to Kaliti and Mega substations. The lines will cost the Corporation an additional two billion Birr, according to EEPCo officials. Meheret believes that the construction years ahead will bring additional business opportunity to both private and public companies in oil, transport, cement, hotels, tourism, insurance, banking, manufacturing, engineering and transit, an estimated six billion Birr. However big the investment, Mr. Lautizi believes EEPCo will return its investment in only five years of operation. 'In this way, it will not only open the way to the growth of Ethiopia in the coming years, but will also help the regional development of East Africa and contribute to its peaceful stability, a very important factor,' he told those who came to witness the signing ceremony at the Sheraton. 'In return, Ethiopia will earn income that may be used for importing what is needed from aboard.' Indeed, the gap in Ethiopia's current account balance soured significantly in 2005 by a negative 1013pc (from -233pc in 2001), according to the World Bank, with its spending to buy goods and services increasing to 4.3 billion dollars, up from 1.9 billion Br, in the same period.

title: Duplicate: PPIAF - Abuja Rail Mass Transit Project
description: (PPIAF) Includes fast rail system from Lagos to Abuja, a light rail from the Murtala Mohammed International Airport to the city of Lagos and Nnamdi Azikiwe International Airport to Abuja City centre. The company would invest in the Abuja Metro Line phase1, phase2, phase3, Power Station plant, Lugbe Housing Project   Surrounding Infrastructure, Tunga Maje Automotive Village and the Abuja Neighbourhood Centre No.1   Security Infrastructure.; Total Project Cost: USD 2000 Million; Chinese Commitment: USD 1000 Million; PPIAF-ID:208See ID# 1851

title: Exempted tariffs on African
description: BEIJING, Feb. 27 (Xinhua) -- The economic and trade cooperation between China and Portuguese-speaking countries has made remarkable progress in recent years, said Vice Minister of Commerce Wei Jianguo here Monday.In 2005, bilateral trade between China and Portuguese-speaking countries reached a record high of 23.19 billion U.S. dollars, up 26.9 percent year on year, Wei said at a press conference about the second ministerial meeting between China and Portuguese-speaking countries on economic issues, which is scheduled to be held in Macao in September 2006.The meeting is under the framework of China-Portuguese-speaking countries Economic and Trade Forum, which was established in October 2003, according to Wei.During the meeting, entrepreneurs from both sides will also hold a conference and talks on future cooperation issues, he said.By the end of 2005, China's direct investment in Portuguese-speaking countries totaled 100 million U.S. dollars, while Brazil and Portugal's actual investment in China reached 229 million U.S. dollars, figures from the ministry show.The Chinese government has provided aid within its capacity for some Portuguese-speaking countries including Angola, Mozambique and Guinea Bissau. From Jan. 1, 2005, China started to exempt tariffs on some products imported from Portuguese-speaking countries in Africa, said Wei.

title: Selling Cheap Goods to Mauritania
description: Hundreds of newly-arrived Chinese wholesale merchants are flooding Senegal's capital Dakar, with cheap goods, pleasing customers and retailers, but angering their Senegalese competitors. At the Centenaire market in Dakar, Chinese wholesalers line the street on both sides, renting warehouses for $1,000 a month, selling everything in bulk from plastic toys to space-age looking DVD players. One buyer, Fatou Gueye, says Senegalese are poor and they love these new shops, because, she says finally she can afford something. Here she says, she can buy for children and adults, for her whole family, almost everything they need. One man who has just turned himself from chronically unemployed to retailer is also very pleased. He is buying bras, cameras, shoes, belt buckles, pots, pans, colorful pens and notebooks to resell in stores and on the streets of Dakar. He says it was very cheap to start his business. He started by selling a Chinese pair of shoes he had bought here for $1. There was no way of finding shoes for under $5 besides flip-flops before. For many people who live on several dollars a day, that's a big difference. The Senegalese manager of one of the warehouses says the Chinese have created jobs. He says young kids who used to be pickpockets are now hired as messengers. Asked whether Senegalese are not afraid the quality of Chinese goods might not be so good, he says that's nonsense. Senegalese want quantity, he says, they want to be able to afford things. Generally, prices in the Chinese shops are three to five times cheaper than in Lebanese or Senegalese stores. The invasion started last year when Senegal's government signed a bilateral agreement with China, to encourage Chinese businessmen to set up shop in Dakar. So-called Senegalese investment packages which include visas have been made readily available in China. But Senegalese shopkeepers say many Chinese who bribe their way buy these business visas at lower than official prices, for about $1,000 a year, and that Chinese typically undervalue their incoming goods to pay lower customs fees as well. One shopkeeper told VOA he is furious. 'Now I think that I have to change business or to change work because business is very hard because of the Chinese here in Senegal,' he said. 'We have to stop them here because they do not pay customs, they have bad, bad, bad products. Chinese are going to destroy our country. They have to go out. Chinese, they are going to kill our economy. Chinese merchants refused to be interviewed for this report, saying their command of French and English was not good enough for an interview, only for making deals. A social commentator, Aboubacar Oumar, tells VOA, Senegal might currently be the world's most open country to Chinese merchants. 'Senegal has what they call an open door market policy which means that government don't interfere in private sector business initiatives,' he said. 'So whoever can come in and invest. What they do is they open the market for competition. So if the Chinese are selling at a cheaper price, what will happen, is if the Senegalese businessmen the way they are complaining, maybe the government will step in to regulate the market and probably put quotas on the Chinese,' added Mr. Oumar. For now, the government has yet to interfere. Chinese wholesalers say they can make several thousand dollars a day being based in Dakar, compared to Senegalese merchants who say they usually struggle to make $100 in a month. The invasion is having an impact in the region as well, as trucks can be heard coming in and out of the Centenaire market, taking the cheap Chinese goods to Mauritania, Mali, the Gambia and even the continent's biggest market, Nigeria. Colombant report: href='http://www.oanews.com/mediaassets/english/2005_09/Audio/rm/colombant_senagal_chinese_23sept05.rm'>http://www.oanews.com/mediaassets/english/2005_09/Audio/rm/colombant_senagal_chinese_23sept05.rm [href='http://www.oanews.com/mediaassets/english/2005_09/Audio/rm/colombant_senagal_chinese_23sept05.rm'>http://www.oanews.com/mediaassets/english/2005_09/Audio/rm/colombant_senagal_chinese_23sept05.rm]. title: 700套房屋建设项目 (Not Cleaned)
description: '2006年11月，中国机械设备进出口总公司与赤几基础设施和城市规划部、财政部和项目办公室签订了700套房屋建设的总包合同，合同金额为5,750万欧元,工期为30个月。2007年01月02日，赤几政府里卡多及其大部分内阁部长参加了该项目的奠基仪式。该工程是落实赤几总统在全国范围内，为改善人民生活居住条件而制定的利民政策中的项目之一。据悉，一系列的利国、利民政策将会通过具体的工程和项目惠及赤几人民。 '

title: Not a project: $500m Investment in Oil Blocs
description: See ID# 1536, 1707, 193'China's state oil firm Sinopec, plans to invest about $500 million on the development of two shallow water oil blocs which lie in Oil Mining Leases (OMLs) 64 and 66.Sinopec is the operator of the two blocs owned by the Nigerian Petroleum Development Company (NDPC).The Federal Government had early this year approved a service contract agreement entered into by the Nigerian National Petroleum Corpo-ration (NNPC) with Sino-pec, which provided for the Chinese oil firm as the lead contractor for a period of three years.At the end of the three year period, NPDC engineers are to take over the operatorship of the blocs, which lie in shallow waters of less than 100 metres in offshore Rivers State.Emerging details of the recent visit by the Chinese economic and trade delegation to Nigeria during which they met with the Special Adviser to the president on Petroleum and Energy, Dr. Edmund Daukoru, revealed that the intending investors sought preferential consideration in the next round of bidding for the deepwater off shore scheduled for 2005.NPDC, the oil producing arm of the NNPC, currently produces at 30,000 barrels per day with reserves level of 300 million barrels.Nigeria, which sees the emergence of the Chinese investors in the country's oil and gas sector as a break in western monopoly, is keen on getting the Chinese involved in the privatisation of the refineries, the pipelines together with the storage depots and the distribution systems, as well as financing of the marginal fields.Thirty-one local oil firms granted licences to operate 24 marginal fields, are currently in search of funds to develop the fields.Chinese businessmen have only recently made known plans to set up projects worth about $7 billion in Nigeria.The investment will be in the area of power generation, crude oil exploration and production, coal processing, setting up of an export refinery and a petrochemical plant and in agriculture.The Federal Government has set up a 15-member steering committee to work out modalities for seeing all the proposed projects through.The committee is headed by Special Adviser to the President on Manufactur-ing and Private Sector, Alhaji Ahmed Abdulkadir, has its members drawn from both the public and private sectors, including Daukoru and four other ministers.The Chinese investors would specifically be pumping $1.5 billion into the development of a Nigerian continental shelf oil bloc, OPL 229.The bloc is owned jointly by two indigenous oil firms, Emerald Energy Resources Limited and Amni International Petroleum.The plan also includes the setting up of an export refinery with a processing capacity of about 180,000 barrels per day (bpd), and the construction of a petrochemical plant by a company known as SinoLink Hydrocarbon Techno-logies. ' 'Paris (Platts)-25Oct2004/837 am EDT/1237 GMT The Nigerian government has set up a technical committee to monitor China's proposal to take over the government's equity in the Port Harcourt and Kaduna oil refineries as well as developing oil blocks 65 and 111, state-owned NNPC's spokesman said Monday. 'There is delegation from China in Abuja as we speak and they are working with us to see what we can achieve. They are definitely interested in the refineries,' he said. The technical committee will also study the possibility of Chinese firms investing in Eleme Petrochemical Company as well as participating in oil exploration in the Chad Basin. The Chinese government has said it plans to invest $500-mil in Nigeria's upstream sector and a further $30-mil for development of the downstream industry. The China Export and Credit Insurance Corp has also pledged $7-bil investment in power generation, coal and agriculture in the next few years.Paris (Platts)-25Oct2004/838 am EDT/1238 GMT Nigeria's presidential adviser on petroleum Edmund Daukoru said the Chinese investments should not be misconstrued to mean that the government is handing over strategic assets China. 'The Chinese are not taking over all the refining opportunities, nothing of that sort is being implied by this business relationship. There is still a level playing field and the more competition we can get the better,' he said, quoted in the ThisDay newspaper. The Bureau of Public Enterprise, the agency managing the government's privatization program, is offering 51% stakes in each of the badly deteriorated Warri, Kaduna and the two Port Harcourt refineries to core investors, while the government, through NNPC, is expected to retain a minority stake. Attracting interest in the four plants, which have suffered years of under-investment, is proving a difficult task. The country's major operators failed to show interest when the bids were called in last November given the enormous investment required to repair the ailing plants, which began operations between 1965 and 1988.Paris (Platts)-25Oct2004/839 am EDT/1239 GMT Bowing to pressure from the country's powerful oil unions, the government last December agreed to invest $150-mil in revamping key production units that would restore production at the plants to full optimal levels before privatization. Daukoru recently told Platts that Shell, which pumps around 1-mil b/d of Nigeria's total production, had expressed interest in taking on a management consultancy role as opposed to direct ownership. Despite having a total domestic refining capacity of 445,000 b/d, Nigeria, Africa's biggest crude producer, is forced to import about 70% of its own fuel requirements. China, in a desperate search for hydrocarbons to sustain its rapid economic development, is building up a network of energy-related relationships throughout west and north Africa particularly Algeria, Egypt, Sudan, Chad, Niger and Gabon. It recently clinched a 50% stake in Angola's deepwater block 18, beating off competition from India's ONGC Videsh by reportedly offering about $2-bil in aid for a raft of projects. ' 'The Nigerian government has set up a technical committee to monitor China's proposal to take over the government's equity in the Port Harcourt and Kaduna oil refineries as well as developing oil blocks 65 and 111, a state-owned Nigerian National Petroleum Corp spokesman said Oct 25.'There is a delegation from China in Abuja as we speak and they are working with us to see what we can achieve. They are definitely interested in the refineries,' he said.The technical committee also will study the possibility of Chinese firms investing in Eleme Petrochemical Co as well as participating in oil exploration in the Chad Basin.The Chinese government has said it plans to invest $500-mil in Nigeria's upstream sector and a further $30-mil for downstream development. The China Export and Credit Insurance Corp also has pledged $7-bil investment in power generation, coal and agriculture in the next few years.Nigeria's presidential adviser on petroleum, Edmund Daukoru, said the Chinese investments should not be misconstrued to mean the government is handing over strategic assets to China. 'The Chinese are not taking over all the refining opportunities, nothing of that sort is being implied by this business relationship. There is still a level playing field and the more competition we can get the better,' he told ThisDay newspaper.China, in a desperate search for hydrocarbons to sustain its rapid economic development, is building up a network of energy-related relationships throughout west and north Africa (see related story).The Bureau of Public Enterprise, the agency managing the government's privatization program, is offering 51% stakes in each of the badly deteriorated Warri, Kaduna and the two Port Harcourt refineries to core investors, while the government, through NNPC, is expected to retain a minority stake.Attracting interest in the four plants, which have suffered years of underinvestment, is proving difficult. The country's major operators failed to show interest last November given the enormous investment required. Daukoru recently told Platts Shell, which pumps around 1-mil b/d in Nigeria, had expressed interest in taking on a management consultancy role as opposed to direct ownership.Bowing to pressure from the country's powerful oil unions, the government last December agreed to invest $150-mil in revamping key production units before privatization. The unions accused NNPC of sabotaging the refineries despite the $700-mil spent on repairs in the last four years to benefit from lucrative fuel import contracts. Seven senior NNPC managers were sacked in April 2003 following an investigation into high port fees paid on imported oil products and the alleged falsification of bills of lading which cost Nigeria some $108-mil last year.Although private oil marketers are now allowed under a deregulation policy introduced last October to import and set prices of gasoline and diesel, the NNPC still plays a major role in fuel imports and distribution.The NNPC spokesman Oct 25 denied reports retail fuel prices had increased to Naira 75/liter ($0.57/liter) and said it would shut marketers caught selling above the Naira 55/liter government ceiling. 'Those are rumors to incite labor to go on strike. Prices are still around Naira 53-54/liter,' an NNPC spokesman said.The Nigeria Labour Congress suspended a four-day warning strike Oct 14 and gave President Olusegun Obasanjo's government two weeks to meet strikers' demands and stabilize prices. Retail prices Sep 23 jumped 20%, the latest in a series of hikes since Obasanjo deregulated sales and removed subsidies.The NNPC spokesman said a new pricing committee set up by the government held regular meetings with NLC and agreed to discuss a mechanism for achieving stability in prices. 'Local prices are not likely to go up any further,' he said.The NLC, the most powerful political opposition to Obasanjo, is holding a meeting of its National Executive Council Oct 26 to decide whether to relaunch its strike. ' 'Chinese firm explores oil in Chad Basin By Chesa Chesa, state house correspondent, Abuja More crude oil will soon flow from Nigerian soil as President Olusegun Obasanjo on Monday midwifed an agreement between a Chinese firm - SINOPEC and the Nigeria National Petroleum Company (NNPC) for the exploration of oil in the Chad Basin.The President, who witnessed the signing of the agreement between NNPC Group Managing Director, Funsho Kupolokun, and the Vice President of SINOPEC, at the presidential villa, also announced that SINOPEC would build a refinery in Nigeria and get fully involved in the upstream and downstream sectors of the petroleum industry.SINOPEC won the oil exploration contract for Blocs 64 and 66 in the Chad Basin, following government's decision to offer 27 oil blocs to investors in order to boost oil production quota from the current 2.6 million to 4 million barrels per day by 2010.Some oil wells being explored in the Chad Basin by Shell, Elf and Chevron were abandoned four years ago on the orders of government.Obasanjo, who assured the Chinese of government's protection of their investments, disclosed that China, which produces 40 percent of television sets in the world, has agreed to produce TV sets in Nigeria.He also announced that a Nigerian telecommunications satellite would be built and launched by a Chinese firm soon, and thanked the Chinese government for providing $2.25 million grant for economic and technological cooperation between the two countries.The president said the federal government has invited China Railway Ministry to come and help develop Nigerian railways.Earlier, the visiting chairman of the Chinese standing committee of the National Peoples Congress, Mr. Wu Bangguo, expressed his country's interest in exploring marginal oil fields in Nigeria.Bangguo, who is on an official trip to Nigeria, said China was equally interested in telecommunications and power generation, and commended the federal government for closing the Taiwan business office in Abuja, as a mark of Nigeria's policy of one China.Meanwhile, President Obasanjo on Monday received strong commendation from the ECOWAS parliament for his 'untiring efforts to bring peace to the sub-region and the entire continent'.Speaker of the parliament, Prof Ali Nouhoum Diallo, who led a delegation of the legislative body to Aso Rock, said the parliament shared and supported Obasanjo's views that Africa's problems were better handled by Africans.Diallo disclosed that the parliament had asked the international community to support Obasanjo's peace efforts and to help African countries recover stolen money stashed in European banks.The president had in his response, commended the ECOWAS parliament for the progress it has made so far towards regional integration. '

title: Package Deal - Irrigation (Duplicate of 1638)
description: 14 April 200209:41 AMPlatts Commodity NewsPLATTEnglishCopyright 2002. Platts. All Rights Reserved.Dubai (Platts)-14Apr2002/941 am EDT/1341 GMT Libya has signed an oil agreement with China as part of a package of deals covering the transportation, farming, irrigation, fishing and the textile sectors, the official Libyan news agency JANA reported Sunday. It gave no details but said the agreement was part of a series of accords agreed by Libyan leader Moammar Qadhafi and visiting Chinese president Jiang Zemin. AFP quoted an official source as saying the agreement offers 'wide-ranging prospects' to Chinese firms in the fields of exploration, development and marketing in Libya's oil sector. Tripoli also agreed on a $40-mil deal for a Chinese company to extend Libya's rail network near the border with Tunisia, the same source said.Document platt00020030719dy4e017

title: Friendship Port continues with financing of new pier (likely duplicate, see ID# 3)
description: Focus China and EU to finance the upgrading of Mauritanian ports. Pieter Tesch 566 words 12 May 2008Lloyd's List LL 6 English (c) 2008 Informa PLC MAURITANIA’s ramshackle port infrastructure is about to be upgraded and updated with major projects at the capital Nouakchott and the northern port of Nouadhibou, Transport Minister Ahmed Ould Mohameden told Lloyd’s List.Mr Mohameden explained thatMauritania has signed an agreement with China for a $300m project to extend the “Friendship Port”, built by the Chinese between 1979 and 1984, with a new 450 m pier.When the desert country in northwest Africa became independent from the French in 1960 there was not even a town at Nouakchott, designated the capital, and for years after independence the French refused to build a port on the nearby Atlantic coast to service the new capital because of their port interests in neighbouring Senegal.But as usual, when western former colonial powers refuse to invest in infrastructural projects in Africa, the Chinese step in.They have now agreed to extend the port facilities because Nouakchott, now home to nearly one third of just under 3m Mauritanians, is thriving. The country is benefitting from investment in its fledgling offshore industry alongside investment in its two other pillars of export: iron ore and other minerals, as well as the fishing industry.Following a visit in April of Dubai World’s chairman Sultan bin Sulayem, Mr Mohameden is negotiating with United Arab Emirates and other Gulf interests on another project that could extend the new planned pier by another 450 m.“This project will include a new container terminal as well, with refrigerating facilities, and a designated free zone to attract further investment to the commercial port,” said Mr Mohameden.He added that, in conjunction with these projects, the government wants to transform the artisanal fishing port, where canoes still land on the beach, into amodern fishing port big enough not only for modern seagoing trawlers but also to handle reefer hips for the export of frozen fish.The government has plans for processing plants to be established around the port as part of a strategy to increase substantially its fish-processing capacity and to increase value-added fish exports.A similar plan is about to be implemented for the northern commercial and fishing port of Nouadhibou, formerly St Etienne, on Cape Blanc, with plans to extend and build new quays and piers for the commercial and fishing ports here, said Mr Mohameden.He explained that tenders would soon be invited for the quay extensions, financed with European Union development money, which will include the deepening of the draught to 8 m for the commercial port and 6 m for the fishing port, as well as land reclamation.Nouadhibou port has the advantage over Nouakchott of being a natural shelter, but neglect during the 1980s and 1990s means that numerous shipwrecks of former Soviet Union and Eastern Block trawlers and factory ships have made the port unsightly and dangerous in places.It was hoped that the EU would assist in funding to clear these wrecks and finance a feasibility study into the further development of the iron ore port, just south of Nouadhibou, said Mr Mohameden.“The Chinese will start their work before the end of the year and the whole project, including the 450 m new pier, should be finished within three years. It is hoped that other projects will start within that period,” he said.1086889125

title: Chinese troops pour into Sudan to fight rebels (TRUE?)
description: 28 August 2000National Post FINP National A12 English (c) National Post 2000. All Rights Reserved. LONDON - Tens of thousands of Chinese have been moved into Sudan in preparation for a major offensive against southern rebels to try to end one of Africa's longest-running conflicts, according to Western counter-terrorism officials. The Chinese, a mixture of prisoners and soldiers, have been brought in by aircraft and ship, ostensibly to guard Sudan's increasingly productive oilfields in which the China National Petroleum Corp. is a leading partner. Colonel Johnny Garang's Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) has managed in recent weeks to advance within 16 kilometres of the oilfields in the Upper Nile region, causing the country's Islamic regime to activate emergency plans drawn up with allies whose interests in the oil project are directly under threat. These plans aim to crush the rebels from the mainly Christian and animist south and bring to an end the 17-year civil war that has cost an estimated two million lives. Since oil production began last year, arms have been arriving from Libya, Qatar and China. The ruling National Islamic Front (NIF) is spending US$450-million a year of its oil revenues on weapons, according to Western intelligence sources. The NIF denies this charge but last month General Mohamed Osman Yassin, the Sudanese army spokesman, told student conscripts that 'thanks to our growing oil industry'' Sudan is now 'manufacturing ammunition, mortars, tanks and armoured personnel carriers.' The SPLA captured a group of Chinese in an attack last week. An internal document from the Sudanese military said that as many as 700,000 Chinese security personnel were available for action. Baroness Caroline Cox, a British human rights campaigner who has just returned from Sudan where she helped free 353 slaves captured by NIF soldiers, accused Western governments of turning a blind eye to what is going on because of their own economic interests in the oil. 'If with foreign help the NIF regime crushes all opposition, we will have entrenched in the heart of Africa a militant Islamist regime aimed at spreading terrorism throughout the continent,'' she warned. 'It's unbelievably serious for the future of democracy in Africa and could happen in the next few weeks.'' She criticized the British government, which last month welcomed the Sudanese Foreign Minister on a visit even though Sudan is still technically under United Nations sanctions that ban such visits, and is officially still regarded as a pariah state. 'The British government has developed a complete cosy relationship to a regime, which is raping, bombing and taking its people into slavery,'' she said. Two British companies have won contracts to build pumping stations on the 1,600-kilometre pipeline from the Heglig oilfield, in the war-torn south, to the Red Sea. Canadian multinational Talisman Energy has also faced public outcry over its involvement in the pipeline. Lloyd Axworthy, Canada's Foreign Minister, sent a mission to Sudan to assess the situation. A UN official told the mission: 'If oil companies don't know what's going on they're not looking over the fences of their compounds.'' On Saturday, the U.S. government condemned the raids on civilian and relief targets including schools, hospitals and feeding stations. According to the SPLA, five such attacks took place last week. A Western aid worker from one of the few organizations operating in southern Sudan said: 'Eeryone knows what is going on. We'e all seen the Chinese being brought in and can only pray about what's going to happen next.''
recipient_agencies: China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC), State-Owned Company

title: $3b energy investment (not in Somalia)
description: 'Text of report by Turkish newspaper Yeni Safak website on 28 December[Column by Ibrahim Karagul: 'Abizaid Sparks Dirty War With One Visit!']A third front has been opened in addition to Central Asia and the Middle East. After Afghanistan, Iraq, Lebanon and Palestine this fifth conflict has been sparked off in Somalia in East Africa, known as the Horn of Africa, a land at least as important as Yemen or the Gulf of Basra or the Eastern Mediterranean. Immediately after 9/11 the United States turned Djibouti into a military base and put the Red Sea under blockade. It is now occupying another country again citing Islamists, terrorism and Al-Qa'idah. But this time it is not doing this directly but with the soldiers of Somalia's neighbour Ethiopia. Ethiopian soldiers, trained, armed and financed by the United States, have been occupying Somalia for several days now and bombing it from the air while the US Navy has laid a sea blockade. How much does Somalia concern us? As much as Afghanistan? As much as Iraq? As much as Lebanon? Believe me it concerns us as much as all of them. The war in Somalia is so very connected to the Lebanon and Iraq crises.Somalia is a poor country devastated by civil war. But that does not concern anybody. Again it is energy, again energy! After the civil war in 1993 and the US intervention fighting again broke out this summer. The Islamist groups were able to take control of a large part of the country despite the war lords and their terrorist organizations. During the fighting in June the United States openly gave financing and weapons to the terrorist groups fighting the Islamist groups, and took part in the fighting through clandestine operations. But, it failed. The Islamists took Mogadishu.I wrote back then, 'Somalia is being turned into a new target for the United States.' Now it is coming true. The Ethiopian army has been attacking Somalia for a few days now. It is occupying Somalia lands and bombing everywhere. The United States, which earlier supported the anti-Islamist groups, is now occupying Somalia using the 15,000-strong Ethiopian army, which it has trained, financed and armed. So, what is the reason for this war? I wrote it once before. Let me repeat:The United States conducted a bloody operation into Somalia using thousands of soldiers in 1993. But there was a terrible disaster. It was a complete fiasco. There was even a movie made about the operation, 'Black Hawk Down.' The aim, as always, was humanitarian intervention! Yet five US companies had all but closed off two thirds of Somalia in order to carry out soundings for oil and gas. This operation was conducted in order to provide security for these companies' interests. The plan failed and these companies' interests were still in jeopardy.In recent years Sudan has emerged as a very important oil country. China, which is opening up across all of Africa and which is forming a balance to offset the United States, made $3 billion of energy investments in Sudan. Sudan was going to meet a significant amount of Beijing's energy needs. Furthermore, it was going to lay an oil pipeline from the south to the Red Sea. China and other Asian oil companies took control of energy investments in many African countries. Furthermore, they started to rebuild the countries they were cooperating with in order to save them from the West's technological and economic pressure. The United States responded to Asia's ventures into Sudan with oil-and gas-rich Darfur. Bringing the UN to its side the United States began a humanitarian intervention project in Darfur because Darfur was emerging as another energy resource. China announced it would veto the UN's resolutions on Darfur and Sudan. They were using Darfur to make Sudan pay the price of collaboration with China. Now, they are making Somalia pay.Just like Yemen, Somalia is a critical country for energy security. If it falls into the hands of others the United States' corridor between Africa and the Middle East will collapse. The United States and its allies, who have been laying siege to the Horn of Africa militarily since 9/11, have all but occupied the Red Sea in the name of fighting Al-Qa'idah and terrorism. Whatever the United States' reason is for invading Afghanistan, whatever its reason is for taking Yemen under control; that is the same reason it has for controlling Somalia.Somalia is not an oil-rich country. Its known reserves are some 200 billion cubic meters of natural gas. But it is known that the country harbours very rich oil and natural gas resources, and that it provides a new opportunity for the United States both by virtue of its own resources and the fact that it straddles the transit route for Middle East oil. US oil companies such as Conoco, Amoco, Chevron and Philips wanted the country to be made secure and for soundings to begin immediately. As a result of this the United States began to offer financial and military support to the warlords in the country. The 'International Crisis Group' established by George Soros took its place on the stage.The operation in 1993 was restarted in a different shape. The way ahead for these companies was going to open up. Civil war again erupted as the result of clandestine operations. This was a new front in the great energy war and the geopolitical game. But the calculations did not stick. The anti-US forces won. They took the capital after four months of fighting. This was the United States' second defeat in Somalia. But less than six months later the United States went in again but this time via Ethiopia. It placed a naval blockade on Somalia. They had been gearing up for this fight since 2001 in order to open the way for the oil companies. Now they have begun. This conflict could spread to East Africa. The whole region could go up in flames all for the sake of controlling the Red Sea.Another note to the cautious: General John Abizaid, who is in charge of the US armies in Iraq, was in Ethiopia this month. A few days later the Ethiopian army acting with the United States switched to the attack. Interesting, is it not? Immediately after China's Head of State Hu Jintao went to Kenya, Sudan and Ethiopia and made energy agreements. We have a new Afghanistan, a new Iraq, anew Lebanon. Somalia, the fifth Muslim country to be drenched in blood as the giants fight, might be along way from you but it is very close to the United States and China.Source: Yeni Safak website, Istanbul, in Turkish 28 Dec 06a5999adbDocument BBCEUP0020061229e2ct000b5'

title: de-mining training courses and donated de-mining equipment (Duplicate)
description: Full Text: China's National Defense in 2008 (36) 侯丽军 563 words 19 January 2009 09:21 PMXinhua News Agency XNEWS English (c) 2009 Xinhua News Agency Prevention of the Introduction of Weapons and an Arms Race in Outer SpaceThe Chinese government has all along advocated the peaceful use of outer space, and opposed the introduction of weapons and an arms race in outer space. The existing international legal instruments concerning outer space are not sufficient to effectively prevent the spread of weapons to outer space. The international community should negotiate and conclude a new international legal instrument to close the loopholes in the existing legal system concerning outer space.In February 2008 China and Russia jointly submitted to the CD a draft Treaty on the Prevention of the Placement of Weapons in Outer Space and the Threat or Use of Force against Outer Space Objects. China hopes that the CD will start substantial discussions on the draft as soon as possible, and negotiate and conclude the Treaty at an early date.Conventional Arms ControlChina has earnestly fulfilled its obligations under the Convention on Certain Conventional Weapons (CCW) and its Protocols. It has taken concrete measures to ensure that its anti-personnel landmines in service meet the relevant technical requirements of the Amended Protocol on Landmines. China actively participates in the work of the Group of Governmental Experts (GGE) on Cluster Munitions. China is also continuing its preparations for ratifying the Protocol on Explosive Remnants of War. China has continuously taken an active part in international humanitarian de-mining assistance. In the past two years, it has held de-mining training courses for Angola, Mozambique, Chad, Burundi, Guinea-Bissau, and both northern and southern Sudan. China has also donated de-mining equipment to the above-mentioned countries and Egypt, and provided Peru, Ecuador and Ethiopia with mine eradication funds.China has actively participated in the international efforts to combat the illicit trade in Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW). It has conscientiously implemented the UN Program of Action (PoA) on SALW and the International Instrument on Identifying and Tracing Illicit SALW. China has issued and implemented new detailed rules on SALW markings, and has taken part in the work of the UN GGE on an 'Arms Trade Treaty'.Transparency in Military Expenditures and Registration of Transfer of Conventional ArmsChina attaches great importance to military transparency, and makes unremitting efforts to enhance military transparency and promote mutual trust with other countries in the military sphere. In 2007 China joined the UN Standardized Instrument for Reporting Military Expenditures, and reports annually to the UN the basic data of its military expenditures for the latest fiscal year.China has made important contributions to the establishment and development of the UN Register of Conventional Arms. After the Register was established, China provided the Register with annual data on imports and exports of conventional arms in the seven categories covered by the Register. However, since 1996 a particular country has provided data on its arms sales to Taiwan to the Register, which contradicts the spirit of the relevant Resolutions of the UN General Assembly as well as the objectives and principles of the Register. China was impelled to suspend its submission of data to the Register. Since the country concerned has stopped the above-mentioned act, China has resumed, since 2007, submitting data annually to the Register on imports and exports of conventional arms in the seven categories. Enditem01Document XNEWS00020090120e51k000r
sector: Humanitarian and Disaster Relief and Preparation

title: 25,000 seat stadium -UNKNOWN- (Inactive: stadium built before 2000)
description: Guinea-Bissau's President Malam Bacai Sanha on Wednesday inaugurated his government's new 25-million-dollar headquarters, entirely built with Chinese funding.The building, situated in the north of the capital Bissau, took 18 months to build and consists of three large blocks that can accommodate 12 ministries.It is 'a symbol of the fruitful cooperation long held with China who we thank from the bottom of our hearts,' said Sanha at the inauguration.At Sanha's side was the Chinese ambassador to Guinea-Bissau, Li Bao Jun.'It is the fruit of frank and enduring cooperation,' said Li.China has already played a hand in other projects in Bissau including the National Assembly, built in 2000 for six million dollars, a military hospital with 200 beds that cost 12 million dollars, as well as a 25,000-seat stadium.Beijing has also financed renovation work on barracks, hospitals and has invested in the west African country's agriculture sector.China is interested in offshore oil exploration and the vast forest and fishing wealth of Guinea-Bissau.But the country has been chronically unstable since independence from Portugal in 1974 with coups, army mutinies and political murders. It has also in recent years been turned into a drug trafficking hub by South American barons targetting European markets.
sector: Trade, Tourism, Banking and Financial Services

title: China's Aid to Slow Desert Spread (Not a project)
description: INTERVIEW-Women's help vital in slowing spread of deserts By Ben Blanchard 507 words 31 May 2006 07:42 AMReuters News LBA English (c) 2006 Reuters Limited BEIJING, May 31 (Reuters) - Women, who make up about 70 percent of rural workers worldwide, are key to turning back the spread of deserts, the head of the United Nations' main agency on rural poverty said on Wednesday. Desertification and land degradation threatens the livelihoods of over one billion people in more than 100 countries and causes annual economic losses of $6.5 billion, according to the U.N. And it is women who must be bought into the fight against the spreading sands, Lennart Bage, president of the Rome-based International Fund for Agricultural Development, told Reuters in an interview. 'Women are very often at the frontline of fighting desertification, or managing land degradation, because very often, in many parts of the world, women are the farmers,' he said, sitting in the U.N.'s Beijing offices. 'Women are crucial, as very often they are the ones responsible for the family for getting fuel wood, water and for tending the fields,' Bage added. 'They often know a lot about resource management.' With spreading deserts making it harder to eke out a living on the land, many men are leaving for urban areas, leaving their families behind and women to confront worsening soil and climatic conditions. 'You have migration taking place, and in many societies the men migrate. So they leave the household and they send back money, but to keep the fields growing and livestock tended to, it's very often left to women and children,' Bage said. About 70 percent of the fund's projects are located in marginal areas, often being affected by desertification. Oer the last 23 years, they have pumped in $3.5 billion to help dry and desertified regions from China to Mauritania. Yet in many African countries, women are denied land ownership and do not even have the right to plant trees or build sand control measures. They also often farm the worst, most marginal land. And it is hard for them to get collateral for bank loans to improve their land. 'We have a policy and a goal to include a gender dimension in all the projects we're involved in. It is key,' said Bage, a Swedish national with more than 25 years in international development. And aid must be directed in a culturally appropriate way, taking into account local conditions, especially the role women play in society, he said. 'The disregard for local knowledge and local commitment ... is one of the main reasons for the failure of so much well intentioned aid.' But desertification is still a problem that has not been beaten. 'In some areas we're winning, but in some areas we're losing,' he said. 'You can't be complacent about it. It's certainly a losing battle in some of the poorest parts of the world.' ENVIRONMENT-DESERT (INTERVIEW)|LANGEN|AFA|CSA|LBY|RWSA|RWS|REULB|GNS|G|RBN|RNA|Z|ABN|C|GRO|MTL|SOF|SXNADocument LBA0000020060531e25000u4

title: US$11 million interest-free Chinese Loan to build houses in Luanda, Angola (Duplicate)
description: BDUEnglishCopyright 2003 China Daily Information Company. All rights reserved.China and Angola, despite the long distance between the two countries, have been enjoying good relations especially in the field of economy and trade.The economic cooperation between the Asian and African nations could date back to 1983 when the bilateral diplomatic relationship was established.However, due to the 27-year civil war in Angola, the economic ties have not been fully developed although there were some Chinese companies doing business in Angola before the end of the war in April last year.Since early 1990s, the trade between the two countries began to develop gradually. In 2000, the trade volume reached US$1.876 billion compared with US$150 million in 1995.According to some estimation, the trade volume could stand at US$2 billion this year as the first nine months have seen it reaching US$1.7 billion.In order to accelerate the reconstruction of country after the civil war, the government of President Jose Eduardo dos Santos has put forward an 'economic diplomacy' policy to attract foreign investment and technology and further develop trade with other countries.Two projects funded by the Chinese government on rebuilding the telecommunication network in three Angolan provinces and repairing some parts of Angolan railways have been carried out in October and November this year respectively.Besides, the Chinese government also provided Angola with economic aid in terms of grants and interest-free loans to the African country to help the displaced.The 15,000-sq. meter economic houses in Luanda, capital of Angola, built by a Chinese company with US$11 million of interest-free loan from the Chinese government have been deeply welcomed by the Angolan people.After seeing what the Chinese government companies have done in Angola, President dos Santos more than once expressed his hope that more Chinese businessmen would come to Angola to invest, trade and participate in the reconstruction of the country.Angola, a country with rich natural resources such as oil and diamond, needs assistance from other countries including China for rebuilding, dos Santos said.As the trade between China and Angola is complementary, the bilateral economic cooperation will surely come to a new high in the process of reconstructing Angola.Document BDU0000020031124dzbo0000p
donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency

description: GENEVA, December 12 (Xinhua) - China supports the international treaty that bans and restricts the use of inhumane conventional weapons and is encouraging more countries to accept it, a senior Chinese disarmament official said on Monday.At the Second Annual Conference of High Contracting Parties to the Amended Protocol II, the head of the Chinese delegation, Sha Zukang, brought up the Convention on Prohibitions or Restrictions on the Use of Conventional Weapons Which May Be Deemed Excessively Injurious or to Have Indiscriminate Effects.'The Chinese delegation has noted that, since the last annual conference, the number of countries that have acceded to the amended protocol has increased from 45 to 58,' said Sha. 'This shows that more and more countries attach importance to the Protocol, which is the first international legal instrument to address this issue of humanitarian concern. Now, almost all major land mine producing and using countries have acceded to the protocol.'However, Sha said, 58 states are too few. 'Lack of universality will undercut the protocol's significance,' he stressed. 'And no matter how perfect an international legal instrument is, its influence and effectiveness will be limited in the absence of universal participation.'He urged the states to follow the Protocol in earnest.Sha announced that the Chinese delegation is strongly opposed to any proposal for further amending the protocol at the current stage.However, he said, states may, on a voluntary basis, take the lead in implementing technical specifications as outlined in the proposed amendments and provide gratuitous technical assistance, equipment and training to developing countries.On humanitarian de-mining, Sha said that the Chinese government is continuing to cooperate with the Mine Action Service of the United Nations Department of Peace-Keeping Operations by co-sponsoring another training workshop on de-mining technology from May to June this year, with trainees from Angola, Ethiopia, Mozambique, and Rwanda.The Chinese government is pressing rapidly ahead with its donations of de-mining equipment to Cambodia, Angola, Mozambique, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Rwanda and Namibia, he added.'We hope this conference will strengthen exchanges and cooperation on de-mining technologies for reducing and ultimately doing away with land mines Sha said.He emphasized that the Chinese government stands ready to cooperate and exchange with interested countries and inter-organizations in the field of humanitarian de-mining assistance and that China is also willing to join other states and explore ways to streamline the de-mining process.Document xnews00020010818dwcc01d3t

title: agricultural products would be allowed into China duty-free (Duplicate)
description: Like other African leaders, Ethiopian Prime Minister Meles Zenawi returned home from a three-day summit in Beijing with enthusiastic praise for his hosts and an armful of new economic agreements. More Ethiopian agricultural products would be allowed into China duty-free, he revealed, and China had pledged some $500 mn for various development projects in Ethiopia. 'China is an inspiration for all of us,' he added. 'What China shows to Africa is that it is indeed possible to turn the corner on economic development.' Fifty years after China established its first diplomatic ties with an African country, the third summit of the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation was held 3-5 November. It marked the biggest-ever gathering between Chinese and African leaders. All 48 African countries that have diplomatic relations with China took part - with most of their delegations led by presidents or prime ministers. In addition, hundreds of African businesspeople went for a two-day trade exhibit immediately following the summit, eager to explore new market outlets in the most populous country in the world, which has one of the fastest growing economies.
sector: Trade, Tourism, Banking and Financial Services

title: road construction pact (Not a project)
description: Excerpt from report in English by pro-Ethiopian government Walta Information Centre website on 31 July Addis Ababa, 31 July: The Ethiopian Roads Authority has signed an agreement with the Chinese overseas contractor, China Gezhouba Group Corporation (CGGC) for the construction of the Shire-Adi Abune [in northern Ethiopia] road with over 443m birr [50m dollars]. The agreement was singed between the authority's general manager, Zayid Woldegebriel, and CGGC Deputy General Manager Peng Yuanping. Zayid said on the occasion that the 83-km Shire-Adi Abune road has been exhausted due to long years of service and it would be upgraded to asphalt road. Construction of the road will be carried out with 429m birr while the consultancy and supervision activities [will be conducted] with 14.8m birr, Zayid said. Some 70 per cent of the cost for the construction will be obtained on loan from the World Bank while 30 per cent will be allocated by the government, the general manager indicated. [Passage omitted] Source: Walta Information Centre website, Addis Ababa, in English 31 Jul 07

title: all-packed economic and trade project (Duplicate)
description: November 12, 2008 (ADDIS ABABA) - China proposed to Ethiopia to enhance bilateral relations through expanding joint cooperation and coordinate their positions on world affairs to safeguard their interests. The offer was made during a visit by the speaker of the Chinese parliament Wu Bangguo to the country from November 8 to 10, the official Xinhua reported. Wu, chairman of the Standing Committee of China's National People's Congress (NPC), called on in his meeting with Ethiopian Prime Minister Meles Zenawi that the ruling parties, legislature and governments of the two nations to step up exchange and cooperation.Wu also proposed the two nations to focus on three key projects that he believed would be vital to foster the bilateral cooperation, referring to an agriculture technology demonstration center, an all-packed economic and trade project including the construction of hydropower stations and the establishment of an oriental industrial zone to attract investment from Chinese companies. 'China encourage its companies to expand investment in Ethiopia and will adopt open policies on technology transfer and as well as training program for the Ethiopian personnel,' Wu told Meles. Echoing on Wu's proposal, Meles said the Ethiopia-China cooperation has become an important drive for the country's development. The cooperation with China is of vital importance to push forward Ethiopia's development and the Ethiopian government highly values it, Meles noted. He said the Ethiopia would make its efforts to further implement the projects between the two sides and consolidate the cooperation in fields such as agriculture, infrastructure and human resource. (ST)

title: Hotel Sheraton Oran
description: China State Construction Engineering Corporation (CSCEC) started the construction of the hotel Sheraton Oran in northwestern Algeria in the middle of March 2002. The first phase of the construction reportedly required some $92 mln. The joint Algerian-Libyan Hotel Company SHO pledged to provide provide some $120 mln  to finance the project and the main partner, Algerian Hotel Investment Company, SIH, announced it would take part in the project by providing an area of 4,500 sq m for the construction. Work appears to have been completed by 2004.  The hotel is an 8-floor building with 407 rooms, conference halls, sports halls, and shops.
