title: Grant to Namibia
description: Chinese benefaction to Namibia in particular held steadfast on Monday when President Hu Jintao announced a N$1-billion soft loan and also offered N$60 million in the form of an interest-free loan, a grant and dozens of scholarships.Hu made the announcement in Windhoek during the fifth leg of his marathon tour of eight African countries some of which have received substantial sums of money in aid while in the same vein benefiting from debt-cancellation from the Asian giant.Hu said during talks with President Hifikepunye Pohamba that China would further avail US$100 million in buyers' credit and build youth-training centres in Namibia.Because Namibia is among the few African countries officially designated a tourism destination by the Chinese government, some of the money would go towards boosting its market share of the rapidly expanding Chinese tourism industry, particularly group tours.During the official talks on Monday that preceded the signing ceremony for the soft loans and other bilateral aid, Pohamba told his counterpart that Namibia has numerous opportunities for investment in the fields of agriculture, tourism, aquaculture, mining, energy, technology and infrastructure and human development.'In this regard, we are inviting Chinese entrepreneurs to come and form joint ventures and other business partnerships with their Namibian counterparts for the mutual benefit of both countries,' Pohamba said at the meeting held with Hu at a local hotel.He assured Chinese investors that they have nothing to fear because Namibia offers a conducive business environment in line with the Reciprocal Treaty on the Promotion and Protection of Investment signed by the two nations.China's tremendous economic and social growth, elevating it to a global economic powerhouse, was also commended by President Pohamba who said Namibia 'would like to emulate' the Asian nation's successes and learn from 'your tremendous experience'.'Namibia needs partners in the promotion and realization of industrial development, investment and local value addition which are all critical for the achievement of our national development goals as set out in our National Development Plans and Vision 2030,' the Head of State said at a meeting that included several cabinet ministers.He said the recent Beijing Summit of the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation reached common ground on major international political and economic issues, especially on the reform of the United Nations and the maintenance of international peace and security.'Namibia supports the China-Africa policy, which is based on peaceful co-existence and anchored on the values of sincerity, equality and mutual common development,' he said.And Namibia being a member of the Troika of the SADC Organ on Politics, Defence and Security, shall continue to support regional efforts aimed at conflict prevention.And equally important Pohamba reaffirmed his government's full support 'for the one-China policy and to reiterate our position that Taiwan is an integral part of China.'Hu said the cooperation between Namibia and China has been growing steadfastly in the fields of politics, economics, education, public health and culture.Since taking office in March 2005, Pohamba has actively promoted bilateral ties with China, and according to the news agency AP, trade between the two nations in the first 11 months of 2006 amounted to US$240 million, an increase of 103 percent from 2005.Hu, whose 130-strong delegation included his wife Liu Yongqing and several senior ministers and high-ranking officials, left yesterday morning for South Africa.//CHINA has offered Government one billion Namibian dollars as a concessional loan over a three-year period until 2010, plus another N$720 million as a credit line, The Namibian established yesterday.The offer was made on Monday during bilateral talks shortly before Chinese President Hu Jintao wrapped up his brief visit of barely 23 hours to Namibia yesterday morning.After talks with Namibian President Hifikepunye Pohamba on Monday, a new grant and an interest-free loan agreement worth N$60 million were signed at a brief public signing ceremony.The state visit culminated with a banquet held in honour of Hu and his 130-member delegation.The Permanent Secretary in the Finance Ministry confirmed the huge amount yesterday afternoon.'The N$1 billion is in the form of a concessional loan, which means that Namibia can use those funds on projects it will decide on,' Calle Schlettwein told The Namibian.'The second offer of US$ 00 million (about N$720 million) is a concessional credit line.This will enable our Government to acquire goods, services and equipment from China,' Schlettwein added.He said Government still had to decide whether it would accept the offer.'We will then have to decide on which projects we will use those funds and then negotiate the loan terms,' he explained.After Hu's departure, the two countries issued a joint communique, but the loan offer was not mentioned.Namibia and China expressed their satisfaction with the strong ties that exist between them as well as political trust and good co-operation.'Both heads of state recognised the achievements made in trade and agreed to work together to strengthen co-operation in mining, agriculture, tourism, manufacturing and human resources development,' the communique stated.Both countries now have four agreements in place: trade and economic co-operation, establishing a joint commission on trade and economic co-operation, a reciprocal treaty for the protection of trade and investments for both Chinese and Namibian businesspeople in China and Namibia.The fourth agreement was signed in Beijing last November during the Forum for China-Africa Co-operation (Focac).The Namibia Investment Centre and a similar institution in China, the China investment Promotion Agency (CIPA), agreed to promote and facilitate investment between the two countries.After Hu left, some 35 Chinese businesspeople who are part of his official delegation remained behind in Windhoek for a business presentation on Namibia as an investment destination.It was organised by the Namibia Investment Centre and the Ministry of Trade and Industry and some 50 Namibian captains of industry attended the session.Minister Immanuel Ngatjizeko called on the Chinese executives to form joint ventures with their Namibian counterparts and to invest in local value addition of the country's raw materials.'It is imperative that during all your deliberations and interactions, value addition should become your central strategy of engagement,' Ngatjizeko urged.//Mar 27, 2007 (The Namibian/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) --GOVERNMENT will engage a Chinese software company to install an electronic management system for the public service.Cabinet approved that the Office of the Prime Minister could secure funding under a concessional loan agreement signed last month between China and Namibia during the state visit of Chinese president Hu Jintao for the implementation of an Electronic Documentation and Records Management System (EDRMS) across the public service.This is viewed as a critical project in terms of existing e-governance policy directives.China offered over N$1 billion as a loan for projects to be identified by Namibia.The EDRMS project team evaluated various appropriate software solutions and found that the system offered by Chinese outfit CA-China SS Software Technology would be best suited for the requirements of the Namibian public service.'The system is not only government user friendly, but also offers easy-to-use interfaces and robust application software that will link up with already familiar public service platforms to ensure records and archival compliance,' Information Minister Netumbo Nandi-Ndaitwah told reporters last week.Cabinet therefore endorsed the EDRMS under the auspices of the Office of the Prime Minister on condition that it complies with tender procedures.Cabinet instructed the Office of the Prime Minister, the Ministry of Finance and the National Planning Commission to discuss the conditions, terms, modality of accessing the preferential loan and credit facility to finance the EDRMS and other priority projects in Namibia with the Chinese Government.Cabinet also granted approval for the arrangement of the grant and the use of the concessional loans for the EDRMS project by the Export-Import Bank of China, subject to concurrence by the Chinese Government.The company CA-CSS is a joint venture formed by New York-based commercial software associates (CA) and China National Computer Software   Technology Service Corporation (CS S).The primary goal of the joint venture was to explore the huge potential presented by the Chinese software market by leveraging the resources and expertise from both parties.The company's head office is in Beijing, China.//Bilateral trade aside, the visit to Namibia in 2007 of Chinese President Hu Jintao during his historic tour of several African countries, resulted in China offering Namibia concessional loans amounting to RMB1 billion. And it also generously extended a preferential line of credit that is interest-free to the tune of US$100 million.From the concessional loan, an amount of RMB41 million was used for the procurement of software and for the implementation of the e-governance project for Namibia, while RMB300 million was used for the procurement of X-ray equipment from China.RMB645 million from the concessional loan funded three developmental projects including for the implementation of one of the phases of the Northern Railway Line as well as the upgrading of the Oshakati State Hospital in northern Namibia, which she noted: 'was very run down and needed to be upgraded'.Part of these funds was used to give a facelift and expansion of the Namibian Broadcasting Corporation (NBC), whose facilities were built during the colonial era.'The Namibian side is satisfied with the implementation of these projects,' she said.She said since her deployment as Chinese Ambassador to Namibia, she has worked tirelessly to ensure that the eight areas of cooperation measures promised by President Hu Jintao at the China Africa Summit held in Beijing in 2006 such as the provision of full support to African countries, that such as assistance to rural schools and hospitals are fulfilled.'Since I came to Namibia, I have been working very hard to implement the eight measures promised by President Hu Jintao at the China-Africa Beijing Summit. Since my arrival, my job was to consolidate different relations and to further the friendship and areas of cooperation. Since my arrival, our mutual trust has grown,' she said.The eight measures announced by the Chinese president included the doubling of grant assistance and providing US$3 billion soft loans and US$2 billion preferential buyer's credit in three years setting up a China-Africa development fund which will be injected with US$5 billion to encourage Chinese companies to invest in Africa.Other measures are: building a conference centre for the African Union, cancelling debts owed by heavily indebted and the least developed African countries, further opening up China's vast market to Africa by largely increasing the number of African export items to China that receive zero-tariff treatment and strengthening cooperation in the fields of agriculture, human resource enhancement, health and education.The inception of the Forum of China-Africa Cooperation (FOCAC) brought tangible benefits to Namibia such as the building of the regional council buildings in Rundu and Outapi, the New State House, the fishery laboratory at Kamutjonga Inland Fisheries Institute in Kavango, the Defence Academy (Okahandja), and the Youth Training Centre.China also availed grants amounting to RMB20 million and it helped to fund a large hospital at Omuthiya where a groundbreaking ceremony has occurred.She said China has provided over 300 training opportunities to Namibians in various fields while at the same time it has seconded a medical team at the Katutura State Hospital. There are several Chinese experts working at grassroots level while rural women and youth empowerment projects have all benefited from China's generosity.At current exchange rates, US$1 is equivalent to RMB6.8.//No18, 2011 (The Namibian/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- THE Ministry of Works and Transport has drawn Government into taking a Chinese loan that was rejected two years ago as 'onerous' in a road-building contract that has also bypassed official open tender process.The Permanent Secretary in the ministry, George Simataa, told The Namibian that the construction of the two roads - between Omakange and Ruacana and between Omafo and Outapi in northern Namibia - will be funded with a Chinese loan but that the Ministry of Finance is yet to apply or approve the loan. The roads are expected to cost about N$1 billion.The Namibian has it on good authority that the loan in question is the same controversial package that the Government ditched in 2009 after Teko Trading, a company owned by two Namibians and a Chinese national now facing corruption charges, was exposed as having received kic-backs of N$120 million from China when the Government bought customs scanning equipment for N$550 million.Teko Trading was said to be the 'local representative' for Nuctech (the Chinese company) although the Ministry of Finance said it had no knowledge of the company's dubious middle-man role.Teko Trading, owned by Public Service Commissioner Teckla Lameck, Kongo Mokaxwa and Chinese national Yung Fan, were supposed to be the 'local representatives' for China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export, and were experted to earn at least 10 per cent 'commission' from the N$1,1 billion tender to complete the 65km northern railway line between Ondangwa and Oshikango.Government dropped that loan agreement, with then Permanent Secretary of Finance Calle Schlettwein calling it 'onerous' and Simataa arguing in documents that the loan was 'risky because of foreign exchange fluctuations'.In a series of e-mails this week, Simataa said two Chinese firms, China Gezhouba Group International Engineering and China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export, have been selected to build the two roads mentioned earlier.While his reply on Tuesday was categorical that the two companies were selected to do the job, after he was asked to elaborate or give definite answers, on Wednesday he changed saying they still have to negotiate and agree on pricing after which they will sign technical and framework agreements.'It is only at that stage that the Ministry of Finance will be approached to apply for a loan from the Chinese Government,' Simataaa said in an e-mail on Wednesday.Asked if it is a condition of the loan that the work be given to Chinese companies he was evasive, saying 'these are Chinese-financed projects. One of their conditions is that the projects should be carried [out] by Chinese firms'.Having already gone ahead with the project, Simataa would also not say for certain whether the ministry was given tender exemption for the work, saying only that proper tender regulations were followed. When pressed if the construction of the two roads were put out on official and open tender Simataa said 'no', citing Chinese loan conditions that Chinese companies be used on the projects. Simataa and the Ministry of Works have been named in research documents as the main culprits in regularly demanding and getting exemptions from public tender regulations.It is unclear why Simataa and the ministry have decided to return to the Chinese loan that they criticised a couple of years ago. There are no indications this time that Teko Trading would be involved.The China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export northern railway line contract was cancelled after it was challenged in the High Court because of alleged tender irregularities.

title: Simandou iron mine
description: raised $15.2bn from a rights issue to form a production joint ventureSimandouIvanhoe MinesRio Tinto and Chinalco have resurrected plans jointly to develop a rich iron ore deposit in Guinea in the first of several moves aimed at repairing the Anglo-Australian miner's strained relationship with Beijing.Both parties are in late stage talks to develop Simandou, one of the world's highest-quality undeveloped iron ore concessions, according to a person close to the situation. Rio in 2008 estimated project development would cost $6bn but analysts now believe it could be closer to $12bn.Chinese steelmakers became Rio's most important customer by far last year. But Rio's relations with China froze last summer starting in June when the miner spurned a $19.5bn capital injection fromChinalco, a state-owned aluminium producer that remains Rio's largest shareholder.The tabular content relating to this article is not available to view. Apologies in advance for the inconvenience caused.The deal would have restored Rio's balance sheet in return for Chinalco taking board seats and stakes in top-tier Australian assets. Instead Rio dropped the deal and launched a $15.2bn rights issue and a joint venture with BHP Billiton.The joint development of Simandou was a feature of a broader 'strategic partnership' that would have accompanied the original Rio-Chinalco deal.Australia's relations with Beijing were further damaged in July when Stern Hu, Rio's executive iron ore salesman in China, and three associates were detained. The four executives were recently formally indicted on charges of taking bribes and their case will now proceed to trial.Discussions over Simandou come on the eve of a trip to Beijing by Tom Albanese, Rio's chief executive. Mr Albanese is on Monday due to address the China Development Forum where he will speak on strengthening global co-operation for a mutually beneficial future.Mr Albanese has maintained over the last few months that Rio's and China's interests are aligned over the long term: China needs iron ore, including from new sources like Simandou, to feed its steel mills, while Rio is the world's second-biggest producer of iron ore.A joint venture in Guinea would allow Rio to share political risk and Simandou's sizeable development costs. Simandou lies 750km from the sea with poor transport links and infrastructure.OPT cut Rio needs to build a customised railway to transport the ore to the coast as well as an export terminal.People close to the Mongolian mining industry have also said they beleived Rio and Chinalco are working out a deal on Oyu Tolgoi, the enormous Mongolian copper-gold deposit that is a joint venture between Rio and Ivanhoe Mines of Canada.Chinese companies including Shenhua have been jockeying to take concessions in Mongolia, an emerging mining province whose valuable coal and copper deposits are located in the southern Gobi desert near the Chinese border.Xiong Weiping, Chinalco's president, this week told Reuters that it hoped to participate in Oyu Tolgoi. 'Since Chinalco is the largest non-ferrous metal company in China, and China has a geographic advantage with Mongolia, we believe that having a big company like Chinalco involved would give some helpful impetus to the project,' he told Reuters.Rio executives have described Oyu Tolgoi as the most important undeveloped project in the company's global portfolio.,20100316_25240_264.xmlDocument FTCOM00020100316e63g002pa------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Rio and Chinalco to share Guinea ore projectBy Peter Smith in Sydney608 words19 March 2010Financial Times (FT.Com)FTCOMEnglishCopyright 2010 The Financial Times Ltd. All rights reserved. Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the web.Rio Tinto and Chinalco confirmed plans on Friday to form a partnership that will develop a rich iron ore deposit in Guinea in what is expected to be the first of a number of joint venture undertakings between the Anglo-Australian miner and its biggest shareholder.The Chinese state-owned aluminium producer said it will invest $1.35bn in the early stages of the Simandou project in return for a 47 per cent stake in a new company alongside Rio with 53 per cent. The partnership will cover mining as well as rail and port infrastructure in a project that analysts believe could cost $12bn to develop.News of the joint venture comes at a delicate time for Rio and China. Stern Hu, Rio's executive iron ore salesman in China, and three associates are due to face a Shanghai court starting Monday on charges they stole commercial secrets and took bribes.China's treatment of the Rio employees will be watched closely by the international business community, particularly those companies employing foreign nationals in the country. The trial also coincides with the arrival in China of Tom Albanese, Rio chief executive, who is due to speak at the China Development Forum in Beijing on Monday.The non-binding agreement to develop Simandou is a clear sign of growing ties between Rio andChinalco.The relationship soured nine months ago when Rio spurned a $19.5bn capital injection from Chinalcobefore launching a $15.2bn rights issue and agreeing a joint venture production company with BHP Billiton to develop its Western Australian iron ore operations.Rio's top management have made a series of references recently to work being done to extend theChinalco relationship.In a statement on Friday, Xiong Weiping, Chinalco president, said Simandou was a world-class iron ore project whose development would enhance economic and trade relations between China and Guinea.'A successful development of the Simandou project will effectively increase the global supply of iron ore, balance the global iron ore market structure and promote the long-term, stable and healthy development of the global iron ore mining industry,' he said.The tabular content relating to this article is not available to view. Apologies in advance for the inconvenience caused.In a client note, Citigroup said the Simandou deal signified a thawing in relations between Rio andChinalco.'Other logical deals to do include the development of Arakun as an extension of the Weipa bauxite mine [in Queensland, Australia] and potentially around the Oyu Tolgoi development in Mongolia,' Citigroupsaid.People close to the Mongolian mining industry have said they believe Rio and Chinalco are working out a deal on Oyu Tolgoi, a copper-gold deposit that is a joint venture between Rio and Ivanhoe Mines of Canada.Rio believes Simandou could become the world's third most important iron ore province outside Brazil and Australia. The miner currently estimates Simandou has 2.25bn tonnes of iron ore, but analysts atCitigroup say it could contain more than 4bn tonnes.It has also said the project could eventually supply steelmakers with up to 170m tonnes of iron ore a year, although the first phase of the mine's development targets 70m tonnes a year by 2018.Mr Xiong added the involvement of Chinalco and possibly Chinese infrastructure companies would accelerate Simandou's development and improve Guinea's local infrastructure.The Guinean government holds an option to buy up to 20 per cent of the project.Blackstone and China International Capital Corporation advised Chinalco on the transaction.20100319_13713_251.xmlDocument FTCOM00020100319e63j001jl---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Chinalco and Rio sign $1.35bn Guinea dealBy William MacNamara in London676 words28 July 2010Financial Times (FT.Com)FTCOMEnglishCopyright 2010 The Financial Times Ltd. All rights reserved. Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the web.Aluminum Corp of China and Rio Tinto signed a $1.35bn deal on Thursday that allows the Chinese state-owned miner to buy in to a rich iron ore project in Guinea, in a move that places both mining companies at the centre of multi-billion-dollar scramble for west Africa's iron ore.Rio and Chinalco - the common name of the Chinese miner - revealed few changes to the earlier agreement they signed in March over Simandou, the Guinean deposit. Chinalco will pay Rio $1.35bn that will fund project development. In return, Chinalco buys its way up to a 47 per cent stake in the Rio-Chinalco joint venture.Rio still disputes the boundaries of its Simandou concession. In 2008 the Guinean government stripped it of half of its Simandou rights, citing the miner's failure to develop a resource that could transform Guinea's export earnings.If Rio had its way, it would still control both the southern block of Simandou and the northern block, which is now controlled by Brazilian group Vale after its $2.5bn deal with Beny Steinmetz Group in April.But such controversies - significant to the economics of the deal - were nowhere to be seen on Thursday during an elaborate signing ceremony in the Great Hall of the People in Beijing.Pomp, champagne, flowery speeches, and photo opportunities signalled a return to warmer relations between Rio and Chinalco, Rio's largest shareholder.The language of the speeches was reminiscent of those that accompanied Rio and Chinalco's $19.5bninvestment deal in 2008. The highly controversial deal, which would have given Chinalco board seats and a higher shareholding in Rio, fell apart amid opposition from the Rio shareholder base. The deal's demise did much to to make relations between the two companies either sour or awkward, according to different sources close to Rio.Chinalco is controlled by the Chinese state. China is Rio's biggest customer, and its purchases of Australian iron ore in particular drive Rio's profits.'Developing our relationship and business links with China is a key priority for Rio Tinto,' said Jan du Plessis, Rio's chairman, in the Beijing ceremony also attended by Tom Albanese, chief executive, and Sam Walsh, chief of the iron ore division. 'This agreement takes our relationship with China and our largest Chinalco to a new level.'Simandou has among the largest untapped iron ore deposits in the world, with some 2.25bn tonnes.The Guinean government has an option to buy a 20 per cent stake in the project. 'The government has recently expressed a willingness to exercise that option,' Rio said. This would mean that no company had an outright majority share in Simandou, although Rio will be project operator. The World Bank'sInternational Finance Corporation is also a shareholder.The $1.35bn investment will not cover all of the infrastructure-spending needed to make Simandou viable. Rio engineers were studying the best routes for a new railway through the mountains of the Guinean interior and building a new port near Conakry, the capital.The flurry of investment in west African iron ore appears to be starting a new infrastructure-building boom in the poor and previously war-torn states of Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone. Vale has plans to build a new port at Didia in Liberia, while ArcelorMittal, the world's largest steelmaker, is refurbishing the port of Buchanan in Liberia and UK-listed African Minerals is building a new port at Pepel near Freetown in Sierra Leone. These and other companies are planning to build new railways linking the deposits with the coast.Before the Rio-Chinalco venture was confirmed, some mining bankers and analysts had speculated that it might involve Oyu Tolgoi. This Mongolian copper deposit, near China's border, has also been rumoured as the site of a potential Rio-Chinalco joint venture. Ivanhoe Mines owns the project, but Rio is a large minority shareholder.20100728_13625_171.xmlDocument FTCOM00020100729e67s0035x---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Team China begins to swing its weightJOHN GARNAUT930 words17 May 2011The AgeAGEEFirst8English© 2011 Copyright John Fairfax Holdings Limited. www.theage.com.au [http://www.theage.com.au]In January, Xiong received the most important regulatory approval, from the National Development   Reform Commission. In February, Foreign Minister Yang Jiechi dropped into Guinea capital Conakry and received an extraordinary reception.'We are following China's road of opening and reform, just like Deng Xiaoping did for China in the past,' President Alfa Conde told Yang, according to Phoenix Television. 'For the moment, what is important is not only what China can bring to Guinea but also what Guinea can give China.'Last month, Vice-Minister for Commerce Fu Ziying toured Guinea and returned to scold Western journalists who asked whether China's generous development aid was linked to its appetite for resources.'Who are the largest iron ore owners?' he said. 'Not Chinese, but Western countries who colonised the place.'A week later, Fu took off his overseas aid hat and told the China Daily about what he had been doing in Guinea: 'There are preferential policies tailored for Chinese companies under the new mining law.'The China Daily also interviewed President Conde: 'We will open the door widely to Chinese companies and provide what China needs.'Chinalco is demonstrating that it holds the political cards in Guinea. It is about to demonstrate that it has the financier, the infrastructure developers and guaranteed buyers for every boatload of iron ore that Simandou can produce.Xiong has sewn up all the finance he needs from the China-Africa Development Fund — essentially a division of the China Development Bank. He has organised a consortium tipped to include Baosteel, China Railway Construction Corporation and a port-building company that will be unveiled after gaining final approval from the Ministry of Commerce and the foreign exchange regulator.In short, Xiong Weiping is setting up the most formidable demonstration of 'Team China' that the investment world has seen. Lately, Xiong has been telling colleagues that he intends to build Chinalco into one of the world's top-five mining companies.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Baosteel Has interests in Simandou Iron Ore Projectwww.yicai.com211 words23 May 2011SinoCast Energy BeatSCEB1EnglishCopyright 2011 SinoCast LLC. All Rights Reserved.BEIJING, May 23, SinoCast -- Baosteel Group Corporation is very much interested in investing in an iron ore project between Rio Tinto and Aluminum Corporation of China (Chalco, SHSE: 601600, SEHK: 2600) in Guinea.Chalco expects to find a steelmaking partner as it is an iron ore trader but not an iron ore consumer, Baosteel chairman Xu Lejiang says.The iron ore project, located in Simandou of Guinea, is the largest untapped iron deposit around the world. Baosteel's participation will help to ensure stable sales in the future when demands for iron ores shrink.Chalco will invest USD 1.35 billion in phases in the coming years so as to gain a 47 percent stake in the venture project finally, in terms of an agreement it signed with Rio Tinto in July last year.Baosteel Group Corporation, the second-biggest mill in China, has been acquiring resources worldwide in recent years. The company bought a 15 percent stake in Australia traded Aquila Resources Ltd. at AUD 286 million, turning into the second majority shareholder, in 2009; it then took over a 9.9 percent stake in Canada's Noront Resources at CAD 17.40 million this year.SinoCast LLCDocument SCEB000020110523e75n0000a-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------DJ Chalco: To Form Chinese Conglomerate To Develop Simandou Iron Ore Project210 words28 November 201108:19 AMDow Jones Chinese Financial WireDJCFWEEnglishCopyright (c) 2011, Dow Jones   Company, Inc.BEIJING (Dow Jones)--Aluminum Corp. of China (2600.HK), or Chalco, will form a conglomerate with several Chinese companies including Baosteel Group Corp., China's second-largest steelmaker by output, to jointly develop the Simandou iron ore project in Guinea, Chalco's parent Chinalco said in a statement Monday.The conglomerate will also include China Railway Construction Corporation Ltd., China-Africa Development Fund and China Communications Construction Co., it said.The conglomerate will participate in the project's construction and some of the iron ore sales.Rio Tinto formally established a joint venture with Chalco in April. Under the agreement, Chalco plans toinvest $1.35 billion in the project in return for a 44.65% stake in Simandou.The deal, first agreed in July 2010, will shrink Rio Tinto's project stake to 50.35%, while the remaining 5% will continue to be held by International Finance Corp.Rio said earlier that it expects the Simandou project will be able to initially produce 70 million tons of iron ore annually.-Yajun Zhang contributed to this article, Dow Jones Newswires; (86 10) 8400-7712; yajun.zhang@dowjones.com-0-Copyright (c) 2011 Dow Jones   Company, Inc.Dow Jones   Company, Inc.Document DJCFWE0020111128e7bs005k1

title: China to build a smelter in Zambia (duplicate of 2296)
description: hina forgives $200m Zambia debt135 words1 January 2007African BusinessAFBZ8Issue 327; ISSN: 01413929EnglishCopyright (c) 2007 Bell   Howell Information and Learning Company. All rights reserved.FinanceZambia's economic fortunes edged up another notch with the announcement by Chinese President Hu Jintao that China is writing off the $211 m owed by the central African nation. The debt was incurred when China built the Tanzania-Zambia railway to circumvent Rhodesia (now Zimbabwe) in the 1970s. The Tazara line enabled Zambia to export its copper through Dares-Salaam without going through the Rhodesia war zone. Hu says the debt cancellation is part of China's latest measures to increase economic and trade relations with Zambia, under its broader aid package to the country. In a related move, China has agreed to build an 800,000t capacity smelter on the Zambian Copperbelt to boost the country's refined copper output.

title: Facai-1 Oil Well (Duplicate of 137)
description: 'In Niger, Chinese National Petroleum Co. International Tenere Ltd. (CNPCIT) is currently drilling the Facai-1 exploration well to an estimated 4,300 metres (14,100 feet) to test Cretaceous sandstones in an anticlinal trap. CNPCIT is the operator and finances 100 per cent of TVI's 20-per-cent share of costs for the minimum work program.''298 words30 August 201107:00 AMMarketwireCCNWSEnglishCopyright 2011 Marketwire All Rights Reserved.CALGARY, ALBERTA--(Marketwire - Aug. 30, 2011) - TVI Pacific Inc. (TSX:TVI) (OTCQX:TVIPF) ('TVI' or the 'Company') announced today that the operator of the Tenere Block in Niger, Chinese National Petroleum Corporation International Tenere Ltd. ('CNPCIT'), has advised that the Facai-1 well was plugged and abandoned on August 23, 2011.CNPCIT started drilling the Facai-1 well on June 13, 2011 and reached a total depth of 3,861 metres (12,667 feet). The well encountered two small gas shows during drilling; however, wireline logs indicated no zones worth testing. The Facai-1 well is the third and final well of a three well carried program for TVI in the Tenere Block in Niger. The well also fulfills the first exploration period work program commitment on the Tenere Block.Once the final well data and reports are received from CNPCIT, TVI will analyze those reports prior to making any final conclusions and will provide an update at that time.About TVI Pacific Inc. (TSX:TVI) (OTCQX:TVIPF)TVI Pacific Inc. is a publicly-traded resource company focused on the production, development, exploration and acquisition of resource projects in the Philippines. TVI produces copper and zinc concentrates from its Canatuan mine, is developing its Balabag gold-silver property for anticipated production in the second half of 2012 and is carrying out an exploration program at its Tamarok copper-gold property. TVI also has oil interests in various stages of discovery, drilling and exploration in Alaska, Niger and off-shore Philippines.Connect With Us www.tvipacific.com [http://www.tvipacific.com]Follow us on Twitter www.twitter.com/tvipacific [http://www.twitter.com/tvipacific]'Like' us at www.facebook.com/tvipacific [http://www.facebook.com/tvipacific]FOR FURTHER INFORMATION PLEASE CONTACT: | TVI Pacific Inc. | Rhonda Bennetto | Vice President, Investor   Corporate Relations | 403.265.4356Marketwire L.P. (Canada)Document CCNWS00020110830e78u0018h'

title: Enhance textile industry capabilities
description: In 2006, China and South Africa signed an agreement limiting the Chinese exports of clothing to the African country. Under the agreement, China has agreed to cut textile imports to South Africa by one third, with quotas on Chinese textiles and clothing imports to be imposed for three years. The agreement was implemented in January of 2007. title: Stake in Lender (duplicate of 16439)
description: 329 words7 January 200801:37 PMAssociated Press NewswiresAPRSEnglish(c) 2008. The Associated Press. All Rights Reserved.JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (AP) - Chinese foreign minister Yang Jiechi began a two-day visit to South Africa Monday, marking 10 years of diplomatic relations between the two countries.Yang paid a brief courtesy visit to President Thabo Mbeki before meeting with foreign affairs minister Nkosazana Dlamini Zuma in Pretoria. It was the start of a tour of Africa, where China foreign ministry officials have traditionally started the year in a sign of the importance they place on the resource-rich continent.Yang was also to visit Congo, Burundi and Ethiopia.Yang said the China-South Africa relationship is 'of great importance,' the South African Press Association reported.Since South Africa, the continent's economic powerhouse, dropped Taipei for Beijing 10 years ago, China has become the country's largest trading partner.Trade between South Africa, the continent's economic powerhouse and a major gold-producing country, and China reached US$240 million in the first 11 months of 2006, an increase of 34.5 percent from the previous year.Last year China's biggest bank, the state-owned Industrial   Commercial Bank of China Ltd. bought a 20 percent stake in South Africa's biggest lender, Standard Bank Group Ltd. in one of China's biggest foreign corporate acquisitions to date.Chinese investments into South Africa amount to US$130 million, mostly in a chromium mine while South African investments in China stand at about US$400 million including investments by Anglo American, SAB Miller and a US$120 million investment by a property group.Yang's visit comes a year after Chinese President Hu Jintao visited South Africa in early 2007.South Africa and China on Monday established a diplomatic mechanism to enhance political, economic and trade relations.Yang and Dlamini Zuma were also expected to discuss co-operation between the two countries in international affairs as well as Chinese support for peacekeeping operations in Africa.7Document APRS000020080107e41700378
sector: Trade, Tourism, Banking and Financial Services
donor_agency: Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC), State-Owned Company

title: PPIAF - Uranium mine complex in Niger - Coal-fired power - Hydrometallurgy (Duplicate of 256)
description: In a separate deal, SinoHydro and another state-owned Chinese company have agreed to spendUS$140 million to build a uranium mine complex in Niger.SinoHydro and Chinese Nuclear Overseas Uranium Resources Development Co. (SinoUranium),a subsidiary of China National Nuclear Corp., will build the mine for the project owner, NigerAzelik Mining Industry. Niger Azelik is owned by the Niger government, China NationalNuclear Corp. and Beijing Zxjoy Technology   Trade.Aside from the mine itself, the facility will also include two coal fired power plants, each witha 6-megawatt output, and a hydrometallurgy plant. Annual production capacity will be 600,000tonnes and the project will be completed in 2.5 years.SinoHydro released news of the agreement last month. The English language website People'sDaily Online ran a story about the agreement based on a news report by China's Xinhua newsagency.

title: Duplicate: Southern Bypass
description: Negotiations for the loan facility are expected to be finalised in the next two months, while construction work is expected to start in April. The project is already running behind schedule by three years after it stalled owing to a lack of funding. “The Southern Bypass project is part of greater efforts by government to provide enhanced road infrastructure to guarantee economic development as spelt out in the Vision 2030 document,” says Kenya’s Minister of Roads, Franklin Bett. Chinese construction company China Road   Bridge Corporation has been awarded the contract to undertake the project, which will take 36 months to complete.The Southern Bypass is touted as a critical project in easing traffic congestion in Kenya’s capital city, as it will divert traffic from the city centre.The road diverts from the Mombasa–Kisumu highway near Jomo Kenyatta International Airport and rejoins the highway at Limuru on the outskirts of Nairobi. The bypass forms part of vital road infrastructure projects identified by the Kenya government as key in driving the realisation of its Vision 2030, which seeks to transform the East African nation into a middle- income economy.Other major road projects in Kenya being implemented by Chinese companies include the $312,5-million Thika super highway and the Eastern and Northern bypasses, being constructed at a cost of $106-million. The Chinese companies involved in these projects include China Wu Yi, Sino Hydro and China Overseas Enginering Corporation.Edited by: Martin Zhuwakinyu
donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency

title: E-government network
description: China and Senegal cooperated in 2009 on an e-government project in 2009. The project aimed to establish data, voice, and video conferencing systems, as well as support the entire e-government network platform and data center for several government agencies. Contacts for this project include Senegalese Minister of Information Technology and Communication, Abdourahim Agne, representative  the Embassy of the People’s Republic of China in Senegal, who co-chaired the ceremony, Ms. Wei Guo and The Director of the Agence de l’Informatique de l’Etat (ADIE), Tidiane Seck. The project completion date (the same date as the formal handover ceremony) was July 10, 2009. Further information regarding the announcement of this project, flow type, implementing agencies and financial amount are unknown.

title: Iron Ore deal struck in 2007 (duplicate)
description: China now second largest buyer of Mauritanian iron ore 266 words 13 May 2008Steel Business Briefing STSCNW English (c) 2008 Steel Business Briefing href=www.steelbb.com>www.steelbb.com [http://www.steelbb.com] The Mauritanian iron ore miner Société Nationale Industrielle   Minière (SNIM) sharply increased its shipments to China last year. According to figures obtained by Steel Business Briefing from the Arab Iron   Steel Union (AISU), China became SNIM’s second largest export market in 2007.This was the first time that a non-European country has been such an important customer of the Mauritanian miner. European steel companies normally take more than 90% of SNIM’s exports, but in 2007 this declined to 81%.SNIM exported 11.8m tonnes of iron ore in 2007. France was its largest market with 2.7m t. China came next with 2.17m tonnes.In 2006, only 4% of SNIM’s 11.1m tonnes of production went to China – less than 450,000t. But in 2007, as SBB reported, two Chinese companies signed long-term contracts with SNIM – Minmetals for 1.5m t/y for seven years, and Laiwu Steel for 1m t/y for five years.The AISU also reports that SNIM is aiming to increase its production to 12.4m t in 2008, up from 11.9m t in 2007. The company aims to raise its production capacity to 14m t in 2010.Its joint project with Australia’s Sphere Investments and Qatar Steel to build a 7m t/y iron ore pellet plant should start up in the second half of 2011.For questions about editorial content, or to subscribe call +44 (0) 20 7626 0600, info@steelbb.com© Steel Business Briefing 2008
recipient_agencies: Group Ltd., Private Sector

title: Construction of two hospitals in Ghana by a Chinese firm （Duplicate）
description: Industry Trend Analysis - Sino-Ghanaian Relations Are Strong In Most Areas - Bar Pharmaceuticals828 words12 August 2011BMI Industry Insights - Pharma   Healthcare, Middle East   AfricaBMIPMEEnglish© Copyright 2011 Business Monitor International. …Healthcare As Soft PowerDespite China's failings in the pharmaceutical sector, they continue to use healthcare and aid as a diplomatic tool. Istyle='BACKGROUND-COLOR:#FFFF00'>n September 2010, the Shanghai Construction Company announced its intentions to build two new regional hospitals in Wa and Kumasi as part of the Chinese government's 'Better Ghana' initiative. Large proportions of the funds for these projects are grants from Beijing, such as a hospital in Accra that was built at a cost of US$13mn with a Chinese grant of US$7.5mn, before being handed to the Ghanaian government. Other gifts include offering scholarships to Ghanaians to receive training in China and flying doctors to the country to help develop Ghana's health strategy.These gifts and concessions appear to be part of a long-term hearts and minds strategy that has recently come to fruition. At the same time as the Shanghai Construction Company announced that it was to build two hospitals, Ghana and China signed a US$9bn set of loans. The first tranche of this loan is valued at US$3bn and is to be released shortly. The Ghanaian government has said the repayments for these large loans will not come from the national budget, but from exports. Although not explicitly mentioned, the exports will be raw materials such as oil, gas and minerals.Ghana welcomes the investment that China is able to put into its economy because, like many African countries, it has struggled to obtain loans from the World Bank and the IMF for much-needed infrastructure projects, as these come with stringent terms and conditions. In return, China receives access to much-needed raw materials. The gifts and aid that Beijing has given Ghana so far are dwarfed by the mutual benefits of the US$15bn of loans and trade deals that have followed.…Business Monitor InternationalDocument BMIPME0020110813e78c00001
donor_agency_count: Shanghai Construction Group General Co., State-Owned Company
recipient_agencies: Shanghai Construction Group General Co., State-Owned Company

title: Wildcat Oil Well (Duplicate of 137)
description: 411 words9 February 2007UpstreamUPSTRM30English(c) 2007, Upstream. To read more Upstream stories you can get a FREE two-week trial of LIVE news, Upstream Hardcopy and Upstream archive news at www.upstreamonline.com [http://www.upstreamonline.com]. Do note that all Upstream articles are protected by copyright. Any unauthorised reproduction is strictly prohibited.China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) is set to start testing operations this week on its Saha-1 wildcat in Niger, which could hold 200 million barrels of oil, writes Iain Esau.According to minority partner TG World Energy, plans are in hand 'to complete bottom-hole operations and rig up for testing which is anticipated to begin within the next few days'.Saha lies in the 71,000 square kilometre Tenere permit, where CNPC International holds an 80% stake with the remaining interest held by Calgary-based minnow TG World.CNPC said delays happened when running logs between about 2500 metres depth in the probe and its target depth at 3500 metres.The operator has identified four intervals that will be tested during an operation that is expected to last until towards the end of this month, a couple of weeks longer than anticipated.Before drilling began CNPC had interpreted three prospective horizons - Sokor, Madama and Yogou - which between them contained potential likely resources of about 200 million barrels of oil, split fairly evenly.Follow up exploration wells are earmarked on the West Fachi prospect, which has about 96 million barrels of potential held in a horizon at more than 4000 metres, 500 metres deeper than Saha.Both prospects are sited in a northern extension of the Dinga Trough, which has proved to be prospective for oil in the Agadem permit to the south.Saha and West Fachi lie in the south of the Tenere permit and are the closest prospects to Agadem, where Malaysia's Petronas and US supermajor ExxonMobil have previously found more than 350 million barrels of reserves.ExxonMobil has withdrawn from Agadem, after failing to reach an agreement with the Niger government on its future participation and an extension to the licence beyond May last year.Petronas is still thought to be in talks with the Niamey government to retain an interest in the prospective licence.However, Ousseini Assane Boureima, exploration boss at Niamey's Department of Mines   Energy, told Upstream late last year that a number of Chinese companies have been in talks with Niger to secure access to the block.If CNPC is one of these players and manages to secure a stake in Tenere, a multi-field development could be on the cards.Document UPSTRM0020070208e3290002b
donor_agency_count: China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC), State-Owned Company
recipient_agencies: China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC), State-Owned Company

title: Sodemi signs manganese mining deal with China National Geological & Mining Corp. (Duplicate)
description: BIDJAN (Dow Jones)--Iory Coast state mining company, Sodemi signed a partnership agreement Wednesday with China National Geological   Mining Corp., or CGM, to develop a state manganese ore mine in the southwest.According to the director-general of Sodemi, Jean Likane-Yagui, the partnership with CGM will boost production at the Lauzoua site from the current 150,000 to 200,000 metric tons to 300,000 tons by 2011, and 500,000 tons by 2013.'China represents our main market for manganese ore at the moment, so it was only logical to work with a Chinese mining company,' said Likane-Yagui.Sodemi says the site has certified reserves of 1.4 million tons.The partnership deal gives 51% to Sodemi, 39% to CGM and 10% to the state.The agreement will also see the construction of a ferromanganese factory at the site with an initial capacity of 50,000 tons per year, with the possibility of an extension to 165,000 tons.'This signature shows the interest international investors have in our country as we leave behind the years of civil war. Iory Coast is open to all investors to exploit the riches of our mineral reserves,' said Minister of Mines and Energy Leon Monnet.Trade with China has more than doubled, from 50 billion CFA francs, or $112.6 million, to 112 billion CFA francs in 2008.Chinese companies are particularly active in transport and construction, with various building projects including a new presidential palace in the capital Yamoussoukro and a new hospital in President Laurent Gbagbo's hometown, Gagnoa.The other main manganese mine is in the northeast at Bondoukou and run by the Indian firm Taurian.So far this year, Iory Coast has exported 74,822 metric tons of manganese ore, down 32,176 tons, or 30%, from the 106,998 tons shipped up to this point last year, according to official port data.Iory Coast is the world's top cocoa producer, but the minerals and hydrocarbons sector is increasingly important.

title: Telecommunications agreement (Duplicate 994)
description: On April 28, 2007, China's ZTE and Ethiopia Telecom Corp signed a $200 million contract enabling ZTE to supply Ethiopia Telecom with CDMA technology, as well as implement three telecommunications projects, including the first phase of a fibre transmission backbone, the expansion of mobile phone service, and the expansion wireless telephone service. ZTE will create over 1.2 million mobile connections in Addis Ababa and eight other towns. Over 652,000 telephone lines will also be added under the first phase of the wireless telephone project. The project would take the fixed and mobile telephone user base to 14 million.  Non-Media Source:Book: China Telecom Monthly Newsletter. title: SSR Airport Expansion (Duplicate of 1156)
description: Travel   tourism: Mauritius221 words16 February 2010Economist Intelligence Unit - Business AfricaEIUBFBusiness Africa23Number xEnglish(C) 2010 The Economist Intelligence Unit Ltd.After some delay, contracts have now been exchanged for the construction of a €195m (US$273m) passenger terminal at Mauritius’s Sir Seewoosagur Ramgoolam (SSR) international airport. The terminal will be developed and operated by a joint venture between Airports of Mauritius and Aéroports de Paris Management. Aéroports de Paris Engineering will be responsible for the design and engineering of the new terminal, which hopefully will increase the airport’s annual capacity from 1m to 4m passengers. The new terminal will be built by the China State Construction Engineering Corporation. The project is being financed by a concessionary loan from the Export and Import Bank of China, and is further evidence of China’s strategic interest in Mauritius as a gateway to Africa.This project is a key component of the government’s plans to expand infrastructure and support the expansion of the tourist sector. The state-of-the-art terminal is planned to be a visual statement of confidence. The present terminal at SSR is saturated and often operates at 160% of capacity, with bottlenecks in all passenger-processing zones. Work was originally planned to start in July 2009 and to last for two years. It is now expected to start by the end of March.bfbfmain20100216t0000000023; Business Africa 16 Feb 2010, Part 23 of 24Document EIUBF00020100302e62g0000n

title: Duplicate: Oil Mining License
description: See ID# 196'Energy-hungry China last month snapped up more oil and gas assets, this time with state-owned international investment conglomerate Citic Group paying $1.91 billion for the Karazhanbas field in Kazakhstan (p13). The purchase follows Sinopec's acquisition of 50% of independent Omimex's assets in Colombia for $800 million in a joint deal with India's Oil   Natural Gas Corp. The deals, coupled with the China National Offshore Oil Corp. (CNOOC) purchase of a 45% stake in deepwater OML 130 in Nigeria for $2.27 billion earlier this year, highlight the increasing financial clout of Chinese companies in their aggressive hunt for oil.According to Yan Qifa, vice general manager of the economic research unit at the Export-Import Bank of China (China Eximbank), 'oil and gas development projects in foreign countries are complex and require more procedures,' which explains why the Chinese state oil firms have at their disposal a few financing alternatives. 'In general, we have direct loans for investment overseas, foreign aid to developing countries and favorable export buyer's credit with oil and gas as returns,' he said.The main national export credit agencies involved in these transactions are Eximbank and -- to a smaller extent -- the China Development Bank, which have been supporting domestic companies in their overseas exploits since the mid-1990s. Both were created in 1994 to facilitate direct loans to state companies.China Eximbank has been charged with the task of implementing state policies in industry, foreign trade and economy, finance and foreign affairs, and is the third largest export credit agency in the world. With abundant resources, the banks are able to bestow extremely favorable terms of credit that are unlikely to be matched in the market. According to sources, the interest rate on funds provided to enterprises investing abroad can be about 3% lower than that offered by commercial banks. 'It may not be profitable for the export credit agencies to provide such favorable loans, but with $1 trillion of foreign reserves, China can afford it,' said one source in Beijing. As of late last year, Eximbank has provided a total of $300 billion in financing to Chinese companies.' 'BEIJING (Dow Jones)--China National Offshore Oil Corp. is in talks to secure right of first refusal on oil blocks to be offered in an international tender by Nigeria - the latest step in its scramble for African assets.Edmund Daukoru, Nigeria's oil minister, told Dow Jones Newswires that the blocks were set to be made available to China's largest offshore oil producer by output in return for an investment package financed by a $2.5 billion loan.An agreement could see CNOOC granted 'lifting rights' on commercial terms from fields in Nigeria for the first time, he said. This would enable CNOOC to ship crude oil back to China to feed the nation's fast-growing economy.China is the world's second-largest consumer of oil and has been ramping up efforts to diversify its sources of crude away from the instability-prone Middle East, with Premier Wen Jiabao leading the latest in a string of high-profile delegations to oil-rich African nations in June.'They (CNOOC) would have preferred to negotiate directly, but we would like the value to come out not by negotiation but through a market competitive process,' Daukoru said during a three-day visit to China.This process involves holding a tender to establish the market value of the blocks rather than an outright discretionary allocation, he said. CNOOC would then have right of first refusal to match the top bid.But Daukoru, who is also president of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, did not reveal the location or the number of blocks being considered as part of the deal.Negotiations followed the signing of a memorandum of understanding earlier this year on expanding economic cooperation between the two countries and a final deal should be signed when Nigerian President Olusegun Obasanjo visits China in November, Daukoru said.In March, CNOOC bought a 35% working interest in a license to explore for oil offshore Nigeria for $60 million, and Chairman Fu Chengyu named Nigeria alongside Myanmar as the two countries where his company wanted to focus its investment in the medium term.Two months earlier, CNOOC agreed to pay $2.27 billion, plus $424 million in expenses, to South Atlantic Petroleum Ltd for a 45% working interest in the OML 130 offshore oil mining license, which mainly covers Nigeria's undeveloped Akpo field.Its activity has been mirrored by state-owned rivals China National Petroleum Corp., the parent company of PetroChina Co. (PTR) and China Petrochemical Corp., or Sinopec Group, which have also been snapping up upstream assets in Africa.'CNOOC is very aggressive. I'm very impressed by that,' said Daukoru.'They are very committed to the kind of undertaking which we are trying to get out of them and in return for which will be oil blocks (and) perhaps crude oil lifting rights on commercial terms.'A $2.5 billion loan has been offered by the Export and Import Bank of China and CNOOC would be expected to cover a large chunk of the interest rate on repayments in return for a deal, Daukoru said.He added: 'By November everything can be agreed and we can sign off on the blocks and the loan is ready for draw down hopefully.'A spokesman for CNOOC could not be reached for comment.Daukoru's whistlestop visit to China included a tour of a fertilizer plant on the southern island of Hainan as Nigeria is known to need more fertilizer for its agriculture sector, which is the mainstay of local communities.Although details have not been finalized, Daukoru said a 'judicious mix' of projects including building fertilizer plants and investment in refineries would be financed by the overall loan put up by the Chinese.Nigeria has suffered sporadic outbreaks of violence against oil infrastructure such as pipelines as communities express anger at the perceived plundering of national oil wealth by overseas firms and the lack of benefits flowing back to the grassroots.Around 600,000 barrels per day of Nigerian crude oil output - or one-fifth of its total capacity - is currently shut in because of sabotage, Daukoru said.Chinese firms have been keen to cut deals that involve investment in infrastructure projects if it means they overtake overseas rivals in acquiring African assets.In May, CNPC - the largest oil producer in China by assets - secured four oil blocks in Nigeria in a deal that also saw it agree to invest $2 billion in the Kaduna refinery there.Nigerian crude is a high-quality light, low sulfur grade referred to as sweet, and is highly prized by oil consuming nations because of its high gasoline content and relatively cheap processing costs. ''BEIJING, March 9 (Xinhua) - China National Offshore Oil Company Limited (CNOOC Ltd.) said Monday that oil and gas production in Nigeria's OML130 project, of which CNOOC Ltd. holds a 45-percent interest, has begun ahead of the planned start-up date.Akpo, an oil formation under the OML130 drilling license, was discovered in 2000. The area is located 200 kilometers from the Nigerian coastline in water depth ranging from 1,200 to 1,400 meters. Akpo's proved and probable reserves are estimated to be around 620 millions barrels of condensate.The development facilities consist of 44 wells, including 22 producers, 20 water injectors, two gas injectors, a floating production storage offloading facility (FPSO) with a designed daily processing capacity of 185,000 barrels of oil and a storage capacity of two million barrels, 110 kilometers subsea pipelines and other infrastructures.To date, 22 wells have been drilled, according to CNOOC Ltd. CNOOC Ltd. acquired a 45-percent working interest of the OML 130 in 2006 for nearly 2.3 billion U.S. dollars.Akpo is expected to reach its plateau rate of approximately 175,000 barrels of oil per day during summer 2009, said sources with CNOOC Ltd.As one of the leading projects with huge potential in Western Africa, and one of the largest deep water projects ever undertaken, Akpo is expected to become the most important new oil field of this year, said Fu Chengyu, Chairman and Chief Executive of CNOOC Ltd.For CNOOC Ltd., the successful start-up of Akpo will enhance the weight of overseas assets in the company's total portfolio by a substantial increase of its overseas reserves and production, said Fu.French oil company Total acts as the operator of OML 130 block. Other partners in the project include Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation, Petrobras of Brazil and South Atlantic Petroleum Limited of Nigeria.Incorporated in Hong Kong, CNOOC Ltd. is a listed subsidiary of China National Offshore Oil Corporation, China's largest offshore oil producer.Enditem'

title: Funding for military operations in Somalia (Duplicate)
description: On November 30, 2011, China's Defence Minister Liang Guanglie signed a deal with Uganda to give 25 million CNY in military assistance to the Uganda People's Defense Force for domestic capacity building and to support Uganda's troops in the African Union Mission in Somalia (AMISOM). The current status and start and end dates are unknown.KAMPALA, Uganda (Dow Jones)--The Chinese government has pledged to boost Uganda's fight against Somalia's al Qaeda-inspired al Shabab militants, who claimed responsibility for the terror attacks in Kampala last year that left at least 79 people dead, officials said Tuesday.The Chinese minister of national defense, General Liang Guanglie, signed two protocols with his Ugandan counterpart, Crispus Kiyonga, in Kampala in which China offered to extend at least 25 million yuan ($3.9 million) for the Ugandan army's operations in war-torn Somalia, Defense Minister Kiyonga said.'We analyzed the regional and international security situation and agreed to strengthen our cooperation,' Kiyonga told Dow Jones Newswires in a telephone interview. 'The funds will be used to acquire transport equipment for the UPDF (Ugandan army) and support operations in Somalia.'The latest funding underscores the growing interest of China in the East African nation, which recently discovered huge commercial oil reserves and is on the verge of joining the ranks of other African oil-producing countries.Uganda has at least 5,000 troops under the African Union mandate in Somalia. In August, the Ugandan-led troops successfully flushed the al Shabab militants out of Somalia's port city of Mogadishu after nearly five years of fighting.However, fighting has continued on the outskirts of the city as well as in several areas of the countryside, and has since sucked in other countries such as Kenya and Ethiopia.The AU mission, which also includes Burundian troops, is mainly funded by the U.S. government.Chinese-owned enterprises hold lucrative oil deals in South Sudan, which neighbors Tanzania. China's state-owned Cnooc Ltd. (CEO) is also slated to start developing oil fields in Uganda's oil-rich Lake Albertine rift basin next year.-By Nicholas Bariyo, Dow Jones Newswires; 256-75-2624615; bariyonic@yahoo.co.uk [ 29-11-11 1009GMT ]Dow Jones   Company, Inc.Document AER0000020111129e7bt0000s
donor_agency_count: Uganda People’s Defence Force (UPDF), Government Agency

title: Stake in Lender
description: 329 words7 January 200801:37 PMAssociated Press NewswiresAPRSEnglish(c) 2008. The Associated Press. All Rights Reserved.JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (AP) - Chinese foreign minister Yang Jiechi began a two-day visit to South Africa Monday, marking 10 years of diplomatic relations between the two countries.Yang paid a brief courtesy visit to President Thabo Mbeki before meeting with foreign affairs minister Nkosazana Dlamini Zuma in Pretoria. It was the start of a tour of Africa, where China foreign ministry officials have traditionally started the year in a sign of the importance they place on the resource-rich continent.Yang was also to visit Congo, Burundi and Ethiopia.Yang said the China-South Africa relationship is 'of great importance,' the South African Press Association reported.Trade between South Africa, the continent's economic powerhouse and a major gold-producing country, and China reached US$240 million in the first 11 months of 2006, an increase of 34.5 percent from the previous year.Last year China's biggest bank, the state-owned Industrial   Commercial Bank of China Ltd. bought a 20 percent stake in South Africa's biggest lender, Standard Bank Group Ltd. in one of China's biggest foreign corporate acquisitions to date.Chinese investments into South Africa amount to US$130 million, mostly in a chromium mine while South African investments in China stand at about US$400 million including investments by Anglo American, SAB Miller and a US$120 million investment by a property group.Yang's visit comes a year after Chinese President Hu Jintao visited South Africa in early 2007.South Africa and China on Monday established a diplomatic mechanism to enhance political, economic and trade relations.Yang and Dlamini Zuma were also expected to discuss co-operation between the two countries in international affairs as well as Chinese support for peacekeeping operations in Africa.7Document APRS000020080107e41700378

title: Not a project: Iron ore exploration
description: China's third largest steelmaker—Wuhan Iron   Steel (WISCO)—is planning to start exploratory drilling for iron ore in the Madagascar Soalala region as soon as May 2011. WISCO Madagascar paid USD100 million for an exploration permit in 2010. 'Our investments are made in stages, depending on the results of the survey. The investment decision is expected in six to eight months, then will come the construction phase, which will last four years. The actual operation could start in five years,' said WISCO's chief executive Jun Yuan Lou.Significance: The operational environment in Madagascar presents some challenges, since the commencement of the political demise in March 2009 when incumbent President Andy Rajoelina seized power. In late December 2010, Madagascar Oil, a public company with the leading position in onshore exploration and development in Madagascar, announced the suspension of trading in its shares (see: Madagascar: 20 December 2010: ).The development comes after the company was listed on the London Stock Exchange's Alternative Investment Market (AIM) less than two weeks earlier. The company's statement read: 'Following a meeting between the Ministry of Mines and Hydrocarbons and Madagascar Oil in Antananarivo [the capital] late on 16 December, the ministry has indicated that it is interested in acquiring from the company all of its licences excluding Bemolanga. There can be no guarantee that any price agreed for such an acquisition will be representative of the fair value of such assets.' Situations such as these have increased the enforceability of contracts risk in Madagascar and could be an investment disincentive for companies and countries not willing to take up such perils in the future. Madagascar's vast mineral riches (oil, cobalt, nickel, gold and uranium) will, however, continue to lure those willing to take a high risk exposure, backed by high returns in the future.锦兴国际与武汉钢铁集团合作经营马达加斯加铁矿场锦兴国际宣布,与中国第三大钢铁生产企业武汉钢铁(集团)订立两份合作协议,当中订定有关于马达加斯加Bekisopa区(公司已收购该区面积约287平方公里之矿产勘探及开采权)及其它地区铁矿及其它矿产资源之勘探权及开采之合作条款。根据首份协议,双方将成立合营公司,锦兴占40%权益,锦兴将以其于Bekisopa区之勘探及开采权作为对合营公司之出资,双方各投入之投资金额及生产场地经营之详情有待公司进一步研究及调查后由双方进一步磋商。根据第二份合作协议,双方同意利用合营公司收购马达加斯加其它地区另一矿产勘探及开采权,倘合营公司取得所需之矿产勘探及开采权,策略伙伴须负责成立及经营生产场地,并已承诺按现行国际市场价购买所有开采出之金属资源。锦兴与策略伙伴已派专业人员及专家往Bekisopa区进行实地考察,并收集样本作测试之用,根据报告,所取得之样本含铁金属53.25%及钛金属11.42%。来源:汇港通讯中国武汉钢铁将勘探开采马达加斯加铁矿(本文由路透中文网编译提供)          路透塔那那利佛4月6日电---中国第三大钢铁厂商武汉钢铁公司(600005.SS: 行情)官员表示，公司计划从5月底开始，在马达加斯加的苏阿拉拉（Soalala）地区勘探开采铁矿石。          武钢去年向马达加斯加支付了1亿美元，获得该地区的勘探许可。许多外国企业都密切关注这个印度洋岛国的矿产资源。          武钢马达加斯加分公司负责人Jun Yuan Lou称：“我们的投资将根据勘探结果分阶段进行。预计将在6-8个月内做出投资决策，然後进入为期四年的建设阶段。”          他在周二晚的新闻发布会上说：“（矿山）五年後将进入实际运行阶段。”当天他与马达加斯加国家环境办公室签署了该矿的环境影响研究及勘探协议。          马达加斯加拥有石油、钴、镍、金、铀等矿藏。自拉乔利纳（Andry Rajoelina）于2009年3月就任总统以来，该国资源勘探业一直受政治危机拖累。（完）

title: Manganese mine- duplicate with 851
description: Officials of the Indian mining concern Taurian Cote d’Ioire, which has been re-named Dharni Sampda, are all smiles these days. After some tough bargaining with mines and energy ministerAdama Toungara, the firm resumed work on May 9 at its manganese mine at Bondoukou in eastern Iory Coast. Africa Mining Intelligence understands that Toungara found no fault with a decree issued by former president Laurent Gbagbo last Dec. 4 that authorized Dharni Sampda to work the mine. At the outset of the crisis following December’s presidential election, the supporters of president Alassane Ouattara had blocked Dharni Sampda’s operations in the region.And on the crest of its recent backing from the new administration the company has begun talks on shortly starting work on a new manganese mine, at Odienne in north-west Iory Coast.The picture, however, is different for another manganese producer in the country, theCompagnie Miniere du Littoral (CML), which works the Lauzoua mine in the Grand Lahou region in the south. CML will have to wait until September before resuming work because the Grand Lahou region remains unstable, with Liberian mercenaries and pro-Gbagbo militia continuing to sow terror.CML is an Iory Coast-Chinese consortium composed of SODEMI (51%), the China National Geological   Mining Corporation (CGM, 39%), and the Iory Coast government (10%). With an annual capacity of 150,000 tons, CML had planned to double its output this year after launching a major investment program worth roughly CFA 10 billion.

title: Road project: DUPLICATE of 2129
description: In 2011, China Communications Construction Company Ltd. held the groundbreaking ceremony for the MiG-Mason   de Meuron asphalt road project in Equatorial Guinea. The road is 26 km in length, 10 meters wide, contains 37 small bridges, culverts, and other various structures, and the designed speed of the project is 60 km. The project is worth $41.06 million USD and is expected to be completed within 18 months of the start date. It is unclear how the road is being financed.

title: China oil firms eye Ghana investment (not a project)
description: Ghana eyes Kosmos Energy's stake in offshore Jubilee fieldjmora451 words6 July 2009Platts Commodity NewsPLATTEnglishCopyright 2009. Platts. All Rights Reserved.Cape Town (Platts)--6Jul2009/456 pm EDT/2056 GMTGhana confirmed Monday that it wants to buy the stake that Texas-based Kosmos Energy is selling in the Jubilee offshore field.The Ghana National Petroleum Corporation, which has a 10% participating stake in the project, had written to Kosmos informing it of its interest, Deputy Oil Minister Kwabena Donkor said.Speaking on the sidelines of the opening of the CWC-organized Africa energy conference in Cape Town, Donkor also said that many companies including Shell, Eni, Total and Chevron were showing an interest in Kosmos' stake in the field.News first broke in February that Kosmos had appointed advisers to handle the sale of its interest in the two blocks that span the Jubilee field.Sources in Ghana also said that the China National Offshore Oil Corporation had offered $3 billion for the stake and that Shell had looked at the data, but had not made a bid.Government approval for the development plan for the Jubilee oil field was expected soon, Donkor said. Tullow Oil is the project's operator and is planning to invest about $3.1 billion along with its partners to start commercial crude production in the second half of 2010.The Jubilee oil field is reported to have around 1.2 billion barrels of oil, and is said to be the largest field to be discovered in West Africa in the last 10-15 years.Kosmos Energy is operator of the deepwater West Cape Three Points block in which part of the field is located, holding a 30.875% interest. Anadarko has a 30.875% stake, Tullow holds 22.896%, the E.O. Group 3.5%, and UK's Sabre Oil   Gas Holdings 1.854%.The rest of the Jubilee oil field is in the deepwater Tano block, operated by Tullow and where Kosmos holds an 18% interest as does Anadarko. Tullow holds 49.5% and Sabre 4.5%. GNPC has a 10% stake in both West Cape Three Points and Tano blocks.While some of the gas will be reinjected to maintain pressure in the reservoir, Donkor said Ghana was keen to harness gas from the field for power supply. The Jubilee field partners are reported to have reached a broad agreement with the government on a gas development plan that will include the capability for gas reinjection and a gas export pipeline to a processing plant on the coast. The Jubilee field discovery well, Mahogany-1, is located 63 kilometers from the Ghanaian coastline and 132 km southwest of the port city of Takoradi in the Tano Basin.0706200916245813869.xmlDocument PLATT00020090706e576001e2

title: China forgives US$211m Zambia debt (duplicate of 2272)
description: China forgives $200m Zambia debt135 words1 January 2007African BusinessAFBZ8Issue 327; ISSN: 01413929EnglishCopyright (c) 2007 Bell   Howell Information and Learning Company. All rights reserved.FinanceZambia's economic fortunes edged up another notch with the announcement by Chinese President Hu Jintao that China is writing off the $211 m owed by the central African nation. The debt was incurred when China built the Tanzania-Zambia railway to circumvent Rhodesia (now Zimbabwe) in the 1970s. The Tazara line enabled Zambia to export its copper through Dares-Salaam without going through the Rhodesia war zone. Hu says the debt cancellation is part of China's latest measures to increase economic and trade relations with Zambia, under its broader aid package to the country. In a related move, China has agreed to build an 800,000t capacity smelter on the Zambian Copperbelt to boost the country's refined copper output.

title: Relief supplies for Madagascar
description: The Chinese government provides the Government of Madagascar with a batch of relief supplies.  The handover ceremony was held in Antananarivo, the capital city, on the December 11, 2009.  Chinese Ambassador, Wo Ruidi, and the Madagascar senior officials of relevant departments, attended the handover ceremony. The relief supplies included diesel generator sets, water pumps, tents, mosquito nets, blankets and bed linen, with a total value of 30,000,000RMB.
sector: Humanitarian and Disaster Relief and Preparation

title: PPIAF - Construction of the Tekeze dam, in the state of Tigray in Ethiopia
description: The total cost of the construction of the 300-mw Tekeze dam in the state of Tigray in Ethiopia was $360 million (it was originally predicted to cost $224 million), with a Chinese commitment of $50 million. The dam was 185 meters tall and was developed and built by the state-owned Chinese National Water Resources and Hydropower Engineering Corporation (Sinohydro). It was also developed by Gezhouba Water and Power Group and Sur Construction Co. The dam was expected to produce 300 MW of electricity. Construction was expected to be completed in 2008, but did not finish until 2009.The dam financier is unclear. According to the World Bank, in 2002, the Export-Import Bank of China provided $50 million on concessional financing. However, a Taiwanese news source said that the China National Water Resources and Hydropower Engineering Corporation that built the dam financed it entirely. It is not clear who will play for the cost of overruns, delays, and lost revenue. See ID# 644Additional source that would not fit:http://www.addisfortune.com/Vol%2525252010%25252520No%25252520491%25252520Archive/EEPCo%25252520Gives%25252520Construction%25252520Contracts%25252520of%25252520New%25252520Power%25252520Plants%25252520to%25252520Chinese%25252520Company.htm
